HEADLINE: Physicians Are Selling Practices To Companies as Changes Loom

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Worried doctors across the country are selling their offices to investor-owned public companies, hoping to bolster their prospects in the rapidly changing health care system. The doctors are signing long-term contracts to work with the companies, in some cases as long as 33 years.
The sales to corporations are part of widespread efforts by doctors, hospitals and insurance companies to prepare for the sweeping changes promised by the Clinton Administration. Although hospitals and insurers are also linking up with medical groups, many doctors say their interests are better served in a corporate setting. 
 "With health care reform coming, private practitioners are scared," said Dr. Steven M. Scott, the chairman of the Coastal Healthcare Group Inc., which acquired a Miami-based network of 12 clinics in July. "They are looking for any help they can get to economize and keep their income streams up."
In the latest high-profile example, prestigious group practices in Houston and Oklahoma City were sold this year to Caremark International, a home care and managed care company with annual revenues of $1.9 billion.
Companies like Caremark typically give doctors cash and stock -- although the companies declined to disclose the amounts they initially paid to complete the transactions -- and promise them a steady income based on a growing number of patients that the companies hope to recruit. The companies put up money for new medical buildings, technology and computers. Some provide malpractice insurance.
 
Pay Is Compared
 And they finance the growing cost of providing managed care, in which doctors and hospitals often accept a flat fee, or capitation, for each person covered by a health plan.
The purchasing companies also manage the business, employ the nurses, technicians and clerks, and assist with the electronic analysis of medical results and strategic planning.
The growth of medical groups used to be financed by member physicians, but many costs have soared out of reach. And younger physicians often have other priorities, including leaving the group after a few years to follow a spouse's career moves.
Family doctors at a clinic acquired last year by Pacific Physicians Services Inc. in a recession-plagued Southern California area see 25 to 30 patients a day, said Dr. Leland Giddings, a clinic medical director. He said they earned $10,000 to $11,000 a month, about the same as before they joined the company. Their benefits -- including an allowance for continuing medical education and malpractice, life and health insurance as well as stock options -- had "markedly improved," he added. The doctors also get a year-end bonus of $5,000 or more if their unit's profit margins exceed 7 percent.
With companies like Caremark the doctors remain in charge of treating patients, although subject to the growing constraints imposed by health maintenance organizations and employers. There are no industrywide statistics available on how many physicians have sold their practices to investor-owned companies, but doctors and analysts alike say the trend is gaining strength.
"This is a paradigm shift of doctors, who were organized as physician-owned groups, to partnerships with other sources of capital, said Dr. Alfredo Czerwinski, corporate medical director of the Kelsey-Seybold Clinic, a large group practice with 175 physicians in Houston.
Kelsey-Seybold's doctor-owners sold their 17 offices and clinics to Caremark, based in Northbrook, Ill., in January. The company will receive a management fee, based on clinic revenues, as well as interest payments on the capital it invests. At least eight more clinics in the Houston area are planned over the next 18 months.
Critics of the trend warn of potential conflicts between medical values of doing everything possible for the patient and company shareholders' insistence on seeing quarterly profits grow. Some also say the company-managed groups may be violating laws in many states that prohibit the practice of medicine by business entities. In smaller markets, a large company-owned physician group may even raise antitrust concerns.
 
'Like Herding Cats'
 Health care executives and analysts cite another challenge: keeping the loyalty of doctors who may chafe under economic constraints imposed by corporate managers. Most doctors fiercely guard their independence.
 "They say that managing physicians is like herding cats," said Neal C. Bradsher, a health care securities analyst at Alex. Brown & Company in New York.
Caremark, which was split off from Baxter International, a hospital supply company, last year, says it is reshaping itself as a diversified managed health care company that could be a prime bidder for contracts in the changing national system. Analysts say prime contractors will command a larger share of the health care dollar than companies that can subcontract only for specialties like Caremark's home care and discounted-prescription drug businesses.
Caremark insists that under the capitation payment system, its clinics will not have incentives to use its home health and pharmacy services; if they did, it might run afoul of Government regulations against doctors sending patients to businesses that they own.
In July, Caremark acquired the Oklahoma City Clinic, which has 102 doctors, and the company says there are 150 physician groups on its shopping list, including ones in Tulsa, Dallas and Southern California.
 
Sales of Practices Grow
 Pacific Physician Services, which operates two dozen Southern California clinics from its headquarters in Redlands, added a 90-physician clinic in Riverside on Aug. 4. And Phycor Inc., based in Nashville, manages physician groups in 11 states.
Lawrence C. Marsh, a health care analyst in Richmond at Wheat First Securities, said the combined annual business of medical groups acquired by for-profit companies would probably exceed $1 billion in 1993 and was growing by 30 percent a year.
Large investor-owned insurance companies, including the Cigna Corporation and Aetna Life and Casualty, also have extensive contracts with physicians who work for the insurers' H.M.O.'s and other managed health care organizations. So do Prudential and Metropolitan Life, which are mutual life insurance companies, owned by their policyholders.
Hospitals have also been establishing close ties with physicians. In California, for example, the Palo Alto Medical Clinic rejected an offer from Caremark in favor of a "strategic affiliation" with the Sutter Health System, a large hospital and physician group based in Sacramento.
"We didn't think Caremark was a good fit for us," said Dr. David Druker, the Palo Alto clinic's executive director. "Caremark is a for-profit organization. I just don't think medicine was set up to be a profit-and-loss center."
But Joseph C. Hutts, president of Phycor, argued that hospitals and health maintenance organizations "have different objectives than physicians."
Dr. William F. Barnes, president of the Oklahoma City Clinic's board, said, "The first concern of hospitals and insurers is their own survival," adding "We needed a partner that was willing to commit to our growth."
C. A. Lance Piccolo, chairman of Caremark, said the company expected to receive $100 million to $120 million in gross revenues this year from the two clinics, rising to at least $150 million in 1994.
 
Foreseeing Profits
 Kenneth C. Abramowitz, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, forecast that profit margins from the clinic operations next year would be 5 percent to 10 percent.
Mr. Piccolo said that H.M.O.'s, which provide health coverage to large groups of employees, would be the main customers. Kelsey-Seybold already has agreements with Sanus, an H.M.O. owned by the New York Life Insurance Company, and on Aug. 3, it also signed with Metropolitan Life's H.M.O.
Because Kelsey-Seybold is not tied to a particular H.M.O., it will be free to seek the business of any group as the health care system changes, Mr. Piccolo said. If a particular H.M.O. loses out in managed care competition, the Kelsey-Seybold doctors can look elsewhere, he said.
But hospital officials and physicians not involved in the Houston deal had questions about doctors' growing relations with for-profit companies.
The American Medical Association and several state medical associations have been warning doctors to be cautious about signing long-term agreements with hospitals, insurance companies or other physician management companies.
"All of us in medicine have a concern that stock exchange companies may put the dollar before the quality of care they deliver," said Dr. Robert Mayo Tenery Jr., a Dallas ophthalmologist who is president of the Texas Medical Association.
Dr. Ralph D. Feigin, physician in chief of Texas Childrens Hospital in Houston, added, "There has to be a different feeling in the health care area than in other corporate activities, because health care is dealing with human life."
Mr. Piccolo responded that Caremark executives had had long experience in dealing with doctors in its home health care business. He said the physicians would have "clinical autonomy," meaning they would be free to decide the best way to practice, and would have half the seats on their clinic's joint policy committee.
But he added that under the clinics' pay system of salaries and shared bonuses, the doctors would be "as at risk as we are" in trying to curb costs.
"We understand the fragility of physician relationships and their strengths," he continued.
 
U.S. Studies Caremark
 The Inspector General's office of the Department of Health and Human Services since 1991 has been reviewing Caremark's former payment arrangements with doctors who supervised home health care patients, looking for possible Medicare fraud and abuse. The company has said it is cooperating in the review and that it stopped paying the doctors a fee for each patient after the practice was questioned.
Mr. Abramowitz, the securities analyst, said most physicians would happily tap the corporations for capital to expand their practices. "They will probably be unhappy to the extent that these new entrants come in and reduce any physician compensation or autonomy they may have," he said.
"Physicians are one of the great cottage industries still around," he said. . "You could argue that this is just the beginning of the corporatization of physicians, which I'm sure they regard as a mixed blessing."

HEADLINE: More Young Californians Spurn Their Strained University System

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORAGA, Calif., Aug. 31

 BODY:
These are the days for goodbyes and good wishes in this San Francisco Bay suburb of dun-colored hills and aquamarine swimming pools, as newly minted freshmen head off to college.
But this year the goodbyes are different. High school graduates who would once have scarcely considered leaving California -- students like Jeff Zell and Lori White, Kristina Artist and her friend Nicole Glassel -- are deserting this state's once envied university system and scattering in record numbers to public universities around the West. 
 "The lure of the university system that once was just isn't there anymore," said Jeff Zell, who was accepted at several campuses of the University of California but chose the University of Arizona. He had heard too many horror stories about fee increases, staff cuts, canceled courses, eliminated programs and students forced to spend six years working toward a degree in the California system.
 
On Their Parents' Heels
 The flight of these young men and women parallels that of their middle-class elders, many of whom have escaped California's crime, crowding, pollution, racial tension and high cost of living for gentler lives in the Pacific Northwest, the Mountain States and the Southwest.
And their exodus from a fragile system of colleges and universities that was once the crown jewel of American public higher education is yet another measure of how deeply three years of budget cuts have eroded the quality of life in California and dashed hope for the future in this not so Golden State.
"There is no question people are going," said Barry Munitz, the chancellor of the California State University system. "I see their parents every day at Rotary lunches and Chamber of Commerce meetings. Not a day goes by when somebody doesn't say, 'Chancellor, I love C.S.U., but I'm encouraging my Sally to go to Eugene, Nevada-Reno, Texas Women's.'
"These are California families who have been paying taxes in part to have the right for their children and grandchildren to benefit from a high quality, low-cost college education," Mr. Munitz said. "It's a worry that they are being driven out. It is one more erosion of California's ability to compete economically, because it sucks brains out of the state."
The data bear out Mr. Munitz's contention that California students are leaving in droves. A study by the University of California shows that migration of college freshmen to Arizona, Colorado, Nevada, Oregon and Washington State rose 14 percent from 1990 to 1992, with larger increases expected this year.
At the University of Oregon, 25 percent of this year's freshman class is from California (including Mr. Zell's classmates Ms. Artist and Ms. Glassel), up from 8 percent in 1986. At University of Arizona, Californians represented 11 percent of the freshman class two years ago and are now 16 percent. And at the University of Colorado, 1,439 Californians applied for admission five years ago as against 2,583 this year (including Ms. White).
The driving force behind the exodus is state budget cuts. For three consecutive years, both the California State system, with its 20 campuses, and the more prestigious nine-campus University of California system, have bowed under the budget ax. Fees at Cal State have nearly doubled in that time, to $1,440 a year from $780. On the university campuses, fees (covering such costs as registration, social and cultural activites and counseling) have more than doubled, to $3,674 a year from $1,820. This brings the total cost, counting living expenses, to an average of $9,300 a year at a Cal State campus and $12,400 at a university campus.
To be sure, California residents still pay less for a year's education than they would at an out-of-state university; for one thing, tuition is still free for in-state students. But the budget cuts mean they get less than they used to: larger classes, fewer sections, majors eliminated and fewer senior faculty members because of early retirements. Some campuses have wiped out whole subject areas. The Cal State system, which had a total of 50,000 classes in 1990, has eliminated an average of 7,500 each fall.
These changes have stretched the time it takes to get a bachelor's degree, often to five or six years. In other states it is often easier to get a degree in four years, for about the same overall cost -- particularly in light of the cheaper housing in many states. (Officials estimate that attending Oregon for a year costs $15,000, Arizona $13,000 and Colorado $16,000.)
 
Selling Out-of-State Colleges
 "We tell them the cost can equal out," said Carrie Besnette, a California-based recruiter for University of Arizona. She says she finds her most receptive audience in well-to-do suburbs like this one.
Out-of-state recruiters know exactly what Californians worry about and fine-tune their pitch accordingly.
Lori Goldman, assistant director of admissions at the University of Arizona, says students often ask if their chosen major will still be offered in four years. They ask if Arizona has "impacted programs," a term commonly used in California for fields of study that accept no new students. They ask if required classes are readily available, making timely graduation possible.
Ms. Glassel was reassured on those points at orientation in Oregon last month. But what impressed her the most, after the harrowing registration stories from siblings and older friends, was that Oregon "had a million classes to choose from, and I got every one I wanted."
It is not only out-of-state campuses that are romancing disaffected California high school graduates. At least one private college in the state, the University of the Pacific, has lately rented billboards near its Stockton campus that promise graduation in four years. "It's causing some people to look at us who might not have," said Doyle Minden, a university spokesman.
The tuition of Californians is helping to prop the sagging finances at out-of-state universities. "We have become a revenue stream for other states with fiscal problems," said Joni Finney, the associate director of the California Higher Education Policy Center, a San Jose research organization.
 
Cashing In on California Woes
 So vigorous was the recruiting at Colorado that more than half of last year's entering class was from out of state, with 22 percent coming from California, up from 15 percent in 1988. The Legislature, alarmed that a tax-supported university would admit so few natives, cracked down, limiting out-of-state students. So this year's freshman class has a slim majority from Colorado and only 12 percent from California.
Most admissions officers are loath to admit that they are cashing in on California's woes, but not Larry Mason, director of admissions at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, where the number of entering Californians tripled in just a year: to 971 in the 1993-94 year from 301 in 1992, including transfers as well as freshmen. "It's a sad situation that we've grown because of somebody else's tragedy, but it's a great market," he said.
In addition to tuition, California students bring four years of spending money to Eugene, Ore., Tucson, Ariz., Boulder, Colo., and other points north and east. "We're talking thousands here," said Andrea Gray, the registrar at Campolinda High School here. "We're talking apartments, gas, taxes they'd pay on purchases, groceries, maybe even a car."
And many will choose to settle where they were educated once they land jobs and marry. "I doubt they'll come back here," said Jean White of her two daughters, who both graduated from Campolindo High School. Lori is a freshman at Colorado and Kimberly a junior at Oregon, and both are glad to be in a "less dog-eat-dog world" than California, Mrs. White said.
Charles Ratliff, the acting deputy director of the California Post-Secondary Education Commission, which advises the Legislature and the Governor, suspects that the leaders of the state university system, in hounding elected officials for more money each budget season, make a bad situation worse.
Invariably, Mr. Ratliff said, the chancellors and campus presidents cry wolf about how many professors will be retired, how many course sections will be scratched, how many departments will die. And their doom-and-gloom scenarios dominate the news during the very months when college decisions are made.
"We've managed to frighten away a lot of young people and their families," Mr. Ratliff said. "It never turns out as bad as we painted it to be. But they don't know that."

HEADLINE: Kodak Asks 275% Tariffs on Some Fuji Imports

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company asked the Commerce Department late today to impose steep tariffs on imported paper and chemicals for color-film processing, a step that could result in higher film-processing prices in the United States.
The case is the first major one in which an American company argues that a Japanese competitor should raise its prices here to reflect the steady rise of the Japanese yen against the dollar. Trade experts say that other American companies, including auto makers, are now deciding whether to file similar cases against their Japanese competitors. 
 Kodak charged today that its rival, the Fuji Photo Film Company Ltd. of Japan, had violated a Federal law prohibiting imports from being sold at unfairly low prices, a practice known as dumping.
It argued that Fuji maintains a near-monopoly in Japan, allowing it to cut prices for photographic supplies in America. Kodak further contended that Fuji used its profits to undermine the economic viability of foreign rivals.
Robert T. Hamilton, Kodak's vice president and general manager for imaging in the United States and Canada, said in a statement tonight that "dumping undermines healthy competition because companies cannot continue to compete profitably where unlawful competition is taking place."
Thomas H. Shay, a spokesman for Fuji Photo Film U.S.A., the American subsidiary, said tonight that the company had just learned of the filing and had no immediate reply.
The case involves materials used to turn exposed film into prints, not the film itself.
Its filing represents a remarkable shift by Kodak. Kay R. Whitmore, the company's departing chairman and chief executive, has long been an outspoken defender of free trade, winning praise from fellow corporate executives for a leading role in the push for a North American trade accord, even allowing an aide to run the corporate lobbying campaign for the pact, the North American Free Trade Agreement.
But Kodak's board, unhappy with Mr. Whitmore's managerial effectiveness, announced on Aug. 6 that it would replace him as soon as a new executive could be found. Big investors have harshly criticized Mr. Whitmore for his reluctance to take unpopular steps, like laying off thousands of workers, to reduce costs and increase the price of Kodak stock.
Paul C. Allen, a Kodak spokesman, said the company remained committed to liberalized trade. "We don't see this action as being inconsistent with our public stance on free trade," he said.
Mr. Allen also said that while today was the first time Kodak had pursued a dumping case involving a photographic product, a Kodak subsidiary successfully sought dumping duties on some Japanese computer disks in the late 1980's.
Kodak is seeking tariffs of 275 percent on imports of photo printing paper and on chemicals used in developing film both from Japan and the Netherlands, where a Fuji subsidiary has a factory.
According to Government statistics, the United States imported $487.7 million worth of the paper and chemicals from Japan last year and $26.6 million worth from the Netherlands. But Kodak contends that the official figures understate the imports, partly because some color-printing paper may be inaccurately classified as paper for black-and-white prints.
Fuji accounts for virtually all of the imports, said Kimberly E. Ritrievi, a photo industry analyst at Lehman Brothers. Kodak and Fuji dominate the United States market while the third-ranking company, Konica, has a factory in the United States, she said.
 
Calculation Method Is Assailed
 The yen's increase makes it easier for American companies to prevail in dumping cases at the Commerce Department because retail prices in Japan rise when converted to dollars. American dumping law requires the department to calculate an imported product's average retail price both in the United States and abroad, and to impose steep tariffs if the foreign price is higher.
The Japanese Government and many foreign companies have complained that such calculations are heavily biased in favor of financially troubled American producers.
But the dumping law also requires domestic producers to prove to the International Trade Commission, an independent Federal agency, that the low-priced imports are a material cause of the American industry's problems.
In two highly visible cases this year and last, the commission ruled that imported steel and imported mini-vans had not caused material injury to the American makers, throwing out yearlong cases on which the domestic industries had spent millions of dollars in legal fees.
The new Kodak case presents President Clinton with a political problem at the International Trade Commission less than two weeks before the White House is to begin its push for Congressional approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement. The nine-year term of one commissioner, Anne E. Brunsdale, recently expired, and she is unlikely to be reappointed. It was she who cast the deciding vote in the mini-van case and in many of the steel cases.
 
Nominee Must Not Offend
 The domestic steel industry is strenuously lobbying for a replacement who is more likely to vote in favor of troubled American industries. But the White House has been reluctant to nominate someone who might be labeled either a protectionist or a hard-line free-trader.
Federal law allows Ms. Brunsdale to continue serving until a replacement is confirmed by the Senate. White House officials have said they expect a nomination soon.
In making its request for tariffs today, Kodak accused Fuji of selling color photographic paper for less than 20 cents a square foot in the United States while charging slightly more than 60 cents a square foot in Japan.
Kodak and Fuji have been locked in an increasingly nasty marketing battle. After years of cheerful ads showing beautiful photographs, for example, both companies have begun including implicit comparisons to their competitors. According to Advertising Age, a recent Fuji television spot pointed out that children now dress, play games and learn to read in new ways, and asked, "So why are you taking pictures of them with the same old film?"
Matthew J. Diserio, an analyst at Paine Webber, said that "in the first six months of this year, Fuji has clearly upped the competitive stakes of the war by increasing their promotional activity."
American companies do not have to win trade cases to be successful. Japanese car makers raised their prices in the United States after the mini-van case was filed last year and again after Detroit auto makers prepared, but did not file, trade cases at the beginning of this year.

HEADLINE: Man Testifies in Inquiry of Commerce Dept.

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 31

 BODY:
A man involved in accusations that Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown took $700,000 from the Vietnamese Government appeared today before a Federal grand jury investigating the Commerce Department.
Federal prosecutors refused to discuss the reason for the testimony by the witness, Nguyen Van Hao, or reveal the target of the investigation. 
 But officials close to the case, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that the panel was examining the Commerce Department.
Mr. Brown has denied taking money from Vietnam to lift trade sanctions. He labeled the accusations "absolutely ridiculous" when they surfaced in U.S. News & World Report and The Miami Herald in mid-August.
Mr. Hao was South Vietnam's vice premier for commerce when the government fell to the communists in 1975, and was the only high official allowed to stay on in Vietnam's new government. He now lives in Coral Springs, a suburb of Fort Lauderdale.

HEADLINE: Indians' Casino Money Pumps Up the Volume;
Plan to Annex 8,000 Acres to a Connecticut Reservation Has Some Non-Indians Upset

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEDYARD, Conn., Aug. 27

 BODY:
This week, the Mashantucket Pequot Indians will open a new building that will double the size of their Foxwoods casino. But even before the expansion, the tribe has become the region's clear center of gravity, with influence that extends from town halls to the State Capitol in Hartford.
In a small town used to small business, the casino's numbers speak for themselves. The Pequots made $26 million in gross profits in July, just on slot machines. By year's end, they expect to be one of the largest employers in the state, with 9,000 workers. Their new building will give the tribe 139,000 square feet of gambling space. They say this will give them the largest gambling operation in the Western Hemisphere, edging out the Taj Mahal in Atlantic City, which claims to be the largest casino in the world. The power of all that money to buy up land has non-Indian residents worried. 
 Last month, in response to an inquiry from the three nearest towns -- Ledyard, Preston and North Stonington -- the Pequots said their long-term goal was to buy 8,000 acres and annex it to the reservation, more than quintupling the 1,850 acres of Federal trust land in the reservation's original boundary. The new lands would all but encircle the town halls of Ledyard and Preston.
"It's too much," said Ledyard's Mayor, Joseph A. Lozier. But Mr. Lozier, who describes himself as "pro-Indian" and "pro-Indian economic development," concedes that the growing power of the Pequots is not to be denied in the town of 15,000 population. "When you're making $26 million a month, it's, you know, what do you want this week?" Mr. Lozier said.
"I despise it," said one man, a lifelong Ledyard resident in his early 30's, who, like many of the Indians' harshest critics, refused to give his name because, he said, he had many friends with jobs at the casino. "They said they were going to preserve the land," he said. "Does it look like they're preserving the land?"
Despite such sentiments, the Pequots make no apologies for their expansion plans.
"The land is what everything is based on," said Bruce A. Kirchner, a tribe member and a senior vice president at the casino. Mr. Kirchner said the memories of the 1970's, when the tribe was struggling to gain Federal recognition and the reservation was almost lost, are too strong. "In order to be a viable tribe, we want to have sovereignty over the land," he said.
 
The Flash Point
 The immediate flash point in the land issue is a 248-acre parcel of non-reservation property just across Route 2 from the casino, which the tribe has petitioned the Department of the Interior to have annexed to the reservation as Federal trust land. If that happens, over the vehement objections of the towns, the land would be exempted from property taxes and local zoning, as are all Federal reservation lands. The tribe has already filed an application to annex another 1,250 acres that it owns contiguous to the first 248-acre section.
What is at stake is both control and money. With zoning restrictions removed, local government would have no say in how the land is developed. Building permits, inspections and other trappings of local land management would be removed because the property would become part of a sovereign Indian nation. Equally important, the towns could no longer collect property taxes.
The land is clearly growing in value. The Pequots have two hotels, a monorail, a virtual-reality theater, a golf course, a bingo and sporting events center, and a tribal community complex all under construction or about to break ground on their various properties.
This summer, the Pequots offered to make voluntary payments of $1 million a year for five years to each of the three towns, in lieu of property taxes on the annexed lands. But town leaders said they could not accept the arrangement without putting it to the voters, which would slow the annexation process.
In the meantime, the towns don't anticipate any help from the state. Connecticut will receive about $113 million from the tribe this year, under an agreement signed in January with Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. guaranteeing the Pequots a monopoly on slot machines in Connecticut. But of that total, Ledyard will get only $183,000.
"Who's really making out here is the state," said Mayor Lozier. "They've got what they want."
Guy R. Martin, a Washington lawyer who is fighting the land annexation on the towns' behalf, said he thinks the root of the anxiety is the fear among non-Indian residents that they will lose their right to have some say in what goes on in their community.
"They're not objecting that the tribe is recognized, et cetera, or the economic development," Mr. Martin said. "What they can't accept is using those vast profits to purchase private land, which by virtue of the trust process is removed from the tax base and all local control. That's what they object to."
 
Local Concerns
 Tribal officials say they understand some local concerns. The crowds -- which on a holiday weekend can triple Ledyard's population to 45,000 -- the traffic, the development, the bustle that never ends, are irritants that residents can and should be concerned about, tribe members say.
But some opponents of the land annexation have gone beyond simple community concerns, some Indians say.
"I can't say it's anything racist," said Mr. Kirchner, the casino vice president. "But reading the paper, some comments made -- that we're not really American, we're foreigners -- were borderline."
Among residents who have received purchase offers from the tribe, however, or those who wish for such offers, emotions are much more complicated than the simple fear of how their town might be changing. The tribe has spent $3.8 million buying single-family homes and lots in Ledyard since early June, according to town land records. Real-estate agents say the tribe has been paying above market prices, then spending even more money to renovate the houses for use by tribe members.
"If the Indians came and made an aggressive offer, would I sell?" said Jane D. Smith. "Probably. Am I panicked? No." Ms. Smith said that at least seven homes in her neighborhood, called Stonehenge, have been purchased since this spring.
 
Pro-Indian but Troubled
 Ms. Smith, like many other non-Indian residents here, described herself as pro-Indian, but troubled by the land controversy.
"I don't think it's right that you have a group of people who don't have to abide by the laws of the state," she said. "I don't agree with having a sovereign nation within a sovereign nation."
Meanwhile, Clifford Allyn, a longtime neighbor to the tribe who rejected a Pequot offer of $10.5 million for his farm, expresses a sort of ostentatious indifference to any and all Indian doings. The casino just down the road? Never been there.
"From what people tell me, it's quite a place," he said.
"I can't say I'll never go," he said. "I might go down when I'm hungry some time at their buffet and eat all I can."

HEADLINE: Facing a Bigger Tax Bite, Will Well-Off Pay or Play?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
The burden of the new taxes in the deficit reduction law, President Clinton has tirelessly reassured the nation, will be borne by the rich and near-rich. But will the rich, in fact, hunker down and pay?
During the months of wrangling over the economic package, some conservative economists voiced skepticism about the Administration's revenue estimates. These criticisms, which were widely discounted as a reprise of discredited supply-side arguments of the 1980's, had little effect on Democratic loyalists or mainstream economists. But in the sober light of the morning after, concern that affluent households will elude the tax collector -- or simply choose to work less -- is being taken more seriously by some economists. 
 Indeed, research, notably a study by James Poterba, an M.I.T. economist not known for any supply-side leanings, suggests that affluent households may well behave differently from others.
 "There is so much financial flexibility among high-income folks," worried Mr. Poterba. "Almost all our information about responses to tax changes is based on the behavior" of people with far lower incomes.
If these fears are indeed justified, then the President's bid to narrow the deficit without burdening the middle class is a high-stakes gamble. For if the tax increases fail to generate something close to the projected revenue, the odds that Mr. Clinton will bury the deficit demon before it buries him will be slim.
The great bulk of the revenue is supposed to come from raising the highest tax brackets for couples reporting more than $135,000. When the extension of the Medicare tax is added to the bracket rises, those reporting incomes exceeding $250,000 will pay 41 cents of tax on their last dollar earned -- up from 31 cents.
Most financial experts agree this increase of 10 percentage points will inspire efforts to avoid taxes. Indeed, the Administration's revenue estimates, based on computer simulations by the Treasury Department and Congress's Joint Committee on Taxation, take unspecified shifts in investment behavior into account. But from the beginning of the budget debate some analysts have contended that these estimates woefully underestimated the capacity of the well-off to roll with the punches.
 While the pickings in tax shelters are much slimmer than they were before the Tax Reform Act of 1986, high-income families can still reduce their tax liability in a variety of legal ways -- everything from borrowing against their houses to increasing gifts to charity to socking away more cash in pension accounts. What is often not taken seriously enough, suggests John Taylor, a Stanford University economist who advised President George Bush and has never been identified with the hard-line supply-siders, is that they can also work less.
One spouse in a two-earner family, Mr. Taylor notes, might be induced to stay home with a new baby. Or a 60-year-old executive might decide to take early retirement. Or the proprietor of a medium-size family business might choose to put expansion plans on hold and enjoy the weekends.
This is guesswork. But Martin S. Feldstein, an economist at Harvard University who was President Ronald Reagan's chief economic adviser, and Daniel Feenberg of the National Bureau of Economic Research used a computer model to make it educated guesswork -- and with some political effect during the debate on the Clinton deficit bill. They simulated the response of high-income households to increased tax rates in 1993, assuming that it would mirror the response to lowering rates in 1982 to 1984. Their result: an income tax gain of just $3.7 billion for 1993, a number they broadcast before the Congressional vote as evidence of the President's folly in trying to soak the rich.
 Not everyone was impressed. For example, Jane Gravell, a senior specialist at the Congressional Research Service, contends that the Feldstein-Feenburg simulations are no more accurate than the assumptions that buttress them. The numbers used by the two economists, she said, are "not a reasonable basis for estimation" because they do not take into account myriad other economic changes in the early 1980's that led wealthy taxpayers to report more income.
Daniel Hamermesh of the University of Texas agrees. "No labor economist thinks work incentives are an issue," he said. "You can just as well argue the rich will work harder" to maintain their after-tax purchasing power.
But a recent analysis of the response to the 1986 tax overhaul by Mr. Poterba of M.I.T. and Mr. Feenberg of the National Bureau of Economic Research suggests that the last word on the subject has yet to be written.
 
Factors Other Than Taxes
 The 1986 law cut the highest tax bracket from 50 percent to 28 percent, reducing the incentives of the wealthy to avoid taxation. The two economists examined the impact on the top one-half of 1 percent of taxpayers -- those with incomes of $280,000 or more in today's dollars. They found that even after excluding gains from the sale of assets the share of national income reported by this elite group leaped from just over 6 percent in the years 1983 to 1986 to just under 10 percent in 1988.
 As Ms. Gravell pointed out, factors other than taxes -- everything from the recovery from the recession to the diverging fortunes of skilled and unskilled workers -- played a role in the redistribution of income in the 1980's. But the post-1986 surge in the reported noncapital gains earnings of the very affluent cannot easily be explained away.
It may be related to greater work effort by the affluent, or by greater willingness to declare earnings as taxable income. Either way, though, Mr. Poterba says, "incentives played an important role in measured income changes after 1986."
Also, the restructuring of the economy has tempered the demand for high-income professionals ranging from lawyers to investment bankers to medical specialists. That suggests when the going gets tough, the tough are less likely to respond to higher tax rates by going on vacation.
But as Mr. Poterba points out, this latter point cuts both ways. The success of the deficit reduction measures turns as much on the ability as on the willingness of the affluent to pay more tax: if the share of income of this economic elite falls in the next five years, tax revenues from the group are likely to fall short of the target.
Deficit reduction in the 1990's is a high-wire act: a single stumble could produce a fatal fall. But that reality -- and the fact that his predecessors can make no claim to surefootedness -- must be modest comfort to a President who would prefer not to be remembered as the leader who lost the struggle for fiscal sanity.

HEADLINE: Ex-Presidents Invited to Help Promote the Trade Agreement

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Stung by complaints that it has moved too slowly in assembling a sales campaign on behalf of the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Clinton Administration has invited the five surviving former Presidents to come to Washington for a bipartisan pitch on Sept. 14.
Presidents George Bush, Ronald Reagan, Gerald R. Ford, Jimmy Carter and Richard M. Nixon have all been asked to take part, and Mr. Carter and Mr. Ford have expressed interest in attending, aides said. Mr. Nixon, who has established what one aide described as warm relations with the Clinton White House, is said to at least be giving the idea some thought. 
 But the idea of lobbying on behalf of a free trade agreement that is obscure to many Americans has apparently not proved a lure to Mr. Reagan. An aide said he had no plans to travel to Washington for the event.
"It is unlikely given his busy schedule that he would come to Washington for a photo op," said an aide to Mr. Reagan, who lives in California. It is unclear whether Mr. Bush will attend.
Mr. Clinton has spent much time bashing the economic initiatives of the Reagan Administration, and Mr. Reagan responded in an article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times on Aug. 3 criticizing Mr. Clinton's economic plan.
Clinton Administration officials hope they can get at least a few of the ex-Presidents to Washington to speak up for the trade agreement, which each has said at different times that he supports.
"This is in the realm of possibility," one White House official said.
Another Administration official said: "I think they want to be supportive of this. And we certainly appreciate their support and counsel."
Mr. Clinton is facing an uphill battle in gaining approval for the trade agreement, which has enemies in organized labor and in Congress. In addition, Ross Perot, the independent candidate for President in 1992, has published a book entitled: "Save Your Job, Save Our Country. Why Nafta Must Be Stopped -- Now!"
In the past, the five former Presidents have gathered for ceremonies but not on behalf of legislation. In 1991, they all attended the dedication of the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, Calif.
The President predicted passage of the despite a Democrat's warning that up to three-fourths of House Democrats opposed the pact.
"I think in the end my position will prevail," Mr. Clinton said today before a briefing on flood-relief efforts.
The President, fresh from an 11-day vacation, was answering a warning from Representative David Bonior, Democrat of Michigan, who said that up to three-fourths the Democratic caucus in the House is opposed to this treaty.
But among the opponents are the second and third-ranked Democrats in the House, the majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, and Representative Bonior, the majority whip.
Most Republicans support the pact, which was negotiated during the Bush Administration.
The pact would lower tariffs and remove other trade restrictions among the United States, Mexico and Canada.

HEADLINE: Jury Gives Litton $1.2 Billion In Honeywell Patent Dispute

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31

 BODY:
A Federal jury here awarded Litton Industries $1.2 billion in damages today after finding that Honeywell Inc. had infringed a Litton patent covering certain airplane navigation systems.
While the jury verdict is a setback for Honeywell, which had argued that Litton's patent was invalid, the 11-week-old case is not yet resolved. 
 Judge Mariana R. Pfaelzer of the United States District Court for Central California is continuing to hear arguments in the case and will decide whether to accept or modify the jury's verdict. A final ruling is expected in the next week.
The judge ordered jurors not to discuss the case as she conducted a hearing late this afternoon to consider Honeywell's claim that Litton's patent was improperly obtained through what Honeywell called "inequitable conduct."
Shares of Litton and Honeywell were halted in trading on the New York Stock Exchange this afternoon before the jury's verdict was announced. Trading never resumed. Honeywell was up 87.5 cents, to $38.875, while Litton gained $1, to $66.50.
Honeywell was cautious about the case's outcome. "Obviously, I am not happy with the verdict, but we think that it's way too premature to say that anyone has won or lost," Edward D. Grayson, Honeywell's vice president and general counsel, said in a telephone interview.
Mr. Grayson said Honeywell would continue to present evidence that he said could change the outcome of the case. He declined to elaborate.
Norman L. Roberts, Litton's senior vice president and general counsel, said in a statement: "We have invested significant funds in the development and production of the Litton technology which the company has every intention to protect. We believe that the jury's verdict was clearly justified by the facts presented in the litigation."
The patent involves a process to coat mirrors used in ring laser gyroscopes, which are the principal element in airplane navigation systems. The mirrors increase the reliability and life span of the gyroscopes.
Honeywell, a Minneapolis-based maker of automation and control systems, invented the ring laser gyroscope in the 1960's. Litton received its first patent for an ion-beam process to coat mirrors in 1978.
Litton and Honeywell are the two principal players in the $400 million market for ring laser gyroscopes. Honeywell controls the commercial side of the market, while Litton dominates the military portion.
Litton, a major military contractor based in Beverly Hills, Calif., filed the lawsuit in March 1990, accusing Honeywell of infringing its ion-beam process. It also argued that Honeywell had violated antitrust law by trying to monopolize markets for ring laser gyroscopes.
Honeywell filed a counterclaim in December 1990 accusing Litton of trying to monopolize the market for navigational systems and of interfering with Honeywell's relationship with suppliers.
 
Questions for the Jury
 The jury was asked to determine if Litton's patent was valid, whether Honeywell's process infringed that patent, and what damages, if any, should be awarded.
Lawyers who have seen the jury's verdict said that it found that Honeywell intentionally induced a Litton licensee to breach its agreement with Litton and affiliate with Honeywell. The jury decided that Honeywell prevented Litton from obtaining the full economic benefit of its patent, the lawyers said.
Litton had licensed Ojay Research Inc. to use Litton's ion-beam coating technique but prohibited the company from selling mirrors that would be used in high-powered lasers, the lawyers said. Honeywell convinced Ojay to sell it mirrors that were later used in its ring laser gyroscopes, thereby competing with Litton, they said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Health Plan Aims To Cover Periodic Checkups

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration will ask Congress to include periodic physical examinations, now available to only about one-third of conventional health insurance customers, as part of its health care package, Administration and Congressional officials said today.
For about half of all adult Americans, who now pay the full cost of regular physicals if they have them, this would be an important new benefit in the plan President Clinton is to propose next month. 
 Details of the proposal have not been settled within the Administration, including how frequently examinations would be provided, what they would cover and whether they would be introduced gradually or at once.
Those decisions will affect the overall costs of the benefit, which various audits commissioned by the Administration have put at $50 to $100 a year per person. This would amount to an additional national health care cost of $6 billion to $12 billion per year.
 
Support in Congress
 Congress may alter whatever the Administration proposes, but the basic idea is likely to command considerable support on Capitol Hill. For example, Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House, regularly reminds his constituents in Washington State that the failure of most insurance policies to cover routine physicals makes it harder "to get people to take care of themselves."
Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, said today: "The insurance industry has neglected this aspect of health care for too long. Preventing illnesses is far less costly than treating them. Coverage of preventive services is the stitch in time that can save billions."
About 35 percent of the 75 million Americans with conventional health insurance plans, which reimburse customers for most of their medical bills, are now covered for routine physicals, said Richard Coorsh, a spokesman for the Health Insurance Association of America. He said that percentage was increasing as a result of public demand.
He said coverage of regular examinations was much more frequent or even customary among people enrolled in health maintenance organizations and other managed-care plans. He said the benefit was available at almost all health maintenance organizations and in about half of preferred provider plans, in which consumers choose from a list of doctors hired by the insurer.
Major employers are especially likely to cover physical examinations. A study of 545 major companies' benefit plans showed that 66 percent of them offered employees periodic examinations, said Michael Langan, vice president of Towers Perrin, an employee benefits consulting firm with headquarters in New York City.
 
A Shift in Emphasis
 Both Mr. Coorsh and Mr. Langan said health insurance plans had been slow to include physical examinations and other preventive services because the original purpose of such insurance was to protect against catastrophic expenses. But now, Mr. Coorsh said, "people are asking more than that" and the association recommends providing more preventive care, including regular examinations.
A major decision the Administration has not yet made is how frequently routine examinations should be included in the basic coverage that it wants all Americans to have. Various Federal recommendations in recent years have called for examinations every three years from late childhood until the age of 40, every two or three years until 65 and every year afterward.
How frequently the examinations are provided will have a significant effect on the cost of the health care program, although the costs in any case are uncertain.
The wide range of cost estimates received by the Administration assumes that examinations are provided regularly, but not each year.
Another unsettled question is whether benefits for physical examinations should be provided as soon as the program takes effect or should be gradually introduced. The Administration is considering guaranteeing examinations first for children and only later for adults.
There is no unanimity about the cost-effectiveness of various routine health examinations, and Administration officials say they are concerned about the cost of frequent, possibly expensive tests that may detect rare medical conditions.
 
A Healthier Work Force
 But officials say that a suitable level of preventive care, including examinations, would also produce the economic benefit of a healthier work force.
They also contend that a greater emphasis on prevention can change the "mindset of the health care system," as one official who asked not to be identified put it today, turning it away from expensive technology and an overemphasis on specialization.
Some of the greatest benefits of regular physical examinations are virtually cost-free, she said. It is possible to calculate the cost of a blood-pressure test or a urinalysis, she said, but the accompanying few minutes a doctor spends urging patients to give up smoking can be even more valuable to public health, even if only one patient in 50 is swayed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Trying to Program Common Sense

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash.

 BODY:
Seated in front of a powerful personal computer here at the Microsoft Corporation, Stephen Richardson, a linguist, types one of those kinds of sentences that for decades have tied the smartest computing machines in knots: "The spaceship photographed Seattle, flying to Mars."
How is the computer to infer that it is the spaceship and not the city of Seattle that is on its way to the Red Planet? Without the vast storehouse of common-sense knowledge possessed by any child, today's computers are clueless about such apparently obvious relationships. 
 But future computers may not be so ignorant if the Microsoft team, and researchers at other corporate and university labs, succeed in teaching machines a little common sense.
 
New Use for Dictionaries
 Mr. Richardson is working with a small group of linguists and computer scientists here to build software tools that can automatically extract those obvious relationships -- what researchers call semantic information -- from standard dictionaries.
"We have been very surprised at how much of what people refer to as 'common sense' is found" through the dictionary approach, Mr. Richardson said. It is possible, for example, to derive the fact that a foot has five toes from the semantic information generated by their software, he said.
They believe it possible to tease enough information first from dictionaries, then encyclopedias and finally other texts like newspapers, magazines and novels, to provide the foundation for intelligent systems.
The resulting web of information will be organized in structured data bases of word relationships, perhaps permitting machines for the first time to understand and use language the way humans do.
Such systems, capable of understanding what researchers call natural language, would have a profound impact on society. They would make possible systems for recognizing speech and handwriting as well as systems that could respond to complex typed queries.
 
Impact on Jobs
 Indeed, social scientists say that natural-language understanding, if it is perfected, will have a far-reaching impact on employment. The technology holds out the potential for replacing people now doing service jobs conducted by telephone, like telephone operators and airline reservations agents.
Microsoft hopes that some simple products based on the technology may emerge within a few years. "This will make possible the first real grammar checker," said Chris Peters, the general manager of the Microsoft Word line of products, referring to software programs that check prose for grammatical errors. "None of them work well today."
To be sure, imposing research challenges remain. After decades of work, linguists acknowledge that there are vast gaps in the knowledge that computers will need for understanding natural language. But promising results from work with electronic dictionaries has generated new enthusiasm in a field that many computer scientists thought had reached a dead end in the mid-1980's.
"On-line dictionaries look like they're the best candidate to be the resource that is needed to break that terrible bottleneck of knowledge acquisition," said Karen Jensen, a computational linguist and the leader of the Microsoft team.
Ms. Jensen's group at Microsoft has taken the Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English, available on computer tape, and analyzed 75,000 of its definitions and phrases. The process focuses on 45,000 nouns and verbs, and each run-through takes about 11 hours to generate about 150,000 relationships between words.
The most widely publicized effort to build such a real-world information base has been Cyc, a project begun in 1984 at the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation in Austin, Tex., and led by Douglas Lenat, a computer scientist.
The project, whose name is short for encyclopedia, involves trying to give a computer common sense by feeding it millions of rules and assertions that people do not think twice about -- such truths as "a child is never older than its parents" or "people usually cannot see through walls."
 
Japanese Efforts
 In Japan, the Government is investing as much as $100 million in developing specialized computer dictionaries to aid in speech recognition and computer translation projects.
Also, a structured knowledge base, called Wordnet, based on analyzing dictionary definitions, has been created by a Princeton University group led by George Miller, a cognitive scientist. Wordnet is now widely used by language researchers.
Despite such efforts, one of the most significant disappointments in the progress of computer science has been the slow headway in perfecting systems that actually understand spoken and written language.
In the 1960's and 1970's the field was characterized by great optimism. "I can remember when people believed that fully automatic machine translation was going to happen by 1962 and that high-quality connected speech recognition would be doable by 1977 or 1978," said Michael Lesk, a computer scientist at Bell Communications Research, a consortium owned by the regional Bell telephone companies.
 
Working on Grammar
 Such hopes were thwarted, but Ms. Jensen's group at Microsoft may now have a significant advantage over earlier efforts. She, Mr. Richardson and a third linguist, George Heidron, came to Microsoft in May 1991 from the International Business Machines Corporation; there, the group had developed a computer-based grammar "parser," a digital schoolmarm that can analyze the grammatical structure of a sentence and identify the role of each word in it.
The group's software development environment, which originally ran on a mainframe computer at I.B.M., has been rewritten from scratch on a personal computer at Microsoft and its scope extended from grammatical to semantic information.
To date, the program works in three modules or stages. During a first pass, the software makes a sketch of the structure of the syntax of the sentence.
In a second pass, the sentence is re-examined, relying on semantic information taken from the data base. For example, the verb "fly" might produce example sentences that permit establishing a relationship between the words "aircraft" and "spaceship," in the case of the sentence "The spaceship photographed Seattle, flying to Mars." That would permit the program to draw the conclusion that a spaceship is more likely to fly than is the city of Seattle.
Finally, during a third stage, the logical form of the sentence is analyzed, deriving such things as active and passive verbs from a set of rules. And the sentence might be revised to make the meaning clear: "Flying to Mars, the spaceship photographed Seattle."
 
Adding Encyclopedias
 While some other researchers say the Microsoft work is promising, they note that lexical knowledge -- the kind of information that can be extracted from written texts -- is only one of several types of information needed to build intelligent systems.
Robert Amsler, a computational linguist who is a pioneer in the field and is now establishing a center for lexical research at Florida Atlantic University in Boca Raton, identifies at least three other kinds of knowledge needed for language understanding: social, economic and experiential knowledge.
He offers an example: Anyone with common sense knows that a locomotive costs millions of dollars, not hundreds, and cannot be bought in a drugstore. But it would be difficult to find any one book, he says, that sets this down as a rule.
Other researchers see similar limitations. "The problem with dictionaries is that they are structured but incomplete," said Judith Klavans, a computational linguist at Columbia University. "There are huge gaps. It may be possible to determine that a foot has five toes, but we may miss the fact that people generally have two arms."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Karen Jensen, center, leads the Microsoft team of linguists and computer scientists developing software to teach human language to computers. The rest of the team, from left: Lucy Vanderwende, Joseph Pentherondakis, Bill Dolan, George Heidorn, seated, and Stephen Richardson. (Doug Wilson for The New York Times)
 
Diagram: "Can Seattle Fly?"
 Hoping to teach computers to understand and use human language, researchers at Microsoft are creating software tools that analyze sentences on the basis of grammar, syntax and semantic clues about the meaning of the words. An early commercial application might be a "grammar checker" program. Here is how it might analyze the following sentence.
 
1. SYNTACTIC ANALYSIS: The program tries to analyze the sentence's syntax, identifying the parts of speech and their relationships to one another. "The spaceship," for example, is identified as the subject of the sentence, and "Seattle" as the direct object of the verb "photographed." But syntactic analysis alone cannot unravel the ambiguity of the participial phrase "flying to Mars."
 
2. SEMANTIC INFORMATION: By consulting semantic clues, like dictionary definitions, the program concludes that a spaceship is more likely to fly than Seattle.
 
3. The computer now understands the sentence. If this was a "grammar checker," the program might suggest this revision to the writer.

HEADLINE: Loan Had a Higher Interest Rate Than Reported, Holtzman Says

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Trying to put to rest questions about a campaign loan that have become an issue in the Comptroller election, the incumbent, Elizabeth Holtzman, has asserted that the loan she accepted from Fleet Bank last year carried a much higher interest rate than election records indicate. But one of her opponents accused her of misrepresenting the facts in the case.
Ms. Holtzman's campaign for United States Senate took out a $450,000 loan from Fleet Bank in late August last year. Ms. Holtzman secured the loan by promising to raise about $680,000 at a fund-raising dinner in early September, and the campaign agreed to repay the debt by Sept. 30. 
 But the campaign's fund-raising fell far short of the goal, bringing in less than $200,000, and Ms. Holtzman, who was the loan's sole guarantor, failed to meet the September deadline. She still owes nearly $240,000.
The loan became the subject of a city investigation because seven months after it was made, Fleet Securities, which is owned by the same Rhode Island financial company, was named an underwriter of city bonds on the recommendation of Ms. Holtzman's deputy, Darcy Bradbury. After the loan was disclosed, Mayor David N. Dinkins, who jointly chooses underwriters with the Comptroller, canceled the firm's designation.
Federal election records show the loan carried a rate of 7 percent, 1 percent above the prime rate. But in recent campaign appearances, Ms. Holtzman has said the loan actually had an interest rate of 18 percent.
"This loan was made at 18 percent interest for the campaign for the United States Senate," Ms. Holtzman said on a radio talk show on Monday morning. "I had to personally guarantee that loan and we have made interest payments and it's a tremendous burden."
Ms. Holtzman has argued that, because the campaign promised to pay a one-time fee of $4,500 to the bank to cover administrative costs, the total cost of the loan would have been equivalent to one month's worth of interest at an annual rate of 18 percent had she repaid it on time.
One of Ms. Holtzman's opponents, Alan G. Hevesi, a Queens Assemblyman, has charged that her argument is specious. "This is a sad attempt by Liz Holtzman to mislead the public about a loan that was clearly not made on usual and customary terms," he said.
Mr. Hevesi's spokesman, Hank Morris, said the question of the loan's ultimate cost is academic, because the Holtzman campaign has never paid the $4,500 fee to the bank. In addition, Mr. Morris said, the one-time fee has not grown over time as the interest has. The interest rate has remained at 7 percent, he said.
Mr. Morris said Ms. Holtzman had purposely twisted the facts. "This is an out and out lie," he said. "The issue is did she lie on her federal election filings when she said the loan was 7 percent, or is she lying now?"
Neither Ms. Holtzman's spokeswoman, Maerwydd McFarland, nor her campaign manager, Edward Miller, returned several telephone calls yesterday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
G.D.P. Data Revised Upward

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
In its annual orgy of statistical revision, the Commerce Department said today that the broadest gauge of economic performance was stronger than previously thought during most of George Bush's Presidency.
Growth in the gross domestic product -- total output of goods and services within the country's borders -- is now found to have been about half a percentage point higher in 1990 and 1992. And the shrinkage of the G.D.P. in 1991 was half a point less, meaning that the brief recession that occurred then was less severe than previously portrayed. 
 This batch of economic data, which comes too late for Mr. Bush, was announced as the department also raised its growth figure for this year's spring quarter to a 1.8 percent annual pace from the 1.6 percent estimated in late July.
 
Offsetting Factors
 Higher investment in inventories and bigger purchases by Federal, state and local governments more than offset downward adjustments in the foreign trade sector and in spending on personal consumption.
But even as the revisions today suggested a slightly stronger economy, consumer confidence as measured by the Conference Board, a business-sponsored organization in New York, remained at a depressed reading of 59 percent in August despite the passage of the Clinton Administration's budget package.
Most analysts had predicted that the G.D.P. revision for the spring quarter would be downward, but word of a slightly faster pace of activity did little to change economists' expectations for the months ahead.
 
Still Not Cheering
 "I don't see a lot of momentum in these numbers," said Lincoln F. Anderson, an economist for Fidelity Management and Research, the Boston-based mutual fund group. "The strength that is there is in components that are unlikely to continue" to do well, like business equipment and the government sector, he added.
At the White House, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the President's top economic adviser, said "this is still a modest recovery," although the United States now shows the best growth of any advanced industrial economy for the latest 12 months.
Ms. Tyson and Alan Blinder, another member of the Council of Economic Advisers, said there was nothing in today's report to cause the Administration to change its forecast of growth at about a 3 percent rate for the rest of this year and slightly less thereafter.
One of the most striking adjustments to economic history in today's report was a jump of a full percentage point, to 5.7 percent, in the growth rate for the fourth quarter of 1992.
Government and private analysts attributed this variously to the relief efforts and the rebuilding from last year's hurricanes and to spending by people who, fearing tax increases under Bill Clinton, arranged to receive in 1992 income that they might otherwise have received this year.
 
Difficult to Measure
 There is no way, however, to quantify either factor, said Robert P. Parker, a Commerce Department official, nor can it be determined to what extent the prospect or fact of Mr. Clinton's election and one-party dominance of the Government might have been a psychological force encouraging spending.
More relevant to the election is the fact that the economy is now seen to have been doing better than perceived during the campaign, particularly in the politically crucial second quarter of 1992. Growth for the period is now put at a rate of 2.8 percent, twice as fast as was reported on three occasions last summer when the political conventions were under way.
Yet it is by no means clear that had the data published today been known a year ago Mr. Bush might have been re-elected.
"What this does is increase the puzzle slightly as to why consumers and voters were so pessimistic," said Ray C. Fair, a Yale University economics professor who has studied the relationship between G.D.P. and other economic measures and election outcomes.
Professor Fair erred last year in predicting a Bush victory based on modest growth, low inflation and the advantages of incumbency.
It is likely, suggested Professor Fair, that voters pay greatest attention to such concrete indicators as paychecks and the availability of jobs, rather than gross domestic product.
Mr. Bush's office did not respond to a request today for comment. Previously Republicans have noted with some chagrin that the best quarter for G.D.P. during Mr. Bush's term was one not reported until just after Bill Clinton's inauguration and that reports of unemployment showed a half-point drop in the months after Election Day and no further decline for the balance of 1993's first half.
For full-year 1990, today's figures show, G.D.P. grew 1.2 percent instead of the previously reported eight-tenths of 1 percent, while the 1991 contraction was trimmed to seven-tenths of 1 percent from 1.2 percent. The 1992 rebound was raised to 2.6 percent from 2.1.
 
Inflation Played a Role
 Each of the revisions, which were larger than usual, primarily involved personal spending for goods, business investment in new equipment and spending by government entities, the Commerce Department said. It added that the main factor in these was new inflation estimates for these components.
The recession, the department also found, involved a 1.6 percent decline in G.D.P. from its second-quarter 1990 peak to its first-quarter 1991 trough, less than the 2.2 percent previously reported.
Today's report also showed that corporate profits from current production rose 2.6 percent in the second quarter after falling 1.7 percent in the January-March period. Current-production cash flow -- internal funds available to companies for investment -- rose 1.3 percent after a 2.4 percent fall during the winter.
The Conference Board's confidence reading of 59, typical of a sluggish economy, was not only the same as in July but the same as a year ago when Mr. Bush was still in office.
"The ordinary citizen is still a very insecure and apprehensive person," said Fabian Linden, supervisor of the monthly mail survey of 500 households. "It doesn't take much to make someone decide to repair the refrigerator instead of replacing it, to spend $50 instead of $500."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Strong Gains On Positive Economic News

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday, buoyed by better-than-expected data on the United States economy for the second quarter.
Gold prices were up in New York and mixed overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery closed at $373 a troy ounce, up $2.40 from Monday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $372.65 a troy ounce, an increase of $2.40. 
 Traders said the dollar jumped after the Commerce Department reported the gross domestic product -- the sum of goods and services produced in the United States -- was up 1.8 percent in the April-June period. That was better than the department's earlier estimate of 1.6 percent.
"It wasn't a tremendous boost, but in the last week or so it feels like the dollar has been stuck in a range," said Matt Porio, a vice president of Chase Manhattan. "This gave it an impetus."
But Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst at Smith Barney Shearson, said the dollar only gained a limited amount from the new G.D.P. number, since it was based in part on higher-than-expected Government spending.
"That's not the same thing as definitive growth," she said.
 
Rate Cut Predicted
 In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 104.18 yen, up 0.28 yen from the close on Monday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 104.70 yen, up from 104.05 yen in Europe on Monday. In New York, the dollar finished at 104.75 yen, up from 103.80 yen.
Traders said the dollar was pushed higher by the purchases early yesterday by the Japanese central bank, which has been trying to keep the yen from skyrocketing against the dollar. In addition, the yen weakened on local news reports in Japan that predicted an interest rate cut, traders said. Such a cut would probably hurt the yen because investments in the Japanese currency would earn less.
The British pound was quoted in London at $1.4870, down from $1.4990 late Monday. Later in New York, the pound changed hands at $1.4915, down from $1.4930 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Fewer Raises Are Expected

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Many American workers will not get raises in the coming year and those who do can expect a small increase as companies try to hold the line on expenses, according to a national survey released yesterday.
Twenty-one percent of United States companies surveyed will not give some employee groups annual raises in 1994, up from 14 percent this year, the consulting firm William M. Mercer Inc. reported. 
 Instead, companies may offer one-time lump sum bonuses amounting to 3.5 percent of a worker's salary because in the long run it costs the company less.
"Raises have a compounding effect on payroll costs, but bonuses of this type do not, a fact that can help employers hold the line on rising expenses," a Mercer partner, Linda Ison, said.
The nationwide annual survey was based on data from 2,700 large employers with a combined payroll of 9.4 million workers.
Employees who survive the latest round of layoffs in any industry can expect a continued shrinkage in the size of average salary increases, projected to be 4.5 percent in 1994, down from 4.6 percent in 1993, according to the Mercer survey. Set against annual inflation projected at just 3 percent, this could provide a 1.5 percent cushion.
According to the survey, raises will tend to be comparatively higher in biotechnology (5.9 percent), computers and software (5.1 percent) and pharmaceuticals (5.1 percent).
On the bottom of the pay increase scale are pulp and paper (3.7 percent), aerospace (3.9 percent) and education (3.7 percent), sectors greatly hurt by the downturn in the economy.
