HEADLINE: Letter: On Saudi Arabia;
Riyadh Outlines Its Fiscal Strategy

BYLINE: MOHAMMAD ABALKHAIL; Minister of Finance & Natl. Economy
Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 26, 1993

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Aug. 22-23 front-page articles about the financial position of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia:
Saudi Arabia, being an important member of the community of nations and the biggest exporter in the world of such an essential commodity as oil, has always managed its affairs prudently, with full realization of its international responsibilities. We do not expect all to approve of our policies, nor do we look for applause and encouragement from all quarters. However, objective judgments require accurate information. 
 You state that Saudi Arabia has depleted the huge petroleum wealth accumulated since 1973 in the transformation of the country from a tribal society to a modern state and that it had spent a lot on the building of infrastructure and huge educational and health facilities. This is correct, and we feel proud of it.
The strategy of development that Saudi Arabia followed was to direct petroleum revenues to building the physical and social infrastructure of this vast country (about one-fourth the size of the United States) and to harness the participation of the Saudi private sector by Government contracts and credit facilities, and through joint projects with foreign contractors and entrepreneurs.
This also helped the private sector build its financial resources and technical capabilities, and to assume its natural role in the national economy. In the last two decades thousands of foreign companies worked in our country, and thousands of new Saudi companies were established. A host of friendly countries, including the United States, also benefited.
Our budget deficit, of which you paint a lurid picture, is not a secret only now disclosed. It is mentioned in the annual Government budgets, which in recent years have also mentioned that the deficit will be financed by borrowing through domestic bond issues, similar to what all other governments do. There is nothing wrong in this, and I see it as the right policy in most circumstances because government borrowing to finance development is in my view better than imposing taxes and fees.
Most of the public debt in Saudi Arabia is an internal debt, and the amount borrowed abroad is very limited, not exceeding $4.5 billion, which is not a high figure for so large a state. The public debt does not exceed 52 percent of gross domestic product, less than the maximum taken by the European Community for its standard of creditworthiness. You should not forget that Saudi Arabia was confronted in 1991 with a war that cost it, as you state, $55 billion.
That Saudi Arabia produces about eight million barrels of oil daily should in itself be an assurance of continuing inflow of foreign exchange. The Saudi currency, which is fully convertible, is covered fully by a special reserve of hard currencies that exceeds $20 billion. The hard currency assets of Saudi banks exceed $15 billion. Government bond holding of the Saudi banks does not exceed $20 billion. Furthermore, Saudi Arabia is among the 10 states holding the largest quotas in the International Monetary Fund.
Saudi banks enjoy a status not enjoyed by many banks in international financial centers. Despite the negative effects of the Persian Gulf war, the banks showed the strength and resilience to realize growth in deposits, assets and profits in 1991 and 1992. The results for the first half of 1993 indicate continuing all-round growth.
The financial position of banks in Saudi Arabia is better than that of most of their counterparts abroad, including American banks, and it is unfair to compare them to U.S. savings and loan institutions.
The Saudi Government has spent nearly $900 billion on a wide net of infrastructure projects and educational, health and other structures, and extended about $70 billion as soft long-term loans to Saudi nationals and companies to support their investment in industry, agriculture, housing and construction of private hospitals and hotels, and also granted about $70 billion as concessional credits and grants to 70 developing countries around the world. Don't you consider that proper use of our resources?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Ranchers Can't Afford Grazing Fee Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The proposal to raise public lands grazing fees made by Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbitt will do just the opposite of what he says it will do. 
 For instance, he says that his 130 percent increase in fees won't drive ranchers off the land. It will so greatly increase the costs of doing business that it won't be feasible for ranchers to operate. Ranchers will be forced to sell off their private holdings to developers, who are even now drooling at the prospects.
The open space that has been maintained by ranching families for 100 years or more will be filled with hotels, ranchettes and condos, and will become elite communities with room only for the affluent. Does anyone think that would be an environmentally friendly change?
The proposal will not add $80 billion to the Treasury, but will take money from the Treasury because the grazing fees paid to the Treasury will be dramatically reduced when ranchers are forced out of business. Government costs will also increase because of the need to hire more land managers to replace the stewardship now provided by ranchers.
Mr. Babbitt says his proposal will improve the lands. But Government agency reports show that Western public lands are in better condition today than at any other time in this century. This, along with significant increases in wildlife numbers, can be attributed to the stewardship and land improvements made by ranchers. If you price the stewards off the land, you won't have stewardship.
Mr. Babbitt also maintains that his proposal will eliminate a Government subsidy. Ranchers aren't receiving a Government subsidy now and don't want one in the future. They want to pay a fair price for public lands forage based on sound economic principles.
That's why the livestock industry is supporting legislation introduced by Representative Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a Colorado Democrat, and Senator Malcolm Wallop, a Wyoming Republican, that will set into law a fair formula to increase the current fee by 25 percent.
Livestock producers aren't crying wolf. The Babbitt proposal will devastate rural economies and lead to environmental damage in the West just when President Clinton wants to improve both.
 
WILLIAM G. MYERS 3D
Director, Federal Lands
National Cattlemen's Association
Washington, Aug. 24, 1993

HEADLINE: Undocumented Immigrants Avoid U.S. Services

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Governor's Brave Stand on Illegal Aliens" (Op-Ed, Aug. 23) by Alan C. Nelson, former Immigration and Naturalization Service commissioner, is rife with questionable "facts" and "statistics" based on the erroneous premise that our borders are out of control, that undocumented immigrants are pouring into the United States at skyrocketing rates and that an unprecedented number are availing themselves of such social services as welfare. In truth, undocumented immigrants, fearful of being discovered and deported, tend not to use social services. 
 No one has the exact numbers of undocumented immigrants living in the United States because it is a population that tends to avoid contact with government agencies. However, the Bureau of the Census estimates that the undocumented population consists of about 4 million to 5 million people, and grows at a rate of 200,000 to 250,000 a year -- a drop in our population bucket, considering that we are a nation of 260 million.
There is some indication of what social services undocumented immigrants do and do not use, based on Immigration and Naturalization Service surveys of immigrants who were legalized during the "amnesty" program of 1987-88.
At the time of application, less than 1 percent of the legalized immigrant population received general assistance, Social Security, Supplemental Security Income, workers compensation and unemployment insurance payments. Less than half of 1 percent obtained food stamps and Aid to Families With Dependent Children.
Moreover, before legalization, undocumented immigrants, men and women, worked. Eighty-three percent of the legalized immigrant population participated in the labor force against 77 percent of the general population. For ages 18-64, 94 percent of the legalized population participated in the labor force against 88 percent of the general population.
Men in the legalized immigrant population worked on the average two hours a day more than men in the general population. Legalized immigrant women worked five hours a day more than women in the general population. Thirteen percent of the legalized immigrant population worked more than 40 hours a week and were not paid time and a half. Of this group, 52 percent were men, and 74 percent were women.
These figures make clear that undocumented immigrants are not the burden on our country that Mr. Nelson portrays them as being, nor is illegal immigration so great a problem as he states. To the degree that it is a problem, I agree that responsible steps must be taken to address it; but the proposals of California's Gov. Pete Wilson, as endorsed by Mr. Nelson, are cruel, unnecessary and irresponsible.
 
FRANK SHARRY
Executive Director
National Immigration Forum
Washington, Aug. 23, 1993

HEADLINE: Undocumented Immigrants Avoid U.S. Services;
California's Burden

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"California Scapegoats" (editorial, Aug. 16) charges Gov. Pete Wilson unfairly with "making immigration a scapegoat." You concede the economic hardship caused by defense layoffs in California. Also, you acknowledge the soundness of Governor Wilson's plea for tamperproof identification cards held by immigrants. In addition, both the Governor and you know that children of even illegal immigrants cannot be denied a public education. That would punish the innocent and run afoul of the Constitution. 
 However, while it is highly unlikely that the Constitution will be amended to deny full citizenship to children born in the United States of illegal immigrants, you are too cavalier in rejecting outright Governor Wilson's proposal. Did the citizenship definition in the 14th Amendment, "all persons born" on United States territory, intend to apply to the progeny of illegal immigrants? Hardly!
Again, although it would be the height of cruelty to deny health assistance to illegal immigrants, you fail to note the huge drain on state resources in California and taxpayer dissatisfaction. Nor with respect to illegals, can Governor Wilson be faulted for not focusing on violations and workplace enforcement. In this case, he may recognize limitations and futility better than you do.
California and other Mexican border states merit additional grants from the Federal Government to deal with an exceptional burden in a national problem.
Neither California nor public officials in those states warrant your characterization of "nativist demagogy."
 
ELLIOTT A. COHEN
New York, Aug. 19, 1993

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Close a Bit Weaker in Volatile Day

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
In a volatile day of trading, the bond market ended slightly weaker yesterday with yields rising. Only the price of the 30-year bond managed to eke out a small gain, which pushed its yield down from 6.11 percent Monday to 6.09 percent, just above the 20-year low reached last week.
The report that the economy grew at a revised 1.8 percent annual rate in the second quarter, after adjustment for inflation, had little impact, although the economic pace was higher than many forecasters had expected. 
 Since the Commerce Department reported two weeks ago a surprisingly large jump in the June trade deficit, in large part because of declining exports, many forecasters had said growth would slow in the second quarter to close to 1 percent. The initial Government report on the growth of the gross domestic product, which was released a month ago, was 1.6 percent.
The expectation that the second-quarter growth would be slower than initially reported bolstered the view that there was little chance that inflation, now rising at a slower pace than last yrear, would accelerate any time soon. And this view had helped the prices of both the 30-year bonds and shorter-term Treasury securities rally in the last two weeks.
When the new G.D.P. figure was released yesterday morning, the prices of short and intermediate Treasuries did fall. But they recovered to end little changed on the day.
"This is a market that wants to improve," said Nancy Kimmelman, chief economist at Technical Data in Boston. "As soon as it can find an excuse to dismiss what would be negative data it rallies. The data are very much ancient history as far as the bond market is concerned."
Ms. Kimmelman said that investors seemed to be in a state where a selloff in the market was viewed as an opportunity to buy securities at a cheaper price rather than a signal that the recent sharp decline in interest rates was slowing or coming to an end.
 
2d-Quarter Economic Growth
 She noted that while the 1.8 percent pace of economic growth in the second quarter was higher than the roughly 1 percent expected by many forecasters, the overall growth rate of the economy for the first half of the year had not increased very much and was certainly still very sluggish with very slow job growth.
In addition, she said that the new data on the gross domestic product did include a downard revision in final sales in the second quarter, to 3.1 percent from 3.7 percent. That number, which excludes the changes in inventories, is a sign that the "underlying strength of the economy" has weakened a bit. The market also got some support because the inflation rate for the seocnd quarter was revised down to 2.3 percent from 3.6 percent..
By late in day in secondary trading, the prices of Treasury notes had seesawed enough to erase most of the losses recorded in the morning. Traders said that the bounce-back during the day was in part a reaction to the fact that the Federal Reserve, as part of its regular monetary operations, had bought billions of dollars worth of Treasury securities. The Fed does this when it has to add reserves to the system to assure that its monetary policy is not tighter than it intends.
The price of the 10-year note was down just 1/32 on the day, with the yield remaining at 5.44 percent. The price has been down almost half a point in morning trade. The price of the two-year Treasury note was down 2/32 as the yield inched up to 3.86 percent, from 3.83 percent Monday.
The yield on the 6.25 percent 30-year bond was down to 6.09 percent, from 6.11 percent the day before. Earlier in the day the price had been up 15/32 in the morning with the yield down to 6.07 percent. As it has recently, the rally in the price of the 30-year bond seems to continue without much regard for whether the economic news is positive or negative.
In the afternoon, the Johnson Redbook survey of chain store sales showed that sales in August, through Saturday, were 1.1 percent below July's. This just added another bit of data to the slow growth outlook.
Trading was heavy in the morning but it may slow some the rest of the week as traders and investors turn their focus to the most important new economic data of the week, the employment numbers for July that will be released by the Labor Department Friday.
Based on the consensus forecast done by Bloomberg Business News, which predicts an increase of 147,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in July, the data should support the idea that the economy is still sluggish and help keep interest rates as low as they are or push them even lower.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 30, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A table in Business Day on Sept. 1, with an article about revisions of second-quarter data on the gross domestic product, reversed the data for current prices and 1987 prices. A corrected table, with final second-quarter revisions announced yesterday, appears today on page D8.

HEADLINE: Pentagon Seeking to Cut Military But Equip It for 2 Regional Wars

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
After spending six months reviewing American military needs, the Clinton Administration unveiled a new plan today for cutting the armed forces, which embraces the Bush Administration's basic military doctrine: with the disappearance of a Russian military threat, the United States should be prepared to fight two regional wars at the same time.
The Pentagon plan, which President Clinton approved this week, would shrink the military to 1.4 million troops from 1.7 million over five years by cutting Army divisions, Navy aircraft carriers and Air Force fighter wings. 
 These cuts go somewhat further than those planned by the Bush Administration but do not represent a significant departure in military policy. The White House insists that its new plan amounts to the first post-cold-war military strategy, but it endorses the basic Bush Administration views.
Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who was instrumental in developing the plans of both the Bush and Clinton Administrations, acknowledged as much today when he outlined the plan at a packed Pentagon briefing.
The strategy behind the Clinton plan is quite similar to the Bush plan, said General Powell, who will retire at the end of the month. "And it ought to be quite similar because the world looks the same to us."
In one significant departure, the new plan shows a willingness to protect the military industrial base in contrast to the Bush Administration's strict adherence to free market forces. [News analysis, page A18.]
In strictly military terms, one contentious issue is whether the forces provided for in the Clinton plan are sufficient to carry out its strategy, called "win win," of fighting two nearly simultaneous nonnuclear conflicts.
 
Overall Question
 Defense Secretary Les Aspin and General Powell said that to carry out the Bush Administration's two-war strategy with fewer forces, the Clinton Administration planned to store enough weapons and equipment for several Army brigades at several overseas locations for use in the Persian Gulf or in a conflict in Korea, to spend more money on precision-guided missiles and bombs and to buy additional ships for transporting troops and equipment.
But some former Pentagon officials say the Clinton Administration may be hard pressed to carry out the two-war strategy.
"It was tough enough to carry out the win-win strategy with the forces envisioned by the Bush Administration," said Zalmay Khalilzad, the head of Pentagon's office of policy planning in the Bush Administration and an analyst with the Rand Corporation. "The question is can they really do win-win with a reduced forced structure."
In the early stages of their deliberations, Clinton Administration officials looked at making even deeper cuts. Under one plan considered by the Pentagon the military would prepare to win one war at a time. Dubbed "win hold win," the plan called for first fighting and winning one war while holding the line in the other.
But reports that the Pentagon was considering such a change in strategy created some uneasiness in South Korea, where officials feared it would mean that the United States was backing away from its longstanding military commitments. The idea was criticized by American lawmakers as well.
After extensive review, the Clinton Administration embraced a win-win strategy, meaning the United States would keep enough troops and equipment ready to fight and prevail in conflicts that begin nearly at the same time. This was the same strategy that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney endorsed as part of the Bush Administration's regional military strategy before he left office.
 
Taking a Chance
 Both the Bush Administration and the Clinton Administration decided to take the chance that two conflicts would not start at exactly the same time. In doing so they held down the need for buying many more costly transport ships and cargo planes.
To justify the two-war strategy, General Powell said the United States needed to be able to fight a war in the Persian Gulf to defend the oil supply while also guarding against a North Korean attack against South Korea, or vice versa. If the United States had the ability to fight only one war at a time, the reasoning goes, adversaries might be tempted to exploit a crisis. If the United States was fighting a war against Iran, for example, North Korea might see it as a time to strike.
One assumption of the new strategy is that the United States may not be able to count on many allies and may have to fight virtually alone. "Our forces must be sized and structured to preserve the flexibility and the capability to act unilaterally, should we chose to do so," Mr. Aspin said in a paper released today.
Another key assumption is that American forces will seek to avoid the use of nuclear weapons, relying instead on high-technology and well-trained conventional forces.
 
Attention to Trouble Spots
 Reflecting its new strategy and its desire to maintain a military presence near trouble spots around the world, the Clinton Administration's cuts in the Navy and the Marines are relatively modest.
It plans to cut the Navy from 14 to 12 aircraft carriers. One carrier were be used for training and occasional patrols. The Bush Administration has planned a force of 12 carriers.
The Clinton Administration planned to reduce the Marine Corps by a smaller amount than the Bush Administration. The Clinton Administration will cut the corps from the current size of 180,000 to 174,000 instead of the force of 159,000 proposed by the Bush Administration.
The Air Force will be reduced to 20 tactical fighter wings, compared with the 24 wings the Bush Administration planned to keep.
The Army, whose role had declined after the dissipation of the Soviet threat, will be reduced to 10 active divisions, 2 fewer than the Bush Administration had planned.
 
More Use of Reserves
 But the Clinton Administration is planning to make greater use of Army reserve units. After the Persian Gulf war, the Bush Administration was disappointed by the failure of the Army to field reserve brigades for possible combat and wanted to cut the Army reserves. But the Congress, yielding to intensive lobbying by reservists, opposed deep cuts.
In a bow to political reality and in an effort to buttress its two-war strategy, the Clinton Administration plans to improve the training of 15 reserve brigades so they can be called up for combat.
Under the Clinton plan, only two weapons programs would be canceled: the AFX radar-evading bomber the Navy has been seeking and the Air Force's multirole fighter. Both the Navy and the Air Force, however, won the Administration's backing for their most-wanted programs. The Navy will field a new version of the FA-18 while the Air Force will field new F-22 fighters.
The Clinton plan disclosed today costs about $13 billion more than the $1.2 trillion than the Administration plans to spend on the military over the next five years, according to Administration officials. Military officials have said they are seeking to make offsetting cuts and it is still unclear how much additional money the Pentagon will seek.
Military experts and Pentagon officials acknowledged that are broad parallels between the forces proposed by the Clinton and Bush Administration.
 
'An Underlying Consensus'

"The similarities between the Secretary Aspin's findings and the Bush Administration's military plans suggest an underlying consensus on the forces that are required to deal with the threats of the 1990's," said Loren Thompson, the deputy director of the national security studies program at Georgetown University.
Like the Bush Administration's, the Clinton Administration plan avoids sweeping changes in the missions of the military services that Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, and Mr. Clinton, when he was a candidate, suggested were needed.
Still, there are some important differences between the Bush and Clinton approaches. The Clinton Administration, for example, has emphasized the development of ground based anti-missile defenses against Scud-type surface-to-surface missiles instead of the development of space-based anti-missile systems. And Clinton Administration has essentially written off the possiblity that Moscow might recreate its conventional military threat to the West and is placing greater emphasis preparing for peacekeeping operations.
Precisely because of its similarities with the Bush plan, however, the Clinton plan was criticized today by some lawmakers who said it did not cut enough programs.
"The Pentagon only canceled two weapons program today," said Representative John Conyers Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the Government Operations subcommittee on national security. "It's a little bit like, 'Honey, I shrunk the military.' Somehow, you feel it's not quite real," he said in a statement.
And the Defense Budget Project, a research group that is often critical of the Pentagon, also challenged the Clinton plan, saying deeper cuts were needed.
"Like the Bush base force plan, the Clinton plan tries to pack too much force structure into too small a budget," it said. "Over the long term, the Defense Department will not be able to maintain a force of 1.4 million personnel within the projected Clinton defense budgets without sacrificing readiness or modernization."


GRAPHIC: The Defense Department unveiled long-range plans yesterday built around the goal of being able to fight two-large nonnuclear regional conflicts at the same time. The Bush Administration had developed a similar long-range plan, which in general called for slightly higher levels of forces.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: 2 Airlines Struggle to Revive Their Fortunes;
Delta May Start Low-Cost Carrier

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Vowing to return Delta Air Lines to profitability as "a lean, tough competitor," Ronald W. Allen, the carrier's chairman and president, said yesterday in New York that the financially troubled company was committed to cutting costs further and was considering starting a low-cost no-frills airline.
Delta's chief executive added that the carrier could furlough as many as 600 pilots in the next few months, including 250 pilots scheduled to be laid off by the end of next month. 
 They are the first layoffs since 1957, a Delta spokesman in Atlanta said. The pilots' union has been unwilling to accept the 5 percent pay cuts that other Delta employees have taken, so the carrier has resorted to layoffs.
 
 
Early Retirement Offer
 Delta, which lost about $540 million last year on $1.78 billion in revenue, has trimmed its work force 7.7 percent, or about 6,200 jobs, since June 1992, mostly by attrition or by ending part-time positions. The carrier also recently offered early retirement to 3,000 of its remaining 73,400 employees.
In yesterday's wide-ranging hour-long news conference, Mr. Allen said the carrier had lowered costs, increased productivity and streamlined every division, in part by eliminating "layers of management."
Asked whether Delta would consider starting a low-cost airline, Mr. Allen said it was an option, but did not elaborate. "We're going to do what is necessary to be competitive," he said. "We haven't ruled out anything."
American and United have suggested the possibility of operating low-cost subsidiaries to compete with Southwest Airlines and with several other airlines that have lowered labor costs through employee concessions or, in the case of Continental Airlines, after emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy-law protection. United's pilots, however, are opposed to any effort to start a nonunion carrier.
Mr. Allen also cited "dramatic improvement" in traffic and revenue on Delta's trans-Atlantic operations. Purchased from Pan Am in 1991 for more than $500 million, the routes have lost $750 million in the last 18 months. Earlier this year Delta eliminated its unprofitable route between Newark and Frankfurt; it will soon end its flights between Miami and Frankfurt, and at the end of the summer it will determine whether to end other unprofitable routes.
"We won't radically restructure our routes," said Robert W. Coggin, Delta's senior vice president of marketing, "we'll just do some refining." One way, he said, would be to add stops to what are now nonstop flights on some routes.
Mr. Allen implied that Delta's European operation would show a profit in the latter part of this year, but he declined to be specific. Likewise, he declared he was "not going to speculate" about future earnings.
Delta's trans-Atlantic woes stemmed from a combination of events, Mr. Allen said, beginning with the failure of the United States economy to improve in 1992, as widely predicted, and the fact that "the European economy went into the tank, particularly Germany." Delta's major European hub is at Frankfurt, from which the carrier flies to nine other European countries.
 
 
'Not Enough Lines'
 But the 21 A310 Airbus Industrie airplanes that came with the Pan Am sale proved to be "inadequate," Mr. Allen said, and would be replaced this year. In addition, the reservations system in Europe did not measure up. "People just couldn't get through to us," he said. "There were not enough lines."
Moreover, although Delta is the United States carrier with the most trans-Atlantic flights -- its 293 weekly trans-Atlantic flights include 115 nonstop departures from Kennedy International Airport -- Delta officials say that it suffers to this day from the image that it is primarily a North American carrier. In contrast, the Pan Am name was known around the world.
Meanwhile, Delta continues to look for computer code-sharing alliances for reservations, Mr. Allen said, in addition to its longstanding ones with Singapore Airlines and Swissair. It recently announced such alliances with Brazil's Varig Airlines and Aeromexico, but they are not yet approved.
Mr. Allen said he did not foresee any change in Delta's alliance with Swissair, which was given permission by the Swiss Government yesterday to enter into formal talks with its European rivals, Austrian Airlines, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and Scandinavian Airlines System, for what is eventually expected to become a joint holding company.
In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, Delta closed at $52.625 a share, down $1.375.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We're going to do what is necessary to be competitive," said Ronald W. Allen, chairman of Delta Air Lines, at a news conference yesterday. The carrier has streamlined each division and planned for layoffs. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Timber Country Sees a Vacation Land

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT ANGELES, Wash., Aug. 31

 BODY:
When Senator Patty Murray ventured into the heart of timber country here today, she expected something less than the customary courtesy given legislators on home-state tours. As the only Senator from the Pacific Northwest to support President Clinton's broad plan to reduce logging on Federal land, Ms. Murray was prepared for jeers and worse.
To her surprise, she found a community trying to transform itself from one based on cutting down giant trees to one where visitors would come to spend money to see the standing forest and nearby sea life. 
 Instead of the usual, crudely drawn posters of endangered birds in gun sights, she found a new residential road named "Spotted Owl Lane." She also heard from dozens of community leaders here in the far northwest corner of the continental United States who are seeking a piece of the new Federal aid program that President Clinton is seeking to help areas hard hit by logging restrictions. People here envisioned using some of the money for retraining programs and building docks for cruise ships, Indian cultural centers and industrial parks.
There was also at least one encounter with an angry logger, Larry Mason of the timber town of Forks, who said the President's plan would put him out of business. And several others in the forest products industry asked what exactly they could be retrained to do.
 
Plan to Reduce Logging
 In seeking to save salmon streams and threatened species, the Clinton plan would reduce logging on Federal forests here to one-fourth of the highest level of the mid-1980's. It seeks to provide $1.2 billion in economic aid over five years to ease the transition. Mr. Clinton estimates the plan would put 6,000 people out of work, while the timber industry says the number would be 10 times that number.
Ms. Murray, a Democrat elected last year as an underdog, did not try to revisit the old ground of environment versus jobs. That fight, she told people here, is largely over. It would be a lie, she said later, to encourage people to believe they could continue logging at anything near past levels. "If we continue in the same old battle lines as the past, you people will be the losers," she said.
It was the Federal Government that created the modern economy on the Olympic Peninsula when it began to open up vast tracts of land for logging in the 1950's. What remained untouched was the scenic centerpiece of the peninsula, the one-million-acre Olympic National Park. As logging has declined, tourism has boomed, with the park's wild seashore and misted rain forest now drawing more than three million visitors a year.
Until now, there have been very few civic efforts to make money from tourists. The Port Angeles waterfront, framed by two pulp mills, is clogged with huge logs that were cut from private land and await export to Asia. A visitor is hard pressed to find even a small stretch of public beach amid the horizontal forest of export logs.
But the port's operators are drawing up plans to learn from Victoria, British Columbia, their neighbor across the Strait of Juan de Fuca, which is a prosperous cultural, tourism and government center.
The community college here, its enrollment swelled by unemployed loggers, asked for assistance to help design retraining programs. The Forest Service is about to embark on a major effort to restore streams damaged by years of excessive logging. But no one is exactly sure how it will be conducted.
 
Proposed Indian Center
 "We used to take logs out of streams, and now we're going to be spending a lot of money putting logs back into streams," said Jim Walton, an educator at Peninsula College, a two-year institution. "What are we supposed to teach?"
To the west of here, the Lower Elwha Indian tribe wants to build a longhouse, a traditional coastal Indian center, on the sand pit bordering the harbor. Farther west, the Makah Indians at Neah Bay presented Ms. Murray with a plan to transform an abandoned Air Force base into a 230-room retreat on the wild Pacific shore.
Inside the park, Ms. Murray visited a dam on the Elwha River that environmentalists want torn down. Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt recently came out for removing the dam, saying it would help to restore a run of chinook salmon used to draw hundreds of fishermen to this area.
Even Forks, long evoked by politicians and in many news reports as the epitome of a depressed timber town, is showing signs of life. Although the unemployment rate has been 19 percent for nearly two years, the town now wants to open an industrial center, where timber would processed into high-value goods from violins to wicker chairs.
"The town is not folding up and dying," said Sandra Kint, a Forks community leader who met with Senator Murray. "A lot of people are stressed, but there is a new infusion of ideas. We are trying to be visionary while still addressing the immediate concern of what you do about the guy who can't make his mortgage payment next month."
 
Approval of Aid Expected
 The dawning new economy here cannot go anywhere without Federal help, community leaders say. This fall, Congress is expected pass most of the President's request for the first year in aid money, about $280 million for the entire Northwest. Officials from the Olympic Peninsula have requested about 10 percent of that amount.
The challenge for Mr. Clinton and the handful of national legislators from the West who have backed him on the timber plan, Ms. Murray said, is to deliver on the promise that one successful way of life can be exchanged for another. "The last thing these people want is another empty promise," she said in an interview.
She also had a small personal request, if the peninsula makes a successful transition from its timber economy. "I wouldn't mind someday coming out here and seeing the Patty Murray Bike Path through the forest," she said.

HEADLINE: A Job-Oriented Defense: Protecting the American Work Place

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
The Pentagon plans to spend billions over the next five years on weapons that it concedes have as much to do with protecting jobs and technology as with protecting America.
As it confronts the task of shrinking the armed forces in the post-cold war world, the Clinton Administration is taking an approach that combines economics and politics with military necessity. The long-range plan announced today by Defense Secretary Les Aspin would use the huge Pentagon budget to keep alive production lines and specialized military technologies that it fears would otherwise disappear. 
 For example, the Navy already has two Seawolf attack submarines on order, all the Pentagon says it needs for military purposes now. Indeed, the Navy plans to retire older submarines and reduce the total number of attack submarines by 1999 to about 45 from the present 81. But the long-range plan announced today calls for building a third Seawolf, for $2.4 billion, an economic life preserver to eastern Connecticut, where the submarine is built.
Mr. Aspin said the Navy would proceed with the third Seawolf because it would be too costly to close the production line and then restart it in the future when the United States needs new submarines.
 
Bridging a Gap
 The Pentagon knows it will need to start building a more advanced class of submarine around the turn of the century. The question, Mr. Aspin told reporters, is what to do in the meantime.
The alternatives, he said, are to shut down the program and restart it "when you need to build it" or to order a third Seawolf to bridge the gap between the time when the first two are completed and when work on the successor class of submarine would begin.
This concern for America's military industrial base is a significant departure from the Bush Administration's position of allowing free market forces to reign, even in technologies critical to the nation's military might.
Preserving critical technologies in areas like fighter planes, submarines and satellites is part of a broader Administration strategy to deal with the human and technical consequences of a vastly reduced military.
The plan includes easing the transition for communities with military industries, military workers and troops leaving the armed services, as well as encouraging military industries to develop products for commercial markets.
In political terms, it also reflects the Administration's concern for keeping a promise Mr. Clinton made during the campaign, when he endorsed buying additional Seawolf submarines, which are built by the Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corporation in Groton, Conn. Even with the third Seawolf, Electric Boat says its employment will shrink to 7,500 workers by 1997 from 17,500 now.
 
New Aircraft Carrier, Too
 Mr. Aspin also said today that the Defense Department would buy a new nuclear-powered aircraft carrier, built by Newport News Shipbuilding in Newport News, Va., which is owned by Tenneco Inc., thus insuring that despite the rapid shrinking of the military industry, Washington can count on one shipyard to build nuclear-powered submarines and another to build aircraft carriers.
The military rationale for the new $3.6 billion carrier is to help the Navy maintain a constant maritime presence around the world. Maintaining jobs and the specialized technology reinforces this need.
"In essence, it's a long-term investment policy," said Richard Bitzinger, a military industry analyst at the Defense Budget Project, a research organization here. "If you lose those niches in the industrial base, you're consigned to being dependent on foreign sources. Except that no one else builds nuclear submarines or aircraft carriers."
Critics of the Clinton Administration's plan, however, argue that the policy is just a Democratic pork barrel project and perpetuates military spending when the country should be making deeper cuts in the Pentagon's budget than the Administration has proposed.
 
Motives Questioned
 "Without any real military justification, the bottom-up review clearly just plans to keep building submarines merely for the United States to be able to keep building submarines," said Joshua Handler, a research analyst with Greenpeace in Washington.
As military budgets shrink and force many contractors to merge or get out of the business, the Pentagon is being forced to abandon its longstanding policy of requiring competition for Pentagon contracts to try to obtain the best prices.
"In certain areas, we are going to find inevitably, as we buy fewer weapons, that we rely on fewer competitors and fewer competing producers, and in some cases we will be down to one producer," a senior Defense Department official told reporters after Mr. Aspin's news conference. "For those very few instances which are defense-unique items, we are going to have to worry about how do we deal with the situation of having one industrial base."
This approach both hurts and helps a company like Newport News Shipbuilding. On the one hand, the Pentagon's decision to buy a new carrier preserves 5,000 to 7,500 jobs and the company's most important future project.
On the other, the Defense Department's decision to insure Electric Boat's survival as the country's sole builder of nuclear submarines appears to foreclose any chance that Newport News could bid on the contract for the third Seawolf.
When reports surfaced in June that the Pentagon would select Electric Boat to build the third Seawolf, Tenneco, in a rare show of pique toward its largest customer, criticized the Pentagon's handling of the matter as short-sighted.

HEADLINE: Study Sees Illegal Aliens In New Light

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

 BODY:
Contrary to the images of Chinese boat people and Central American day laborers that dominate the public perception of New York State's illegal immigrants, the three major groups are from Ecuador, Italy and Poland.
The first complete analysis of undocumented immigrants, released yesterday by the City Planning Department, estimates that the illegal population in New York State is the second largest in the country, after California's. 
The analysis, based on a complex formula that used data from border crossings, airports and the census, found that among the 18 million residents of New York are some 490,000 illegal immigrants, with more than 80 percent living in New York City.
The report's profile of the illegal immigrants in New York differs strikingly from the national picture. Whereas Mexicans -- the largest group nationally -- and other Central Americans dominate illegal populations in much of the country, they barely show up in the state statistics. Illegal immigrants in New York are much more diverse, coming predominantly from Europe, the Caribbean and Latin America.
The illegal Ecuadorean, Italian and Polish populations are followed closely, and less surprisingly, by Dominicans, Colombians, Haitians and Jamaicans, the analysis found. But illegal Chinese immigrants do not even make the top 10, and illegal Mexicans are not even in the top 20. In fact, contrary even to the expectations of immigration experts, the typical illegal immigrant in New York is twice as likely to be an Italian who overstayed a travel visa as a Chinese migrant smuggled in by gangsters, the analysis concluded. The state is even home to slightly more illegal Israelis, 13,492, than to illegal Chinese -- 12,655, according to the report.
"The data show that much of the current debate over immigration is based on myths and stereotypes rather than facts and figures," an immigration expert at the American Civil Liberties Union, Lucas Guttentag, said. "I have to say -- Italy! -- now that's news to me."
The Immigration and Naturalization Service has struggled for years to amass reliable estimates about illegal immigrants. This year the agency's statisticians drew on more than 100 million records from 11 years. To estimate how many immigrants slipped undetected across the border, they used the Census and legalization and arrest statistics. To count those who overstayed travel visas, they analyzed departure records from airports and ports.
The agency estimated that there were 3.2 million illegal residents in the United States last fall and estimated that an additional 300,000 arrived in the last year, with as many as 45,000 settling in New York.
 
Criticisms of Newcomers
 At a time when illegal immigrants are under attack for draining the resources of an economically troubled country, advocates for immigrants welcomed the new statistics as fair, moderate appraisals of the illegal population. The figures were released not by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which distributed them just internally, but by a New York City agency.
"This whole anti-immigrant hysteria is not borne out by the statistics," said Patrick Young, director of the Central American Refugee Center in Hempstead, L.I. "Only about 1.25 percent of the U.S. population is undocumented, and if all the problems of your country are attributable to this minuscule population, then your system's really in trouble."
A majority of illegal immigrants live in California, followed by New York, Florida, Texas and Illinois, immigration officials said.
But the proportion of illegal immigrants in California has decreased in the last six years, from 50 to 40 percent of the national total. Similarly, the proportion in New York City has increased, to 15 percent from 10 percent. That is a result of the legalization of illegal immigrants, mostly Mexicans, and mostly California residents, under the Immigration and Reform Control Act of 1986.
Many experts expect illegal immigrants to follow their legal countrymen in mirrored proportions. So, since very few Italians number among the legal immigrants to New York City, the size of the illegal Italian population -- at an estimated 27,425, the second largest -- caught most experts by surprise. But not totally.
"It's hardly a shock that New York draws Italians, given the fact that Italians are the largest ethnic group in the state," a city demographer, Joseph J. Salvo, said. "And in retrospect it's not that surprising that they are coming illegally, since the legal pathways for them have pretty much dried up."
Most legal immigrants are sponsored by their immediate family members. But most Italians immigrated a few generations ago, and their family ties are too distant for sponsorship.
In contrast, Dominicans, by far the largest legal immigrant population in the city, more easily sponsor their families to join them. The illegal Dominicans, however, may be undercounted in the statistics, as some enter the country through Puerto Rico, posing as Puerto Ricans, Mr. Salvo said.
 
Poles Apparently Melted In
 Presumably, the illegal Ecuadoreans have joined their legal compatriots in Queens, where, as the seventh largest legal immigrant group in the 1980's, they settled mostly in Jackson Heights and Corona.
The illegal Poles seem to have melted into the established Polish communities in Brooklyn, especially Greenpoint, Williamsburg and Borough Park. Polish immigrants were the seventh largest legal immigrant group to the city last year.
The number of illegal Chinese immigrants represents a small fraction of the illegal population in New York City. But, strikingly, New York is home to more than half the illegal Chinese in the country, Mr. Salvo said. In contrast, New York draws just one-fifth of the legal Chinese immigrants. Similarly, New York receives a greater proportion of Korean, Indian, Polish and Israeli illegal immigrants than legal immigrants.
Although their numbers are high, New York receives a smaller proportion of illegal than legal Dominican, Haitian, Honduran and El Salvadoran immigrants.
The statistics director of the I.N.S., Robert Warren, said it was possible that illegal Mexicans in New York City were underrepresented in the numbers. The statistical distribution of immigrants nationwide was based on their patterns of settlement in 1986, as shown in their applications for legalization. Immigration officials did not account for possible changes in migration patterns.

HEADLINE: A Paper Boom in Real Estate Investments

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
A California home builder recently raised a pile of money by selling notes that promised a startlingly high 10.375 percent interest rate with a rating below investment grade. Using the draw of high yield, the home builder collected $155 million, attracting investors to the troubled world of real estate even though the company was already behind or in default on about $143 million in loans -- a fact that was presumably reflected in the low credit rating.
A yield of around 20 percent was reportedly the draw in another real estate deal, this one from Daiwa Securities America, the American arm of the big Japanese brokerage firm. It turned a package of nursing-home mortgages into five classes of securities: three with investment-grade ratings and two with considerably more credit risk. One -- sold privately, and therefore not publicly described -- reportedly yielded around 20 percent. 
 The two deals illustrate a growing trend: high yields are drawing big money into the depressed real estate market -- and especially into securities that promise high returns but carry investment-service ratings that are junk, or below investment grade, or carry no ratings at all.
And the money is coming not just from traditional real estate investors.
"What you have is a marketplace that is obviously chasing yield, and real estate can produce the yield," said Stan Ross, managing partner of Kenneth Leventhal & Company, an accounting firm that specializes in real estate. "It's a signal that there is some capital returning to real estate."
Despite their mouth-watering yields, commercial mortgage securities are not for everyone. "These can be fabulous for smart investors, but they could be dangerous for people who don't understand the complexities," said Andrew D. Stone, a senior managing director at Daiwa Securities America, one of the most innovative firms in the business.
Commercial mortgage securities make up one of the fastest-growing markets on Wall Street. With the growing acceptance of the notion that commercial real estate values have hit bottom, about $12.2 billion in commercial mortgage securities were issued in 1992, up from $4.3 billion in 1991 and $920 million in 1990, according to Prudential Securities Inc. This year's number will probably be higher, as private securities issuers rush into the market to take up the slack left by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency that disposes of the assets of failed savings and loans. The R.T.C. was the largest issuer in the market last year, but it has packaged far fewer loans this year.
Residential mortgages have long been made into packages of securities, but commercial mortgage packaging is fairly new. The crash in commercial real estate values chased many investors out of the market.
But in the last year or so, as banks, savings and loans, insurance companies and other traditional lenders continued to reel from their bad real-estate loans, bottom-fishing among buyers of buildings heated up. That has been accompanied by a surge of interest from investors who do not want buildings, but securities. And many of the securities are made up of loans bought from -- not surprisingly -- the banks, savings and loans and insurance companies.
 
Deals Are Many and Varied
 The new securities deals are many and varied. Here are a few examples:
*The R.T.C. has issued $14 billion in mortgage-backed bonds. Some pools of mortgages, especially those composed of delinquent or otherwise troubled mortgages, are typically backed by a reserve fund of assets to be used as security in case any of the loans fail to pay off. These offerings have made the agency the largest issuer of commercial mortgage-backed securities, with 75 percent of the total issued last year.
*In another sign that private companies are following the R.T.C.'s lead, the Pacific Investment Management Company has set up the first investment-grade securities fund backed by commercial mortgages. Pacific Investment, known as Pimco, is a top money manager, with about $50 billion under management. Last Friday, Pimco raised $165 million for the fund by selling 11 million shares at $15 apiece with a 7 1/2 percent coupon. Pimco is planning to buy at least 65 percent in investment-grade securities backed by commercial mortgages, with up to 35 percent going into below-investment-grade issues.
*In addition to the California home builder, the Baldwin Company, other developers have raised money in the same way this year. The Toll Corporation of Pennsylvania issued $75 million in notes priced to yield 9.625 percent in March. The notes were rated Ba3, below investment grade, by Moody's Investors Service. In April, UDC Homes, an Arizona builder, issued $115 million of 11 3/4 percent senior notes that Moody's rated B2, also below investment grade.
*In one of the more esoteric deals, Daiwa cut up $193 million in mobile-home park mortgages into seven slices of securities ranging from a top slice, with a rating of AA by Standard & Poor's -- its second-highest rating -- and a floating rate, down to two unrated offerings that were sold privately with undisclosed returns.
Sellers of such securities structure the deals to attract as many different investors as possible, often pooling debt and cutting it into slices, called tranches, with the lowest yields in the investment-grade top slices and progressively higher yields as the ratings drop to below-investment-grade. The purchaser of the top slice is first in line to get money from the mortgage payments.
Mr. Stone described a hypothetical typical deal: Daiwa purchases 50 commercial mortgages, combines them into a diversified pool, and issues bonds. The first slice, say 60 percent, is rated AA and yields around 6.25 percent, like other AA bonds. Another 20 percent may be rated BBB, the lowest investment-grade level, with a yield around 7.5 percent. The bottom slice, with no rating at all, may give a yield around 17 percent -- which is "enough money so I can keep a nice profit margin and pay out a healthy yield," he said.
"What I'm saying to you is, 'Don't buy real estate today,' " Mr. Stone said. "I'll sell you a bond that's performing, diversified and that the ratings agencies have just looked at. If there's any trouble, I'll give you the real estate. There is no equity -- you take over the property."
 
 
A Chance to Take Property
 Indeed, the chance to get at equity is what sometimes attracts many real estate players to the mortgage securities market. People in the business say that many investors who are taking the lowest-rated slices of debt offerings in these packages are real estate professionals themselves. They might be just as happy to be able to take the property.
William C. Powers, managing director at Pimco, said his firm found the market for mortgage-backed securities attractive partly because ratings agencies were basing their assessments on the expectation that real estate values would continue to decline at the rate of the last few years. But, he said, to make money, "one does not have to assume that commercial real estate values are going higher, or even that they will remain flat."
"One has to assume," he said, "that the decline that we have seen over the past few years will continue, but at a lesser rate."

HEADLINE: HURRICANE EMILY;
Near Miss Revives Debate Over Building on Islands

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OCRACOKE, N.C., Sept. 1

 BODY:
The residents of this thin sliver of sand southwest of Cape Hatteras awoke today to find their world miraculously intact, their damages limited to a few days of lost tourism business.
But if North Carolina's Outer Banks largely dodged a bullet on Tuesday, when Hurricane Emily grazed it and headed out to sea, few areas in America exemplify the knotty issues surrounding coastal development more than this string of islands jutting into the Atlantic. 
 Over the last two decades the Outer Banks have been transformed from a modest stretch of motels and beach cottages, where wild pigs and horses roamed free, to one of the fastest growing resort areas in the nation. The issues raised by the population boom on these shifting coastal sands will linger far after the memories of the storm's near miss have faded.
Indications today were that both the natural environment and the man-made one had avoided catastrophic damage, with the exception of the town of Buxton north of Cape Hatteras, which was hit hard by wind, rain and surging 10-foot seas.
 
Fears of Erosion
 Buxton, at the extreme southeastern tip of the Outer Banks, was hit much harder than Ocracoke and suffered the greatest damage.
But, for the most part, beach damage all along the Outer Banks was less severe than many had feared.
There had been fears that the hurricane would accelerate the erosion of the beaches along the Outer Banks, where the islands for the most part are less than a half mile wide. Experts say it clearly did some major damage to the beaches around Cape Hatteras and Buxton. North of Buxton, in Kitty Hawk, where many houses were built on the beach, several houses collapsed into the sea as the sand eroded beneath them.
"We dodged a very large bullet here as far as erosion goes," said Doug Remaley, chief of the Nags Head Fire and Rescue Department north of here. "There was a substantial amount of erosion, but my personal opinion is that this was no worse than a severe northeast storm, which we get in the winter months."
 
Growing Body of Knowledge
 In recent years, researchers have increasingly documented the degree to which the 295 barrier islands that stretch in a broken line from New England to Texas have been eroded in recent years. The Outer Banks are among the most vulnerable.
One of the most visible national symbols of the coastal debate is the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse. When it was built in 1870, 1,500 feet of dunes and beach guarded it from the waves. Now that sandy buffer has been reduced to less than 300 feet, and no one knows what would have happened if the hurricane had come ashore there.
Dare County, which includes Nags Head and Kitty Hawk, grew in population by 70 percent, to 22,746 in 1990 from 13,377 in 1980. Property values there have increased by 1,231 percent since 1976.
"It's not like you get one Hurricane Andrew and wipe your brow and say, 'I'm glad we got that over with,' " said Beth Millemann, director of the Coast Alliance, a national coalition of environmental groups. "We have hurricanes after hurricanes after hurricanes, and the problem with living on the beach is it involves not only the people who have the beach house; it involves every taxpayer in America."
 
Development Has Support
 Ms. Milleman was referring to a variety of programs, including National Flood Insurance, beach projects by the Army Corps of Engineers and bridges and highways, all of which employ tax money to support coastal development.
Proponents of coastal development say her argument misses both the degree to which coastal development is an economic plus and the simple fact that people have always gravitated toward shores and always will. Many add that if people were moved away from all the nation's hazards, there might not be enough places to live.
"If my house blew down tomorrow, I'd starting rebuilding the next day," said Guy Newell, who lives here. "I'd rather be here than in the Midwest floods, or in Tornado Alley or in some places that's likely to have an earthquake."
But most agree that the major questions are not whether the coasts will be developed, but how they will be delveloped and who will bear the risks. Hurricane Andrew last year and the Midwest floods this year have renewed questions about the Federal flood insurance program, which critics say subsidizes development in hazardous areas. Similarly, critics have for years called for the mapping of erosion-prone coastal zones to help regulate development, but developers have so far fought off any such plan.
Some experts say that the building codes and construction standards on the Outer Banks are quite good, and that the development there is a reminder that man and nature can coexist even on barrier islands.
"The barrier islands have had thousands of hurricanes, and they survive," said Spencer Rogers, a coastal engineer at North Carolina State University. "The problem has been the fragile nature of what we build on them, not that the islands are fragile. And that depends on how we build."
But others look at the glossy Outer Banks Magazine, with its advertisements for high-cost malls and wonder what they are doing on a barrier island.
"I'm shocked by what I see there," said Stephen P. Leatherman, director of the Laboratory for Coastal Research at the University of Maryland at College Park. "I grew up in North Carolina when the Outer Banks was just simple classic cottages. It's as if there are no development controls at all."

Dick Thompson, a real estate agent in Kitty Hawk, looked at the spot where a cottage stood before Hurricane Emily grazed the coast. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUDGET IS RECAST AS A BETTER PLAN

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
With its Republican critics on Congressional recess and not much else competing for headlines, the White House issued an economic report today that depicts its deficit-cutting labors as more muscular, and even more successful, than advertised to Congress just weeks ago.
Private economists and budget experts said the rosier description seemed reasonably credible, but cautioned that it relied on assumptions of continued low inflation and almost subterranean interest rates that have not been seen in recent decades. 
 The Administration report, the mid-session budget review, estimated that the Federal debt, more than $4 trillion, would grow by almost $100 billion less through 1998 than was forecast in August, after Congress approved a five-year deficit-cutting package.
Back then, the White House predicted that the overall Federal debt would rise by $1.1 trillion during the five years covered by the fiscal 1994 through 1998 budgets. Today, Mr. Clinton's budget director, Leon E. Panetta, pegged the total increase at $1.004 trillion.
 
Thinking Behind Changes
 Both projections include the effect of the $500 billion or so in new taxes and spending cuts that Congress approved in the deficit-cutting package. That figure is more or less unchanged under the new fiscal projections.
What is changed, and what will make the debt grow more slowly, is largely a melding of three factors. The first is the unexpectedly small growth in spending on Medicaid, which budget analysts now say will cost $36 billion less, through 1998, than they predicted a few months ago.
The second is a new forecast by White House economists that interest rates -- and therefore, the costs of financing that $4 trillion Federal debt -- will remain near historic lows for years to come. The Administration now figures it will pay $39 billion less interest on the debt in the next five years if rates on the main financing vehicle -- the 10-year Treasury bond -- hold steady at about 5.9 percent. The bond yields about 5.5 percent now.
The third, more subtle change is in the way the White House made all the economic projections in today's report. Until now, Mr. Panetta's analysts have used figures from Congress's forecasting agency, the Congressional Budget Office, as the base for all White House economic projections. Mr. Clinton pledged early this year to use the nonpartisan Congressional figures during the debate over his budget, saying that would remove any suspicion by critics that the White House was cooking its economic figures for political gain.
Today's report is the first important Administration document to rely not on Congress's numbers but on the estimates of Mr. Clinton's budget office and the White House Council of Economic Advisers.
 
Explaining the Switch
 The Congressional Budget Office will issue its own revised budget projections next week. They are expected to be slightly more conservative than the numbers released today.
An aide to Mr. Panetta, Barry Toiv, described the switch from Congressional to White House estimates as both natural and expected, now that the budget debate was over. In a briefing today, Mr. Panetta hastened to quash any suspicion that today's optimism was the result of rigged books or political scheming.
"There have been estimates about where deficits are headed over the last few years that have always been proven wrong," he said. "The reason we are confident that we can make these numbers is essentially because of the economic plan and the credibility of the economic plan. The numbers are real."
Mr. Panetta called today's report a "credible, conservative forecast." Mr. Clinton's chief economic adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, called it "cautious." Indeed, it contemplates a rate of economic growth -- 2 percent this year, down from an earlier 3.1 percent, and no more than 3 percent in future years -- that rivals the sluggard economy of the Bush years.
Still, those and other officials put a positive gloss on some numbers that could be read several ways.
 
Role of 'Income-Shifting'
 Ms. Tyson at first said that the Administration's projection of anemic growth for this year was merely "an adjustment for the loss of the stimulus." That was a reference to Congress's defeat last spring of Mr. Clinton's plan to spend $19 billion on highways, Federal agency equipment purchases and other jobs programs.
Challenged by skeptics who noted that such a minuscule sum could not possibly wipe out a third of the growth in a multitrillion-dollar economy, Ms. Tyson later allowed that other factors played larger roles. Among them, she said, was "income-shifting" -- "a very large and unexpected increase in wages and salaries, primarily due to bonus payments," in the last months of 1992, offset by a similar decline in wages in early 1993.
An economist with the forecasting firm DRI, David Wyss, called today's report realistic, with some caveats. "They're not being nearly as rosy as in the Reagan era, when they were forecasting four percent growth and low inflation far as eye can see," he said.

HEADLINE: LABOR CHIEF URGES A RETRAINING PLAN

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
When the Portage, Pa., factory she had worked at for 20 years shut its doors last February, Mary Ann Bertolino, a sewing machine operator, found no government assistance to enable her to train for a new occupation. The reason was that she used to sew men's topcoats, not men's shirts or women's nightgowns.
Under the current patchwork of government programs to help workers permanently put out of jobs, the reason a worker has lost a job -- imports, military cuts, the spotted owl -- has to be the right one. The wrong one can mean that older workers whose job skills are no longer in demand are not eligible for much more than 26 weeks of unemployment checks and a bit of counseling. 
 American-made shirts and nightgowns have been hit hard by imports, so workers who used to sew them qualify for generous, longterm trade-adjustment assistance. But topcoat orders dried up when the economy turned sour, so Mrs. Bertolino is not eligible for the extra help.
 
Offsetting the Hurt
 To change that, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said today that he proposed to overhaul the current system by folding disparate programs into one giant "re-employment program." His proposal to grant assistance to dislocated workers no matter why their jobs vanished is supposed to ease the pain of economic change, especially for older, less-skilled and less-educated workers.
"The challenge," Mr. Reich said, "is to ease the transition of Americans from the old economy to a new one."
An Administration economist familiar with the proposal said: "Economic change benefits everybody a little, but a few people get hurt a lot. We want to do something to offset that."
Striking back at the Administration's critics, Mr. Reich made it clear that the proposal was also intended to blunt criticism from labor unions, many Democrats and the Perot camp that the North American Free Trade Agreement would cost jobs.
"The adjustment assistance program is an important political element in getting Nafta approved, " said a Senate staff aide.
 
Framework for Legislation
 The Secretary's "Draft Proposal for a Comprehensive Worker Adjustment Program," a Labor Department spokesman said, has been circulated inside the Administration and to various constituents for comment. The proposal, which was published last month in the trade journal Daily Labor Report, is being modified, but it will be a framework for legislation that could be introduced as early as November.
If the proposal is adopted by Congress, the new program would be financed with $1.1 billion already earmarked in the 1994 budget for existing efforts as the Economic Dislocation and Worker Adjustment Assistance program. The costs, the proposal indicated, would roughly triple by 1998. The $180 million Trade Adjustment Assistance Program, which reaches about 23,000 workers a year, is apt to continue at least temporarily as an independent program.
Existing programs either provide a restricted number of services or limit the eligibility to workers who lost their jobs because of imports, military cuts or the Clean Air Act. By contrast, the new adjustment assistance program would fold most of the existing programs into one.
More importantly, it would be available to any workers with two or, more likely, three years on the job. According to the proposal, about 2.2 million such workers are potentially eligible for job placement services and cash grants while they attend school.
"The big thing the proposal does is that you don't have to prove that you lost your job because of imports or trees or clean air," said an Administration official. Mrs. Bertolino and her former co-workers in Pennsylvania, for example, have been turned down twice for assistance under the trade adjustment program.
 
Streamlining Called a Help
 People whose job involves helping dislocated workers get their lives back on track say that the proposed changes would help them reach more workers faster. "Some streamlining would be very beneficial," said David Seidel, a state official in Altoona, Pa., who has been working with garment workers who lost their jobs when factories closed or moved. "All the programs have different eligibility criteria," he said. "We're dealing with having to apply for separate grants for one group of dislocated workers."
What's more, the new program would especially avoid steering workers into the kind of short-term government-sponsored training programs that the Labor Department's proposals calls "ineffective for permanently laid- off workers." Instead, it would provide instant help for finding a new job, from resume-writing workshops to psychological counseling to help workers cope with the shock of losing their livelihoods.
And, for those who decided after a job search that they needed new careers, the program would provide cash -- equal to unemployment insurance payments -- to workers enrolled in community colleges and technical institutes. The proposal envisions a small fraction of dislocated workers -- about 300,000 a year -- needing support after unemployment insurance runs out at the cost of about $3,000 to $3,500 a worker.
"You can't just exhaust unemployment benefits and go into training," an Administration economist said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Sluggish Ahead of Jobs Report

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The lull has begun. It is the week before Labor Day, and the Labor Department will release the July employment report tomorrow. So traders and investors are either away or sitting on their hands, and little is happening in the bond market.
In moderate trading yesterday, prices and yields barely budged. By late in trading, the price of the 30-year bond managed to gain 3/32 , which was enough to push the yield down to 6.08 percent, setting another in a growing string of 20-year lows. Price and yield move in opposite directions. 
 The prices of Treasury notes were also little changed. The price of the two-year note was unchanged, with the yield at 3.86 percent. The price of the three-year note was up 1/32 as the the yield slipped to 4.16 percent from 4.17 percent. And the price of the 10-year note was down 1/32 , with the yield up to 5.45 percent from 5.44 percent.
 
 
Data Have Little Impact
 There were a number of economic reports released yesterday, and most of them indicated that the economy was still sluggish. But the data made little impact ahead of the employment report, which is the first significant look into how the economy fared in August.
Among the reports yesterday, one showed a drop in personal income of two-tenths of a percent in July. Wall Street forecasts had expected a rise of three-tenths of a percent. And the National Association of Purchasing Management said its August index fell to 49.3 from 49.5 in July, showing a slight contraction in the manufacturing sector of the economy. A reading above 50 indicates the manufacturing economy is generally expanding, while one below 50 suggests it is generally declining.
"Whatever bets they wanted to make, they have made them," said Peter McTeague, an analyst at Technical Data in Boston, referring to bond traders.
Traders, he said, "will not do anything dramatic" today before the release of the employment data. The consensus forecast on Wall Street, he said, was that nonfarm payrolls would rise by about 150,000 jobs in August.
 
 
Risk of Weaker Employment
 But Mr. McTeague added that there was a risk that the number would be lower than expected, based on recent data like yesterday's purchasing managers' report. The manufacturing employment index in the report dropped to 40.4 in August from 43.2 in July, the lowest level since May 1991. The news gave the credit market its only lift.
If the employment report is weak, it will probably have two effects. First, it may give the price of the 30-year bond the support it needs to push the yield to 6 percent and below. As of yesterday's close at 6.08 percent, the price has to increase just 1 1/8 point -- or $11.25 per $1,000 in face value -- to get the yield to 6 percent. A price increase of 1 1/4 point will get it to 5.99 percent. That could happen in a single day of frantic trading, or it could happen, as it has, slowly and relentlessly, day by day.
Another effect of weak employment data may be the revival of talk that the Federal Reserve will have to lower short-term interest rates again to keep the economy from faltering. The Fed has left its short-term interest rate target at 3 percent for a year.
If traders and investors begin to believe that a rate cut is likely, short- and intermediate-term interest rates could move lower. But the outlook now seems to be that the economy will not be weak enough for the Fed to cut interest rates again.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Off Against Mark But Strengthens Versus Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell to a 10-week low against the German mark yesterday, after investors sold dollars for marks on reports of strong German industrial growth.
But the dollar firmed against the Japanese yen because of repeated intervention by Japan's central bank and speculation about a potential fall in Japanese interest rates. 
 In New York, the dollar fell to 1.6595 marks, from 1.6767 marks on Tuesday. The dollar rose to 105.35 yen from 104.75 yen.
 
Speeds Recovery Timetable
 The mark also rose sharply against the yen and other European currencies on news that industrial production in western Germany rose five-tenths of a percent in July after a revised drop of three-tenths of a percent in June.
"People have taken this as supporting the idea of an early recovery in Germany," said Chris Turner, an analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd in London. An economic rebound would reduce pressure on the Bundesbank to cut interest rates. Lower interest rates make a nation's currency less attractive to investors.
By contrast, fresh American economic data proved disappointing. The National Association of Purchasing Management's index fell to a reading of 49.3 in August from 49.5 in July. Government data on personal income showed Americans took home two-tenths of a percent less pay in July than in June. With consumption up four-tenths of a percent in July, the savings rate dropped to an abysmal 3.3 percent. And construction spending fell five-tenths of a percent in July.
"The numbers in sum don't make us feel really comfortable about the dollar and any type of hike in U.S. interest rates," said Jim Phoenix, foreign exchange dealer at Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.
Dealers also said the decision by the White House to lower its growth forecast for 1993 to 2 percent from 2.8 percent suggested growth would not be robust.
Meanwhile, speculation that Japan will soon cut its 2.5 percent official discount rate, perhaps by as much as three-quarters of a point, weighed on the yen. Many dealers expect the Bank of Japan to offer easier credit to help spur the economy.
Meanwhile, the British pound rose to $1.5030 in New York, from $1.4905 on Tuesday.
