HEADLINE: U.S. Consumer in July Spent More With Less Pay (Again)

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
American consumers increased their spending for the fourth straight month in July, the Commerce Department reported today, a sign that the economy continued to grind ahead slowly.
The latest rise, four-tenths of 1 percent, came despite an overall decline in income that reflected the costs of the Midwest flooding. 
 "The new quarter got off to a pretty decent start in terms of consumer spending," said Russell W. Sheldon, senior economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. Since then, however, other data on retail sales and automobile sales have tailed off.
Other reports today also depicted a sluggish economy, with mortgage delinquencies in the spring rising for a second quarter, construction edging down in July and purchasing managers' reporting a small but unexpected decline in August industrial activity that included job losses. [Page D3.]
The Commerce Department put consumer spending for July at an annual rate of $4.40 trillion compared with $4.38 trillion in June, a gain slightly larger than May's but less than those of April or June.
Amid this low state of confidence in the economy, various indicators pointed to a reluctance by consumers to make commitments for housing and other big-ticket items even while they continued to spend money on less costly goods.
On Tuesday, the department lowered its figures on personal spending for the second quarter, to an increase of 3.2 percent from 3.8 percent. A drop in durable-goods purchases accounted for most of the change.
Spending on durable goods, products intended to last at least three years, was virtually unchanged in July, while spending for nondurable goods posted the biggest gain since April. A fourth consecutive advance was recorded for services -- much of it for utilities, especially for air-conditioning in hot weather.
July's reported two-tenths of 1 percent decline in income was called satisfactory by economists, after they made allowances for the floods and for drought in the Southeast.
Except for these factors, which the department took account of by estimating crop and property losses and allocating seven months' worth of them to July, personal income would have increased five-tenths of 1 percent for the month.
Wages and salaries rose six-tenths of 1 percent in July, the third gain in four months, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said.
These results seemed less dire than was suggested by the fact that declines for June, upon revision, and for July represented the first back-to-back reductions in income since 1954. The disposable-income figures were not adjusted for inflation. When adjusted, they were down four-tenths of 1 percent, also the second consecutive decline.
 
Saving Down, Late Payment Up
 The nation's savings rate slumped to 3.3 percent from 4 percent, the lowest in almost four years. Savings -- disposable personal income, minus outlays -- ran at a $152.3 billion pace in July, well under the $186.3 billion in June, the department said.
The Mortgage Bankers Association of America reported that 4.39 percent of conventional and Government-backed residential mortgages were at least a month past due in the spring quarter, up from 4.29 percent in the January-March period.
The rise came entirely in F.H.A. and V.A. loans, suggesting to officials that lower-income households, which rely more on these Government-backed loans, are less able to take advantage of current low interest rates to refinance mortgages.
In still another report, the Commerce Department said that housing, highway and other construction begun in July totaled $458.2 billion on an annual basis, slightly under the revised June estimate of $460.5 billion. The decrease was concentrated in stores, hotels and home renovation. This was mostly offset by a rise in home building. Construction over the first seven months of 1993 was 5 percent above that in the comparable period of 1992.
Over all, Michael P. Niemira of Mitsubishi Bank said, the statistics did little to alter expectations of continued but choppy growth. He said that over the last month he had become increasingly pessimistic because while consumers continued to spend for some goods, plans for scaled-down auto production were likely to weigh heavily on the broad economy.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing, and Factory Jobs, Fell in August, Survey Says

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Manufacturing in August slumped for the third straight month, with factory employment falling sharply, a monthly survey of corporate purchasing executives indicated yesterday.
"The manufacturing sector is still essentially dead in the water," said Richard Berner, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. 
 The survey index, from the National Association of Purchasing Management, dipped to 49.3 in August, from 49.5 in July. A figure below 50 indicates that manufacturing is declining.
However, a reading above 44.5 usually means that the overall economy is growing. With the index averaging 51.9 this year, the economy is thought to be continuing a slow climb from recession.
Economists and the Federal Reserve Board track the purchasing managers' survey because it is one of the first indicators of economic activity for any month. The survey is considered a good gauge of future business activity because purchasing managers are responsible for buying raw material.
 
Employment Takes the Hit
 The overall August index was pulled down by the drop in jobs. But figures for production, new orders and delivery time were marginally higher, leading some economists to predict an upturn this month.
The rate of job cutting in August was the highest in more than two years in the survey, which draws on purchasing managers at more than 300 companies. Ten percent of them reported hiring in August, while 27 percent reduced employment. The job situation at the rest of the companies was unchanged.
Economists said manufacturing-job losses were worst in the aerospace and defense industries, which have been hurt by airline and Government military cutbacks.
The index of industrial production was up in August, to 51.6 from 51.3 in July. The index of new orders, considered a harbinger of future manufacturing activity, rose to 54.0 from 53.1.
The delivery of supplies was taking longer, indicating that demand was strengthening and companies were having trouble filling orders immediately. And more purchasing executives reported increased backlogs in orders than those who reported declines, a reversal of the situation in July.
Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's business survey committee and director of corporate purchasing at Pitney Bowes, commented: "If you set that against a backdrop of lower manufacturing inventories, it really converts into the fact that any new orders coming through manufacturers are going to require new buying or purchasing throughout the entire supply chain. That would suggest to me that the month of September could be an improvement."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold and Silver Prices Fall As a Rally Ends Suddenly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold and silver prices fell sharply yesterday as a two-day rally in the futures market ended abruptly.
"It was a paper rally and paper rallies eventually run their course," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist for Merrill Lynch Futures in New York.
On other commodity markets, oil prices fell in reaction to a report of surprisingly large supplies. 
 Gold for October delivery lost $3.10, to $370.80 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. December gold, the most active contract, dropped $3.10, to $372.60. September silver dropped 9.9 cents, to $4.739 an ounce.
 
Selloff Wipes Out Gains
 The selling wiped out nearly all the gains posted in the two previous sessions.
Precious metals began climbing on Monday when some Middle Eastern silver purchases touched off a storm of investment fund buying on the Comex. The futures market drew an unusual amount of action because both the London and Hong Kong metals exchanges were closed Monday for a holiday.
On Tuesday, the buying interest shifted from silver futures to gold futures, then waned.
"There was no follow-through overnight, so we just drifted off today," said George Milling-Stanley, precious metals analyst with Lehman Brothers Inc.
Mr. O'Neill said there was no fundamental justification for the rally. "If you look at the economic data, we're still in the same type of sluggish growth, no-inflation-threat atmosphere," he said. "Certainly the economic side of the market doesn't provide an incentive to buy gold."
Elsewhere, crude oil fell below $18 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a trade group reported higher American inventories of crude than traders expected.
The American Petroleum Institute said in a weekly report released late Monday that crude supplies rose by 3.3 million barrels last week. Most analysts had expected supplies to decline by up to 4 million barrels.
Light sweet crude oil for October delivery fell 32 cents, to $17.97 a barrel. Also, October heating oil lost 0.52 cent, to 53.12 cents a gallon; October unleaded gasoline sank 0.76 cent, to 51.68 cents a gallon, and October natural gas fell 0.9 cent, to $2.366 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
After the floods, seeking a more comprehensive rebuilding policy.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WITH the Mississippi in retreat, all that's left to do is honor the indomitable spirit of the river valley dwellers and help them rebuild. Or is it?
Surely this charitable impulse sums up the view of the great majority of Americans. And it translates into a political imperative for Washington, which is dutifully scrambling to restore the river's protective levee system and parcel out some $5.7 billion in aid. 
 But it frustrates many economists who have long been struggling to transform after-the-fact disaster relief into a comprehensive policy for minimizing damage and insuring against risks -- a policy that asks those who gamble with nature to bear the consequences. "When scenes of families stranded on rooftops appear on the nightly news for five days running, nothing can stop Congress from picking up the tab," says Robert Stavins of Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.
It is Federal policy to help potential disaster victims help themselves. Since 1980, farmers have been able to insure most crops against natural calamities. And the National Flood Insurance Program, pieced together from a variety of initiatives since 1968, insures houses and other property in flood-prone areas.
What's more, disaster insurance is intended to be operated on a business-like basis. Crop insurance premiums are linked to actuarial risks. The flood insurance program does give a break to existing property, but charges actuarially sound rates for new development.
That, however, is hardly the whole story. Bob Hunter, director of the flood insurance program in the Carter Administration, charges that "government agencies and banks have failed to live up to the spirit of the law." Indeed, requirements that property owners with federally insured mortgages maintain flood insurance have not been enforced. A General Accounting Office survey after a 1989 flood in Texas found that 79 percent of homeowners with federally backed loans had not kept up their premiums.
As disturbing, fewer than one-fifth of those at risk actually buy flood or crop insurance. And economists suspect the reason is that people figure (correctly) that Uncle Sam will cover them after the fact. "The idea Washington will hang uninsured flood victims out to dry is just not credible," argues Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute.
But Howard Kunreuther, the co-director of the Risk Management Center at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, believes the choice to forgo insurance is more about lack of sense than dollars. The center's surveys of earthquake and flood victims suggest that people often discount small probabilities of natural disaster to zero -- the "it will not happen to me" syndrome.
Where incentives are more likely to count heavily, however, is where local governments or levee districts make decisions about big investments. And here, there is evidence that Federal largess encourages rebuilding in harm's way.
Uncle Sam will underwrite four-fifths of the cost of bringing both Federal levees and eligible, locally built levees back to pre-flood capacity. Even the local share may be finessed, providing the local sponsor is nimble enough to funnel other Federal disaster money into the repair effort.
The Clinton Administration has organized an interagency task force to screen the renovations and look for cheaper solutions. There are programs on the books, for example, to allot funds for purchasing "flood easements" through low-value farmland. Farms at risk can also be purchased for restoration as wetlands, which serve both as a habitat for wildlife and as a filter for groundwater.
But these alternatives are voluntary. "If an eligible levee sponsor says I want my levee rebuilt, that's what we do," confirms Scott Saunders, a spokesman for the Army Corps of Engineers.
Oleta Fitzgerald, the Agriculture Department coordinator for flood relief, is still optimistic that communities will look carefully at cheaper alternatives to concrete and earthworks. She notes that while the Army Corps has the money to repair Federal levees, the funds available will not cover every repair to which local levee sponsors may be technically entitled. By the same token, disaster relief will not come close to covering total property and crop damage, conservatively estimated at $12 billion. And that, she suggests, raises the pressure to get the most bang for a Federal buck.
Leonard Shabman, an economist at the Virginia Polytechnic Institute, is inclined to look on the bright side. Washington's huge investment in flood control did pay off handsomely, he notes. Only 30 of some 200 Federal levees were breached, sparing the big cities along the Mississippi and Missouri from serious damage. Where levees were washed away, the losses were less than astronomical because relatively little property was inundated.
But critics remain skeptical. "American values and institutions," said William Riebsame, a natural disaster expert at the University of Colorado, "just don't make it easy to tell people what to do with their property."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Fade to Black: Pinstripes in Peril on WPIX

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
Free telecasts of Yankee games, a tradition for 43 years, seem headed toward extinction because WPIX and the MSG Network are at an impasse.
"This is what the consumer feared all along, the loss of all free games to cable," said Michael Eigner, the president of WPIX/Channel 11. "I've been hopeful of making a deal, but they've made an offer and said, 'Take it or leave it.' " 
 Control of all Yankees telecasts has resided with MSG since 1991 as part of its $486 million cable contract with the team. Over the last three years, MSG has aired 75 games, paid about $5 million a season for the time on WPIX to telecast 50 games and then sold the advertising for both outlets. MSG said it was now time for WPIX to pay for the right to show Yankee games and has proposed a figure of $15 million annually.
 
Mets Have Even Split
 When MSG and WPIX struck their deal before the 1991 season, the reason was the importance of keeping a significant portion of games on over-the-air, or free television. MSG had 4.9 million subscribers, including 3.5 million in the New York market.
The cable network is available in 49 percent of the TV homes in which WPIX is seen in in the New York market area, so appearing on WPIX expanded the geographic reach of the games. Appearing on free TV enables viewers who can't afford cable or can't get it to watch games. The Mets have an even split of telecasts, with 75 games on SportsChannel and 75 on WWOR/Channel 9.
MSG officials say that they have lost $22 million on the WPIX arrangement and that continuing it is economically unfeasible. WPIX says MSG is making a profit, but MSG refuses to include in its WPIX arithmetic the advertising revenues and subscriber fees it gets for its cable games.
"It's a tough situation," said Douglas Moss, president of the MSG Network. "All we're trying to do is make a reasonable deal. But we can't continue to suffer losses."
During the spring, MSG proposed that WPIX continue to air 50 games a season through the year 2000 for a $15 million annual fee. At $300,000 a game, said Moss, "that's exactly what we're paying now, not one cent more." He was referring to MSG's contract with the Yankees, which costs about $5 million a year.
WPIX rejected the offer, and made three counterproposals, said Eigner: continue the current arrangement; a revenue-sharing deal in which WPIX would sell the advertising time and split revenues with MSG; pay the $15 million rights fee if MSG shared one-third of its subscriber fees.
Last week, MSG rejected the counteroffers. Moss called them all "fancy ways for us to keep losing money."
"They have not offered anything else," said Eigner. "There have been no other proposals from them. They said they'd accept any reasonable offer and we made three of them."
 
Additional Talks Planned
 Moss said they would sit down for talks again later this month.
"We have months and months to work on this and come up with something new," he said.
"We don't have to offer WPIX anything, but we don't want to hoard games," said Bob Gutkowski, president of Madison Square Garden, the parent company of the MSG Network. Both are part of Paramount Communications.
Eigner said: "The Bronx and Brooklyn have very low cable penetration. Over 80 percent of the homes don't subscribe to cable or can't get it. So we want to keep the franchise on the station."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Ramirez Loses Luggage, but Not His Way to Majors

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Manny Ramirez hurried through the bowels of the Metrodome, late on his first day in the major leagues. It was only 55 minutes to game time.
"Which way?" he asked a companion. 
 "Over there," came the reply.
And just ahead was a sign that read "Visiting Team Club House." Ramirez, in light-blue sport jacket, T-shirt with a gold chain around his neck, blue jeans and black boots, pushed through the clubhouse door and was greeted by several members of the Cleveland Indians.
"Where you been?" infielder Alvaro Espinosa asked, shaking his hand.
Ramirez began to explain that the plane was late, that the airlines had lost one of his bags, that. . . .
"Get ready quick," Felix Fermin, the shortstop, said in Spanish, "you're in the lineup."
Ramirez looked around the clubhouse. "It's unbelievable I'm here," he said.
Unbelievable that this 6-foot, 190-pound outfielder made it, unbelievable that he made it so quickly, unbelievable that he had come so far, unbelievable that he will be playing in Yankee Stadium on Friday night, when Cleveland visits his hometown for a weekend series.
Only two years and three months ago, Manuel Aristides Ramirez was playing third base for the George Washington High School team in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan. Two years ago he was living with his father, Aristides, in a narrow sixth-floor walkup. He was considered the best baseball player in New York City in 1991, hitting for an average of .633, with 21 home runs. Legends had developed around him, some saying that when he hits the ball it sounds different from when anyone else hits one.
Ramirez was born in Santiago, the Dominican Republic, 21 years ago, came to the United States in 1985 when he was 12, played for the Pablo Morales Little League in Washington Heights and then for George Washington High, the school that produced the Hall of Famer, Rod Carew, and another of the famed, Henry Kissinger.
Ramirez was chosen in the first round of the 1991 draft by Cleveland -- the 13th pick over all -- and signed a $250,000 bonus. And he began tearing up the minor leagues. He was sent first to Burlington, N.C., where he hit .326 with 19 homers. He moved on to Kinston, N.C., where he had 13 home runs until he sustained an injury. Then this season he went from Class AA, Canton-Akron, to Class AAA Charlotte. He batted .340 at Canton with 17 homers and 79 runs batted in and .317 with 14 homers and 36 r.b.i. in only four and a half weeks with Charlotte.
 
A Call From Indians
 This morning he had flown into the Richmond airport from Charlotte when his manager, Charlie Manuel, was paged. After taking the call, which was from the Indians' office, Manuel motioned for Ramirez.
"You're going to Minnesota, you're going to the big leagues," Manuel told him.
"I didn't know what to say," Ramirez recalled. "I said, 'Thank you.' "
While Ramirez is considered a great talent, he is still a raw one. He is a born hitter, apparently, with amazingly quick hands and great power. His outfield play and his base running still need refinement, the Indians believe. But they have great hopes for him, and wanted to give him a taste of the big leagues, starting today, the day rosters can be expanded.
The Indians called up Bob Milacki, a pitcher, along with Ramirez. They had flown into Richmond on economy class and flew back out -- on the same plane -- first class.
Milacki, who had been in the major leagues for four years, turned to Ramirez in the first-class seat and said, "This is the only way to travel."
 
Missing Luggage
 But even first class can have problems. And Ramirez's bag with his sport jackets and slacks was missing. He had to put a tracer on it, and so time ticked away. He had to get to the ball park, but he also needed his clothes. Another bag was left in Charlotte, and that one contained his baseball equipment, his glove, his bats, his supporter. But all that would be provided by his new team.
Everything had happened so fast that he couldn't even call his father at the electronics store where he works as a handyman, or to the garment factory in Manhattan where his mother, Onelcidad, is employed as a seamstress. "I didn't know their numbers at work," he said, "and didn't have time to find out."
But he was able to call one of his high-school friends, Nestor Cruz. "He told me that they had thought I might get called up and a lot of people in the neighborhood already bought tickets for the Yankee game Friday."
"I'm excited to go back to New York, where all my friends will see me," said Ramirez. He smiled. "I heard they're going to be bringing signs about me."
One will say "The Hit Man From Washington." And they'll be wearing Cleveland caps for one of their own.
 
'He's Just Like Us'
 "He was the most exciting player ever to come out of here," said Jose (Peligro) Matteo, an old friend and the owner of Peligro Sandwich, a combination baseball card shop and deli on 170th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. "And he never forgot the neighborhood. He's just like us."
In the Cleveland clubhouse tonight, Manager Mike Hargrove told Ramirez that, because he had come late, he was being scratched as the designated hitter. He was assured that he would get his chance.
"Just relax," Hargrove said. "Don't try to be Reggie Jackson. Or Henry Aaron. Just be Manny Ramirez. That's all we can expect -- and it's all we want."
Manny Ramirez nodded and smiled. And then put on the Cleveland uniform -- No. 24 -- which looked like a perfect fit.

HEADLINE: A Sensible Teachers' Settlement

 BODY:
After two years of negotiations, Mayor David Dinkins of New York City and the teachers' union have reached agreement on a new contract. The timing of the contract can't hurt the Mayor, coming as it does before the start of the school year and the concluding phase of the mayoral campaign. But it will also bring improvements in the teacher evaluation process and is sounder financially than the previous teachers' contract.
It's disappointing that this agreement does not include many long-term gains in teacher efficiency in the classroom. Other labor pacts have also failed to achieve productivity gains. Even so, Mr. Dinkins seems to have learned a lesson from his expensive agreement with the teachers three years ago. That contract gave them a one-year, 5.5 percent raise at a time when the city faced a severe recession, and established a precedent for other labor agreements the city could ill afford. 
 This time the teachers' settlement follows other municipal labor contracts, including one reached in January with about 180,000 civilian employees. That contract called for a raise of a relatively modest 8.25 percent over 39 months.
The new teachers' contract provides for a net 10.53 percent raise over 48 1/2 months -- a bit costly but fair. The increases are not evenly distributed. They become more generous as the contract matures, taking the risk that the city will have more money three or four years from now.
In addition, the most experienced teachers will get the biggest salary boost; maximum salaries will jump from $52,750 to $60,000 in 1995. That's meant to retain senior teachers by making top salaries more competitive with those in many nearby school districts. Since recruiting new teachers isn't a problem, beginning salaries will increase more gradually, from $26,375 to $28,749 in 1995.
In exchange, there are some real educational gains. Teachers will now be evaluated on an annual basis, not just when they come up for tenure. That should improve the quality of teaching. And the union will help push for state legislation that extends the time period during which teachers may be subject to disciplinary action.
This agreement may serve the political interests of Mr. Dinkins and the union. It also serves the city's budget and its schoolchildren.

HEADLINE: Avoid a Bosnian Quagmire

 BODY:
The Geneva peace talks have broken down once again, with Bosnian Muslim leaders refusing to sign a plan based on a three-way partition of the country unless they are allotted more territory. Serbian and Croatian leaders insist they have made their last offer. Either way, the new plan to end the Bosnian war so reduces Muslim territory that it's a big step backward from the earlier, flawed Vance-Owen plan. It was that earlier plan that the Clinton Administration once pledged as many as 30,000 American troops to enforce.
But if agreement is reached, President Clinton would be mistaken to let that earlier pledge be taken as a blank-check guarantee that U.S. forces will be available to enforce the current plan. 
 The new plan would also require enforcement by tens of thousands of international troops. Mr. Clinton now wisely indicates he wants to wait and see the details before committing Americans to an enforcement effort. Rightly, he makes the fairness and enforceability of any final agreement the key criteria.
The current mediators, Lord Owen and Thorvald Stoltenberg, are pressing for a crude partition that would leave Bosnia's mostly Muslim Government with lands that could not survive economically and are not even connected. The mediators have frankly told the Bosnians that the only alternative to three-way partition is a two-way partition between Serbs and Croats that would leave the Muslims no territory at all.
Given the unwillingness of Western governments to intervene and Europe's insistence on maintaining a one-sided arms embargo, that's probably an accurate prediction. But the Owen-Stoltenberg plan is scarcely a formula that Americans could accept as the basis for a long-term commitment of a larger American force. It doesn't reflect the interests, preferences or principles of the U.S.
When you trace the outlines of this plan, the picture that emerges is that of a quagmire. Moreover, it is a quagmire that the European powers are themselves avoiding, but urging Mr. Clinton to wade into. The mediators estimate that enforcing the new plan would require at least 40,000 new peacekeeping troops beyond the 25,000 already in Bosnia. The peacekeeping forces would be expected to remain in place for years, and they would be constantly in harm's way.
The peacekeepers' main assignments would be to separate the combatants, patrol the newly drawn boundaries and defend vital transportation corridors, duties that would put them in the line of fire if local militias follow their bellicose history and attempt to redraw the treaty map with force.
Britain and France, the plan's main diplomatic sponsors, aren't willing to commit significant additional troops from their standing armies or to spend the money to expand their forces. And the idea of German or Turkish troops has been ruled out because of Serbian political sensitivities. Some Russian troops may be available, but U.S. allies in Western Europe want the main burden -- perhaps 20,000 troops -- to fall on the United States.
These are the same allies, of course, that rejected the Administration's preferred alternative of lifting the U.N. arms embargo and reinforcing Bosnia's bargaining position with NATO air power.
The Clinton Administration is right to want to see Europe take more responsibility for its own security in the post-cold-war world. But it must resist having its healthy commitment to multilateralism result in the use of American troops to enforce an agreement that goes against America's own policy preferences and principles.
Sending tens of thousands of U.S. troops to enforce such a dubious plan in Bosnia would set a dangerous precedent for other enforcement actions around the world.
Mr. Clinton should hold fast to his latest criteria. Given the military and diplomatic pressures surrounding the negotiations, there's ample grounds for questioning whether the Owen-Stoltenberg plan can be judged fair or freely arrived at. And given the likely circumstances of its institution, with all sides questioning the details, there's reason to doubt whether it is enforceable without unacceptable risks to American lives.

HEADLINE: In Ex-Soviet Lands, U.S. Must Use Caution

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"U.S. Cavalry for Soviet Borders?" (editorial, Aug. 23) is right to call for a serious assessment of the situation on the periphery of the former Soviet Union before there is any United States involvement -- whether it be negotiation or peacekeeping. 
 Russian foreign policy debates are too multisided to view as only reformers versus conservatives. Many "liberal" reformers are finding it difficult to deal with Russia's loss of superpower status and empire. Moreover, Russian fears of Islamic fundamentalism and growing civil unrest have led Boris N. Yeltsin's Government to support enlightened and not-so-enlightened authoritarian regimes in other former Soviet republics.
They have opted for short-term stability instead of long-term political development and democratization. In the longer run, Russian involvement in these areas is not the answer. Such intervention could be seen as imperialist and could inflame those very forces that Russia (and the United States) wish to contain.
In Russia, the absence of a well-defined national interest has created strong support for Russian nationalism, a tendency fueled by fears of the disintegration of the Russian federation. Reform alone will not necessarily mitigate the tendency. Fights over resources, tax revenues and political power contribute to decentralization.
The United States needs, first, accurate knowledge of Russian politics and the often confusing situations in the other former Soviet republics. These are the results of the long legacy of Russian domination and age-old ethnic conflicts. These conflicts could trigger outside interventions, especially from Turkey or Iran.
Our second priority should be to prevent Russian intervention and to facilitate the Red Army's withdrawal from the conflict areas.
Then, we should promote economic development, reform and democratization in the other successor states. It is dangerous to focus all our attention on Russia.
 
CAROL R. SAIVETZ
Fellow, Russian Research Center
Harvard University
Cambridge, Mass., Aug. 23, 1993

HEADLINE: On Abortion-Clinic Rounds: Forceps and Bulletproof Vest

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 28

 BODY:
It was 7:45 A.M., and still cool, but as Dr. Bernard Smith drove his Jeep to his abortion clinic, he was sweating. It was his bulletproof vest that was making him hot.
Dr. Smith has been performing abortions for more than 10 years, much of the time driving a weekly 600-mile circuit of abortion clinics in three states. As fewer and fewer abortion doctors are willing to put up with the harassment and tension in their own communities, such circuit riders have become far more common. 
 Among the things Dr. Smith knows about his business is that violence against doctors has been on the rise. He got the bulletproof vest six months ago, after an abortion doctor was fatally shot outside a clinic in Pensacola, Fla. Another doctor was shot and wounded two weeks ago in Wichita, Kan.
As Dr. Smith approached the Affiliated Medical Services clinic on Milwaukee's east side, 30 anti-abortion protesters were waiting with picket signs and pictures of bloody fetuses, as they are every Saturday. The tall, broad-shouldered doctor showed no tension or anxiety.
"It's always the same," he said. "They tell me: 'Bernie, don't do any killing today. Shame on you. Repent.' I just agree and keep walking. I used to try and talk to them, but I just don't feel up to it anymore. It's at an impasse. There's no common ground."
Dr. Smith, who put himself through Northwestern Medical School 20 years ago by working nights as a mail carrier and is on the board of the National Abortion Federation, describes himself as a passionate defender of a woman's right to have an abortion.
 
Cheers for Landmark Ruling
 "I remember being in a lecture in medical school when they announced that Roe v. Wade had passed," he said of the landmark Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion in 1973. "We all cheered. I've had to question my motives. Do I really want to do this in the face of all this adversity? Am I willing to risk this whatever the consequences? The answer is yes."
It is not only his bulletproof vest that protects the 49-year-old doctor; it is his cloak of professionalism. To him, abortion is simply not a moral issue. "I know exactly what I'm doing and why I'm doing it," he said. "I'm providing a medical service. I do it out of a sense of duty, just the way other doctors do theirs, only mine happens to be in a controversial field."
And if he did not do his duty, he said, the clinic in Milwaukee, one of five in the city, might close its doors. Dr. Smith is the only doctor in the area who performs abortions as late as 20 weeks into a pregnancy. The next closest doctor who does that works out of a clinic in Madison, 90 miles away. Most doctors stop performing abortions after the first 12 weeks, after which the danger to the woman increases.
Anti-abortion protesters have picketed Dr. Smith's home, surrounded his car, distributed "wanted" posters with his picture branding him a "child killer," blockaded the clinics where he works and mailed him anonymous death threats.
"Those are techniques of shame and embarrassment, and I am not ashamed of what I do," Dr. Smith said. "I'm not proud of it, either. It would be nice if what I do wasn't really needed. That would be O.K. by me. People think I don't like kids. But I have four kids, and an 8-month-old grandchild."
The director of the clinic, Victoria Sprinkman, worries for Dr. Smith. She is the one who insisted that he get a bulletproof vest.
"He's either not scared, or he's covering it up better than anyone I've seen in my life," she said.
 
Slaying in Florida
 Dr. David Gunn, who was killed in Pensacola, had received numerous death threats and carried three guns in his car for protection. Dr. Smith says he will not get a gun, though lately he has been varying his route, and checking his rear view mirror more than he used to.
He spends a lot of time behind the wheel of his Jeep: he makes a 600-mile, six-day, weekly circuit from a clinic in Niles, Mich., to one in Peoria, Ill., to Milwaukee. With fewer and fewer young doctors being trained in abortion, even as older doctors are reaching retirement, Dr. Smith's is not an uncommon journey. Dr. Gunn used to put in 1,000 miles a week, covering clinics in Alabama, Georgia and Florida. Some doctors have become pilots so they can fly their own planes from state to state. Others have stopped providing abortions because of the harassment.
Dr. Smith says he considers himself fortunate to have the support of volunteers from the Milwaukee Clinic Protection Coalition, a local volunteer group. "I'm not out there alone," he said. "That means a lot to me."
The volunteers were there when he pulled into the parking lot at the clinic here. They escorted him past the line of protesters, and through the locked door, with a sign above: "This clinic stays open."
Inside, the doctor took off his bulletproof vest and put on his blue scrubs. Every year 1.3 million abortions are performed in the United States. Today 23 women, ranging in age from 16 to 35, were waiting for the doctor. They were black, white, Hispanic and Asian, married and unmarried, employed and unemployed.
Dr. Smith, who will soon be divorced, says he regularly visits his children: three grown daughters and a teen-age son. When his children were small, he said: "I told them, 'Your daddy does abortions. That means he interrupts pregnancies. Some people are going to say your daddy is a baby killer. I don't see it that way.' "
He said that his oldest patient was a 54-year-old who never dreamed she could get pregnant, and that his youngest was an 11-year-old victim of incest. "How is an 11-year-old going to raise a child?" he asked. "What was she in -- fifth grade? How could she possibly understand what was happening to her?"
To the protesters outside, though, there can be no exceptions. Asked about the 11-year-old incest victim, one of them, a fundamentalist Christian named Karen Schneider, said: "That baby is created by God. I believe there should be no compromises. A life is a life."
Among Dr. Smith's patients on this day was a waitress with four children, who said she could not afford another. There was a mother of five on public assistance who had worked as a prostitute and been shot and stabbed, according to her records.
Another, a 30-year-old mother, is rearing a daughter alone, working as an administrative assistant and dreaming of one day going back to college. "My job is very demanding," she said. "It would be in jeopardy if I had another child. I could end up on welfare. I've been crying for weeks. This is not something I want to do."
Mrs. Schneider, 39, the protester, who has three sons, acknowledges having had four abortions more than 10 years ago before she married. "I listened to the feminist viewpoint that it is better for us to have control over our bodies than to bring children into the world," she said, clutching her Bible. "The first one was at age 24. I have to admit I wanted that abortion. I was in graduate school. I did not want to be saddled with that child."
Dr. Smith is familiar with Mrs. Schneider's story. "Why can't other women have four chances and then repent?" he said. "Why can't other women have a chance to make mistakes?"
 
Too Poor to Dream
 Dr. Smith, who is black, was one of 11 children who grew up in Mississippi and Chicago with a mother who scrubbed white people's floors. "I knew about the color thing growing up," he said. "But I didn't find out about the man-woman thing until I got older. Women can work anywhere they want to now. They can't harass you in the workplace anymore. What else can they do? They can harass you in the moral arena."
He was the first person in his family to graduate from college. He went to work as a high school mathematics and science teacher on the South Side of Chicago. "We were too poor for me to even dream about becoming a doctor," he said. But at the age of 25, under a minority recruitment program, he started medical school.
He began his career in emergency medicine at Methodist Hospital in Gary, Ind. He had no intention of doing abortions, he said. But in 1979, the director of a local Planned Parenthood chapter said his clinic needed a doctor. After long reflection, Dr. Smith said, he decided to help.
On this day, one of his last patients was a 17-year-old girl with a pearl heart necklace over her sweatshirt and braces on her teeth. Her father and her boyfriend, who is also 17, sat with her in the waiting room. In five days she would start her senior year of high school. She is a dancer on the pompon squad. She had a job at a fast food restaurant. She was nine weeks pregnant.
"I'm sad," she said, with her hands scrunched inside the sleeves of her sweatshirt. "I don't want to do this, and I do want to do this. My best friend said it's my fault. I shouldn't have had sex. She wants me to give the baby up for adoption. I don't want the baby to die because it's not his fault. But I don't want to mess up my life, either. I want to go to college.
"My dad says he doesn't want me to end up like him. I was an unwanted baby. My mother had three abortions before me. My dad wanted her to have another one. They got divorced over it." Her father, who was not present while she spoke to a reporter, said later that everything she had said was true.
The girl's mother was 16 when she was born; her father was 19.
The price of her abortion was $260 with local anesthesia, $320 with a stronger medication, called "twilight." Her father ordered the local. The girl said she would leave if he did not pay for the twilight. She got the twilight. Her boyfriend held her hand during the three-minute operation.
Afterward, Dr. Smith checked the tissue with forceps to make sure he had gotten everything. With forceps, he indicated the embryo. It was an inch long.
"This is what everybody's fighting about," he said. "It has a beating heart." It had no skeletal structure, only buds for limbs.
After performing thousands of abortions, Dr. Smith added, he looked upon the embryo much as another doctor might view an appendix he had just removed. "To me, I'm playing the same role at 8 weeks or at 12," he said. "The decision that was made by the woman is paramount. It's the woman's choice."
He placed the the embryo and other tissue in a sealed plastic bag with preservatives. It would be sent to a secret location for incineration.
It was after 5 P.M. when Dr. Smith got back in his Jeep and started on the two-hour drive home, to Chicago. His children live there. Sunday was his day off.
By 6:45 A.M. Monday he was back at the wheel, heading out of downtown toward Niles, Mich., two hours away. Thirty-four abortions were scheduled. The youngest patient would be a 13-year-old girl. Often, women drive five and six hours from upstate Michigan to the Niles clinic.
"There's a clinic about three minutes from my apartment in Chicago that would hire me in a minute," Dr. Smith said. "But they've already got doctors. The other clinics would close if I left. And the staff in Milwaukee said they'd shoot me if I did."

HEADLINE: CLINTON CUTS AIMS ON MENTAL HEALTH AND DENTAL COSTS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided to jettison some of the ambitious plans for comprehensive health benefits that he and his advisers had decided should be guaranteed to all Americans, Administration officials said today.
Because of concerns about cost, the health care overhaul package will initially include only limited amounts of mental health care and will not cover dental services for adults. 
 White House documents say the package to be proposed by Mr. Clinton, which would prescribe the minimum coverage provided by all health plans, is "as comprehensive as those offered by most Fortune 500 companies." But the public's aversion to new taxes forced the President to scale back plans to offer coverage broader than many big employers now provide.
 
Objections by Tipper Gore
 Administration officials said limits on mental health care -- in general, 30 outpatient visits and 60 days in a hospital each year -- were more stringent than they had originally hoped. But they said the plan would still permit coverage that is more generous than many Americans now have.
The limits were adopted over the objections of Tipper Gore, the Vice President's wife, who has advocated complete parity in coverage of mental and physical illnesses.
But White House documents show that the President's plan, scheduled to be submitted to Congress later this month, will recommend expanding coverage of mental health, dental and preventive services in the year 2000.
 
Medicare Curbs Planned
 Asked about his proposals, President Clinton said today that he planned to slash the growth of Medicare and Medicaid, the programs for the elderly and the poor, to help finance new benefits like long-term care and prescription drug coverage for the elderly. The Government typically tries to curb the cost of these programs by limiting payments to doctors and hospitals or by requiring beneficiaries to pay a larger share of the bill.
In addition, Mr. Clinton said that "a bureaucratic system of price controls" would not be needed to hold down health costs. Some drug companies and other segments of the health care industry have offered to keep prices in line with inflation for a year or two, Mr. Clinton said, and "they should be given the opportunity to adhere to the commitment that they've made."
Democrats and Republicans alike have warned Mr. Clinton that price controls would not work in the health care industry. In trying to allay such concerns today, Mr. Clinton conspicuously omitted any reference to one type of price controls that he does intend to impose: limits on private health insurance premiums.
By controlling the annual increase in premiums, he hopes to make insurance companies restrain payments to doctors and hospitals, thus controlling all health care spending.
The Health Insurance Association of America assailed this aspect of the Clinton plan, saying it had "ominous implications for consumers" and would not fully control health costs.
Mr. Clinton intends to unveil his health care plan in a speech to Congress the week of Sept. 20, and he will probably issue a detailed description of it at that time. But it may take weeks for the Administration to submit draft legislation to Congress, officials said.
Kevin Anderson, a White House spokesman, said the guaranteed benefits, like other elements of the plan, could be changed as a result of Mr. Clinton's discussions with Congress, scheduled to begin next week.
 
A Minimum Package
 As it now stands, the basic benefits package will include hospital and doctors' services, family planning services, pregnancy-related services, hospice care, home health care, nursing homes care (up to 100 days after a hospital stay), routine eye and ear examinations and preventive dental services for children.
The benefits package will not cover cosmetic surgery, hearing aids, eyeglasses for adults, in vitro fertilization services, sex-change surgery or private hospital rooms.
The basic benefits package reflects a minimum that all health insurance plans would have to cover. Employers could provide more. But under the Clinton proposal they would lose their Federal tax deduction for such extra expenses after three years, or at the end of existing labor contracts that expire after Jan. 1, 1997.
Many companies already cover dental care for employees and their families, and this benefit has proved popular with employees.
Hewitt Associates, an employee benefits consulting concern based in Lincolnshire, Ill., says more than 90 percent of big employers offer dental benefits to their workers. This estimate is based on data collected from 1,000 companies with 20 million employees and 35 million spouses and dependents.
 
Congress to Weigh Plan
 Mr. Clinton's proposals are subject to approval by Congress, which has made clear that it intends to prescribe the minimum package of health benefits in minute detail.
White House documents say the Administration "proposes to phase in additional benefits in the year 2000." For example, the documents say, adults would become eligible for preventive dental care in that year, and hospital coverage for mental illness would be increased to 90 days, from 60 days. In addition, the documents say, the Administration hopes to eliminate limits on the number of outpatient psychotherapy visits in the year 2000.
But such improvements are contingent on "savings from reform" of the health care system and on of Mr. Clinton's efforts to reduce the Federal budget deficit, the documents say.
In a letter to the White House this week, Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota and 14 other Democratic senators argued against "artificial caps on the length of treatment" for people with mental disorders.
"For too long," the senators said, "standard health insurance plans have imposed arbitrary restrictions on treatment for mental and addictive disorders. Such discriminatory policies are based on stigma and outmoded assumptions about these illnesses."
White House documents show that Mr. Clinton's plan would require all insurers and employers to cover some mental health services. For treatment in a hospital or a group home, the required coverage would be "30 days per episode," or spell of mental illness, up to a total of 60 days a year.
Limits would be stricter for services outside a hospital. Insurance provided in the basic benefits package would cover part of the cost for 30 visits to a psychotherapist; White House documents say that in many cases the patient would have to pay half the cost. A patient's initial visit to a psychotherapist would not be subject to this limit.
 
Dental Service for Children
 Under Mr. Clinton's plan, the initial package of benefits would include dental services for children under 18 years old. In the year 2000, when dental benefits may be extended to adults, low-income people may pay as little as $20 for each visit to a dentist. Other patients would be expected to pay 40 percent of each dental bill, up to a total of $1,500 a year.
But even in the year 2000, patients would generally be expected to pay 20 percent of the cost of the first 12 sessions with a psychotherapist and 50 percent for subsequent visits.
The documents list routine physical examinations among the services that may not be covered till the year 2000. In that year, the documents say, the Government may require employers and insurers to cover "periodic medical examinations: every three years for individuals age 20 to 39, every two years for adults age 40 to 65 and annually for adults age 65 or more."
Ira C. Magaziner, the President's health policy coordinator, has said the White House was considering explicit controls on doctors' fees, hospital rates and drug prices as a temporary measure to curb health spending.
But today, when asked if the idea of short-term price controls was dead, Mr. Clinton said: "They never were alive. I never embraced them."

HEADLINE: A New Information Mass Market

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Rupert Murdoch's acquisition of Delphi Internet Services, a gateway to the global Internet computer network, may be the clearest indication yet that businesses are eager to tap into a market of computer users that is growing by as many as a million new customers a month.
When the News Corporation, of which Mr. Murdoch is chairman and chief executive, said on Wednesday that it would buy Delphi, an on-line computer service, the company said it planned to offer many of its newspapers and magazines in electronic form over the Internet. It was one of many recent moves helping to lift the company's stock. [Market Place, page D4.] 
 The Murdoch deal followed by one week the announcement that Continental Cablevision, the nation's third-largest cable TV company, would join forces with Performance Systems International Inc., the largest private provider of Internet services, to offer hundreds of thousands of telecommuters connections to the Internet via Continental's cable network.
The Internet is an ad hoc amalgamation of thousands of individual computer networks that are interconnected by a routing language that permits them to exchange messages and share data. Most industry estimates say that more than 15 million computer users are now connected to the Internet, and that as many as one million new users a month are learning how to employ it for work or recreation.
The international reach of its tentacles is awesome to consider. But the scramble by big media corporations may miss a fundamental point: deep pockets and mass-media savvy are no guarantee of commercial success in the quirky, anarchistic world of the Internet.
"The Internet is now big enough that it qualifies as a mass market," said Vinton Cerf, president of the Internet Society in Reston, Va., an organization that sets network standards. "This strikes fear and anger into many people who live in this piece of cyberspace."
It is the fear of being late to the party that has communications and publishing companies rushing to repackage their products digitally for the new information economy.
"People are just beginning to realize the implications of the fact that anything can be digitized," said Stephen Wolff, director of the network division of the National Science Foundation. "The Internet is the universal communications medium of the future."
But as big companies discover the Internet, they will find that the Net, as it is known, is already a thriving electronic marketplace for thousands of mom-and-pop electronic ventures and tiny cottage businesses.
One of the newest examples is the Global Network Navigator, offered by O'Reilly & Associates, a small book publisher in Sebastopol, Calif. The Navigator is a software program that is part interactive magazine, part book catalogue and part computer dashboard for retrieving information in the Internet. Because no one is yet certain what the electronic magazine of the future will look like, dozens of ventures are trying to develop innovative and interactive alternatives to today's paper-based publications.
 
No Guarantees for Success
 Even officials at the News Corporation acknowledge that size and economic influence in themselves will not guarantee that large publishers eventually displace smaller start-ups in an environment where any computer connected to the network can serve as an electronic publishing house. But they say that their ability to use other media to promote their Internet products will give them an edge.
"We certainly have the power to promote what we build," said John Evans, president of News and Electronic Data Inc., a News Corporation subsidiary in Clinton, N.J.
"Today people buy bits of dead cellulose and have an emotional experience," he said, referring to the print media. "Maybe there's a way to use a piece of dead silicon instead."
The growth of the Internet is also shaking up telecommunications providers, because it is largely based on a different pricing model than previous data- and voice-transmission services.
While commercial electronic mail services have typically priced their services on a per-message basis, Internet services are usually priced on a monthly flat-rate basis. This tends to make it more economical to offer messaging and information services, and encourages customers to make greater use of the network than they would on a pay-as-you-go basis.
The potential impact can be seen in a small Washington-based company, the Internet Multicasting Service, which recently introduced an Internet facsimile service that will effectively bypass the long-distance telephone network and charge much lower rates. To encourage Internet computer hubs to serve as local relay points for this fax network, the company allows these hosts to sell local advertising that can be displayed on the bottom third of the fax cover sheet. Larger national advertisers are also being offered advertising space.
 
Proven Marketing Uses
 As the bandwidth -- the carrying capacity -- of the Internet increases, and it becomes as feasible to send voice conversations and video as it now is to transmit data, the Internet is certain to have a far greater impact on the traditional communications carriers. And the Internet has already demonstrated its power as a marketing channel, particularly for software.
"The Internet has a tremendous reputation as a market that's a channel for connecting with people with a need for products and information," said Christopher Locke, editor of the Internet Business Report, an industry newsletter in Manhasset, L.I.
One company using the Internet to help sell its product is Qualcomm Inc., a San Diego-based digital communications company. Last week Qualcomm began marketing a commercial version of an electronic mail program called Eudora, which was once offered for free to Internet users. The program is popular among habitues of the Net for its ease of use and power.
The program, which will sell for $50, is already being used by more than 100,000 electronic mail users and Qualcomm executives said they were confident that many of them would purchase the commercial version, which has additional features.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Los Angeles Times Weighs Sale of Headquarters

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Pressed for cash in a depressed California regional economy, the Times Mirror Company, publisher of The Los Angeles Times and Newsday, is considering selling its downtown Los Angeles headquarters and moving to a high-rise office tower, people familiar with the plan said today.
Officials of Times Mirror said today that they had hired a consultant to conduct a feasibility study of the cost advantages in moving but that no decision to relocate had been made. 
 The headquarters complex, known as Times Mirror Square, is situated on more than a square block, a valuable area running mainly from First to Second Street and from Spring Street to Broadway, across from City Hall. It consists of three connected buildings and two parking garages. The Los Angeles Times is largely written and edited there, and most business operations are there, too.
Times Mirror is a large and diverse company that publishes other daily and weekly papers, including The Baltimore Sun and The Hartford Courant, and owns television stations and specialty publishing companies.
The Los Angeles Times has occupied the downtown site for more than 55 years, but is now facing a severe advertising slump that has forced it to cut costs. Much of the space in the complex is in disrepair, and fixing it could be far more costly than renting space elsewhere, those familiar with the plan said. The offices were built in the 1930's, 40's and 70's.
Still, selling the headquarters, particularly the signature building, which is identifiable at night by huge lighted letters reading "The Times," is a drastic step, and it underscores a tenuous financial condition.
In the first half of the year, advertising revenue at The Los Angeles Times was $374 million, compared with $406 million in the first half of 1992. Ad revenue for Times Mirror's Eastern newspapers was $336 million, compared with $330 million in the corresponding period last year.
Since its peak in 1990, advertising revenue has fallen 15 percent. The Los Angeles Times's publisher, David Laventhol, said today that no improvement in advertising was foreseen in the next year.
In the second quarter of 1993, Times Mirror had net income of $47.9 million, or 37 cents a share, compared with $44.1 million, or 34 cents a share, in the period last year.
Last month, rumors circulated that the paper had put its headquarters up for sale. But Times Mirror said then that it had not approached any potential buyers and was simply responding to requests made from time to time by brokers and developers about relocating, since it no longer printed the paper there.
Officials of the company said today, in confirming that a relocation consultant had been hired, that they were talking as well with a real estate developer, John Cushman, and with brokers.
Mr. Laventhol, who is also president of the Times Mirror Company, said it would be a mistake to think that selling Times Mirror Square was a centerpiece of the paper's efforts to cut costs. Asked why rumors of the sale had created such a stir in recent weeks, he said: "I don't think they have. We all know that change is a challenge for a lot of people, and where there's the possibility of change taking place, they react to it."
And Martha Goldstein, Times Mirror's corporate communications director, said of the reports, "We have not made a decision, nor do we have a timetable for making a decision."
But commercial real estate brokers here said the company was in serious negotiations to sell the complex to the Metropolitan Water District, which is looking for new space in the civic-center district.
Robert Gomperz, a spokesman for the water district, said it has had preliminary contacts with Times Mirror about possibly acquiring the square but that no hard negotiations have taken place. It is also considering other options, such as building a new facility or leaving downtown altogether, he said.
In addition, the brokers said Times Mirror had been involved in talks to lease space at Security Pacific Plaza, a major corporate office tower a few blocks away.
Some reporters and editors of The Los Angeles Times have expressed glee at the prospects of moving to a modern building, describing their current work place as a "dump," where the plumbing does not work and they are harassed by beggars and transients on the street.
Others, especially some who have been at the paper for a long time, said they were saddened that The Los Angeles Times would even consider moving, given the history and traditions of the downtown building.
Ms. Goldstein, the Times Mirror spokeswoman, said the buildings were in "above average" condition for structures their age.
Newspaper analysts said that relocating the headquarters was a viable cost-cutting choice that Times Mirror was smart to consider. In other cost-related moves, the paper has closed its San Diego edition and significantly reduced its staff through buyouts.

HEADLINE: Texaco Gets Aid to Invest In Russia

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The United States and Russia have put together a fund to encourage American companies to invest in Russia, and in a White House signing ceremony yesterday Texaco became the first beneficiary.
The oil company, which has an $80 million project to restore the production of 150 dormant wells in the giant Sutormin field in western Siberia, concluded an agreement with the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a Federal agency, which will provide $28 million of loan guarantees and insurance against political risk for the effort. 
 OPIC helps American businesses invest in developing nations, and one of its major goals is to support economic change in formerly Communist nations. Since 1971 the agency has supported investment worth about $60 billion.
 
Dual Policy Goal
 The agency is prepared to provide up to $2.5 billion in new loans, loan guarantees, equity and insurance in the next year to support private investment in Russia.
Increased investment by the oil industry serves a dual policy goal -- not only bolstering relations with Russia, but also providing an alternative to importing from the Middle East. Many analysts have warned of potential political risks in overdependence on the Mideast oil producers.
Under yesterday's agreement, an investment fund has been set up by the Russian Government, which will contribute $25 million; $50 million more will be guaranteed by OPIC.
Ruth R. Harkin, the president of OPIC, said the Texaco agreement was "a pioneer project in a long line of U.S. projects for U.S. companies contemplating the vast opportunities in the Russian oil and gas sector."
The agreement was signed at the White House, and the ceremony was attended by Vice President Al Gore and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia.
The fund is the first of its kind, and it is hoped that it will eventually generate several hundred million dollars of investment in Russia by helping to overcome the reluctance of American companies to invest there because of political uncertainties.
Alfred C. DeCrane Jr., Texaco's chairman and chief executive, who signed the agreement yesterday, said that OPIC "is a valuable resource for U.S. companies making investments in newly independent states."
Texaco has overcome a major stumbling block to investment in Russia by being paid in dollars from oil that is exported by Sutorminskneft, a western Siberian oil and gas production association.
United States oil companies have put their toe into Russia, but are still wary and are seeking ways to operate in spite of this.
 
Texaco's Current Operation
 Texaco estimated that the project would bring $76 million to the United States, helping the balance of payments.
The company has about a dozen employees there and has helped restore the production of nine wells generating about 4,000 barrels a day. When completed, the project will help restore the production of about 30,000 barrels a day.
Russian petroleum production has fallen as fields have stopped operating and replacement parts have been hard to obtain. The Russians are making a major effort to restore production to generate convertible foreign currency, which they need to buy imported goods and otherwise spur the economy.
Through the first two years of production, it is estimated that the project will generate $62 million in foreign exchange for Russia.
 
Russia Serves a Need
 Major foreign oil companies are seeking ties with Russia because it has huge and promising undeveloped reserves. The oil companies are under pressure to build up reserves at a time when many have given up exploration in other areas.
Texaco's project is an important step in moving toward larger investments in long-term exploration for new fields.
The company has an agreement with Russia to explore in the Timan-Pechora area in Siberia over the next 50 years, where reserves could turn out to be about five billion barrels.
Texaco, through its subsidiary Texaco International Operations Inc., signed its agreement with Russia in March to restore production at the field, which lies about 200 miles south of the Arctic Circle and 1,500 miles from Moscow. About 40 percent of the wells were idle at the time.

HEADLINE: Medical Issues Shine On Mixed Trading Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed in heavy trading yesterday, bolstered by drug issues and low interest rates but held back by weakness in airline and cyclical stocks.
Reports that President Clinton had backed away from cost controls as part of the Government's proposed health care program led investors on a shopping spree for drug stocks. Pfizer's settlement of liability cases in California related to a heart valve added a lift to the group. 
 Airline issues came under pressure as investors focused on the industry's financial plight and weak profitability. Another group under siege was the high-technology sector, mostly on profit taking.
 
Weaker Factory Orders
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19 points, to 3,626.10, pulled down by Alcoa, Caterpillar, General Motors, and International Paper. These and other cyclical issues, which are sensitive to the economy's direction, were hurt by the Commerce Department's report of weaker-than-expected factory orders in July.
Drug stocks and health maintenance organizations, which are well represented on the Nasdaq, pushed the Nasdaq composite index up 2.50 points, to 748.65, its fourth straight record closing high. The American Stock Exchange was the only other index to close at a high.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 259.9 million shares, up from 246.6 million traded on Wednesday. The number of issues trading lower outpaced gainers by 1,033 to 945.
Among medical issues, Merck rose 1 5/8, to 33 1/8; Bristol-Myers Squibb 7/8, to 57; American Home Products 1/2, to 64 5/8, and SmtihKline 1 3/8, to 30 1/8.
Renewed interest in the medical stocks also rallied shares of HMO companies. U.S. Healthcare added 2 7/8, to 47 1/8; Oxford Health 6 3/8, to 72 1/2; United Health 3, to 62 1/8, and Coventry 2, to 32.
Pfizer gained 2 on the day to close at 64 3/4, after the news of the settlement of most cases and claims concerning the Bjork-Shiley heart valve. The company said it did not see any material adverse affect on its financial condition.
Medimmune, however, fell 4 5/8, to 19 1/8, in active trading. The company reported that the Food and Drug Administration had postponed a review of product license applications for its Respivir drug.
 
Retailing Report
 Elsewhere, retailers reported mixed sales for August. Wal-Mart, fell to 24 3/4, down 1, and J. C. Penney dropped 3/4, to 41 1/8. Sears, Roebuck, however, gained 3/8, to 54 3/4, and the Bombay Company rose 1 5/8, to 44 1/8.
Avon Products fell 4 5/8, to 54 7/8, on a sluggish earnings forecast.
Western Waste rose 3, to 20, after the environmental-control company agreed to be acquired by Browning-Ferris in a stock swap. Traders said there was some talk that Browning-Ferris, down 1 1/4, to 23 5/8, was paying a premium for Western Waste. The swap calls for Browning-Ferris to exchange 1.02 shares of its common for each share of Western Waste.
Shares of Chipsoft, the personal finance and tax-preparation software company, fell 1 1/2, to 13 3/4, after its agreement to be acquired by Intuit,, another software company. Intuit was down 1/8, to 32 1/8.

HEADLINE: Haiti's Prime Minister Installs His Cabinet

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 2,

 BODY:
With Haiti's military high command among the witnesses, Prime Minister Robert Malval installed his Cabinet today and formally ended nearly two years of military rule.
"It is perhaps our last chance as a nation," Mr. Malval said in a ceremony at the National Palace, where the Army arrested President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in September 1991 and sent him into exile. 
 Under an accord signed July 3 by Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, Father Aristide, a Roman Catholic priest, is to be restored to power on Oct. 30.
International sanctions were suspended last week after Haiti's Parliament approved Mr. Malval as Prime Minister.
In a brief address, Mr. Malval, who was selected by Father Aristide, urged the military to join civilians in combating "the enemies of change."
"Together we can check these acts of banditry and vandalism that leave families mourning and discredit our country," he said.
Among the diplomats present was Dante Caputo, the United Nations special envoy who played a crucial role in the peace accord. Mr. Caputo came to Haiti to discuss the resumption of economic aid, which was suspended after the coup, and a proposed 1,000-member United Nations police and military aid mission.
The United States will have a much greater role in the United Nations mission than originally thought: the Pentagon is to pay for the group reforming the Army, and the Justice Department is to pay for the program to establish a civilian police force.

HEADLINE: Fall in Business Confidence

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Business executives' confidence in the economy fell in August to the lowest level since just after the recession, the United States Chamber of Commerce said today.
Martin A. Regalia, the group's chief economist, said the drop in the chamber's bimonthly confidence index reflected "the economy's inability to develop any real momentum." 
 The business confidence index fell to 45.6 in August from 47.7 in June and 59.3 in April. It was the lowest level since the index hit 39.3 in December 1991, six months after the recession ended.
An index reading of 50 or more indicates moderate economic growth. A reading of 70 or more signals strong growth.
"In addition to their concern over the economy's failure to generate significant job growth, businesses are unsure of the Administration's economic plan and are worried about future regulatory and health care costs," Mr. Regalia said.
Of the 8,280 businesses surveyed for the latest index, 13.9 percent said the economy would improve in the next six months, 48.6 percent said it was in decline and 37.5 percent said it would hold its own.
Executives were a bit more optimistic about sales: 36.8 percent expected an increase, 25.1 percent a decline and 38.1 percent no change. On employment, 17 percent expected an increase, 20.6 percent a drop and 48.2 percent no change.

HEADLINE: On Bosnia Talks: Hoping to Bridge a Slender Gap

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Sept 2

 BODY:
Despite the breakdown of the latest peace talks on Bosnia and Herzegovina, the three warring parties were apparently so close to agreement Wednesday night that diplomats here are still hopeful that Bosnia's Muslims, Serbs and Croats will try again soon to end their war.
After Bosnian Serbs rejected an earlier peace plan this spring, the immediate result was an upsurge in fighting between Serbs and Muslims and between Croats and Muslims, with the Muslims scoring their first significant military successes against the Croats in central Bosnia. 
 This time, however, while the danger of increased warfare exists, all three parties have pledged to respect a shaky cease-fire and, perhaps most important, the Bosnian Serb forces appear to have no interest in occupying more than the 70 percent of Bosnian territory they now hold.
 
Willing to Return
 Further, although the Muslims in the end refused to endorse a peace agreement drawn up by international mediators, they as well as the Serbs and Croats insisted that the plan is "still on the table" and that they are willing to return to Geneva for more talks.
"I would say that it's not a time to be pessimistic," a senior United States official said. "There is no reason to despair at this point. Yes, we're disappointed, but we hope the parties will come back as soon as possible to complete this negotiation."
President Clinton warned today that NATO could still carry out air strikes against Serb positions if the shelling of Sarajevo resumed. But diplomats here discounted any military intervention while an agreement to end the 17-month-old war was still within reach.
All sides have already agreed to partition Bosnia and Herzegovina into three autonomous ethnic republics with a weak central government.
 
New Demands
 But, while the Serbs and Croats accepted a map prepared by the European Community's Lord Owen and the United Nations envoy, Thorvald Stoltenberg, the Muslims returned to the negotiations here this week with new demands for additional territory.
The map would give the Muslims 30 percent of the territory against the 10 percent the Bosnian Government now controls, while the Serbs, who occupy 70 percent, would retain slightly more than 52 percent. The Bosnian Croats now control 20 percent and would be left with almost 18 percent
But Alija Izetbegovic, the President of Bosnia's Muslim-dominated government, argued that the map "rewarded" Serb aggression and "ethnic cleansing" and he claimed about 4 percent more land in eastern and north-western Bosnia as well as part of Neum, Bosnia's only Adriatic port.
During talks with the mediators Wednesday, the Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, offered a two-mile-wide corridor -- instead of the Muslim-controlled highway proposed under the peace plan -- linking the Srebrenica-Zepa enclave and Gorazde. The Croat leader, Mate Boban, in turn said the Muslims could buy land in Neum and build their own port.
 
Pressed for Flexibility
 Diplomats said that both Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia, and Franjo Tudjman, the President of Croatia pressured Dr. Karadzic and Mr. Boban respectively to be flexible. But when no new offers were forthcoming last night, Mr. Izetbegovic refused to sign the draft agreement.
The question now is: What can the Muslims do to force the Serbs and Croats to meet their demands? One month ago, Mr. Izetbegovic still hoped for NATO air strikes.
But there were no air strikes and, with the Serbs having eased the siege of Sarajevo in recent weeks, there may be no immediate justification for such an action. "The Serbs will do nothing to give anyone an excuse for air strikes," one United Nations official said. "They're going to be very careful."
Today, Dr. Karadzic forgot all his earlier threats to crush the Muslims if they failed to accept the agreement, pledging to respect the cease-fire and calling on the international community to encourage all parties "not to miss this opportunity for peace."
"No one can understand why the Muslims should fight if they're doing better at the bargaining table," he went on. "Honestly, I could not believe that the Muslims were refusing this honest offer, which was fair and meant a way out without winners or losers. We still hope the Muslims will sign."
 
Talking in Turkey
 Unable to change the military balance on their own, the Muslims can now only hope to win new concessions through diplomatic pressure. Today, Mr. Izetbegovic flew to Istanbul for talks with Turkey's President, Suleyman Demirel, a strong ally of the Bosnian Muslim cause. Mr. Izetbegovic also plans to travel to New York to address the United Nations Security Council on Monday.
So far, however, while Islamic countries have repeatedly urged both the Security Council and Western powers to use force to stop Serb attacks, the United States, Russia and the European Community have preferred not to interfere in the negotiations.
The senior United States official reiterated today that it was up to the warring parties to reach an agreement. But he also blamed the "intransigence" of the Serbs and Croats in refusing to give "that extra bit."
"It's in the hands of those who have taken territory by force to make the necessary moves to present a solution acceptable to those who have little force," the official noted, adding the Serbs and Croats were asked to make "a very minimum addition" to what was already agreed.
Diplomats said they expected Washington and European Community to send the message to Bosnia's Serbs and Croats as well as to Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Tudjman that they will not accept a resurgence of warfare and that they insist on an early political settlement.
In this, they have two potential weapons: the promise that economic sanctions against Serbia will be lifted as soon as a peace accord is implemented in good faith and the suggestion that an early agreement could protect senior Serbian and Croatian leaders from being brought before a planned international war crimes tribunal.
For the moment, though, the mediators are taking a wait-and-see attitude. "There's a feeling that public opinion in Bosnia may express itself," Lord Owen said after the talks broke up. "People are war-weary, fed up that their politicians don't get on with settling the conflict. Perhaps people will demand peace."
