HEADLINE: Sumburgh Journal;
As Oil Calamities Go, Shetland Spill Was a Wimp

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SUMBURGH HEAD, Shetland Is lands, Aug. 28

 BODY:
The Braer's giant steel hull has been smashed and scattered by the long Atlantic swells. Only its blunt prow remains intact, tilted at a broken angle from the boiling surf where the tanker was driven aground in January, spilling its cargo of 630,000 barrels of oil.
But shoreward of the wreck, along a narrow cleft in the steep coastline that only last winter was oiled black and stinking with petroleum, there is nothing to suggest that this ragged headland had been the site of one of the biggest tanker accidents in a decade. 
 Instead, less than 200 yards from the broken ship, more than 100 gray seals now bob and tumble in the clear sea, or bask on rocky islands at the foot of cliffs dotted with the nests of seabirds. Overhead, white fulmars and black-tipped gannets wheel and dive over a ruggedly scenic coast that remains home to one of the largest seabird colonies in Europe.
Atop the sheer headland overlooking the wreck, in treeless pasture stippled with sea pink, a heather flower, Les Fishman, a tourist from southern England, watched the seals playing near the ship and shook his head in wonder.
 
Why Damage Was Limited
 "It's amazing, but in a way, it also belies the situation," Mr. Fishman said. "I think we are just very lucky it was not much worse."
Scientists cautiously acknowledge that they do not know what kinds of hidden, long-term effects the oil spill might yet have on the islands, and are still carefully monitoring everything from bird breeding populations to the blood chemistry of residents who inhaled the gagging oil-tainted mist that storm winds carried over the island for several days last winter.
But nearly eight months after one of the fiercest winter storms in memory pounded the helpless Braer onto rocks at the southern tip of these remote islands, 200 miles north of Aberdeen, and broke apart her tanks, the environmental and economic effect of the accident remains surprisingly muted, even though the volume of oil lost here was more than twice the amount spilled onto the Alaska coast by the Exxon Valdez in 1989.
The Alaska accident fouled a sheltered wildlife estuary with a thick, tar-like crude, but the oil pouring from the Braer was much lighter and thinner. At the same time, the very winds and pounding seas that doomed the Braer also kept the spill from forming large shorebound slicks; instead, the leaking oil was scattered and dispersed by the constant churning of 30-foot seas.
Much of the oil was carried away from the islands by deep sea currents. An extensive survey last spring revealed that the largest patches -- about 30 percent of the Braer's total cargo -- are now mixed in muddy bottom sediments in two separate ocean basins covering hundreds of square miles, far to the west and the southeast of the islands.
Only a small portion of the oil was washed ashore, and wildlife specialists who have combed the Shetlands' rugged and windswept coasts say they have yet to find evidence that the spill here has cost the life of a single sea mammal. Although surveys taken last January counted half a dozen dead seals and sea otters, scientists now say those deaths were unrelated to the spill.
Moreover, because few of the Shetland bird colonies breed here in the winter, the oil accounted for only limited and highly localized damage to the islands' vast colonies of seabirds.
"The population of shag and eiders were down near the wreck," said Peter Ellis, the Shetland representative for the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds. "But otherwise, we had a reasonably good breeding season over the summer, and the overall effect appears remarkably light."
But Mr. Ellis says further monitoring is essential to measure whether contamination of seabeds has done long-term damage to the population of sand eels and other marine animals on which the seabirds feed.
So far, more than $16 million in claims have been paid out to local islanders from the International Oil Pollution Compensation Fund. Most of the money has gone to salmon fisherman and salmon farmers up the coast from the wreck, where the rainbow sheen of oil spreading from the ship tainted their stock and has forced them to destroy two seasons worth of fish.
In the island capital of Lerwick, a picturesque coastal village about 30 miles north of here, officials say they have extracted promises from the British Government to install maritime radar systems that will monitor the passage of tankers and other ships in the busy shipping channels around the islands.
The Braer was passing south of the islands in January when the tanker lost engine power and began drifting helplessly toward the rocky southern coast. While rescue teams managed to save the ship's 34-man crew, they say they could have towed the tanker free of danger as well, if they'd had more warning that the ship was in trouble.
Among the islands' 23,000 residents, most agree that so far the relatively limited nature of the damage has been almost too good to believe. "Everyone knows it could have been so much worse," said Mark Donaldson, who owns the Sumburgh Hotel, less than two miles from the scene of the wreck. "But I think people are still a bit wary; they want to know for sure everything will turn out all right."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The serenity of the Shetland Islands coastline belies the anguished scene eight months ago when the tanker Braer spilled its cargo of 630,000 barrels of oil. The only evidence of that calamity now is the ship's prow breaking the surf. Still, residents wonder if there are not hidden, darker consequences ahead. (Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Home Is Where the Profits Are;
Suburbanites Reap the Benefits of a Weak Economy as Entrepreneurs Come Calling

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 2

 BODY:
On Sunday mornings, sporting a black wet suit and neon fins, Harry Triola of Fort Salonga, L.I., flip-flops over to his neighbor's swimming pool, where he meets Nicholas Martielli, his personal scuba-diving instructor.
At least three nights a week, Eric Swenson, an estates and trusts lawyer, sets himself apart from the competition by writing clients a complete will, in the privacy of their living rooms, for $99. 
 On Thursday afternoons, Carol Shapiro of Glen Cove, a physical therapist who makes house calls, runs home to meet Terry Tetro of Franklin Square. For $18, she enjoys a manicure and pedicure while sitting at her kitchen table.
Increasingly, suburbanites across the metropolitan area are finding that they can get almost any service they need at home, and often for no more than it would cost elsewhere.
The market is there, experts say, because many families, especially two-career couples, have long had trouble finding the time for routine chores like buying groceries and picking up the dry cleaning. But the phenomenon also reflects a weak economy in which people are looking for new ways to make money or trying to keep busy after being laid off.
"It's partly due to a weak economy, but it's also an entrepreneurial spirit that is driving this," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "It is part of the growth of the service industry. A lot of people who see a tough job market out there are looking around for a new niche in the service economy."
Entrepreneurs and small businesses are scrambling to fill such niches, offering every service from food shopping to dog grooming. Freshly picked vegetables, all-natural granola, even a pint of Ben and Jerry's ice cream is just a phone call away.
There are mobile dog groomers, mobile boat repairmen and mobile car repairmen, and for $22 someone will even come to the house and clean the barbecue grill.
"People don't have a lot of time to take care of their household chores and personal needs," said Peter Lambert, a researcher at the Long Island Regional Planning Board. "Because of the economy, both husband and wife are working. They are working longer hours, many of them are working two jobs to afford their mortgage and all their other expenses."
The same phenomenon is apparent elsewhere.
"I see a definite trend" said Gary Levine, executive director of the Fairfield, Conn., Chamber of Commerce. "I don't think people have time to make their own dinner anymore, but now you can order from a gourmet restaurant and they will deliver."
Brad M. King, an insurance broker in Manhattan who spends summers in Southampton, is an enthusiastic user of the services in the home.
 
Poolside Service
 "It's great," he said, "Everything is available at our convenience, it's done on our time. It's a great way of differentiating a service from the other guys and it gives them a competitive edge."
Mr. Triola, a mortgage and securities broker in Manhattan, said he was thrilled when he learned that he could become certified in scuba diving at a neighbor's home. "I work crazy hours. I commute and don't get home until after 7 P.M. I want to have time to spend with my wife and the kids, and that means that I cannot sign up for a scuba course at one of the local Y's."
Mr. Martielli, the scuba instructor, said he would be in a real bind without his personal-service business. Last year, he was laid off from his job as a lab manager at the New York Institute of Technology when the school's Islip campus closed. Now he works as a private tutor of math, physics, chemistry and scuba diving.
"I was glad to have my tutoring and scuba business," he said. "It's not like I am making money, but it has a lot of potential. If I could get booked up for the entire summer, I could earn up to $1,000 a week."
Two years ago, Scott Beagelman and Scott Fletcher of Glen Cove and Paul Jacobs of Dix Hills graduated from college and wanted to go into the restaurant business, but did not have the money. Instead, they offered meals from local restaurants delivered for a $2 service charge by a driver decked out in a black tuxedo and white shirt -- thus the company name, Black Tie Express.
The company has served well over 100,000 meals on Long Island and has helped other young entrepreneurs open operations in five states: Ohio, Texas, New Jersey, New York and Connecticut. Three weeks ago, the company opened an operation in Westchester County and "already we have over 400 customers," said Mr. Fletcher.
"People call us from the car, give us their order, and say, I'll meet you in my driveway in 30 minutes," he said. "People love the service, because they just don't have free time anymore. They come home, they are tired and they would rather not cook."
 
So Much to Be Done
 Mr. Beagelman said the company plans to offer other services soon, including picking up dry cleaning, prescription drugs, videotapes, groceries and pets from the groomer, and taking mail to the post office. It will even make trips to the motor vehicles department.
Terry Tetro, the manicurist, said: "When I started the service, I just wanted to make some extra money, but it turned out to be something I really like. People like it because it is a little more personable and it's away from the hectic atmosphere of the salon."
Doctors, veterinarians, chiropractors, even psychiatrists are making home visits. Susan Estep, a massage therapist at a chiropractor's office in New Hyde Park, said she earns a large portion of her income traveling with her massage table to people's homes.
"Most of my clients are overworked and stressed out," she explained. "When the recession hit, my business really picked up. People that decided to save their money and not take their vacations were really stressed out about it. That made them tense, so they used the money they saved to get a massage."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Suburbanites in the metropolitan area are finding that they can get many services at home, often for no more than it would cost elsewhere. Nicholas Martielli, right, gave scuba diving lessons recently to John Christy at Mr. Martielli's pool. (Lois Raimondo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: Will Mattresses Take Their Lumps?;
And Now the Innkeepers Are Critiquing the Rooms

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Move over Mobil and the American Automobile Association, a new entrant will start rating hotels: Days Inn of America, the economy chain that says it is the nation's largest hotel franchiser.
But instead of awarding lodging properties one to five stars (as do Mobil's guides) or one to five diamonds (A.A.A.'s Tour Books), Days Inn -- in keeping with its corporate sunburst logo -- will award as many as five sunbursts. And rather than have independent evaluators rate a range of hotels, Days Inn's own quality-assurance department will rate only the company's 1,400 properties. 
 To allay suspicion that this is the ratings equivalent of the fox guarding the henhouse or employees writing their own evaluation reports, Days Inn said its ratings system had "tough standards" based on three detailed inspections a year. The ratings are based on scores measured on a 500-point system, with anything below 370 points unrated. Three sunbursts or more requires at least 425 points.
Based on incomplete results for this year, the company said, 217 Days Inn lodgings would qualify for the five-sunburst ranking, and an additional 1,125 would score three or more. Thus, Days Inn ranks 96 percent of the properties above average.
"But most of the properties get pretty much the same grades from the A.A.A.," said Brian Feldman, public relations manager of Days Inn. "So it's not just our ratings system." Jerry Cheske, an A.A.A. spokesman, said the auto club awarded only 48 properties across North America five diamonds in 1993.
Days Inn also said it would not hesitate to downgrade any property that does not measure up. "A bad rating will force our franchises to improve," Mr. Feldman said.
The ratings will be published next spring in the almost two million directories the company publishes twice yearly, and customers can request individual hotel ratings when they call the company's reservations system.
Meanwhile, hotel guests might do well to remember that five diamonds, five stars and five sunbursts are not necessarily one and the same.

HEADLINE: Police Identify 13th Body As Victim of L.I. Killer

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 2

 BODY:
Body parts found last summer in the waterways around New York City have been identified as those of a 20-year-old Manhattan woman who the police believe was among 18 women killed by Joel Rifkin.
The body of the woman, Violet O'Neill, is the 13th that the police have identified and linked to Mr. Rifkin, a 34-year-old unemployed landscaper who the authorities say has confessed to the murders of 17 women, many of whom were prostitutes. Another body is still unidentified, and four women believed to be among his victims are still missing, the police said. 
 The body parts belonging to Ms. O'Neill were identified through D.N.A. tests, said Detective Joseph McConville, a New York City police spokesman. Last week, the victim's mother, Victoria O'Neill, and a sister supplied their own blood and other tissue samples for the tests, the mother said today.
 
Three Grisly Discoveries
 Officer Peter Friscia, another police spokesman, said the body parts were found over three days in July 1992. On July 22, a torso wrapped in a plastic bag was found in the Harlem River at East 123d Street. Three days later, arms and a left leg were found wrapped in plastic in a suitcase in the East River at 23d Street, and a right leg was found in the water near Governors Island two days after that.
Mr. Rifkin, of East Meadow, is being held without bail at the Nassau County Jail, where he is awaiting trial in the one murder with which he has been charged, that of Tiffany Bresciani. The body of the 22-year-old Ms. Bresciani was found in the back of Mr. Rifkin's pickup truck on June 28 by state troopers who had chased his vehicle and pulled him over in Mineola for a routine traffic violation.
In a telephone interview, Victoria O'Neill of Manhattan said she last saw her daughter on July 16, 1992, when Violet was staying with her grandmother on East Eighth Street. After her disappearance, the family distributed fliers bearing her description and asking anyone with information about her to come forward.
The mother said that Violet had a 6-year-old son, but declined to offer more details about her life.
"My daughter was a very beautiful girl," Ms. O'Neill said. "The only thing that makes me feel a little better is to think that perhaps she didn't die in pain."
She added, however, that she was upset that the identification had taken so long. Last year, she said, the police had told her that some of the body parts might have belonged to her daughter. But no one followed up until the recent developments in the Rifkin case, she said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Factory Orders Fell 2.1% in July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Orders to American factories dropped 2.1 percent in July, the biggest decline in 19 months, as demand for aircraft and communications equipment plunged, the Commerce Department said today.
Despite the decline and other signs of economic sluggishness in the July-September quarter, including sluggish retail sales for August, the job market continues to show evidence of a slow but steady revival. 
 The Labor Department said the number of first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 7,000 last week, to 324,000, the lowest since the week that ended on Feb. 6. More important, the less volatile four-week moving average of jobless claims fell by 3,750, to 327,500, the lowest level since September 1989.
 
 
Unemployment Report Is Due
 Economists suspect that a report due out on Friday will show that the nation's unemployment rate ticked up to 6.9 percent in August from 6.8 percent in July. But it should soon start to show gradual improvement, they said.
Factory orders fell to a seasonally adjusted $250.2 billion in July. It was the worst decline since December 1991 and the fifth in seven months. Orders had risen 2.9 percent in June.
"Manufacturing is certainly languishing," said Laurence H. Meyer, an economist who heads a consulting firm in St. Louis. "The industrial sector is struggling to even stay flat."
 An indicator of future factory employment -- the backlog of unfilled orders --suggested that manufacturing would not soon be an important source of new jobs. The backlog fell three-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted $457.9 billion, the lowest level since September 1988. It was the fifth drop in a row and the 20th in 23 months.
A shrinking backlog is an indication that the current factory work force is having little difficulty keeping up with the flow of new orders.
Manufacturing has been weak this year, in part because domestic demand has been soft and because recessions in Europe and Japan have cut the export sales of American companies.
"In recent months, export growth has all but stopped," Mark Zandi, an economist at Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa., said. "That's hurting a wide range of manufacturing from computers to chemicals. Right now that's the most significant impediment to manufacturing."
 
 
Better Job Growth
 Even though manufacturing has lagged compared with last year, job growth is better. It has been averaging 169,000 a month, more than double the 80,000 average of 1992. Most of the job growth, however, is at service companies, not manufacturing concerns.
In July, orders for transportation equipment fell 16.7 percent, more than reversing a 14.5 percent increase the month before. Aircraft orders plummeted 37.3 percent after rising 52.5 percent in June. Orders fell 10.8 percent for autos and were also down for railroad equipment.
Excluding the volatile transportation sector, orders edged up two-tenths of a percent in July after a 1.2 percent gain in June. But those back-to-back increases followed three consecutive drops.
Orders for military goods surged 18.7 percent. Excluding the military, orders fell 2.6 percent.
Durable goods manufacturers -- those making big-ticket items that are expected to last three or more years -- said orders fell 3.1 percent. Orders declined 1 percent for nondurable goods.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against Yen; Investors Rush Into Marks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen yesterday but was mixed against European currencies as investors piled into the German mark, convinced that German interest rates would remain high and United States rates low.
Traders said investors were selling dollars and buying marks in part because of lackluster United States economic data issued this week. "It doesn't give a good feeling about the U.S. right now," said Jack Griffin, a vice president at Fuji Bank Ltd. in New York. 
 AS a result of the middling economic news, the Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates low, spurring the economy but also reducing the returns for investors holding United States dollars.
In contrast, the president of the German central bank warned yesterday against a "too rapid easing of our interest-rate policies." The remarks by Helmut Schlesinger indicated that investors would continue to benefit from high interest rates for mark-denominated investments.
Belgium's central bank raised short-term interest rates after speculators dumped the Belgian franc, betting the Government would not be able to hold to its policy of tightly pegging to the German mark.
 
Change in Policy Seen
 The dollar also continued to rise against the Japanese yen. Traders said the market had come around to the idea that the Federal Reserve was no longer pushing for a strong yen to fight the trade deficit. A stronger yen makes Japanese exports more expensive, and imports into that country cheaper.
The dollar was also helped by dollar-buying by the Japanese central bank during Asian trading, and heavy selling of yen for marks, a transaction often done through the dollar.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 105.50 yen, up 0.56 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 105.85 yen, up from 105.72. In New York, the dollar finished at 105.87 yen, up from 105.35 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.5005, down from $1.5060 late Wednesday. Later, in New York, the pound was trading at $1.5030, cheaper than $1.5040 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold and Silver Off Sharply While Copper Prices Surge

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices hit a 16-week low yesterday as the sluggish economy continued to undercut investment demand for precious metals.
Silver futures also fell sharply on the Commodity Exchange in New York. On other commodity markets, copper futures rose sharply and soybeans rebounded. Grain futures and energy futures were mixed, while livestock futures rose. 
 Gold for October delivery dropped $6.30, to $364.50 a troy ounce, the contract's lowest daily settlement since May 11. The more heavily traded December contract also fell $6.30, to $366.30 a troy ounce.
September silver ended 17.1 cents lower at $4.568 a troy ounce after plunging early in the session to $4.38, the lowest price for near-term silver deliveries since June 23.
Silver led the decline on selling by Middle Eastern interests and individual speculators. Light trading before the Labor Day weekend enabled speculators to push silver prices down far enough to set off computer-driven selling by investment funds, analysts said.
The selloff was also driven by Government reports showing slumping manufacturing and lackluster retail sales.
"It's just been a solid two weeks of bad news -- or at least no good news for the industrial sector," said Ted Ryan, research director at the Chicago Corporation, an investment firm.
Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst at Prudential Securities, saw a positive sign in silver's recovery from the day's low.
"It means the funds were doing their technical thing; now we'll have to assess whether the fundamentals take over," she said. Investment funds trade mainly on technical factors like chart patterns and price trends. Fundamentals are basic supply-and-demand factors.
Mr. Ryan predicted a recovery in gold prices in October and November, based on the dollar's weakness against major European currencies.
September copper surged 3.05 cents on the Commodity Exchange to 86.45 cents a pound. Ms. Raptopoulos said the rally reflected perceptions of a potential for tighter supplies in the future.
In energy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, October light sweet crude oil ended unchanged at $17.97 a barrel, while October heating oil rose 0.08 cent, to 53.20 cents a gallon. October unleaded gasoline fell 0.34 cent, to 51.34 cents a gallon, and October natural gas rose 0.40 cent, to $2.406 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Finding a Whole World in 64 Squares

BYLINE: By WILL JOYNER

 BODY:
ON a recent Saturday afternoon in the thick of August, Manhattan was anything but deserted. The humidity was down, the sky was blue and an insistent breeze appeared to have convinced streams of people in Greenwich Village that a good mood was in order, that a distant beach wasn't a better place to be.
In the southwest corner of Washington Square Park stood the 19 chess tables that recently regained notoriety by way of the film "Searching for Bobby Fischer." The movie describes the early playing days of Josh Waitzkin, who is now a 16-year-old international master and ranked No. 1 in that age group in the United States. I was not looking for the next Josh Waitzkin. In the interest of exploring the chess world of New York City shown in "Bobby Fischer," I was simply trying to summon the nerve to play a game with one of the hustlers who threaded through the onlookers, competition clocks in hand, saying, "Speed chess, anyone?" 
 Sixty-four squares to a board, eight pieces and eight pawns to a side, five minutes a person to win. White goes first; then anything can happen.
At one of the tables, three men were engaged in a sort of round robin for a pot of "just a few dollars," one of them explained, with the money going to whoever prevailed in two consecutive games. A man who was wearing wraparound sunglasses and delivering his chatter in both English and Spanish was the hustler here. But the two others, a slight man with a beard and an academic type who easily fended off gibes about his Chinese origins, were clearly acquaintances of his, regulars on the scene.
The three played impressively and for the most part equally, maintaining decisiveness with the clock buttons and concentration on their positions despite a torrent of words that came at them from all around. ("Is he a master? He's a master of disaster.") What was most striking, though, was the respect they showed for one another, in spite of occasional tension. It was difficult to stop watching as they hurried to endgame after endgame, exchanging places and, from time to time, rumpled bills.
Earlier in the afternoon, in a brownstone just a few blocks north, a contest was under way in what is probably the opposite pole of New York's chess world, the understatedly stately Marshall Chess Club, which was founded in 1915 by Frank Marshall, the United States champion from 1909 until 1936. In a second-floor drawing room full of engraved trophies and era-hopping photographs, 20 players were in a competition of games timed at 15 minutes. Each would play eight games, then $175 would be apportioned, according to the players' United States Chess Federation ratings, to winners at various levels.
As these games proceeded, the only sound, beyond the clicking of the pieces and the tapping of the clock controls, was classical music coming from a small office filled with books, a desk and piles of documents. Sitting at the desk, Ron Young, an employee of the nonprofit club, said that Marshall members made up about half of the day's field.
As they finished a round, players stood up from the old wooden tables and quietly surrounded games still under way, or whispered insistent but polite analyses of one another's performances, waiting for Mr. Young to post the next pairings. In the sparely appointed entrance hall, an annotated national ranking of players under age 21 showed that 14 of the top 30 were Marshall members. These included 17-year-old Erez Klein of Forest Hills, Queens, who is ranked No. 14 and was progressing well in the day's event, having won his first two games. At No. 4 on the national list and No. 5 on a nearby overall club ranking was Josh Waitzkin.
 
Reality Behind a Film
 This exploration of the New York chess world began on Aug. 11 with the opening of the film "Searching for Bobby Fischer," which is based on Fred Waitzkin's book about his grappling with his son's gift in the mid-1980's as Josh, then 8, succeeded at the top rung of national scholastic chess competition. It's a story that examines the emotional tug between father and son and the fine line between pressure and support, a distinction I often ponder, having two sons. And with world-championship intrigue already swirling around two rival matches that are to begin next week, this film about the dawning of chess inspiration took on added meaning.
After my elder son, 6-year-old Luke, watched the movie, he said: "Just right, Dad. The best scene is where they kick the parents out of the competition hall and the kids cheer."
Although I first showed him the game, Luke quickly went beyond that instruction last year when he entered the Dalton School, which has an extensive chess program, administered by Svetozar Jovanovic, a Yugoslav emigre who is one of the most respected teachers for young people. Last spring, as we played in the evenings, Luke began to pass along Mr. Jovanovic's advice. I began to take the games more seriously and urged him to pay more attention. But it seemed that yet one more private thing had been thrown into the New York pressure cooker.
My father taught me chess, on a tiny peg set that he packed across Europe as a young soldier in World War II; those games were relaxing engagements. My games with Luke had become something different, and I wanted to understand why. The movie helped, but it couldn't explain everything about what Fred Waitzkin, whose new book is "Mortal Games: The Turbulent Genius of Gary Kasparov" (Putnam), described as "a self-contained little world full of fascinating people who are so needy and brilliant."
On a threatening weekday afternoon, Luke and I discovered a place for chess that was cool and not fraught with tension. The Chess and Checkers House is in the southern portion of Central Park, just across the Park Drive from the Carousel, on a hill above Wollman Rink. There is an actual brick house, which was closed, but in a circle around it, within an open, gazebolike structure, are 24 of the 2,048 stone chess tables the Department of Parks and Recreation estimates are in the city.
We placed our armies and began to play. The music of the Carousel drifted around us; the storm held off, and I proceeded to lose three games in a row.
At a table nearby, two men were playing, with a clock. At the end of a game, they explained that they were acquaintances and often played here together, but never arranged to meet. Joe Green, 50, said he lived nearby and came to the Chess and Checkers House almost every day, and played as a hobby. The stronger player, Mark Crawford, 25, of Flushing, Queens, said he worked in a nearby office building and occasionally came to play during his lunch hour.
As a teen-ager in Kingston, Jamaica, Mr. Crawford said, he played in tournaments and had a rating. He wants to return to tournament chess, but has no illusions about his prospects. "I started at 13, which was not young enough," he said. He inquired about Luke's age and, after hearing the reply, said, "That's the age to start."
 
Josh Waitzkin at 16
 The next day, I spoke by telephone with Fred and Josh Waitzkin, who were in the Bahamas, where their family fishes each summer. Fred -- who has a more animated voice than Joe Mantegna gives him in the movie, but the same focused friendliness -- was asked what he would do differently, looking back on his early days as a chess parent. His answer was surprising, but then made sense given Josh's progress since the time covered in the film.
"As Josh got older and better, I realized that a lot of my guilt was stupid," the writer said. "If I had it to do over again, I'd probably encourage him to study a little bit more, because what became clear is, there are no miracles here. If you're lucky in life, you're gifted in one or maybe two things. Then, it's work."
Josh Waitzkin, who also possesses a friendliness that resonates across a telephone line, also gave a surprising answer. As portrayed in the film by Max Pomeranc, a 9-year-old Manhattanite who is making his own way in tournament chess, Josh is a competitor who can win without a killer's instinct. What about the 16-year-old Josh?
"That's Utopia," he said. "There's a sad truth in the movie that you do have to hate your opponent, during the game. On a higher level, every psychological power goes into the game, to ripping your opponent apart."
This fall, Josh, an 11th grader, will transfer from Dalton to the Children's Professional School, hoping to find a more workable blend of academics and competition. During the school year, he works at chess about 16 hours a week. His teacher, Grigory Kaidanov, a 33-year-old grandmaster who immigrated to Lexington, Ky., from Moscow two years ago, flies to New York every five weeks for a four-day, 10-hour-a-day work session.
A couple of days later, I met Josh's first teacher, Bruce Pandolfini, who is portrayed by Ben Kingsley in "Searching for Bobby Fischer" as a small, hard man who bends just a bit in the face of Josh's amiability. The real Mr. Pandolfini, looking almost as youthful as he did in 1972 when he helped Shelby Lyman analyze the Bobby Fischer-Boris Spassky world-title match on PBS, is tall and lovable, amiability itself. Although he was up against a deadline for delivering the manuscript of his 18th book on chess, he bounced into a Broadway restaurant to discuss fledgling chess parents.
"The key ingredient is intelligent parental involvement: knowing when to withdraw when you're pressuring too much, but certainly pressuring to a point, if you want to succeed," he said. "If you don't show any interest, it's very hard for a child to push on with anything."
Should you let a child win?
"One approach is that you have to show them what is true about the world, that you've got to beat them," Mr. Pandolfini said. "That's ridiculous. What you're actually showing them is that the world can be sadistic.
"I think you should essentially let the child win. You can find creative approaches. One might be this: At the point when you're about to win, you could make it a problem and say, more or less honestly, 'Well, I think I can beat you now. If you can show me how, you win.' "
 
A New Chess Center
 Unlike the Bruce Pandolfini in the film, the real one has brought the game of chess to thousands of children. In addition to writing his books, he runs the chess programs at Trinity and several other private schools, and he still teaches, although to only about eight students at a time.
Perhaps his greatest influence, however, has been through the Manhattan Chess Club School, an outreach program now in more than 100 New York City public schools, which he was the primary designer for in 1985. It reached a special moment of glory in 1991, when the Raging Rooks of Adam Clayton Powell Junior High School 43 in Harlem won the National Junior High School Championship, and is now being used as a model in Dallas and San Francisco, as well as in other parts of New York State.
Since last November, this program, among many for players of all ages and levels, has been run out of the American Chess Center, a slickly renovated four-story brownstone on West 46th Street. This is the new home for both the Manhattan Chess Club, which was founded in 1877, and the American Chess Foundation, a private group that raises money to develop serious players for the United States. The center, which still has a just-moved-into feel about it, clearly represents a dream of what chess might finally become in this country rather than a finished reality, but it's undoubtedly a democratic dream.
"I was optimistic to think that when we had such a wonderful building, people would come running in the door and we would just sign them up," said Faneuil Adams, a retired oil-company executive who serves as president of the foundation, treasurer of the club and United States representative to the International Chess Federation. "It turns out that hasn't been the case at all. It turns out we have to go out and sell."
On a recent night, Bill Colias, a foundation employee who also acts as a manager of the club, was doing an estimable job of selling to several prospective members, on top of running a tournament of 30-minute games for lower-rated players in a large ground-floor hall. In a small fourth-floor room designed primarily for teaching, Nick Conticello was overseeing the first night of a competition among expert and master players who are trying to qualify for international ratings.
On the second floor, sitting at a bank of finely built tables in the building's most striking competition room, Asa Hoffman, who is the same age as Bobby Fischer, 50, and who played speed games with him in the old days, was reflecting on his life as a money player.
"I'm from pre-inflationary times," he said. "I remember bus fare to Washington was $10 and a hotel room was $15. You could really afford to go away for a weekend and play in a tournament. Now, it's hundreds of dollars. It's more a rich man's game."
Back downstairs, in a front room that serves as office, meeting place and kibitzing parlor, Mr. Hoffman -- who was portrayed in "Searching for Bobby Fischer" as a raving chess casualty, much to his bemused consternation -- dismantles a regular in a game of blitz, complete with gently mocking commentary.
On a bulletin board near what will soon be a street-level bookstore, run in partnership with the national federation, the members' ranking of the club reveals that it has certainly brought its competitive swagger from its old home in the Carnegie Hall building. At the top is Gata Kamsky, a 19-year-old grandmaster from Russia who many feel will have a shot at the world championship someday; he is also ranked No. 1 in the country. At No. 3 is the grandmaster Joel Benjamin, 29, like Mr. Fischer a prodigy from Brooklyn; he is ranked No. 3 in the country. (Larry Christiansen, who recently moved to Europe, is No. 2 on the club list, while Boris Gulko, another Russian emigre, is No. 2 in the country.) Mr. Kamsky and Mr. Benjamin will be on the United States team at the prestigious World Team Championship in Lucerne, Switzerland, in October.
 
'Different Dimension'
 In Washington Square Park, the afternoon had worn on and the tension among the speed-chess players had escalated as the alcohol began to flow. The scene was quieter at the nearby Village Chess Shop, a dusty institution that's about as old-world comfortable as you can get.
To the left, in glass cases, was an exotic array of chess sets. A handcarved Polish set was going for $199; a goldplated set was priced at $129. The most expensive was Egyptian, at $5,600. On a couple of tables were piles of boards. At the cash register, Lucien Crowder was helping a couple choose a board that would fold.
To the right, the coffeemaker was on, set against a wall covered with newspaper and magazine clippings from the present back to the 1960's. Chess pieces were set out in wicker baskets on several long tables. Four games were in progress, quietly. At one board, the players held hands as they stared at their game.
In the shop was a woman who had been playing in the park. Her name was Olga Zugor, and she said she was an artist and a fabric designer and a regular at this place. She came to this country from Budapest in 1956, and she, too, learned to play chess from her father. "He needed a partner and had only three daughters," she said. "I was the one."
Ms. Zugor is a member of the Manhattan Chess Club, still plays in tournaments, "for fun," and still has a national federation rating, although "it's going down and down." But her love of chess has to do with something other than triumph.
"It's so relaxing because you have to focus on the board, and the moves, and it really takes you to a different dimension," she said. "But everyone has a different reason why they play. For a lot of players, it's their ego pushing them to get better."
That same day, at a stone table along Riverside Drive, Luke and I prepared to play. Adding his basketball to the bench as a perch, he sat and arranged the black side, his favorite these days. His brother, 1-year-old Alec, took tentative steps around us and stooped to pick up rocks.
My chess games will be with them, for as long as they wish to play with me. Sixty-four squares to a board, eight pieces and eight pawns to a side, all the time in the world to win, or lose. White goes first, then anything can happen.
 
 
Stars at Their Boards Overseas
 The film "Searching for Bobby Fischer" has in its title -- and at its heart -- the eerie nonpresence of Mr. Fischer. In the 1950's and 60's, the Brooklyn youngster's genius awed his elders in tournaments and matches around the world. And in 1972, he sparked enormous new interest in chess when he beat Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union to become the world champion.
When he refused to defend his title in a dispute with the International Chess Federation (the game's governing body, which is known by its French acronym, FIDE), and disappeared from public life, Mr. Fischer took with him much of the standing of chess in the United States. But in the 1980's, chess slowly rebounded in this country, through scholastic programs and the revitalization of the clubs, along with the influence of the dynamic Gary Kasparov, the highest-rated player in chess history. Mr. Kasparov captured the world title from Anatoly Karpov in 1985, then defended it against Mr. Karpov three more times, the last in 1990, in a match that began with fanfare in Manhattan in the Hudson Theater at the Hotel Macklowe before shifting to Lyons, France.
Bizarrely, Mr. Fischer re-emerged a year ago to beat Boris Spassky in an exhibition match in Yugoslavia. Also bizarrely, news came last month that the 50-year-old Mr. Fischer, who faces arrest on charges of tax evasion if he returns to the United States, wished to play a match of high-speed games against 17-year-old Judit Polgar of Hungary. When she was 15 years 4 months old, Ms. Polgar, one of three prominent chess-playing sisters, broke a Fischer record by becoming the youngest grandmaster in history.
Mr. Fischer met recently with Ms. Polgar at her summer home outside Budapest to try to arrange the match, but nothing definite has been announced. Reports from Hungary indicate Mr. Fischer is demanding a $5 million purse, a sum considered unrealistic even for such a widely desired matchup. But preliminary feints and flourishes are familiar to Mr. Fischer's many followers, who are eager to see him play Ms. Polgar but who, from bitter experience, tend to remain skeptical about his plans.
Next week, the world championship season opens without Mr. Fischer and chess enthusiasts everywhere are caught up in an exciting but conflicted time. The throne has been officially vacant since Mr. Kasparov, who was born in Azerbaijan but represents Russia, was stripped of his crown last March as part of a long feud with FIDE.
On Tuesday in London, by arrangement of the new Professional Chess Association, an organization he is spearheading, Mr. Kasparov, 30, will start his own world-title match against the 28-year-old British grandmaster Nigel Short. They will be playing under the sponsorship of Rupert Murdoch's newspaper The Times of London, for a purse of $2.5 million.
The day before, the federation, which has erased Mr. Kasparov and Mr. Short from its list of ratings, will have begun its own championship match in Zwolle, the Netherlands, between the losing semifinalists from its own three-year title-playoff process. They are Mr. Karpov, the Russian grandmaster and former world champion, and the Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman. The second half of that match, which now has a purse of $2.64 million, will be played in Oman.

HEADLINE: A Shepherd Coyotes Are Sure to Hate: the Llama

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTEREY, Va.

 BODY:
On a hillside here in Highland County, Count Dondi surveys his flock, his elegant neck poised, his doleful eyes ever watchful, his ears twitching expressively at the slightest sign of potential danger.
On the steep, partly wooded slopes of southwestern Virginia, where sheep graze in the shadow of the Allegheny Mountains, danger means coyotes. Farmers in these parts have used donkeys, dogs, traps, snares, even night vision glasses to combat the wily predators, to little avail. Now the coyotes may have met their match in an unlikely combatant: the docile llama. 
 Llamas, domesticated South American animals related to the camel, have been used extensively in sheep farming areas in the West as an answer to the growing coyote menace that has decimated many sheep flocks.
Here on a 1,100-acre farm, Count Dondi and his brother Smokey are George and Peggy Bird's answer to the coyote threat to their 240 sheep. Even though the animals' lineage is impressive -- their paternal grandparents are Dr. Doolittle (renowned as a prolific wool breeder) and Grace Kelly -- they do not look as if they could strike fear into the heart of a coyote.
Yet the normally placid llamas are surprisingly effective. If a coyote approaches, the llama will sound a high-pitched trumpeting alarm. It will charge toward the intruder, chase and kick or paw at it with front hooves, and if is really riled, the llama will spit.
Llamas are naturally inquisitive and protective, and once they have bonded with a flock of sheep "they will investigate anything that is different" in the area, said Dr. Donna Matthews, a veterinarian in Luray, Va., who specializes in llamas. "They chase coyotes because it's a fun thing to do."
The Birds got their llamas in May and are still the only farmers in this area who use guard llamas. During the lambing season earlier this year, the Birds and other farmers in the Mill Gap area -- 12 miles south of Monterey, the county seat -- lost about 60 of 300 sheep to coyotes.
"It was real frustrating around here during that time," Mr. Bird said. "One farmer along this road was practically wiped out." But since the llamas' arrival, the Birds have lost only 4 sheep, as against 16 in the previous two months.
Other animals are used as guards against predators. "Donkeys worked better than anything else until the guard llamas came along," Dr. Matthews said. A favorite game of some male donkeys is to play with lambs, but occasionally they play too rough and end up injuring or killing them.
 
Man's Better Friend?
 Dogs are widely used as guards, but they have short life spans compared with those of llamas and need to be fed daily. In addition, to be effective, they must be raised with sheep and have little or no human contact. Llamas, on the other hand, live for about 25 years and can be left alone to thrive on a simple herbivore diet.
Coyotes are a major headache for an industry that is already struggling. Sheep losses to predators cost American sheep farmers more than $80 million a year, one study found. For many sheep farmers, "the coyote problem is kind of the last straw," driving them out of the business, said Rodney Leech, the agricultural extension agent here.
"Coyotes have won the battle so far," said Mr. Leech, pointing out that 26 of the county's 175 sheep producers had given up over the last five years.
But llamas have helped even the score for sheep farmers in other areas of the country. Dr. William Franklin of Iowa State University at Ames interviewed 145 sheep producers using guard llamas in the West and found that 7 percent of sheep flocks were lost to predators after llamas were introduced, as opposed to 21 percent without them. Eight of 10 producers rated their llamas "very effective" or "effective."
Controlling coyotes has become something of an obsession in this picturesque, rural community about four hours from Washington.
A predator control committee was established, and this year it raised $4,500 to buy a pair of night vision glasses, similar to those used in the Persian Gulf war, to spot coyotes at night. Sheriff Herbert Lightner is in charge of the after-dark sorties, a task he relishes since his father lost many lambs to coyotes earlier this year.
 
Lambs Will Be the Test
 The Birds did not have much of a problem with coyotes until recently, because a local trapper was placing snares for the animals around their property. But after the trapper died, the Birds bought Count Dondi and Smokey from a local llama farm.
"We really won't know how the llamas have worked until next year," Mr. Bird said, when the animals will have guarded the sheep through a lambing season.
Llama breeding is a growth industry in the agricultural world, with the creatures becoming increasingly prized for their soft, fine wool. They are also used as pack animals and kept as pets. But while females, especially those with dark or beige wool, can cost up to $20,000, the white males are out of fashion, especially those that do not meet the industry's breeding standards. Many of these can be bought for as little as a few hundred dollars and are the most likely to end up as guard animals.
"Most people think that llamas aren't economical," Mr. Bird said. He paid $700 each for Count Dondi and Smokey, so each llama need only save about a dozen lambs, each worth about $70, for him to recoup his investment.
The unwanted male llamas often come from herds of hobbyist llama breeders, Dr. Matthews said, city dwellers using the animals on their country property as a way of qualifying for agricultural tax breaks.
The arrangement works to everybody's advantage. For the sheep farmers, the llamas can mean the difference between survival and failure, and for the breeders, Dr. Matthews said, guard llamas provide a way of cashing in on "a lot of males that don't really serve a useful purpose."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Once they have become close with the sheep they are to protect, llamas like the vigilant Count Dondi, above, will investigate anything different in their domain, fearlessly confronting predators like coyotes. Count Dondi guarded a flock on the farm of George and Peggy Bird in Monterey, Va.. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bank Fraud Plea Forestalls Questions About Iraq Arms

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
A bank fraud case that was to have been the main stage for an accusation that the Bush Administration secretly engaged in the arming of Iraq and then sought to cover it up came to a surprising close today when the defendant, a week away from trial, struck a deal with the Government and pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Atlanta.
The defendant, Christopher P. Drogoul, former manager of the Atlanta branch of a Rome bank, Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, had earlier insisted that he wanted to go to trial to demonstrate that he had been a pawn in an international conspiracy, involving the Bush Administration, to strengthen the Iraqi regime of Saddam Hussein in the months before its invasion of Kuwait. 
 But today Mr. Drogoul, who had been indicted on 70 counts stemming from the Atlanta branch's secret loans of more than $5 billion used by Iraq for an arms buildup, pleaded guilty to three of those counts: one of wire fraud and two of making false statements to bank regulators.
Mr. Drogoul's lawyer, Robert M. Simels of New York, said the defendant had decided to enter guilty pleas because his family had urged him to bring the prosecution against him to a close.
 
Two Crucial Rulings
 But a far more important factor was apparently a pair of rulings last month by Judge Ernest Tidwell, who was to have presided at the trial and who accepted Mr. Drogoul's pleas today.
In those rulings, which cut the heart out of the strategy that Mr. Simels had been expected to pursue, Judge Tidwell held that the defense could not present evidence concerning Washington's policy tilt toward Baghdad during the 1980's and President George Bush's subsequent determination that economic and political incentives should be used to moderate Mr. Hussein's actions. The judge said such evidence would be irrelevant to the charges against Mr. Drogoul.
Judge Tidwell also ruled then that Mr. Simels could not present evidence that senior officials of the Italian Government, which largely owns B.N.L., had pleaded with the Bush Administration to limit its inquiry into the Atlanta branch's loans.
After those rulings, Mr. Simels said today, "it became apparent to the defense that a search for the truth in this matter was being curtailed."
 
Approval by Reno
 At the Justice Department today, Carl Stern, the agency's chief spokesman, said the plea arrangement had been approved by Attorney General Janet Reno.
"With these three counts," Mr. Stern said, "the Government achieved the likely prison term which would have been achieved no matter how many counts you took to trial. It would have been pointless to go to trial."
Mr. Drogoul is to be sentenced on Nov. 29. Government prosecutors said that under Federal sentencing guidelines, Judge Tidwell was obliged to send him to prison for 46 to 57 months. But Mr. Simels said he would argue that Mr. Drogoul, who has already been imprisoned for 17 months while awaiting disposition of the case, should be sentenced to time already served.
Mr. Drogoul and five other officers of the Atlanta branch of B.N.L. were charged with bank fraud after the Federal Bureau of Investigation raided their offices in August 1989 and found evidence of illegal loans to Iraq.
In the many months that the issue has simmered, there has been little doubt that Mr. Drogoul, in arranging for unsecured credit to a nation that had a history as a bad credit risk, had been involved in the improper lending of money, some of it backed by a Federal guarantee program.
 
Did the White House Know?
 What was at issue was whether the loans had been made with the knowledge of White House officials trying to buy favor with Mr. Hussein, and whether those officials sought to cover up their efforts after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990.
The Bush Administration's Justice Department charged that the six Atlanta bank officers had defrauded the parent bank by making the loans without the knowledge of the Rome headquarters.
But at a tumultuous hearing in Atlanta last September before Judge Marvin H. Shoob, who was then presiding over the B.N.L. case, it was disclosed that the Central Intelligence Agency had apparently concluded that bank managers in Rome had been aware of the loans and thus could not have been defrauded.
Immediately after that disclosure, Mr. Drogoul, charged with receiving bribes of $2.5 million in exchange for the loans, withdrew an earlier guilty plea and demanded a trial in order to demonstrate that the loans had been made with the knowledge of senior American officials working with the Italian Government.
Much of the speculation that quickly surrounded the case was whether the C.I.A. and the Bush Administration had sought to limit the investigation to the Atlanta bankers, in order not to embarrass President Bush, who was then running for re-election, and the Italian Government.
After expressing ever-increasing skepticism of the Government's contention that the trail of suspicion led only to the Atlanta bankers and no higher, Judge Shoob agreed to a Justice Department request that he relinquish the case involving Mr. Drogoul to another judge.
During the Presidential election campaign last year, Bill Clinton said he would favor the renewal of a law allowing for the appointment of independent prosecutors and would seriously consider seeking the appointment of one to take over the B.N.L. case.
But at a sentencing hearing last week for the five bankers who had worked under Mr. Drogoul, a senior Justice Department official signaled that the Clinton Administration did not believe there was any need for a special prosecutor. That official, John Hogan, a special assistant to Attorney General Reno, said the Administration had conducted its own review of the B.N.L. matter and had concluded that there had been no conspiracy by Mr. Bush or his aides.
Judge Shoob, who still retained control over the cases of those five bankers, reacted harshly to Mr. Hogan, saying such a conclusion was possible only "in never-never land." He said it was highly implausible that a multibillion-dollar bank fraud had been run out of a small branch in Atlanta.
He described the five defendants before him as pawns in a large international conspiracy and rejected the Government's request that they be sent to prison. He instead put them on probation.

SECTION: Section A; Page 17; Column 1; National Desk; Law Page

LENGTH: 600 words

HEADLINE: Inequity Seen in Drug Forfeiture Law

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 2

 BODY:
A California state law aimed at seizing the money and property of major drug dealers is increasingly taking assets from people who can ill-afford to defend themselves, a newspaper says.
The San Jose Mercury News reported this week that while leaders of drug rings had learned to fend off forfeitures with lawyers and accountants, the poor, those who speak little English and those who are casual drug users most often had their money and property seized by the authorities in drug-related arrests. 
 In more than 6,000 forfeiture cases filed by local prosecutors last year, 94 percent involved the seizure of less than $5,000, the newspaper reported. The police must report any seizure of $5,000 or more to the Franchise Tax Board. Seized assets are distributed for use among local police and prosecutors.
 
Lack of Legal Help
 The Mercury News found dozens of cases in which claimants without lawyers had to fill out 14-page questionnaires with nearly 200 questions and were asked to produce documentation for purchases, bank statements, canceled checks and a list of medical and dental expenses dating back five years. Claimants can also be forced to undergo hours of cross-examination from a prosecutor.
Seizing the money of people never intended to be targets of forfeiture "is like shooting fish in a barrel," said Justin Scott, a Sacramento forfeiture lawyer.
The state forfeiture law leaves many people little recourse to reclaim assets seized by the authorities, Mr. Scott said. The burden is on claimants to prove they obtained the seized assets legally by producing bank statements or receipts.
"If it's less than a couple of thousand dollars, I tell people not to bother unless they've got some kind of ironclad proof," Mr. Scott said. "And usually, when it's cash, you don't have it."
 
10-Day Filing Limit
 Claimants also have only 10 days from the time of seizure to file a claim for the seized property. Although the law requires the police to give written notice explaining how to claim seized property, many officers wait until suspects are about to be booked into county jail, said a former Santa Barbara County judge, S. Jon Gudmunds.
"They get him in front of the jailer who's going to do the booking, they hand him the notice at that moment, and the jailer says, 'empty your pockets; give me everything you've got,' and he takes the paper out of the guy's hand," Judge Gudmunds said. "The guy has the notice in his hand for 10 seconds maybe, if he's lucky."
Thomas Muscio, Deputy District Attorney of Santa Barbara County, acknowledged that such a practice was possible.
"You're allowed to keep legal papers in your cell, but if they don't understand what it is, it may be taken away from them," he said.
Slight mistakes in filling out often-copious forms can also mean that forfeited property will never be recovered, as one woman found.
Sacramento County deputies arrested Karri Welch and seized $1,013 from her for drug trafficking in 1992 after discovering eight one-hundredths of a gram of methamphetamine -- about the size of a grain of salt -- in her purse. After being released from jail, Ms. Welch had five days to file her claim.
"They didn't notify me until after the time expired that I hadn't signed the form correctly," Ms. Welch said. "I lost $1,000 because I didn't sign the form in two places. I only signed it in one."
Forfeiture claims are often too small, and the process is often too expensive, to recoup losses after paying lawyers' fees and a $182 filing cost, Mr. Scott said.
"Economically, it's just not worth it," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Toyota Unit Sues Its Former Agency

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
Toyota Motor Corporate Services of North America said yesterday that it had filed a lawsuit in New York State Supreme Court against its former agency, Martin Davis Omon & Partners, seeking the return of funds forwarded to the agency for payment of media bills and other charges related to the company's corporate advertising account.
The $5 million to $10 million account had been at Martin Davis in New York from February 1990, when the agency was known as Omon New York Ltd., until June 13, when the account followed four former Martin Davis executives to their new shop, Oasis International Group Ltd. in New York. 
 Toyota said under its contract with Martin Davis, the company had paid the agency in advance for related media and production charges, but the agency left invoices unpaid while holding Toyota's advanced funds. As part of the legal action, Toyota said it had obtained a court order that prevented further spending of those funds on expenditures unrelated to the outstanding billings.
Tim Andree, the group manager of external affairs for Toyota in New York, declined to discuss the amount of money involved, but said, "It justifies us taking legal action."
Joanne M. Davis, the president of Martin Davis, said, "The allegations of financial impropriety are completely false and without merit." She added that Omon had "reason to believe that the actions of both Toyota and certain former employees of Omon in connection with the formation of the Oasis advertising agency were improper." She said her agency "is considering options including legal actions against those parties."
The other Martin Davis principal, Rodd Martin, who is now an executive vice president and group creative director on the Diet Coke account at Lintas New York, did not return telephone calls seeking comment.

LENGTH: 556 words

HEADLINE: Where's the Bottom?

 BODY:
With its only superpower enemy having retired from the global battlefield, does a fiscally strapped United States still need to spend more than $1.2 trillion over the next five years for defense? It's hard to see why. But that's the number on the bottom line of the Pentagon's new "bottom up review," unveiled Wednesday by Secretary of Defense Aspin.
By cutting perhaps $120 billion more than the Bush Administration had planned over the five-year period and scrapping some of the forces and weapons aimed solely at the now-vanished Soviet threat, the review makes a modest start at adjusting defense budgets to new international realities. But the start is too modest to do justice to competing fiscal needs. 
Sure, it's still a dangerous world out there, and it would be reckless and economically disruptive to abruptly shrink America's defense effort to the levels other countries consider comfortable. One of the reasons most of our allies spend less is that they count on us to spend more.
The Pentagon document's greatest merit is that it usefully reorients American strategy away from confronting the vanished Soviet Union toward more plausible regional threats, and scraps a handful of weapons programs that no longer serve any realistic purpose.
But then it ingeniously totes up the costs of fighting regional wars with conventional weapons in ways that make them nearly as expensive as facing down the thermonuclear weapons and intercontinental missiles of the old Warsaw Pact.
One reason for these unnecessarily high costs is Secretary Aspin's determination not to give allies a veto on whether the U.S. takes military action against regional aggressors like Saddam Hussein or, potentially, North Korea's Kim Il Sung.
Given the Europeans' performance on Bosnia, the Secretary's concerns are understandable. But America's allies aren't likely ever to be induced into more constructive multilateralism if Washington budgeters continue to offer them a free ride.
Besides assigning too much of the regional-conflict burden to American taxpayers, the Pentagon's program also keeps alive a number of no longer needed weapons programs. The acknowledged reason is to keep production lines in place, preserve defense industry jobs and ease economic pressures on military contractors. For example, the main rationale for building a third Seawolf attack submarine, at $2.4 billion, and a new nuclear carrier, at $3.6 billion, is to keep afloat the Connecticut and Virginia shipyards that construct them.
This seems to reaffirm the old political truth that defense lobbyists have a much easier time protecting their endangered programs than do those who press for public investment programs. Last month, Administration initiatives like youth apprenticeship, college tuition aid and even adjustment assistance for those thrown out of nondefense jobs were all cut back sharply to meet budget reduction targets.
President Clinton's obvious political need is to avoid further disaffection in states like California, Connecticut and Virginia, already hard hit by base closings and procurement cuts. But slighting more critical national needs is no answer.
Mr. Aspin's handiwork needs to be re-reviewed by the White House and Congress. The security of America depends on a realistic defense budget, not a padded one.

HEADLINE: 'Star Wars' Deception Just Prolonged Cold War

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Robert McFarlane's claim in "Consider What Star Wars Accomplished" (Op-Ed, Aug. 24), that the Strategic Defense Initiative was designed to bring the Soviet Union to its knees and that it helped do so, is as much a fantasy as "Star Wars" itself. 
 As to the design, Ronald Reagan did not present the Strategic Defense Initiative as a way to gain "even greater political and economic leverage" over the Soviets, as his former national security adviser may have seen it, but as a way to end reliance on "mutual assured destruction" by making nuclear weapons "impotent and obsolete." He even offered to share the benefits with the Soviets.
Mr. McFarlane now seems to imply that the Administration's rationale was an artful deception, not just of the Soviet Union but also of the American electorate. If he is right, this is an even more serious disclosure than the report that a critical Strategic Defense Initiative test was rigged with the knowledge of high Reagan Administration officials.
The claim that the Strategic Defense Initiative hastened the collapse of the Soviet system by five years (which Mr. McFarlane attributes to a former Soviet official), saving us $100 billion in defense spending, is one of those propositions that can neither be verified nor falsified because they are gross oversimplifications.
Already under Yuri Andropov, the Soviet leader in 1982-84, the Politburo recognized that its command economy was falling behind the West's market systems. Investment would have shifted to the civil sector sooner had the Reagan military buildup, including the Strategic Defense Initiative, not allowed Soviet generals to object that lower military spending would compromise security.
Although Soviet weapons experts advised that the Strategic Defense Initiative could not provide an impenetrable defense, the leadership feared that the general buildup would improve the West's offensive capacities to jeopardize strategic parity. All these considerations helped generate the "new thinking" under Mikhail S. Gorbachev that led to "perestroika" and to willingness to negotiate cutbacks in levels of nuclear weapons.
The subsequent Soviet implosion was due far more to internal developments, including the reforms themselves, than to any of the policies of the Reagan Administration. It caught Mr. Reagan by surprise as much as the rest of us. Any credit he deserves for it hardly vitiates the blame he bears for helping saddle us with a crippling deficit, partly to pay for a strategic military buildup we now know was not needed to match anything the Soviets were doing.
In any case, what Mr. McFarlane's praise for the supposed political benefits of the Strategic Defense Initiative does not alter is that the program altogether failed to achieve its technological objectives. Had the $30 billion wasted on the Strategic Defense Initiative been spent to upgrade our civil technology and work force skills, the cold war would still be over, and our economy would be a lot healthier than it is now.
 
SANFORD LAKOFF
LaJolla, Calif., Aug. 24, 1993
 
The writer is co-author of "A Shield in Space: Technology, Politics, and the Strategic Defense Initiative."

HEADLINE: Ukraine Agrees to Allow Russians To Buy Fleet and Destroy Arsenal

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Faced with a deepening economic crisis and a heavy debt to Russia for oil and gas, President Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine agreed today to let Russia buy Ukraine's share of the disputed Black Sea Fleet, and to dismantle the nuclear weapons remaining on Ukrainian territory, in return for the uranium extracted from their warheads.
Mr. Kravchuk's agreement with President Boris N. Yeltsin marked a sharp rollback in Ukraine's ambitions for equal status with its giant and powerful neighbor. But the accords need to be approved by both the Russian and Ukrainian Parliaments, and such action is not necessarily preordained. 
 Ukraine's concessions on the Black Sea Fleet, one of the most contentious and emotional issues to divide the Slavic neighbors, would return the fleet to Russian ownership. The transfer of the 176 nuclear missiles to Russia would end any further Ukrainian claims to nuclear status but allow the country to use uranium from the warheads as fuel for nuclear power plants.
 
U.S. Disarmament Efforts
 The United States has pressed Ukraine to turn over its missiles to Russia and not seek to become a nuclear power on its own. The United States has offered to help defray the costs of Russian disarmament, and presumably a Ukrainian decision to go along on the nuclear plan would help persuade Washington to be more generous in its aid to Ukraine.
The Black Sea fleet has about 350 ships, as well as aircraft, and has about 70,000 sailors. In the Soviet era, it was one of the most important wings of the armed forces, projecting the Soviet Union's presence into the Mediterranean.
At their last meeting, Mr. Kravchuk and Mr. Yeltsin had agreed to split the fleet in half by 1995, but that plan ran into difficulties, particularly from a predominantly Russian officer corps for whom the fleet, founded by Catherine the Great, is an integral part of Russia's historical legacy.
 
Many Details Unclear
 The current agreement was reached after a day of talks at Massandra, a mountain resort in the Crimea, a peninsula in the Black Sea. It was the fifth such meeting between the two leaders in two years.
Many details of the agreement are unclear, in particular, the terms of Russia's rental of the fleet's home port, the naval base at Sevastopol on the Crimean peninsula. But as Mr. Yeltsin made clear at a news conference after the meeting, if the accord is approved, the fleet will belong to Russia, although it may also be charged with guarding the Ukrainian coast.
"We agreed that Russia would buy out half of the fleet," said Mr. Yeltsin. "Russian payment for its share of the fleet will be counted against Ukrainian debts to Russia. If the balance is then in Ukraine's favor, then Russia will pay."
The Russian and Ukrainian Parliaments never had a chance to vote on the last agreement reached by Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Kravchuk. At Massandra today, Mr. Kravchuk said that the previous agreement to split the fleet had not been a mistake, but rather the reflection of an earlier set of circumstances.
In Kiev, the capital, the head of the Foreign Affairs Committee in the Ukrainian Parliament worried that Ukraine was sacrificing too much.
"In my mind, I can understand that it should be done," said Dmytro Pavlychko, speaking about the sale of the fleet, "but in my heart, I feel we have retreated too far."
"It was not a compromise, but almost a capitulation," said Mr. Pavlychko. "But we had to do it, we were forced to because of our economic difficulties. We agreed, I am sure, in order to be paid rather than start shooting guns."
In his statement at the news conference today, Mr. Kravchuk emphasized that the use of Sevastopol would be subject to further negotiations. Mr. Pavlychko noted that "the fact that Russia will pay rent means they recognize that it is Ukrainian territory."
"At the same time, it gives us oil and gas, and that is a big plus," Mr. Pavlychko added, "but a big minus is that Russia will be able to modernize the Black Sea Fleet and turn it into a strategic fleet that could fight or pressure Ukraine."
 
Russia's Economic Leverage
 In recent weeks, while the two sides prepared for talks on Ukraine's mounting debt to Russia, Russia drastically cut back on the gas it supplied to its neighbor because of back debts of about $600 million. Ukraine was given another reminder of Russia's economic leverage last week when Mr. Yeltsin, visiting Poland, signed an agreement that would allow Russia to bypass Ukraine in transporting natural gas to Europe. Ukraine has retaliated against threatened price increases on Russian gas by raising the tariff for gas piped westward across its territory.
Before the meeting today, Mr. Yeltsin's press spokesman, Vyacheslav V. Kostikov, said Russia would not threaten Ukraine with ultimatums, or with higher prices for gas and oil deliveries. But, he said caustically, "independence involves responsibilities."
Mr. Yeltsin told reporters that the two Prime Ministers had reached an agreement today for the transfer of nuclear weapons to Russia to be dismantled, with the provision that Russia then supply Ukraine with uranium to be used as fuel at nuclear power stations. No mention, however, was made of a schedule for dismantling the intercontinental missiles, with an estimated 1,800 warheads, that were left on Ukrainian territory after the breakup of the Soviet Union.
Washington has offered $175 million in aid to help disarm Ukraine. The Pentagon is authorized to spend up to $800 million to help the former Soviet republics destroy nuclear weapons and safeguard nuclear materials.
Russia has insisted that it will remain the only nuclear state among the former Soviet republics. Initially, the three other former republics where nuclear weapons were based, Belarus, Kazakhstan and Ukraine, agreed to hand over all nuclear weapons to Russia. But as relations between Ukraine and Russia soured, the Ukrainian Parliament moved to declare the 1,800 nuclear warheads to be Ukrainian property, and delayed promised votes to ratify the Start 1 arms control treaty and to sign the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons as a non-nuclear state.

Yeltsin of Russia agreed yesterday that Ukraine's debt to Russia and economic crisis could be helped with the sale of the Black Sea Fleet, shown in Sevastopol Harbor in 1992, and uranium extracted from its 176 nuclear warheads.
