HEADLINE: LEADING INDICATORS AND PAYROLL JOBS DISPLAY WEAKNESS

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
In reports raising fresh doubts about the durability of the economic recovery, the Government said today that the number of payroll jobs fell in August for the first time in more than a year and that its chief forecasting index turned down in July.
These and other sobering results more than offset improvements elsewhere among figures released today, including a slight decline in the August unemployment rate, to 6.7 percent from 6.8 percent in July. 
 The index of leading indicators, which is intended to predict the course of the economy six to nine months in advance, edged down a tenth of a percent in July. It was the seventh month in a row in which the Commerce Department index moved in the opposite direction from the preceding month; it had gained a tenth of a percent in June.
 
 
At Odds With Other Data
 The monthly employment report is widely thought to be the best single indicator of the economy's performance, as well as a window on the financial well-being of the nation's households. But today's report appeared to be at odds, at least superficially, with other recent data, including upward revisions in output for the spring quarter and for 1990, 1991 and 1992.
"It's kind of confusing," said Robert T. McGee, an economist at Tokai Bank in New York, noting various crosscurrents in today's labor-market figures.
As is often the case, jitters about the economy prompted a scramble to buy bonds, sending long-term interest rates skidding below 6 percent, the lowest level in 25 years. [Page 35.]
"The economy has slowed here in the summer," said Paul W. Boltz, an economist at T. Rowe Price Associates, a mutual fund group in Baltimore. "These payroll figures really look worrisome."
 
Northeast Jobless Rate Up
 The one-tenth of a point decline in the unemployment rate was considered too small by the Bureau of Labor Statistics to be statistically significant.
In the Northeast, joblessness rose three-tenths of a point, to 7.3 percent, as the rate moved up in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts, the only states in the region for which individual results are reported.
"We don't need anybody," said Donna All, a member of the personnel department of the Dale-Pak Corporation in Vineland, N.J. The 40-employee company, which makes components for corrugated boxes -- a product that has historically led upturns and downturns in the economy -- describes business as essentially flat.
While the shrinkage in payroll jobs, was relatively modest at 39,000, including losses from flooding in the Midwest, a gain of about 150,000 had been generally expected. And not only was there a further 42,000 drop in manufacturing -- bringing the total factory job loss since February to 239,000 -- a gain in service jobs was only about a third as big as the average monthly increase since early 1992.
Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, said the Administration was "disappointed" by the drop in factory and other goods-producing sectors and by too many people being forced to work in temporary or part-time jobs. After a sharp rise in July, the "part-time for economic reasons" category swelled 42,000, one-fourth as much, in August.
But the department's survey of households showed a 409,000 jump in the number of people with jobs, enough to more than absorb an increase in the work force and thin the ranks of the unemployed by 108,000.
Rather than hiring new workers, employers are asking their current employees to work longer hours. Employees were called on to work an average of 12 minutes a week longer in August, driving hourly and weekly earnings sharply higher. Although longer workweeks are historically a precursor of hiring, many analysts suspect that uncertainty over factors like higher health care costs may be inhibiting further hiring.
In addition to the 7.3 percent jobless rate for the Northeast, the regional rates were 6.5 percent in the South, down from 6.6; 5.5 percent in the Midwest, down from 5.8, and 8 percent in the West, down from 8.4.
 
Ominous Situation
 While the July decline in the leading indicators was smaller than many economists had expected, it was viewed direly by those familiar with the work of two researchers, Gerald Anderson and John Erceg of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland.
The often-cited rule of thumb is that a shift in direction by the indicators, confirmed immediately by two similar readings, points to an impending turn in the economy. But the researchers found that in calling downturns, at least, four out of seven negative readings are more reliable than three in a row.
Now that the four-of-seven condition has been met, Prof. James F. Smith of the University of North Carolina said today, the chances are two in three that there will be a business peak -- that is, the beginning of a recession -- within 14 months.
Another worrisome sign, other analysts said, is that the department's companion index of coincident indicators -- those that tend to move with the economy instead of anticipating it -- eased in July for the second straight month after nine months with no declines.
"We've gone for two years now in which the leading index has moved up sharply and the coincident index has failed to follow," said David B. Bostian of Herzog Heine Geduld, a New York brokerage firm. "It's eerie."
The employment report showed little change in the status of most ethnic and demographic groups, but the Hispanic jobless rate dropped 1.2 points, to 9.7 percent, more than offsetting a July increase. And unemployment among black teen-agers posted a sharp decline -- to 31.4 percent from 41.4 percent -- in the last two months. But William G. Barron Jr., the Deputy Commissioner of Labor Statistics, cautioned that there had been no confirmation yet that this improvement represented more than temporary summer jobs.
Although the overall jobless rate moved negligibly last month to a 25-month low, there has been a decline of three-tenths of a percent from the 7 percent rate that prevailed in June and was the average for both the first and second quarters.
Elsewhere in the report, only 46.6 percent of industries enlarged their payrolls last month, wiping out the big July advance, and the construction industry shed 8,000 jobs.
And while the index of aggregate hours, watched by the most studious economists, jumped six-tenths of a percent, to 124.9, the figures were disheartening to Robert Giordano, research chief at Goldman, Sachs.
He said the index almost always rises in the middle month of a quarter. And, he added, not only was the August rise less than usual in this context, but also some heavy-industry components fell. Mr. Giordano suggested that this could mean that investment in labor-saving machinery was "wobbling."
Today's report also showed a 274,000 decline in the newly unemployed -- those out of work five weeks or less -- but virtually no change in the 1.74 million people who have been jobless more than six months. Special benefits for the long-term unemployed will run out on Oct. 2 for workers in 48 states.
Seven of the 11 components of the index of leading indicators contributed to the one-tenth of 1 percent July decline, that report showed, paced by a drop in consumer expectations.
The two biggest positive contributors were a longer average workweek and a rise in construction permits.
Still another indicator, an index of items like the prime rate and the duration of unemployment that tend to move only after the economy has turned, climbed six-tenths of a percent in July, the second straight gain after three declines.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
The number of United States payroll jobs fell in August for the first time in more than a year, and the Government's chief forecasting index turned down in July. These and other sobering results more than offset economic improvements elsewhere, including a slight decline in the August unemployment rate, to 6.7 percent from 6.8 percent in July. [Page 1.] The jobless rate rose slightly in New York and New Jersey, but remained unchanged in New York City. [47.] 
Long-term interest rates broke through 6 percent, with the 30-year Treasury bond closing at 5.94 percent. The long bond and shorter-maturity debt moved on further bad news on growth and good news on inflation. [35.]
The drop in the 30-year Treasury bond's yield is a sign of near-consensus that the American economy is hunkering down for a long period of stable prices and tepid growth. [1.]
President Clinton pushed his "School-to-Work Opportunities Act," a measure that would provide development grants for states to create training programs to help students make a more successful transition from school to the work place. [A8.]
 
Companies
Sales of domestic cars and light trucks continued their steady rise in late August, gaining 19.7 percent from a year earlier. Many dealers said low inventories kept them from selling more vehicles. [35.]
Advanced Micro Devices' stock fell after the company disclosed that its "cleanroom" version of Intel's 486-series computer microprocessor was not so clean after all. [35.]
A Federal judge in Los Angeles struck a blow against diversion, the migration of luxury goods into discount stores. [37.]
Dial Page is merging with other two-way radio makers to create wireless communications intended to compete with cellular telephones. [37.]
Browning Ferris agreed to buy Los Angeles County's largest trash hauler in a $500 million deal. [37.]
UAL suspended the sale of its flight kitchens to speed up an effort by its unions to put together a buyout proposal. [37.]
Airlines and the Government are doing little to reverse growing dangers of flying, Ralph Nader charges in a new book. [9.]
Executive Life's assets will be transferred to French investors in a deal that will provide full value to most policyholders. [37]
Air-India posted a record profit despite disruptions caused by the travel of Government leaders. [37.]
 
International
Volkswagen's supervisory-board chief indicated support for the company's embattled chief of production. [35.]
Some British aristocrats are offering themselves as well as their castles and manors to the corporate world. [35.]
 
Markets
Stocks gained in moderate trading as the bond market's rally kept equities afloat. [36.]
The dollar fell sharply against the mark because of expectations that United States interest rates would remain low. [46.]
Oil prices finished lower, ending a bearish week in which prices declined $1 a barrel. [46.]
 
Your Money
People should deal with their older relatives' finances before a crisis develops, experts urge. [33.]
A growing breed of investment strategists favors broad diversification and cautions that the credit markets cannot continue to deliver terrific returns. [33.]
Some tax advice for students and their parents in dealing with the Internal Revenue Service. [34.]

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 7.83 for Day But Slips 6.70 for Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were up modestly on moderate volume ahead of Labor Day, as weakness in the European markets carried into early trading yesterday in the United States. But a strong rally in the bond market on weaker-than-expected employment data for August kept equities afloat.
Long-term interest rates slipped below 6 percent for the first time, making the return on investment in equities more attractive and limiting the downside to the market as some buyers stepped in from the sidelines. 
 Analysts at MMS International, a Wall Street economic analysis and research firm, said the employment data had caused a slow leak in the market rather than a blowout. The perception that the Federal Reserve may have to ease rates to jump-start the economy contained market losses, the analysts said, and allowed a small rally near the close.
 
Trading Is Slower
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.83 points on the day but closed down 6.70 points for the week, to 3,633.93. Only the Nasdaq composite and American Stock Exchange managed to scratch out new highs.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 197.2 million shares, down from 259.8 million on Thursday. Advancing issues outpaced decliners, 1,019 to 890.
Steven Resnick, senior investment strategist at Cowen & Company, said he expected a bullish trend on the assumption that good corporate earnings would continue.
"Our forecast for this year, if your talking about S.& P. 500 earnings on an operating basis without extraordinary items, is for an increase of 13 percent this year and 10 percent next," he said. "This is assuming that you have a growing economy and you get continued benefit on the bottom line from restructuring. And it's not difficult to justify a price earnings ratio of 17 or 18 times when money market rates are at 3 percent and the long-term Treasury is about 6 percent."
Medical issues and H.M.O. stocks, which rallied strongly on Thursday, were mixed yesterday. Merck was down 1/4, to 32 7/8; Bristol-Myers Squibb rose1/4, to 57 1/4; Oxford Health gained 3/4, to 73 1/4, and United Health fell 5/8, to 61 1/2.
Scimed Life Systems fell 2 1/8, to 54 1/4. The manufacturer of disposable medical products used in the treatment of cardiovascular and vascular diseases set up a reserve to buy back inventory from its Japanese distributor, reducing second-quarter revenue by about $2.5 million.
St. Jude Medical dropped 2, to 29 1/2, as Carbomedics, a unit of Switzerland's Gebruder Sulzer, received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to market a heart valve that will compete with St. Jude's product.
Elsewhere in the market, Advanced Micro Devices was down 2, to 29, in heavy trading, amid concern about the company's legal battle with Intel over a chip design. Prudential Securities reduced its rating to hold from buy.
Cami'z fell 1 1/8, to 7 1/4, on news that its merger with Chauvin International, parent of B.U.M. Equipment, which was expected to be completed in December, will be delayed until next spring.
On news of a definitive agreement for the merger of Dial Page and two specialized mobile radio operators, Transit Communications and Advance Mobile Comm, shares of Dial Page rose, 3 3/4, to 40. The combined company will be the third-largest operator of specialized mobile radios in the country.
In Tokyo yesterday, stocks ended higher as foreign investors pushed the Nikkei index to a new closing high for the year. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 133.01 points, or more than six-tenths of a percent, at 21,116.21.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Appears to Alter Stand On Exemptions to Budget Cuts

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor, appears to have altered his position on exempting certain city agencies from the substantial budget cuts that he proposed last month.
In releasing a broad plan for the city's economy and the municipal budget on Aug. 10, Mr. Giuliani said he would reduce the size of the city's work force by about 35,000 jobs, from about 215,000 workers to 180,000 workers, within four years. Mr. Giuliani said he would trim the size of local government through attrition and early-retirement packages. 
 At the time, he also proposed "exempting a few agencies and programs that have already experienced disproportionate cuts," including "critical city services involving children and public safety and parks and cultural affairs."
But in an interview with WABC-TV news, taped on Thursday night and scheduled for broadcast tomorrow, Mr. Giuliani seemed to pull back from his initial position.
 
No Blanket Exemptions
 "I haven't exempted anyone," he said, according to a transcript provided by the station. "What I have said is that in making the determination in how to do the cutbacks, we're going to take a look at those agencies that have already been cut back."
Mr. Giuliani cited the Parks Department and the Fire Department as two agencies that had already absorbed significant budget cuts, adding that they "would be at the bottom of the list" for additional reductions.
"We're going to have to try and exempt them, have to find restorations for them," he said at another point in the interview. "But since no one really knows what's going to happen in the economy next year, what's going to happen with regard to receipts by the city next year, you can't make blanket exemptions in any particular area."
The Dinkins administration seized on Mr. Giuliani's remarks last night, contending that he had flip-flopped on the issue. Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's press secretary, argued that Mr. Giuliani's shift was similar to changes he had made previously in his positions on rent control and on abortion rights.
"I think that Rudy Giuliani ought to be honest enough to admit that he did not know what he was talking about then and that he doesn't know what he's talking about now," Mr. Jones said of Mr. Giuliani's fiscal proposals.
But Richard Bryers, a spokesman for Mr. Giuliani, contended that the Republican candidate had not altered his position on the budget. When Mr. Giuliani said in the television interview that no agencies would be exempt, he was referring only to the requirement he would place on all agency heads to look for potential savings and new efficiencies throughout their agencies, Mr. Bryers said.

HEADLINE: Peronist Backsliding

 BODY:
Argentina's President, Carlos Menem, proudly claims the mantle of Juan Peron, the charismatic strongman who transfixed his nation from the 1940's through the 70's. And with his brilliantly successful economic policies, Mr. Menem has revived the political fortunes of the Peronist movement. Unfortunately, as Nathaniel Nash of The Times reported this week, Mr. Menem seems to have revived some of the negative sides of Peronism as well, including thuggish attacks on reporters who dare to criticize his Government.
Mr. Menem points out, rightly, that he is a Peronist with a difference. Where Juan Peron nationalized, Carlos Menem privatizes. And where Juan Peron won ovations and elections by demonizing the United States, Mr. Menem loves to boast of the "carnal relationship" he has established between Buenos Aires and Washington. 
 The idea has been to revitalize Argentina's once-thriving economy with a new burst of foreign investment lured by political stability and consistently pro-market policies. So far, Mr. Menem's approach has been a stunning success. Inflation has been subdued, a long-abused currency has been stabilized and economic growth rates have soared.
But a shadow has been cast on this progress by the contempt for law and democracy displayed by some Peronist loyalists, and on occasion by Mr. Menem himself. There's no evidence personally linking the President to the worst abuses, but he has sometimes set an unfortunate tone.
For example, he has carelessly appointed corrupt relatives and cronies to high office and has brazenly manipulated the courts. And by officially forgiving past acts of military insubordination, Mr. Menem undid painfully won progress on establishing accountability and civilian control. Now his bitter attacks on press critics are widely believed to have spurred misguided loyalists to physically attack reporters.
There's an easy way for Mr. Menem to refute such damaging suspicions and reinforce his own record of reform. He could publicly clarify his personal commitment to a free and unintimidated press and insist that criminal attacks against journalists and other critics be fully and fairly prosecuted. To Peronists and other Argentines, that could make a big difference.

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: When Workfare Is Just Make-Work

BYLINE: By Betsy Gotbaum; Betsy Gotbaum is Commissioner of New York City Parks and Recreation.

 BODY:
As usual, Washington is a few steps behind New York City. Federal lawmakers have been making a lot of noise about the need for "workfare" programs that would require able-bodied welfare recipients to work as a condition for receiving benefits. In New York, we have tried such a program and know it doesn't work.
At the Parks Department, about 800 welfare recipients currently help clean parks as part of the citywide Work Experience Program, started in 1987. Participants work 35 hours every other week, and can only stay at the Parks Department for nine months. 
 After that, they have to find a job in the private sector or with another city agency. The time restriction exists to encourage the workers to think of the program as a steppingstone, not a career.
For taxpayers determined to get a return for their investment, this arrangement does achieve a kind of rough economic justice: Welfare recipients are punching a time clock in the public service. But if the goal is to get people off public assistance then the program falls short.
As it is set up now, the Work Experience Program offers little encouragement to participants because hard work won't earn them a promotion or even a permanent job with the city. For the agencies involved, there is no point in training the workers, because they will be gone in nine months. This is a shame: many of them lacks skills as basic as the ability to drive a car.
It is a semi-enlightened type of chain gang. Because of the lack of incentives and training, the productivity of the workers is usually low.
Some turn out to be enthusiastic workers anyway, and in better economic times city agencies have hired them as full-time employees.
As part of the Work Projects Administration during the Great Depression, Robert Moses put as many as 80,000 unemployed people to work in New York City parks. In 1936 alone, Moses opened 11 of the mammoth outdoor swimming pools that are still keeping New York's children cool.
In November, the Parks Department will begin a new program that is not as ambitious but that suggests a new direction for welfare reform in the 90's. With about $1.1 million in public and private funds, the Parks Career Training program will employ 250 welfare recipients for a year and train them in a range of job skills, from driving tractors to computer processing to tending gardens.
This will cost $4,400 a worker in public and private funds. The Parks Department is now surveying workers taking part in the current program to find recruits, and we will not exclude those with criminal records or a history of drug abuse.
At the end of the on-the-job training, participants will be guided into full-time unionized jobs at the Parks Department, other municipal agencies, civic organizations and private companies through a partnership with America Works, a private, for-profit organization that finds jobs for welfare recipients.
The participants will be actively at work maintaining parks around the city. This is not job creation (as was the case with the Work Projects Administration) but an investment in reducing the welfare rolls while gaining much-needed extra hands. Participants won't be taking jobs away from anyone because they will be working at tasks that simply cannot be performed with the current staff.
The motives behind the program are based solely on self-interest: the Parks Department has lost 1,000 employees over the last two years because of budget cuts, yet park acreage -- 26,000 acres -- has not diminished, nor has the use of parks, pools, ballfields or playgrounds.
In New York City, the Work Experience Program currently costs $8,700 per person every year, and provides little hope or incentive for participants to leave the welfare system. By investing just $4,400 more for each participant than the Work Experience Program, we hope to be running an on-the-job training program that offers a permanent exit from the system.

HEADLINE: Weicker Calls Special Session Over Patriots

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. summoned the General Assembly today for a special legislative session later this month on the subject of football, specifically the hows and whys of luring the New England Patriots professional football team south from Massachusetts.
Mr. Weicker said the move poses an "opportunity of potentially great benefit" to Connecticut and thus qualifies as an emergency that justifies a special session. It is to begin Sept. 22. 
 "A prompt and clear expression of support for such a transfer is necessary to maximize the probability that such a transfer will occur," Mr. Weicker said.
 
Asking for a Stadium
 Administration officials have been negotiating for months with a group of investors who have said they would try to buy the team and move it to Hartford, in return for a $260 million stadium built by the state. The legislature will have to consider the money questions: how and whether to sell bonds for a stadium, buying the land, and "related infrastructure improvements," as Mr. Weicker put it.
Legislative leaders said they were ready to play ball with the Governor. But they warned that for all the euphoria that the notion of a local National Football League team has produced among fans and business owners, the talks are preliminary and the arrangement will still have to prove itself economically for the city and the state, or it will go nowhere.
"I want to know what the deal is that we're going to have to live with," said Senator William A. DiBella, a Democrat from Hartford and the Senate majority leader. Mr. DiBella, who has opposed Mr. Weicker on several recent issues, notably casino gambling -- Mr. DiBella favored it, Mr. Weicker was against -- has lately been one of the loudest voices in questioning the Patriots proposal.
The plan calls for an investors group led by a former minority owner, Francis T. Murray, to buy the team, which would play in a state-financed 70,000-seat stadium. But many questions remain unanswered. Mr. DiBella said lawmakers had not been provided with a list of the team's prospective buyers, which he described as the most basic of first steps.
 
Bargaining Chip?
 Other legislators have voiced concerns that Hartford's hopes are being raised simply as a bargaining chip to pressure Massachusetts to build a new stadium to replace the Patriots current site in Foxboro, or negotiate a more favorable deal there. The team now has one of the least generous leasing arrangements in the league, industry experts say, and has chafed for years about not getting any money for parking or concessions.
"I do not want to be perceived as an obstructionist, but as a skeptic," Mr. DiBella told reporters in outlining his concerns. "I am a skeptic by virtue of my having to spend $260 million in taxpayers' money."
Connecticut is already heavily invested in sports. In a deal announced earlier this week after six months of negotiations between the Weicker administration and the owners of the Hartford Whalers hockey team, the state said it would assume $27.5 million in debts of the team in return for a 20-year commitment by the Whalers to remain in Hartford. The state went further into the entertainment business by agreeing to take over control and revenue of the luxury skyboxes and the parking garage at the Hartford Civic Center, where the team plays.
 
State Could Own Whalers
 The state could even end up owning the hockey franchise, under an agreement that gives the Connecticut Development Authority an option to buy a majority interest in the team if the current owners want to sell and cannot find a local buyer during the 20-year contract.
In both the Whalers deal and the initial study of the Patriots proposal, state officials have said that the bonds sold to pay for the investments would be paid off through concessions, fees and tax revenues generated by the franchises themselves, and that taxpayers would not be stuck with the bills, even though public money was used.
A state-commissioned study by KPMG Peat Marwick, the consulting firm, also concluded that as major league cities go, Hartford is not far short of the mark. The study, issued this week, said that if the region within 25 miles of the city were ranked among the 10 N.F.L. teams with the highest attendance in 1992, the Hartford market would rank fourth in average household income and eighth in population. About 2.4 million people live within a 60-minute drive of Hartford, which is 120 miles from New York City and 105 miles from Boston.
A move by the Patriots would also have to be approved by the N.F.L. Legislative leaders said this week that they want to commission their own study to validate the numbers from Peat Marwick.

HEADLINE: Out and About: A periodic look at summer in the New York area;
All Summer Long, in One Weekend

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILDWOOD, N.J., Sept. 2

 BODY:
As the sun drops in the sky and the children grow tired and the gulls become cockier, the people who linger on the beach go down to the water and stand in it, sit in it, lie in it, surrender to it.
On the wide beach that runs for miles here, an old man stood ankle-deep in the surf, staring out to sea and massaging his belly, as round as his wife's when she bore their children. A woman lay on her back in the wet sand, knees drawn up, arms at her sides, eyes closed, as if waiting to be swept away. A girl knelt in the shallow surf, each retreating wave digging her deeper into the sand. But she would not close the book she was reading or rise from the water. 
 This is the last week of summer, a quiet time even for resort areas like Wildwood Island, before the final crush of beachgoers comes over the bridges for the Labor Day weekend. It has been a good summer for vacation areas throughout the New York region, a season of sunny weekends and large crowds, and the respite is almost welcome here, where a hot day in August brings 250,000 people to the beach and the boardwalk.
"We're still kind of on autopilot for the end of the season," Edmund J. Grant Jr., Wildwood's part-time Mayor, said as he worried over his crowded schedule for coming weekends, when vacationing families are succeeded by conventioneers and empty-nesters and American Association of Retired Persons tours.
Most of the college help is back at school. The exchange students from Ireland who wait on tables are in their last week. "People double up, work a little harder, and I always say no job is beneath me," said Mary Erseg, who runs the Heart of Wildwood motel with her husband, Joseph. "Our motto is, 'if you see it, do it.' "
Tourism officials say that even as the poor economy led to shorter vacations, the good weather and renewed confidence in the water quality off Long Island and New Jersey produced the best summer in years.
"Reports range from the best ever to the best in five years, since the beach washups in 1987," said Eugene Dilbeck, director of the New Jersey Division of Travel and Tourism. "The big thing is the weather really cooperated, and the water quality has been excellent."
Bern Rotman, a spokesman for the New York State Division of Tourism, said most areas of the state were reporting an excellent season. "People aren't saying 'I can't go anywhere at all,' " he said. "They're saying, 'I still have to get away, so I'll do it close to home.' "
 
Too Much Beach for Some
 On the Wildwood beaches, the biggest complaint is that the strip of sand grows every year, making the walk to the water longer and longer. This might sound like lunatic grumbling elsewhere on the Jersey Shore, where beaches are eroding. But trudging across nearly a third of a mile of hot sand is no vacation.
"Younger people are coming down from up north," Nicky Ripoli observed from his umbrella-rental stand in Wildwood Crest, as evidence that the expanding sands are spurring a migration.
"Up north," to Mr. Ripoli, who is 17 years old, is 26th Street in Wildwood, at the heart of the boardwalk and amusement piers, but also where the beach is broadest. If the younger crowd is leaving the boardwalk for a shorter walk across the beach in "the Crest," a dry town whose hotels cater to families with small children, other herds must also be on the move.
The Wildwoods are a world apart from the rest of the Jersey Shore. In the 1950's and 60's they tore down the Victorian homes that their neighbor Cape May let stand, and a riot of hotels and motels took their place.
The local owners pillaged the world for their hotels' names -- from the Alps and the Aztec to the Shalimar and the Waikiki -- dressed them up in wraparound wrought-iron balconies, and planted artificial palm trees around the pools.
The 1970's lowered the drinking age to 18 and brought new life to Wildwood as a party town. But when the drinking age went back up to 21, the island remained what it had always been, a family resort for the kind of families who somehow never got around to buying that summer home.
Stone Harbor and Avalon had their sedate summer colonies and their beach-tag police; the Wildwoods had free beaches and thousands of affordable hotel rooms and efficiencies.
 
Mom-and-Pop Charm
 "Sometimes I'm a little jealous of Cape May," said Joseph Salerno, who owns the Imperial 500, a block-long motel near the boardwalk. But there is also charm in Wildwood's mom-and-pop motels and their period architecture, even if that period is 1964.
"They're not the quality of a Hilton or Sheraton, but they're not sterile and anonymous, either," he said. "There's a warmer quality to them. With the open balconies, you get to meet your neighbors. I've seen people become friends."
At season's end, the island now has the families who are squeezing in a vacation, getting away one last time before school begins, or getting away for the first time after a long summer of saving or being stuck at work.
Down in the surf, their chairs set in about four inches of water, Mary Ellen Keaney and Debby Ference of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., gave different reasons for rewarding themselves.
 
Conflicts With Sports Leagues
 "My summer's been great," said Ms. Keaney. "This is our vacation for the end of the year."
This was Ms. Ference's first vacation; her 12-year-old daughter, Nicole, and 6-year-old son, Stephen, were in sports leagues all summer. Still, she said, she was lucky. "We have friends here whose son couldn't come, because he'd be benched if he missed football this week."
The Branco sisters of Montreal, Sandra, Teresa and Lucy, first came here with their parents 20 years ago, and now come each year with their parents, their husbands and their children, 14 people in all this year. They rent a house, cook their own meals, and so save enough for a goal of many Canadians, a winter vacation in the Caribbean.
"We always take the last week in August, because it's not as crowded and it's still hot," Teresa said. "And there aren't as many other Quebecers, either. We want to get away, after all."
 
Paradise for Little Suckers
 The beach is so wide that to people standing in the surf, the hotels and boardwalk seem to be another island. And indeed the boardwalk is one more escape, perhaps the last place where parents don't have to worry when a stranger calls to a child; all he wants is for another sucker to spend a dollar on the Frog Bog.
Ian and Sarah Gillespie of Cranford wanted their parents to spend $5 so they could play Boat Tag: they would pilot an armored boat while as many as a dozen people fired rubber balls at them at 90 miles an hour. Their father, John, had doubts.
But their mother, Linda, said it was fine. They were here for a day and a night, and this was their entire vacation. "John had to work through his vacation, so he said, let's come down here," Mrs. Gillespie said. "I prefer the quiet on Long Beach Island, where we usually go, but this is for kids, and they're having fun."
Mr. Gillespie walked up, holding a five-dollar bill, enough for a jumbo bucket of balls. "This is how you get back at your kids," he said. A minute later, his wife joined him at a second gun, firing at point-blank range. They seemed to be having fun, too.

HEADLINE: Enrollment Diminishes At Blue Cross

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
Buffeted by criticism and management turmoil, New York State's largest health insurer, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, lost half a million of the 7.6 million people it was insuring at the beginning of the year.
Empire executives attributed the loss to a variety of causes, ranging from rate increases to its customers' smaller work forces to a year of internal disruption and an erosion in consumer confidence. For the company, which has always prided itself on being the nation's largest Blue Cross plan, the loss is humbling, but its financial effects are unclear. 
 Indeed, in filings with the State Insurance Department, which show how dramatically Empire's business has changed, the company is predicting its first annual profit in years. In January, when it was granted rate increases of as much as 27 percent, it projected a loss of $92 million.
 
Claims Lower Than Expected
 Company officials said the unexpected profit was largely a result of a health-industry-wide phenomenon in which the size of claims for virtually every type of medical service, including hospital and doctor care and drugs, has been running far lower than anticipated. They said the development may serve to hold down future rate requests, and the company's new chief executive officer said that it had not determined what action it might take regarding increases already approved.
Salvatore R. Curiale, the State Superintendent of Insurance, has described the prospect of further large increases by Empire as "nauseating." In addition to the rate increases that more than 100,000 of Empire's 7.1 million customers already face this year is the potential for a further increase of 35 percent now being pondered by the company. The increase would be for those who pay for major medical coverage directly, rather than as members of groups and who in many cases are among the oldest and sickest residents in the state -- people no other company will insure.
The changes in Empire's financial projections are contained within a quarterly filing the company made with the state on its performance through March 31. Surprised by its prediction of profitability, State Insurance Department officials asked the company for a clarification, and in replies, as well as in interviews yesterday, several of Empire's top executives indicated how sweepingly the company's profile and its strategies have changed since its longtime leader, Albert A. Cardone, was forced to leave the company last spring.
For example, Empire's new chief executive, G. Robert O'Brien, questioned the strategy of seeking landmark insurance legislation, which the company had lobbied for tenaciously for years and which took effect last April. The regulation requires any insurance company writing coverage for smaller employers and groups to provide coverage to all applicants, something that Empire and other nonprofit companies alone had to do previously.
 
Accounts Lost
 One result of that legislation, Mr. O'Brien said, was a raiding of Empire accounts by brokers who received commissions from for-profit companies, which Empire is barred from paying by state regulation. The company said it lost 7,000 of the 41,000 small groups in what are called its community-rated pool since the legislation took effect.
Mr. O'Brien also said that in light of continuing losses involving its business with large national companies -- losses that the company estimates will top $10 million this year -- it had decided not to rebid for the indemnity contracts it currently holds with A.T.&T., which cover several hundred thousand people and which will expire next year. Under Mr. Cardone, Empire had actively sought such large national accounts, ostensibly to provide profits that would subsidize losses it incurred as the insurer of last resort for hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers.
According to company figures, however, the national accounts appear to be the only ones showing losses this year while the community-rated accounts, after six years in which they sustained losses of $600 million, are showing a projected profit of more than $30 million.
Donald L. Morchower, Empire's chief operating officer, said Empire would continue to bid for other types of A.T.&T. business and would make a bid for the indemnity insurance as part of a consortium of several Blue Cross plans.
Mr. O'Brien and Mr. Morchower cited several reasons for the significant decline in business at Empire, including ever-increasing rates and substantial employee reductions at many companies it insures, like I.B.M. But, a significant factor for many, Mr. O'Brien said, was "the adverse publicity."
"They don't have faith in the company anymore. Based on everything I know, there is not a risk of this company going out of business. But the perception on the street is it's very shaky."
According to company figures, 80,000 of 685,000 people who maintained individual policies with Empire dropped their coverage this year. According to what Mr. Morchower described as the study of a small sample, "about 25 percent left us and went uninsured."
Mr. O'Brien said Empire's sales force had difficulty in particular in acquiring new accounts in light of newspaper reports that cited the executive salaries and perquisites and questionable business decisions that led to Mr. Cardone's ouster and the company's own admission that it submitted false business figures to the state.

HEADLINE: 30-Year Treasury Bond's Yield Falls Below 6%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates plunged to their lowest level in a quarter century yesterday, riding a rising wave of bad news on the economy and good news on inflation that could carry interest rates even lower.
Although expectations had grown for a drop below 6 percent in the yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond, a yield of 5.94 percent was still an unfamiliar sight to many on Wall Street. 
 Traders and analysts reared in the high-inflation years of the late 1970's and early 1980's have never seen rates this low, which is why many had refused to believe that the rally of the last month would continue.
And even for those who remember 6 percent, this move had an odd sensation. When long-term rates were last at this level, in the late 1960's, they were on the way up, not down.
"When I came to the bank in 1972, the yield on the 10-year note was 6.27 percent," said Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Securities as he looked at his handwritten entry of the yield on July 6, 1972. Yesterday, the yield on the 10-year note fell to 5.28 percent, the lowest since 1968, when Mr. Fine was in graduate school at Columbia.
But as strange as the new levels may feel, both traders and analysts are going with the flow, saying that long-term rates should keep falling.
"The window has not closed for lower yields," said Mr. Fine, who had forecast that 6 percent would be breached. "But you have to be more cautious when you get below 6 percent."
Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers, said, "This is certainly one of the dramatic rallies in modern times," referring to the drop of three-quarters of a percentage point in the yield on the 30-year bond in just six weeks. Since the election of President Clinton in November, the yield is down more than one and a half percentage points.
"So you would think we are due to catch our breath," added Mr. DiClemente, suggesting yields would rise a little and prices fall as traders and investors take stock. "But the economic fundamentals -- subdued inflation and slow growth -- and policy considerations, all suggest there is no lasting threat to this rally. We're not prepared to say sell."
But both those outlooks assume that the economic backdrop to the rally -- low inflation and very slow growth -- stays in place. If there is a surprise on the high side in the August inflation data or the economy picks up some steam faster than now expected, the yield decline could at least stall, if not reverse slightly.
 
Jobs Data Are Key
 The rally yesterday, which also drove down intermediate- and short-term interest rates, was set off by a surprisingly weak jobs report for August. According to the Labor Department, nonfarm payroll jobs fell 39,000 last month while the expectation in the market had been for an increase of around 145,000.
In half-day trading ahead of the Labor Day holiday, the price of the 30-year bond ended up 114/32 , while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.94 percent, from 6.04 percent Wednesday.
Shorter-term maturities fared even better. The yield on the two-year note dropped to 3.69 percent, a low for the year, from 3.81 percent the day before. This sharp move seems to indicate that there are investors in the market beginning to think that the Federal Reserve Board may be forced to cut short-term interest rates if the economy continues to be as weak as the jobs figures indicate.
Combined with recent data that show inflation rising at a 2.8 percent annual rate this year, the slow growth makes a perfect backdrop for falling yields. On the one hand, it dampens any fear that prices will rise soon, which helps long-term rates fall. On the other hand, it helps short-term yields fall because it makes it unlikely that the Federal Reserve will move any time soon to raise short-term interest rates, which the central bank would do if it felt economic growth was speeding up enough to push prices higher.
But the economic fundamentals are not the only factor moving prices higher and yields lower. There are portfolio managers and small investors who are just scrambling for higher yields.
There are others who have little concern about the interest rate and price levels they are buying at. This is another reason many analysts feel that rates can move lower.
These buyers are portfolio managers who have invested in mortgage-backed securities only to see them prepaid much earlier than expected as homeowners refinance their mortgages to take advantage of declining rates. To keep their portfolios with the average maturity level they want, they have to grab quickly for long-term Treasury securities.
State, city and local governments also need Treasury securities for the escrow funds they set up to pay off the old, higher-interest-rate municipal bonds they are refinancing.
"People aren't paying through 6 percent because they want to," said Williman Pike, who runs the primary dealership at Chemical Securities. "They need it for their investment objectives, and they are doing it because they have to."
And because of these buyers, he concluded, "there is no reason to think that this trade has ended."
 
Troublesome Dates
 Determining when interest rates on the 30-year bond were as low as yesterday is not as easy at it might seem.
Regular issuing of 30-year bonds did not begin until May 1977. So only since then has there been a consistent market in 30-year Treasury bonds.
Based on historical data compiled by Salomon Brothers, yesterday's 5.94 percent is the lowest since the monthly average yield of 5.82 percent in January 1973.
But Mr. DiClemente argued that that yield was not an accurate reflection of 30-year Treasury yields at the time. The yield is based on old 30-year bonds sold by the Treasury that were selling at a deep discount to their face value as inflation started to rise. This meant the yield was lower than real market levels, a point reinforced by the jump in the average yield to 6.89 percent the next month.
Thirty-year utility bonds, which unlike Treasury bonds were regularly issued 25 years ago, are a good proxy, therefore, to use to determine when 30-year interest rates were last at the level they reached yesterday. Based on that, the yield on double-A utility bonds is now back to the 6.5 percent it was at in the fall of 1968.
The Salomon reading of the old 30-year Treasury bonds for late 1968 puts their average yield then at 5.57 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Built Vehicles in Sales Rise

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks continued their steady rise in late August, gaining 19.7 percent from the corresponding period last year, when sales were sluggish.
Many dealers reported that low inventories of 1993 models, rather than flagging consumer interest, kept them from selling even more vehicles. "Sales were decent, but inventory was so low we could have done better," said Bob Van Ramshorst, co-owner of Ridgeway Chevrolet-Geo in Lansing, Ill. He said that that problem was easing as the new 1994 models arrived in his showroom. 
 "Right now we're selling as many as we can get," he said.
Inventories are low at many dealerships in part because demand is stronger than expected and in part because some plants have been shut to gear up for new models.
 
Clearance Sales Cited
 "The figure for August probably understates the strength in the market, because inventories are low," said Susan Jacobs, president of Jacobs & Associates, a consulting firm in Rutherford, N.J.
Some dealers attributed the strong period to clearance sales, to make room for the new models, and to low interest rates. "The credit unions are sending out fliers telling people about the low rates," said Curtis Markland, new-car sales manager at McMorris Downtown Ford in Austin, Tex.
Analysts who had been worried that demand appeared to soften in early August were reassured by the new figures. "The positive thing I see is that we don't have big spikes in demand," said Joseph S. Phillippi, a Lehman Brothers analyst. "It looks as if demand is in a steady uptrend."
In late August, sales of domestically built cars rose 17.8 percent, while sales of light trucks rose 22.4 percent. The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales was 6.8 million for the Aug. 21-31 period, compared with 5.9 million for the corresponding period last year and 7 million in mid-August. For the entire month, the rate was 6.7 million, compared with 5.9 million last year.
For the month, total vehicle sales -- including domestically built and imported cars and light trucks -- rose 8.7 percent, to 1,148,132, compared with 1,056,393 in August 1992. Dealers sold a total of 702,507 cars and 445,625 light trucks.
The Big Three lost a sliver of market share in August, selling 67.1 percent of cars and light trucks, compared with 67.4 percent in August 1992. Japanese-built vehicles accounted for 27.9 percent of the market, as opposed to 27.2 percent last year. The Japanese gains came thanks to cars and trucks built at plants in the United States, rather than from imports.
Vehicles built by European and other producers declined to 5 percent of the market, from 5.4 percent last year.
Sales of domestically built cars totaled 201,641 for General Motors, 150,940 for Ford Motor and 51,310 for Chrysler.
Honda sold 50,992 domestically built cars, while Toyota sold 36,181, Nissan sold 24,548, Mazda sold 8,513, Mitsubishi sold 7,016 and Suburu sold 4,040.
August sales of domestically built light trucks totaled 131,266 for G.M., 144,028 for Ford, 91,764 for Chrysler, 10,957 for Toyota, 15,929 for Nissan, 6,413 for Isuzu and 3,760 for Mazda.
While G.M. posted an increase in total car sales -- domestic and imported -- of 4.8 percent, to 210,117, its share of the car market slipped to 30.3 percent, from 31.2 percent during August 1992. Its total truck sales slipped 5.3 percent, to 131,701.
Ford continued to gain its share of the market, rising to 22.2, compared with 21.8 percent last year. Chrysler claimed 8.5 percent of the market, compared with 8.2 percent last year. Car sales rose 10.2 percent at Ford, to 154,212, and 11.4 percent at Chrysler, to 58,772.
August was the 21st straight month in which Ford beat its comparable month's sales, and the 19th straight month that Chrysler did.
Nissan's car sales posted a 10.2 percent gain in August, to 43,864, thanks partly to strong sales of the Altima sedan. Nissan's truck sales rose 11.3 percent, to 20,074.
New cars helped increase Mitsubishi sales by 53.5 percent, to 15,206. The maker's truck sales rose 29.8 percent, to 719.
Toyota car sales rose 5.2 percent for the month, to 69,727, while truck sales increased 31.3 percent, to 40,426. Honda car sales rose 5.2 percent, to 75,759.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Is Flat for New York City

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The August unemployment rate rose slightly in New York and New Jersey but remained unchanged in New York City, according to a Labor Department report issued yesterday.
New York State's unemployment rate rose to 7.9 percent, from 7.5 percent in July, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Last year in August, the unemployment rate was 8.5 percent. 
 In New York City, the unemployment rate for August was 9.5 percent, unchanged from July, but down from the August 1992 figure of 11.1 percent.
New Jersey's unemployment rate was 7.1 percent for August, up just slightly from 6.9 percent in July. In August 1992, the rate was 9.2 percent.
 
U.S. Rate at 2-Year Low
 Nationwide, the unemployment rate edged down to a two-year low of 6.7 percent in August. The Labor Department survey of the largest industrial states does not include figures for Connecticut.
"A broad, sustained job expansion continues to be a tough proposition to put into place," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
In another measure of economic activity for the region, the report found the number of employed people declined slightly in August in New York City and New York State, and remained almost unchanged in New Jersey.
In New York City, it said there were 2,985,000 people employed in August, 52,000 fewer than in July. In New York State, it said there were 7,814,000 people employed in August, 45,000 fewer than in July. In New Jersey, it said there were 3,662,000 people employed in August, a gain of 21,000 from July.
 
Issue in Governor's Race
 In New Jersey, the figures were released as the campaign for Governor was expected to intensify after the Labor Day weekend. The campaign of Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican challenger to Gov. Jim Florio, seized on the figures.
"The rise in unemployment is continuing proof that the economic policies of the incumbent administration aren't working," a Whitman campaign spokesman, Carl Golden, said.
In a statement, Mr. Florio said: "The long-term trend continues to be encouraging, but we are in a long, slow battle for economic recovery. We will keep doing everything possible to create jobs and build an economy that offers good jobs for good pay."
 
Pennsylvania Rate Is Up
 The employment picture in New Jersey continued to be brighter than its neighbors'. Pennsylvania's jobless rate crept up two-tenths of a percentage point, to 7.5 percent.
Richard M. Stein, vice president and associate economist with the Corestates Financial Corporation, a bank holding company in Philadelphia, said the increase in the size of New Jersey's labor force might indicate that discouraged workers were no longer dropping out of the labor pool. It could also signify a reversal of net migration out of the state by unsuccessful job seekers.
Mr. Stein said he expected little change in the state's future jobless rate.
"We'll see a tenth of a point change up or down on a monthly basis," he said. "Over all, even for 1994, we'll see a rate that averages above 7.5 percent."

HEADLINE: Olympus Drops Plan for New Headquarters in Melville

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 3

 BODY:
The Olympus Corporation, the Japanese-owned manufacturer of cameras and medical equipment, has dropped plans to build a new American corporate headquarters on 53.7 acres of state land in Melville, L.I., citing legal opposition from a local civic association.
The decision, conveyed to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in a letter today from Kenji Fujii, the president and chief executive officer of Olympus America of Lake Success, marks the collapse of a two-year effort by the State Urban Development Corporation and Suffolk County to assist the company in siting the headquarters on a corner of the 500-acre Long Island Developmental Center, a former state center for the retarded. 
 Mr. Fujii said in the letter that "the continued uncertainty of the proposed project" and "strong opposition" from the civic group compelled the company to look for another Long Island site on which to consolidate its Lake Success and Woodbury offices.
 
Lawsuit by Owners' Group
 The group, House Beautiful at Dix Hills Owners Association, filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court in July charging that the Urban Development Corporation had overstepped its authority and violated state environmental laws in trying to advance the project on land surrounded by residential communities, including Dix Hills. The state property is zoned for residential use.
Sheila Saks, the group's president, said group members hoped that Olympus would relocate in a commercially zoned area of the town. "Hopefully the state will work with the town and the community in developing a master plan for the Long Island Developmental Center property that is compatible with the surrounding area so as to avoid further controversy and litigation," Mrs. Saks said.
The Town of Huntington, where Melville is located, had also sued to stop the project, but the town and officials of the Urban Development Corporation were near a settlement. "The Olympus action therefore comes as a complete surprise," said Matthew L. Hickerson, a town spokesman.
 
Hearing on Restructured Plan
 Under the Urban Development Corporation plan, the state would have leased the 53.7 acre site to a developer, Ronald Parr, for a $7.2 million initial payment. Mr. Parr would then have built the 234,000-square-foot headquarters office building to house 600 Olympus employees. The Suffolk County Industrial Development Agency was to issue $40 million in bonds to back the project.
However, the Urban Development Corporation contended that the pending legal actions had hindered private financing. The state agency had scheduled a hearing for Sept. 12 on a restructured plan under which the agency would agree to assume financial responsibility for the project if construction was delayed or halted by court order.
In a statement today, the chairman of the Urban Development Corporation, Vincent Tese, decried the stifling of "reasonable economic growth" by "narrow, parochial concerns that some citizens would place above the legitimate interests of the broader community in which they reside."
Mr. Tese said that Long Island "needs to preserve its global competitive stature, and needs to remain a hospitable locale for such clean, responsible, high-technology companies as Olympus."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Ends the Week Lower As OPEC Exceeds Ceiling

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Oil prices finished lower yesterday, ending a bearish week in which prices declined $1 a barrel.
Pressure is coming from high output by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which is producing well above the group's ceiling of 23.6 million barrels a day. Petroleum Intelligence Weekly said output was 25 million barrels a day, with some oil going into stockpiles. 
 "OPEC is increasing its crude supplies to Europe and elsewhere in a battle for market share ahead of the Sept. 25 meeting," said Al Roark, energy economist at the WEFA Group.
October crude oil dropped 24 cents, to $17.73 a barrel, October unleaded gas fell 0.54 cent, to 50.80 cents a gallon, and October heating oil sank 0.32 cent, to 52.88 cents a gallon.
After the close of trading, the American Petroleum Institute said that for the second time in six weeks the United States had imported a record amount of crude oil, averaging 7.9 million barrels a day.
 
New Contract Highs on Pork
 Commodity trading was slow in most markets ahead of the three-day holiday weekend. All United States commodity exchanges will be closed Monday, Labor Day.
Pork prices soared to new contract highs on growing sentiment among traders that the Government had previously overestimated the size of the hog herd. "Traders are finally realizing that the hogs are simply not there," said Dennis Smith, director of research for Linnco Futures Group.
The pace of the hog slaughter slowed again this week despite strong cash prices. Some livestock analysts suspected that the Government's previous pig crop report had exaggerated the size of the herd, although prices declined on suspicions that Midwestern flooding had hindered efforts to market the animals.
Adding to the price strength yesterday was talk that Russia would seek to buy pork through the United States export enhancement program, in which the Government subsidizes foreign sales of grain and other agricultural commodities.
Coffee prices sank, with September off 2.1 cents at 73.35 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Mark On Drop in U.S. Payroll Jobs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against the German mark yesterday after an unexpected drop in the number of United States payroll jobs convinced investors that American interest rates would remain lower than those abroad. The dollar also dropped against most other currencies.
Gold prices were up domestically and mixed overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery closed at $364.50 a troy ounce, up 90 cents from Thursday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted gold at $364.50 a troy ounce, up $1.10. 
 The dollar plunged to its lowest closing level against the German mark in nearly three months after the Labor Department reported that businesses cut 39,000 jobs from their payrolls in August. Traders had expected an increase of 140,000 or more.
"It was like a shock to the market," said David De Rosa, a foreign-exchange director at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
He said that German officials had indicated continued support in recent days for keeping relatively high interest rates as their economy emerges from recession. Other European countries, while expected to drop interest rates soon, also offer higher returns on government bonds than the United States.
 
Move Hurts Dollar
 Government authorities are expected to keep rates low, which is thought to stimulate the domestic economy, but hurts the dollar as investors look to other currencies for higher returns.
The dollar's decline was exaggerated by the thinness of the market just before the Labor Day weekend.
Investors also sold European currencies and the Japanese yen to buy marks.
The dollar lost the momentum it had gained against the yen in the last week, after indications that the United States Government was no longer pushing for a stronger yen as a way to close the huge United States trade deficit.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 105.55 yen, up 0.05 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted lower at 105.05 yen, compared with 105.85 on Thursday. In New York, the dollar finished at 104.55 yen, down from 105.87 on Thursday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.5263, up from $1.5005 late Thursday. In New York, the pound finished at $1.5265, more expensive than $1.5030 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: A Primer: The Forces Propelling Interest Rates Back to the 1960's

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
The earth did not tremble when the interest yield on 30-year Treasury bonds slipped below 6 percent yesterday for the first time in a quarter century. But as economic symbols go, it was a big one, a sign of near-consensus that the American economy is hunkering down for a long period of stable prices and tepid growth.
 "The Wall Street types are all redoing their charts to go back to the 1950's," said John Makin, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute -- back to an era when savings accounts paid 2 percent and inflation was something that happened to profligate foreigners. 
 That is good news or bad news, depending on what you own and whether you are securely employed. With interest earnings on bank deposits barely covering inflation, those living on savings have been induced to take bigger risks to find higher returns. Tens of billions of dollars have poured into mutual funds that invest in bonds and stocks, driving the securities markets to record highs and cutting the cost of borrowing for homeowners and businesses.
 The messages are equally mixed for Washington's movers and shakers. On the one hand, the willingness of Americans to lend their money to Uncle Sam for as long as three decades at just half the rate they demanded as recently as late 1984 is evidence of the Federal Reserve's credibility as a bulwark against a decline in the purchasing power of the dollar caused by inflation. On the other, it is evidence that Corporate America lacks sufficient confidence to respond to attractive credit terms with a boom in investment.
 An interest rate is a price determined by supply and demand. Just as the price of a bag of Fritos represents the terms of the deal struck between snack-craving teen-agers and the Frito-Lay Company, interest represents the bargain between those willing to part temporarily with their savings and those eager to command the use of resources they do not own.
There are many interest rates, of course, not one. Rates vary with the perceived risk that the borrower will fail to honor the contract. The Grace L. Ferguson Storm Door and Airline Company pays higher rates than General Electric. And G.E., in turn, pays higher rates than the United States Treasury.
Treasury rates are sometimes called "riskless" rates because Washington can always create enough money to meet the interest bill on Government securities. But riskless is a bit of a misnomer since it only refers to the chance the borrower will default. Those who lend dollars -- even to the Government -- are taking a risk about how much the periodic payments they get in the future will be worth in terms of shoes or rent or phone calls to Grandma.
 
Eyes on the Calendar
 By no coincidence, then, lenders generally demand higher rates for longer loans: yesterday, the annualized cost of borrowing for 30 years was roughly double the cost of borrowing overnight. But it is often higher because longer commitments are sometimes seen as more favorable to lenders than borrowers.
If, for example, most people expect the cost of borrowing to fall in a few years, borrowers will be reluctant to lock in as high an interest rate on, say, a 10-year loan as on a one-year loan. The last time this happened -- the last time the "yield curve" tilted downhill -- was in the summer of 1981, when the Federal Reserve was in the midst of the battle to convince jittery financial markets that Washington would absolutely, positively not let inflation fly out of control.
The Fed, as just pointed out, does play a role in determining interest rates. But as millions of college sophomores who have struggled through Econ 101 know at least before exam time, there is more than an occasional slip between cup and lip.
As the owner of tens of billions of dollars worth of Government securities, the Fed can influence the interest cost of short-term loans by buying or selling from its vast portfolio. Buying Treasury securities from the public makes more money available for private loans, lowering interest rates. Alternatively, selling Treasury i.o.u.'s siphons money out of private bank accounts and makes credit less plentiful and more expensive.
Such "open market operations," along with a handful of other techniques in the Fed's bag of tricks, give the central bank effective control of the cost of borrowing money for a day, a week or a month. But the Fed's influence on the terms of longer loans is more elusive.
 
How Short Affects Long
 In the most direct way -- and the way things seem to be working -- lowering interest rates on short loans drives down the rates on longer loans by increasing the willingness of savers to part with their money for longer periods. Just ask the hordes of retirees from Miami to Santa Barbara, who have been plowing their billions from maturing bank deposits into long-term bonds that pay a few percentage points more interest.
But this is a game in which the rules can change. At some point, people may recall what happened in the 1970's, when two oil shocks and a boom in grain demand sent world prices soaring. If retirees -- and more important, the professional advisers to pension plans and mutual funds -- begin to fear that easier credit terms today will lead to more inflation tomorrow, low short-term rates could actually lead to higher long-term rates.
For the moment, though, inflation is apparently a very distant worry, and for obvious reasons.
The Federal Reserve has been telling everyone who will listen that it will not casually let go of its hard-won credibility as keeper of a sound currency -- that it is more inclined to tighten credit than to loosen it. Banks, shellshocked by a barrage of bad real estate debt in the late 1980's, are still reluctant to lend. And as Henry Kaufman, a longtime observer of Wall Street, points out, much of the borrowing by homeowners and corporations is merely recycling existing debts at better terms.
After four years of slow or no growth and wave after wave of corporate belt-tightening, neither businesses nor wage earners are in a mood to take chances with other people's money.
Thus, how one views the breaking of the 6 percent barrier depends on where one stands. For those who assumed the 1970's and 1980's were a prelude, it is reassurance that instability is not a new fact of economic life. But it is hardly a vote of confidence in the vigor of the Great American Job Machine, or for that matter in the wheezing economic giants of Japan and the European Community. Interest rates are low because "the industrial economies are going nowhere," concludes Mr. Kaufman.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 33; Column 1; Financial Desk; Your Money Page

LENGTH: 1000 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Looking for Safer Yield In All the Right Places

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:
PREDICTING the course of interest rates is notoriously difficult. It requires getting the economy right, and then timing the market. Who could have guessed that a Democratic President with ambitious social programs would send yields to their lowest levels in decades?
But for investors who trembled as long Treasuries burst through 6 percent this week, a growing breed of strategists aims to provide some protection should yields bounce back up. Foreign debt, junk bonds, high-yielding stocks and municipals are among their suggestions. In general, the strategists favor broad diversification and caution that the credit markets can't continue to deliver terrific returns. 
 Like most messianic longings, the search for higher yields with lower risks has given rise to impostors. Short-term global income funds looked remarkably like safe domestic funds with higher yields until last September. When Europe's monetary system cracked, investors in these funds learned about the currency risks. Faddish, adjustable-rate mortgage funds have also attracted yield seekers, but have been among the year's worst performers.
The standard advice to wary bond investors is to shorten maturities, because going from 20 or more years to 5 or 10 can usually preserve much of the yield with less chance of loss. But now, the longest maturities yield so much more than the shorter ones that a sudden jump in interest rates could leave holders of the shorter issues no better off.
Robert A. Beckwitt, who runs the Fidelity Asset Manager funds, calculated this week that whether you buy 5, 10 or 30-year Treasury issues, a rise in yields of three-tenths of 1 percent over the coming year would leave you with total returns of slightly more than 3 percent. That's about the same as the one-year bill. If rates remain stable or lower, the 30-year bond would provide returns so much better that he recommends it over the shorter issues. As of yesterday, the five-year yielded 4.6 percent, the 30-year 5.9 percent.
Most mainstream domestic debt offers yields and potential price gains far below the returns of recent years, Mr. Beckwitt says. He has turned instead to foreign debt, junk bonds and some stocks. He likes emerging markets, especially Mexico, "an investment grade country, but it's not rated that way," he said. Mexico's Brady bonds, with the principal guaranteed by the Treasury, are still paying much more than American issues of similar security.
Falling interest rates in Europe also make debt there attractive, although Mr. Beckwitt has hedged most of his currency risk.
Junk bonds? The experience of a few years ago was terrible, Mr. Beckwitt concedes -- so terrible that spreads over other bonds remain advantageously high. "People remember Michael Milken," he said, "but the circumstances now are completely different." Yields of 9.5 to 10 percent on relatively sound issues provide a thick cushion against a reversal in the credit markets, he said. Some analysts, however, question the safety of a junk bond market that has welcomed new offerings from Donald Trump.
If a strengthening economy causes interest rates to rise, the improved health of junk bond issuers might still protect the value of their debt. Flourishing economies here and abroad would also lift cyclical stocks, which have generous dividends to boot. Energy stocks, Mr. Beckwitt adds, offer both high dividends and an inflation hedge based on the underlying commodities.
Mr. Beckwitt's major fund, with top ratings from the Morningstar newsletters, has had total returns of more than 15 percent this year. Eric E. Ryback, who also ranges across the stock and bond markets in search of income and capital gains, has returned 14 percent to his Lindner Dividend Fund investors.
Like Mr. Beckwitt, Mr. Ryback owns some junk, searching especially for corporate turnarounds. "We're value players, so we try to find things that have been depressed for reasons we believe are temporary," he said. For him, Dell Computer's 11 percent bonds represent good value from a company whose prospects are better than its press.
Otherwise, he has maintained his appetite for both bonds and preferred stock that is convertible into common, again favoring unloved issues. Both have higher yields than common stock but stand to benefit much more than straight bonds from improved business. His fund now yields about 6.5 percent.
Mr. Ryback has also bought some high-dividend stocks, including Eastman Kodak in the $40's last year when it was yielding about 5 percent. Most of the payoff has come from price gains, to $60 yesterday.
With money pouring into his fund, Mr. Ryback, worried about his ability to place it in a pricey market, closed the fund to new investors in early March. He plans to start a utility fund at the end of September.
Henry Kaufman, an economist whose consulting and money management firm bears his name, recommends not only the foreign markets but also municipal bonds. Depending on their credit quality, municipals are yielding 80 to 90 percent as much as Treasuries, and are especially attractive in view of rising tax rates.
Municipals are also more stable, Mr. Kaufman contends. Their yields have not fallen as far as other bonds' recently, but if the market turns, municipals will be safer.
Even if interest rates rise somewhat -- a quarter to half a percentage point on long Treasuries -- the stock market will remain steady, Mr. Kaufman said. But he sees little chance of the robust growth that could send rates much higher. "We have our stethoscopes out, but we're listening to faint murmurs instead of strong heartbeats," he said.
Rather than lending money to governments and corporations by buying their bonds, those worried about higher rates could always become borrowers. "Buy a house," said James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer. And take out a huge, fixed mortgage. Then, if inflation returns and interest rates rise, "You're paying back with cheaper dollars."
