HEADLINE: Budapest and I.B.M. Make Music Together

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, Sept. 3

 BODY:
When subscribers to the Hungarian Symphony Orchestra arrive for the season's opening night at the handsome Art Nouveau Academy of Music here next month, their tickets, their programs and the posters in the lobby will be emblazoned with the corporate logo of I.B.M., which is sponsoring the season. And I.B.M. is backing a special four-concert Mozart series and a Mozart piano concerto contest.
The idea of corporate support for cultural institutions is new in Eastern Europe and is still treated somewhat gingerly in countries where Communism held sway for so many years. Art is often considered by East Europeans to be sacrosanct and too pure for the incursion of crude commerce. But as a sign of the changes now taking place, Budapest University is offering well-attended courses on the economics of arts institutions, with a heavy emphasis on how to attract private money for culture. 
 I.B.M. says its initiative in Hungary is the start of a trend, and that similar efforts will flow from the financial needs of arts institutions in Eastern Europe and from the need for corporate image-building in these increasingly consumer-oriented societies.
"We would be supporting the Hungarian Symphony even if it wasn't having financial problems," said Balint Nagy, the marketing manager for I.B.M. here. "The orchestra has the image that suits us; it is an integral part of the cultural life here." Just as Marlboro sponsored the recent Formula One car race in Budapest because racing cars fit the cigarette company's identity, so the orchestra dovetailed with I.B.M.'s image, he said, adding, "We are trying to reach the music audience."
 
Innovative Efforts
 While Hungary's arts budgets have not been drastically cut by the Government, they have not been increased to keep pace with inflation. Thus, said Miklos Marschall, the Deputy Mayor for Culture in Budapest: "We have to come to a competely new way of financing culture and we have to do this in a situation in which there is no wealthy citizenry."
Mr. Marschall has been busy for the last year trying to marry commerce and culture. "The writers union came to us, for example, and said they couldn't pay the rent on their headquarters, and they asked us for money," he said. "We said we can't give you money but organized an American-style fund-raising event. We invited leading writers and bankers and businessmen. In this way we're trying to encourage Budapest firms to be patrons for the capital's culture."
I.B.M.'s sponsorship of the Hungarian Symphony, the first of its kind in the region, came after the company backed a special concert last year. "Discussions began then on how the relationship could be developed into a more fruitful and long-term cooperation," Mr. Nagy said.
The company's contribution involves only a fairly small amount of money: about $34,000 to be spread among the orchestra's costs, prize money for the student contest and support for the Mozart series. Mr. Nagy said the Hungarian Government had started to make provisions for tax exemptions for sponsorship of cultural groups.
 
Some Czech Doubts
 In Prague, the Czech Philharmonic, after several years of management difficulties, is in worse financial straits than the Hungarian Symphony. To turn the orchestra's economic situation around, a development director, a new term in the East European cultural lexicon, was hired this summer from England.
The orchestra, like all the major ensembles in Eastern Europe, earns hard currency from foreign tours but most of this is spent on new instruments. To plug a $1 million hole in the Philharmonic's $3 million budget for performances in the Czech Republic, the orchestra's new development director, Penny Steer, is searching for corporate help.
"We're at the beginning," said Miss Steer. "As yet there is no law for tax deductions that would favor potential sponsors, so the climate is not helpful. And recent statements by Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus make it clear he is not favorable to sponsorship."
Mr. Klaus, one of the most pro-business politicians in Eastern Europe, expressed surprisingly old-guard ideas about support for the arts in an interview with a Czech newspaper in July.
"A sponsor says through his behavior that he doesn't accept the state view of sponsorship, that he disapproves of the way the state chooses its priorities and secures the public good," Mr. Klaus said in the interview in Cesky Denik, adding that he was opposed to tax breaks for sponsorship.
But Miss Steer said a debate was starting and Mr. Klaus's opposition might provoke the arts organizations into making "a united stand." Some companies have already offered help, she said, including Ceska Sporitelna, a national savings bank and the country's biggest financial institution.
The Rudolfphinum, the concert hall on the edge of the Vltava River where the Philharmonic plays, was built under the bank's auspices in the late 1800's, so the bank felt a natural affinity with the orchestra, she said. The bank gave a "meaningful" grant this year, Miss Steer said, although she would not say how much.
 
Warsaw Makes Do
 In Poland, the two best-known performing institutions, the National Philharmonic and the Wielki Theater, are finding that their government subsidies do not even make up for inflation. But with the exception of occasional sponsorship of special performances, corporate involvement has not been encouraged. Rather, these two organizations make do with revenue from overseas performances and increased rentals of their halls.
But in the provinces in Poland, where music, dance and theatrical groups abound, business involvement in the arts is rising. One such beneficiary is a new contemporary dance group, the Silesian Dance Theater based in Bytom in southern Poland, which won praise at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., this year. The troupe has received $7,000 or about 15 percent of its budget from three regional banks and an insurance company, said its director, Jacek Luminski. In return, the donors ask that they be identified in the programs and on the posters for the performances in the town's culture center, which until four years ago was run by the local Communist Party.
In Gdansk, on Poland's northern coast, the Teatr Wybrzeze, a repertory group with 36 full-time actors and 12 premieres a year, will lose its annual city subsidy of $80,000 next year. To make up the shortfall, the theater will open a restaurant, a bar and an art gallery. But the company also plans to try to increase corporate sponsorship to 5 percent of revenues from the current 0.5 percent.
"There's no tradition here of corporate sponsorship, so it's something we have to really sell companies," said Ewa Bonk-Wozniakiewicz, the theater's director. "But once they see a Western firm has sponsored us, it's easier to convince them. Our Shakespeare Festival was sponsored by British Airways."
"True corporate sponsorship is sort of selling out," she added. "But I would rather commercialize art a little than close down altogether."

And Bear In Mind
(Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
CRAZY IN ALABAMA, by Mark Childress. (Putnam, $22.95.) Southern American humor yet again, but in a novel that pounds every convention of the genre into submission; not even the dead bodies interfere with the funniness.
"DADDY'S GONE TO WAR": The Second World War in the Lives of America's Children, by William M. Tuttle Jr. (Oxford University, $30.) A historian finds that some "home front children" still feel indoctrinated in fright and hate, while others believe the war enhanced their understanding of this country and its culture.
EPSTEIN: Artist Against the Establishment, by Stephen Gardiner. (Viking, $35.) This polemical book defends at every point a major artist who all his life defied bourgeois conformity yet managed to die the proprietor of a knighthood.
FOXFIRE: Confessions of a Girl Gang, by Joyce Carol Oates. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $21.) A dark and troubled epic of women who revenge themselves on men, set in the slow-witted 1950's, before female bonding had been discovered.
THE KOMMANDANT'S MISTRESS, by Sherri Szeman. (HarperCollins, $17.50.) A powerful novel, forged from refractory materials: the personal narratives of a death camp commander and the Jewish woman he chose as his mistress.
LET THE SEA MAKE A NOISE . . .: A History of the North Pacific From Magellan to MacArthur, by Walter A. McDougall. (Basic Books, $30.) Lively narrative, bold analysis and prodigious research adorn this popular history of a vast sea surrounded by mutually mistrustful peoples.
SADE: A Biography, by Maurice Lever. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) A life of the French aristocrat and novelist (1740-1814) so wicked they renamed wickedness in his honor, so to speak.
SECOND SIGHT, by Robert V. Hine. (University of California, $20.) A splendid, highly literate personal account by the fortunate recipient of a miracle, a distinguished historian who slowly lost his eyesight and suddenly got it back.
SIGNS OF DEVOTION: Stories, by Maxine Chernoff. (Simon & Schuster, $19.) Smart, antic short stories in which people understand new experiences by recalling old ones, and the trivial is examined until its importance transpires.
STRIP TEASE, by Carl Hiaasen. (Knopf, $21.) The author, a reporter for The Miami Herald, delights to foul his front yard in hilarious fiction. What a horrible place! One nice woman in the book only makes things worse, the poor thing.
THEIRS WAS THE KINGDOM: Lila and DeWitt Wallace and the Story of the Reader's Digest, by John Heidenry. (Norton, $29.95.) A hugely detailed, engagingly written history of a single bright idea and the preacher's kids who ran that idea into a multibillion-dollar global enterprise.
THE WRESTLER'S CRUEL STUDY, by Stephen Dobyns. (Norton, $22.95.) Probability has no place in this entertaining post-modern novel, governed by the presence of a wrestler's manager who talks and thinks like Nietzsche.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 19; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1119 words

HEADLINE: CRIME

BYLINE: By Marilyn Stasio

 BODY:
The company's in trouble, the power brokers are ruthless, the players are greedy, and the investors are nervous. But hold on, here -- it's a Broadway show, not a brokerage house, that Annette Meyers is clobbering in MURDER: THE MUSICAL (Perfect Crime/Doubleday, $18.50), the juiciest of her five witty mysteries featuring Leslie Wetzon, the ethical half of Smith & Wetzon, a Wall Street headhunting firm.
Wetzon's friendship with a Broadway choreographer takes her uptown to the Imperial Theater for the gypsy run-through of "Hotshot: The Musical," a ritual rehearsal for industry insiders that we never get to see because the production stage manager is found murdered in the mezzanine. For her friend's sake, Wetzon sticks with the show during its tempest-tossed tryout in Boston, where two more murders inspire extravagant displays of artistic temperament from members of the high-strung company. 
 The show's producer-director, a flamboyant artiste described with affectionate malice as "selfish, manipulative, egomaniacal and not a little crazy" (not to mention "sadistic" and "notoriously ambivalent about women"), would easily win any Tony Award given for offstage tantrums. Ms. Meyers, who once worked for the director Harold Prince, provides plenty of dish to keep readers who are either in the know or out of the loop laughing up their sleeves.
In FOURSOME (Pocket Books, $20), the eighth detective story in a terrific series about a Boston private eye named John Cuddy, Jeremiah Healy uses a gruesome murder case to examine the territorial antagonisms of people who think they get along just fine with neighbors who have different beliefs. Called to Maine to help in the defense of a young executive who is accused of using a crossbow to kill his wife and the couple who were their best friends, Cuddy learns that everyone on the tranquil lake where his client kept a summer home loathed the foursome for exercising their yuppie values so conspicuously in this unspoiled place. The detective encounters more naked animosity in the Boston suburb where the two couples lived side by side, and at the defense plant on Route 128 where his client was working on a big weapons deal.
Mr. Healy's prose grows increasingly eloquent with each trip that Cuddy takes into the Maine woods, which are teeming with loons and eagles and herons and hawks, along with some taciturn natives who treat these creatures with more respect than they pay weekenders from Boston. Entranced by it all, Cuddy finds out the hard way that "nature for all her glory can be a damned dangerous thing."
Christmas in Yorkshire is a natural for Peter Robinson's polished descriptive style: the log fire in the hearth, the tree lights in the window, the Vivaldi cantata on the turntable, the body on the couch. "It was a shame," Chief Inspector Alan Banks thinks in PAST REASON HATED (Scribners, $20), "that such a glorious and transcendent piece of music should be associated with such a bloody deed."
Mr. Robinson's erudite detective tends to notice incongruities like a piece of music that is out of context or a bit of behavior that is out of character. Banks is methodical -- let's call it slow -- about finding out who killed Caroline Hartley, a pretty, vivacious young woman who was well liked by just about everyone in the market town of Eastvale, except her lesbian lover's former husband. But by collecting his thoughts on the odd, intriguing details of the case, Banks comes up with keen psychological insights into the dead woman and the secrets in her past.
The author's characterizations are unfailingly sharp and subtle. But even when he just seems to be taking us for a leisurely ride around Yorkshire, where Christmas carolers sing in the square and a winter sea batters the shore, Mr. Robinson is always looking for the little signs of evil that can give away a town like Eastvale.
Puzzle fiends who enjoy banging their heads against a good riddle should enjoy MURDER IN MINIATURE: The Short Stories of Leo Bruce (Academy Chicago, $20). Most of these 28 classic teasers, compiled by B. A. Pike, were written by Bruce (the pseudonym of Rupert Croft-Cooke, who died in 1979) in the 1950's for a London evening newspaper, which is probably why you can measure their reading time in quick subway stops.
As cunning as they are economical, these brisk little narratives illustrate clever ways to shed a spouse and ingenious methods for the premature collection of an inheritance. But the tales are as comforting in tone as they are disquieting in subject matter. "Women don't get murdered for their handbags in England," declares Sergeant Grebe, a village copper who acts with intelligence on his lamentably outmoded convictions. "I don't think that even now this country has reached a point where women can be murdered for the sake of a few pounds."
Although the plot's the thing in this collection, some stories are enhanced by the flat-footed appeal and common-sensical methods of a detective named Sergeant Beef. With his disdain for "your ritzy types with titles and private incomes," this "ordinary sort of chap" was the author's droll comment on the snob-sleuths of contemporaries like Christie and Sayers. Bully for Beef.
Funnier and sadder than a dancing bear, Paco Ignacio Taibo 2d's NO HAPPY ENDING (Mysterious Press/Warner, $17.95) makes merry reading, in William I. Neuman's snappy translation, until you get its political message and feel the existential pain of its hero. Hector Belascoaran Shayne, the private eye who calls himself an "independent detective" working for "strange and revolutionary reasons" in this remarkable series, suspects a macabre practical joke when he discovers a corpse, dressed in the costume of a Roman centurion, in the bathroom of his Mexico City office. After a second corpse turns up, Shayne traces the dead men to their onetime employer, an escape artist named Zorak who was killed while performing one of his daredevil stunts.
Shayne is intrigued and a bit charmed by the "uniquely Mexican" nature of Zorak's celebrity, "a glory bordering on the ridiculous: ephemeral, commercialized, prostituted." But Shayne sinks a little deeper into his customary state of melancholia once he connects Zorak to the Halcones, a para military arm of the Government long associated with violent repression and secretly growing in strength. "His only chance for survival," Shayne has always known, "was to accept the chaos and quietly become one with it." But this time his credo is not enough to keep this good man from plunging into total despair, and Mr. Taibo leaves us with the awful feeling that his hero and his country, like Zorak, may have fallen all the way to hell.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 5, 1993

SECTION: Section 6; Page 18; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3641 words

HEADLINE: Fishing With Presidents

BYLINE: By Howell Raines; Howell Raines is the editorial page editor of The New York Times. This article is adapted from his book "Fly Fishing Through the Midlife Crisis," to be published this month by William Morrow.

 BODY:
George Bush invited me to go fishing.
It happened because I saw a report on CNN that showed him fly-fishing from a boat on a stream near Kennebunkport. It seems there are a few sea-run browns in the headwaters of one of the coastal streams there. I thought Bush threw a pretty good line, so in the middle of 1991, I wrote him and requested an interview about fly-fishing. The recession was just taking hold. I was curious, among other things, to see if Bush was going to develop a Hoover problem, casting happily while the economy and his political support went to hell. 
 I got back a very nice letter, dated Aug. 8, 1991.
"Dear Howell:
"I am flattered that you would like to have my experiences on fly-fishing -- flattered because I am not a good fly-fisherman at all. I like the sport, but I have only done it a couple of times: once with Jim Baker in Wyoming, and once with Alan Simpson, also in Wyoming. I've got some outstanding reels and fly rods, but what I lack is fly-fishing experience."
He went on to describe his fondness for catching bluefish off the Maine coast: "We take them on bait-casting reels and light rods and 12-pound test line." Bush said he would be happy to be interviewed about his "enthusiasm for fishing generally," but I should not take that film clip as evidence of expertise in my favorite branch of the sport. "The point of all this is that I would not be a good subject for even half a chapter for any book if the topic is fly-fishing."
The letter impressed me in one way and gave me pause in another. I admired the President's candor about his fly-fishing experience, his preference for light tackle and the general modesty of his tone. But I was taken aback by the news that Alan Simpson, the Republican Senator from Wyoming, was a fly-fisherman. So much for the ennobling influence of the sport. During Bush's term, Simpson established himself as the meanest man in the Senate. True, his hatefulness had a kind of Dickensian grandeur. But there was no way you could follow his rantings about women, the environment and civil rights and still believe that fly-fishing in the mighty temple of the Rockies is guaranteed to purify the soul.
SPEAKING OF SOULS, HERBERT HOOVER WROTE A book entitled "Fishing for Fun -- and to Wash Your Soul." He was a surprisingly spiritual man, but like Bush, he had a politically fatal attachment to the idea of the Presidency as a passive stewardship. I think history will remember both as well-meaning men who did not understand that the President must be an active guardian of the people's welfare, more attuned in hard times to the suffering of the poor than to guarding the economic pieties by which the wealth of their class is preserved. Neither seemed to grasp the lesson of Franklin Roosevelt's Presidency. The stability of American society depends less on defending the rich against imaginary threats than on providing a decent standard of living for the unfortunate. If Bush had been as worried about the fact that he could see homeless people in Lafayette Park from his bedroom window as he was about lowering the capital-gains tax, he would still be President. Similarly, if Hoover had been as concerned about hunger in Alabama as he was about the depth of trout pools on the Rapidan, he might have won a second term.
The fact is, the Rapidan is a river that can make people greedy. To see it is to want to possess it. So it was with Hoover when he first came in 1929 to the deep hollow between Fork Mountain and Double Top Mountain on the eastern flank of the Blue Ridge. This is where the Rapidan plunges through a hemlock forest and through gray boulders that jut from the ferny earth like the aboriginal bones of old Virginia.
In no time, a crew of 500 marines was splitting the silence with bulldozers and hammers. Camp Hoover became a layout of a dozen cabins, barracks for 250 men and riding stables. Hoover liked to think big. The marines carted in 51 tons of boulders for a single fireplace in the President's lodge. By 1930, plans were under way for a 100,000-trout hatchery on the river bank.
A few Democrats grumbled about this use of tax money to create a private, 164-acre playground, but Hoover assured them that he had done his part. He had paid $5 an acre for the land and chipped in $15,000 worth of lumber for the Marine carpenters. As for the road building, the White House explained that this was a training exercise that the President had generously allowed to take place on his land.
Hoover delighted in making members of his Cabinet and distinguished visitors like Charles Lindbergh join him in building rock dams in the stream. Their labor did result in better holding water for trout in a few pools. So far as I know, this was the only undertaking of the Hoover Administration that actually improved conditions in a Southern state. Except for his fishing camp, Hoover opposed, as a matter of principle, the spending of tax money on public-works projects in the South. His firmness in this regard allowed the region to enjoy an especially intimate experience with the Depression, and no doubt many older Southerners can identify with the sentiments expressed by my then-82-year-old father when I described Hoover's idylls along the Rapidan. "Yeah, we heard back then that Hoover liked to fish," he said. "We were hoping he would fall in and drown."
Hoover's book came out in 1963, near the end of his long, grumpy retirement. He died in 1964 at 90. The preface captures the tone of Hoover's last three decades. He had put together this slim collection of his speeches and magazine articles on fishing, Hoover said, because an editor suggested its publication would be a relief from "the daily grind of trying to find out why the Communists get that way."
It is a curious book, revealing Hoover to be both a fly-fishing elitist and a meat fisherman so dedicated that he made fish killing a political virtue. Americans believe "they have a divine right to unlimited fish," he said. "They have inherited this notion from 10,000 generations of free fishermen."
In an essay entitled "The Class Distinction Among Fishermen," Hoover put dry-fly fishermen at the top of his pecking order, followed by wet-fly casters, spin casters and, on the lowest rung, users of live bait. In what sounded like a personal confession, Hoover added that "toward the end of the day, when there are no strikes, each social level collapses in turn down the scale until it gets some fish for supper." In other words, fishing, in the final analysis, is about food.
Despite this retrograde tendency, Hoover made it clear in "Fishing Presidents and Candidates" that he was a snob about fly-fishing. He reported -- "with a slight egotism!" -- that only he, Teddy Roosevelt and Grover Cleveland "had been lifelong fly-fishermen before they went to the White House." A mixed lot of chief executives who leaned heavily to Democrats like Wilson and F. D. R. went after the "common fishes," he sniffed. With a surprising lack of feeling, Hoover needled his predecessor and fellow Republican, Calvin Coolidge, for failing to progress from worms to dry flies in his trout fishing.
The best part of Hoover's book is a few paragraphs in which he elaborated on his well-known remark, "Presidents have only two moments of personal seclusion. One is prayer; the other is fishing -- and they cannot pray all the time!"
In the book, he began by ruminating on the appeal of fishing for Presidents. Most are first drawn to it, he said, because of the "political potency of fish" as a signal that a candidate has the common touch. Once they are in the White House, something else sets in.
"That Presidents have taken to fishing in an astonishing fashion seems to me worthy of investigation," he wrote. "I think I have discovered the reason: it is the silent sport. One of the few opportunities given a President for the refreshment of his soul and the clarification of his thoughts by solitude lies through fishing. As I have said in another place, it is generally realized and accepted that prayer is the most personal of all human relationships. Everyone knows that on such occasions men and women are entitled to be alone and undisturbed.
"Next to prayer, fishing is the most personal relationship of man; and of more importance, everyone concedes that the fish will not bite in the presence of the public, including newspapermen.
"Fishing seems to be one of the few avenues left to Presidents through which they may escape to their own thoughts, may live in their own imaginings, find relief from the pneumatic hammer of constant personal contacts, and refreshment of mind in rippling waters. Moreover, it is a constant reminder of the democracy of life, of humility and of human frailty. It is desirable that the President of the United States should be periodically reminded of this fundamental fact -- that the forces of nature discriminate for no man."
HOOVER predicted the attractions of privacy and discipline that would draw Jimmy Carter to fly-fishing. But he was not so prescient when it came to George Bush. Here was a President who hated solitude, got itchy on any Saturday when his schedule allowed a quiet day in the family quarters with Mrs. Bush, and generally preferred gregarious pastimes to solitary sports.
Before considering Bush and Carter in detail, I should note that the sports and recreations of a President sometimes crystallize in the public mind as a controlling metaphor for his regime. There was Ike the genial golfer and casual fly-fisherman. With Carter, the attack of the killer rabbit on his fishing skiff in Georgia and his collapse while jogging created an image of haplessness that hardened into a governing electoral reality when the helicopters that were supposed to rescue the hostages in Teheran crashed in the desert. In the 1992 campaign, Bill Clinton's decision to play golf at a segregated golf course in Little Rock fed into public doubts that he was a Democrat who espoused one set of values and practiced another. Could a few more sporting gaffes Carterize -- or Bush-whack -- the Clinton Presidency? Recent history suggests that Clinton might use a fishing trip now and then to take the curse off all that time on the golf course.
In his successful 1988 campaign, Bush demonstrated the lasting efficacy of Hoover's wisdom about the "political potency" of the fish as a symbol of the common touch. He cannily presented himself as a bass fisherman, a fan of country music and a muncher of pork rinds. But once in office, he reverted to his true enjoyments. My guess is that his decision to deliver comments from a golf cart as he dispatched American troops to the Persian Gulf helped produce the image of elitist detachment that crippled him in 1992. Similarly, Bush did not grasp that it was unseemly for a petroleum millionaire to be ripping along in his gas-guzzling cigarette boat when he was waging what many Americans suspected was a war for oil.
Bush detests any kind of psychological analysis of his motives, tastes or behavior. He calls it "being put on the couch." He once complained to Marlin Fitzwater, his press secretary, that Maureen Dowd of The Times was studying his golf game too closely. "I saw her giving me the Gail Sheehy treatment," he wrote in a memo to Fitzwater. "Indeed, she was trying to figure out what makes this crazy guy tick." It is not surprising, then, to read what Newsweek found in its post-election report on the 1992 race: "When campaign honchos Bob Teeter and Fred Malek told Bush more than a year ago that he should quit playing golf and riding in his speedboat because it furthered the image that he was out of touch with voters, Bush paid little attention."
Apparently, hubris and overconfidence are viruses that breed in the ventilation system of the Oval Office like some exclusive form of Legionnaires' disease. Even Carter, a religious man whose faith called for self-abnegation, sometimes slid over into self-congratulation. Yet in the course of his Presidency, he moved from amateur to expert status in fly-casting for trout and in fly-tying. In 1991, the museum of the Jimmy Carter Library in Atlanta mounted an exhibit called "The Tie That Binds." The displays included Carter's fly-tying desk. It was clearly the workplace of a craftsman. Plenty of people would argue that fly-tying is the ideal hobby for a micromanager and that, if the Hoover Presidency failed while he flailed the waters of the Rapidan, Carter lost the 1980 election by spending too much time at such a desk on the second floor of the White House.
Carter, of course, was a more sensitive President than the architect of the Depression, even if he did bring us Depression-level interest and inflation rates. Anyone who puts his book "An Outdoor Journal" alongside Hoover's can also see that he understands the mechanics and psychology of fly-fishing on a much deeper level.
"It levels people out," Carter said when I visited the exhibit at the library. "The trout don't give a darn if you're President of the United States or a local farmer or a high-school kid. It's a disciplinary thing, too," he added, noting the constant pressure to learn "a little more about how currents behaved, what kind of trout will take a certain kind of fly at a certain time of year or what the temperature of the water does or how a cloudy day affects it or how I can approach a pool without my shadow or silhouette being outlined against the sky. If you read a whole book on it and only come up with one suggestion, it adds to your repertoire and so you become increasingly effective. But then you realize that nobody can ever master the sport. Even Lee Wulff hasn't mastered the sport. He's still learning, he tells me."
Carter made this comment shortly before Wulff, a legendary fisherman who lived in upstate New York, died in a plane crash in 1991. He had used the Presidency the way any smart fly-fisherman would -- to get expert coaching. He fished with Wulff and George Harvey, who taught a well-known fly-fishing course at Penn State, and Dave Whitlock, a consummate fly-tier and fisherman who was hired by L. L. Bean to direct its effort to cut into Orvis's business. In 1980, Carter asked a number of experts, including Ben Schley and Ed Shenk, to Camp David for a fly-fishing clinic. He also invited Vince Marinaro as the featured speaker, providing at least one occasion at which the crusty old dry-fly innovator from Pennsylvania could feel he was getting the recognition he deserved.
I had first met Carter in 1973, when he was the Governor of Georgia and I was assigned to cover him for The Atlanta Constitution. Our fishing careers had many parallels. Both of us fly-fished for bluegills and bass in our youth and then became devotees of the sport upon moving to Washington. Big Hunting Creek near Camp David was a school for both of us, although Carter told me that as President he visited Camp Hoover and the Rapidan only once.
The arc of his career can be detected in artifacts in the Carter Library. They have there a picture of Carter splashing water with a boat paddle toward the infamous killer rabbit that tried to climb into his skiff when he was fishing on a farm pond near Plains midway through his Presidency. The photograph shows a spinning rod in the boat with a bobber attached to the line. The President as bait fisherman. The library has this photograph in its files, but it is not on display.
What is on display is a frame of varnished wood that is used as a drying reel for fly lines. Carter built it in his workshop on the day after he lost the 1980 election. The object bespeaks the therapeutic values Carter found in fly-fishing after a crushing defeat and his desire for top-to-bottom mastery of the sport that reshaped his attitude toward fishing.
"It's hard to talk without derogating other kinds of fishing, which I also enjoy," he said. "I really enjoy fishing with a plastic worm for bass in the warm-water areas in South Georgia and Florida. I don't want to derogate that, but at the same time, fly-fishing to me opened up just a new panorama of challenge. Because you had to learn the intricacies of streams, of currents, of water temperature, of different kinds of fly hatches, how to tie your own flies, which you wouldn't ordinarily do in other kinds of fishing, and then try to match whatever fly is hatching off and experiment. It's a matter of kind of stalking, a great element of patience, because the consummate fly-fishers really spend a lot of time observing a pool or a stream or current run before they ever put a fly in the water."
THIS BRINGS US BACK to my fishing trip with George Bush. It is hard to imagine Bush going into that kind of detail with his fishing. He is an active, rather than a contemplative, man. But let it also be said that while fishing brings out the testy side of some people, it was just the opposite with Bush. He was such a genial and considerate host that I found it hard to square that behavior with his lackadaisical performance and meanspirited policies. He was also, by every sign I know, a deeply snake-bit fisherman.
For one thing, by the time we got to the Washington Navy Yard and climbed into the bass boats that would take us down the Potomac toward Mount Vernon, the wind was really honking through the trees. It was early morning on a cold March Saturday, and out on the open water, the wind chill must have been in the teens or lower. Luckily, the guide in my boat, Bob Denyer, had a snowmobile suit in one of the storage compartments. Since the President was in the other boat, I did not have to worry about protecting the leader of the free world from frostbite. But there was not a word of complaint from Bush, even after our long run with the open boats banging unpleasantly across the chop and him with nothing but a light jacket for cover.
We fetched up in a cove that offered a bit of shelter from the wind. The boats were close enough for conversation among the three fishermen in each craft, and the President soon dispelled any idea I had that when the Chief Executive gets ready to go out, there is somebody from the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration to tell him how many layers of insulation he is going to need. Bush said he'd gotten up around 5 A.M. and asked his wife if he ought to wear his long underwear. She said no and rolled over and went back to sleep.
The wind kept building. The sun was weak. Bush's clothing looked inadequate, and the skin on his gloveless hands looked chapped and papery. I was now squarely up against a novel etiquette problem. If the President of the United States has been kind enough to invite you somewhere, it is difficult to say to him that this is not a very good day for it and you would really be just as happy going back to the White House and having a cup of tea. It is even more difficult to say what I really thought, which went something like this: "Sir, you are 68 years old, which is just old enough to be my father, if you happened to be an early breeder. I would not have my father out here in nasty weather with inadequate clothing."
Bush, for his part, seemed pretty content. He proved to be handy with both spinning and bait-casting tackle. To my surprise, the security forces did not get in our way or interfere with other fishing boats or with the joggers who passed along a trail on the shore. I caught the first fish, a small bass still pale from the long, dark winter. After an hour or so, Bush caught a fish. I think there was one other taken by the party, and after four or five hours, the President said we could go in.
It turned out that the Secret Service and their helpers from the District of Columbia police had run aground with the twin-screw police cruiser that was going to take us back upriver into the teeth of the wind. They got it unstuck, and I was happy to get out of the open boats and into the cabin. There were no seats, and Bush and I were standing side by side, chatting about the fishing. I could not help noticing a loud whomp-whomp-whomp sound when the pilot tried to open the throttles on his diesel engines.
"Sounds like you bent a shaft when you went aground," the President said. There was no reprimand in his voice. He had the matter-of-fact tone of an old Navy man who knows the sound of a bent shaft when he hears it. So we went back upriver at a fast idle.
I admit I lost my courage and did not ask Bush about the theories of Dr. Juice, a Minnesota physician who was interviewed in The Wall Street Journal in 1990. Dr. Juice, a.k.a. Gregory Bambenek, invented Dr. Juice Hand and Lure Cleaner. This product is intended to mask a fish-repelling amino acid called L-serine. It seems that Dr. Juice took a fingerprint from the President at a bass-tackle show that Bush visited in Springfield, Mo., during the 1988 campaign. The Journal's conclusion: "George Bush is a walking L-serine factory . . . his fingerprint on the bait will stink up the water with L-serine and send fish zooming in the other direction."
Maybe it was too cold on the Potomac for Bush's bass to smell the Presidential secretions. But that lone fish did little to dent the general air of pessimism that prevailed all day among Bush's attendants. They carried themselves like parents taking an insistent kid on what they know is a hopeless mission. Even so, I was surprised with the blunt consolation one of them offered to Bob Denyer when he said he regretted not having been able to put the President on to more fish on one of his rare days off.
"Oh, don't feel bad," a White House photographer told the guide. "The President never catches anything."
That day, he was lucky not to catch pneumonia. But he might have taken the weather and the bent shaft as an omen for the rest of 1992.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 25; Column 3; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 959 words

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
This Architect's Eyes Are Fixed Upon the Sea

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
When he was 10 years old, Der Scutt, the New York architect who designed Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue, built model boats from orange crates at his family's home near Reading, Pa. While studying architecture in 1958, he began a decade-long project photographing every ocean liner that docked in New York Harbor.
"I rarely missed a ship," the 59-year-old Mr. Scutt said recently. 
 As passionate about vessels and collecting as he is, Mr. Scutt had never bought a model until four years ago. His first acquisition was a steel curiosity fitted with derricks and hoists that looked like an outsized tug designed to sleep 30. It was, in fact, a miniature of a craft built for use in oceanographic research by the United States Navy. The model cost $300 at a Manhattan flea market. A week later, Mr. Scutt returned to buy a hand-carved Norwegian trawler for $125.
Now his collection of 500 models, made between the 17th and 20th centuries, is one of the most comprehensive in the world -- especially when it comes to ocean liners. The smallest ships in his collection are six-inch cast-metal replicas of virtually every ocean liner and cruise ship ever built -- from the Titanic through the Queen Elizabeth II -- and the largest is a six-foot-long version of the pre-World War II German luxury liner Cap Polonio. They crowd his sprawling offices in a midtown Manhattan loft; the reception area looks like a flotilla of ships caught in a traffic jam. The conference room is choked with sailing vessels -- frigates, clippers, schooners, sloops and whalers. Flat-bottomed Dutch barges and sleek submarines cover the walls and desks in an office, and paddle steamers, freighters and yachts are displayed near drafting tables.
Mr. Scutt describes his collection -- which also includes books, posters, memorabilia and drawings -- as a private museum. And so far several hundred collectors and marine enthusiasts have filed through his office, while smaller groups have viewed the models of 150 or so sailing vessels displayed in his Upper East Side town house. Earlier this summer, many more people admired his models when they were on view at the Seamens Church Institute in Lower Manhattan.
Mr. Scutt prides himself on the accuracy of the models he has commissioned from craftsmen from around the world. The 40 superliners and historic ships he has had built to an architect's scale of one-sixteenth of an inch to a foot are based mostly on the original shipbuilders' drawings. Emphasizing realism rather than romance, the focus is on the proportions and fittings. More often than not, the effect is visually riveting.
The prize of Mr. Scutt's collection is a model of the Normandie, one of the world's most beautiful ships. Built by Lebigre of Paris, the sleek five-and-a-half-foot black-hulled ship, topped by crisp white decks and red-and-black smokestacks, is the essence of French Art Deco elegance.
"That model was on the pier at Le Havre for the maiden voyage in 1935," Mr. Scutt said. "But its whereabouts later were unknown until last January, when the English owner advertised it in a trade magazine." By the time Mr. Scutt caught up with the model a month later, it had passed through the hands of two collectors and was in an antiques shop in Rouen -- at double the price.
At more than 1,000 feet long, 120 feet wide and 10 stories high, the Normandie was the world's largest ship in its day and was described as the Empire State Building lying on its back.
For Mr. Scutt, models of the Normandie and such other ocean liners as the Queen Elizabeth II, the France and the Nieuw Amsterdam are his favorites. But equally awesome to him are some replicas of sailing vessels, including a 20-year-old model of the Soleil Royal, designed in the late 17th century by Charles Le Brun, the court painter of Louis XIV. The broad-beamed model, with a seahorse figurehead on its prow, lives up to its reputation as one of the most impressive and powerful French warships then afloat.
Another handsomely detailed model, complete with fully stitched sails and a mahogany deck, is the 40-year-old Lilliputian copy of the Susquehanna. Admiral Matthew Perry commanded the original steam sloop on his 1854 trip to the Far East that ended Japan's isolation from the West.
While most of his ship models are historical replicas, Mr. Scutt was never interested in building copies. As a boy, he constructed yachts and motorboats of his own design, using slats from orange crates to shape the hulls after soaking them in water to make the boards pliable.
Two years ago the architect designed another ship -- this time a full-scale 70,000-ton ocean liner, larger than the United States but smaller than the Normandie -- to serve as a cruise ship. "The tonnage had to be limited so it could go through the Panama Canal," Mr. Scutt said. "Because of the world economy, this ship may or may not be built."
He is certain, though, that the tallest building he has ever designed, the recently announced 80-story Trump Tower Tokyo, will be built as planned in the near future.
And since his knowledge of ships has probably influenced all his architectural designs, especially compact interiors, Mr. Scutt expects that it will be put to use in the Japanese building, too. "On a ship, every square meter counts, so ingenuity is mandated throughout," he said. "Even though there's much more flexibility in buildings, there are times when site limitations and zoning pose some tight situations."
Surprisingly, Mr. Scutt owns no full-scale ships, not even a dinghy. "My boats are all out of the water," he said. "There's too much maintenance on yachts and sailboats. The most I want to have to do on any boat I own is a light dusting -- now and then."

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Governments Take a Share

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
NEW YORK CITY still has by far the highest taxes in the country on hotel rooms. When the New York State Legislature adjourned on July 8, the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau was vexed that the legislators had failed to repeal a 1990 state tax of 5 percent on hotel rooms costing $100 or more. The tax -- which is collected as part of general state revenues -- means that a visitor to New York City who rents a room costing $100 will pay $121.25 for the night: 8.25 percent state and city sales tax, 6 percent city occupancy tax, plus the 5 percent state tax, plus a $2 city tax for rooms over $40.
Visitors to New York have the biggest burden, but a multitude of other cities in the United States put a double-digit bite on overnight visitors, who come to enjoy and spend money, but are not there to vote or picket council members who decide to tax transients. The lawmakers' motives are not always so bald as in Denver, where the 12 percent bite on a hotel room comprises an 8 percent sales tax and a 4 percent levy called a "travelers' tax," but even elsewhere no one is deceived. 
 Of course, travelers pay more than room taxes. Airlines collect a 10 percent Federal airline ticket tax, an international departure tax of $6, a $3 "passenger facility charge" for arriving at or leaving 131 United States airports, a $5 fee for passing Immigration on return to the United States, a $5 fee for passing Customs and a $1.45 fee for Agriculture Department inspections. There are also restaurant meal taxes and taxes on car rentals.
 
More Charges Pending
 The Clinton budget does not give travelers any reason to rejoice either. Gasoline taxes affect Americans' principal mode of vacationing; Congress has been asked to raise the Immigration fee to $6 from $5, and to apply it to cruise passengers as well as air passengers. The Justice Department is also considering an Immigration and Naturalization Service charge of $1 or $2 a person for people driving into the United States from Mexico or Canada.
The Federal bite on airline tickets is no surprise; it's there when you buy, and most tickets now even have pink slips in them to insure you know the airlines and travel agents are not collecting all the dollars. Getting hit for a $3 passenger facility charge for a trip to or through a particular United States airport, or for a maximum of four of them on a round trip, will depend on how your trip is routed. But probably not for long; soon all airports are likely to have such a charge. What airport manager is going to pass up the chance to repair runways and build parking lots without a bond issue? Imposition of these charges, incidentally, was authorized by Congress in 1990 when it dropped its objections to airport head taxes, long common overseas; the Federal Aviation Administration approves individual airports' applications, so no local vote is involved.
Departure taxes from foreign airports may be a surprise, although travel agents may tell you in advance to save local currency to pay this tax when you leave. The tax may not be trivial: Bermuda levies a $15 charge per departing passenger, for example. Charges of $6 to $10 are more common. The 13-nation Caribbean Community is proposing a change in seaport head taxes for cruise passengers, to a minimum of $6 to $10; the range now is zero to $10. If these plans go through, the impact on a cruise itinerary was estimated by one shipline executive at $30 to $40. Unlike the foreign airport departure tax, this will be incorporated into the price of a cruise ticket and passengers will not be nickel-and-dimed to death along the way. Jamaica plans to raise its cruise head tax to $15 from $10 by 1997; the Jamaica airport departure tax is $8.
 
Hotels and Car Rentals
 The surprises thus lurk mostly in hotel and rental car taxes. The adjoining chart shows only some of the cities where state, city and even county taxes on hotel rooms add up to more than 10 percent. Car rental surcharges began with Florida, in 1989, where the charge was initially 50 cents a day; it is now $2 a day. Other legislatures saw the opportunity. Jan M. Armstrong, executive vice president of the American Car Rental Association, who tracks these taxes and surcharges, puts the count at 12, besides Florida, but acknowledges that others may have slipped through.
In Arizona, Maricopa County (Phoenix) has a $1.50-a-transaction surcharge above regular excise taxes, and Pima County (Tucson) adds $2.50 a transaction. In California, Lake Tahoe charges $4 a day. Connecticut charges $1 a day; Hawaii, $2 a day; Iowa, 4 percent; Minnesota, $7.50 a transaction, and New Mexico, $4 a day. In Ohio, Cleveland charges $4 a day. In Nebraska, Omaha charges $2 a transaction. Pennsylvania charges $2 a day.
An organization called the Travel and Tourism Government Affairs Council, sponsored by 33 tourism groups, notably the Travel Industry Association in Washington, D.C., has taken arms against the advancing sea of taxes, arguing that taxing the traveler will kill the goose. One survey used in this campaign said that New York State, because of a chill on tourism brought on by the occupancy tax, lost $962 million in taxes on visitor spending in 1992 in order to collect $463.2 million in the 5 percent room tax. The survey, conducted by the American Economics Group of Washington, D.C., was commissioned by the Hotel Association of New York City and the New York State Hospitality Association.
Aubrey C. King, the organization's executive director, said he saw some hope, despite the Legislature's failure to repeal the state hotel tax in New York. "Look at the good guys," he said. "Prince Georges County, Md., has had a 15 percent hotel tax, the highest in the Washington area. They voted in May to reduce that by July 1, 1995, to 10 percent."
"We are heartened by that success," Mr. King said. He acknowledged, however, that it was the only jurisdiction he knew of that had rolled back a hotel tax.

HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:

Condo Committees
 
Question: My condominium is run by a board of managers, which is assisted by committees that make recommendations to it. What entitles one to join a committee? . . . Marvin Kommel, Manhattan
 
Answer: According to Eric Davis, a Manhattan lawyer, as long as the board is acting with a legitimate corporate purpose and not in bad faith, it has almost unquestioned authority in selecting committee membership. "A condo board has expanded powers with regard to governing and running its operation," he said. "Generally, a legal battle where an individual is seeking membership on a committee is unlikely to be successful. Further, when someone is denied membership, it is usually based on the fact that a committee is filled." 
 To join a committee, Mr. Davis suggested approaching a board member, asking for a list of committees and voluteering your services.
 
Exchanging Property
 
Question: I own a vacation home. I understand that if I trade the property I will not have to pay a fairly large amount in capital gains tax. So, instead, I would like to trade my home for a similar one in the Sun Belt. Is there a newsletter, brokerage firm or some other vehicle to assist me in finding an appropriate "barter" property? . . . Arlene Suchotliff, Bridgewater, Conn.
 
Answer: To find out if your situation qualifies for as a "like-kind exchange" and a capital gains tax-deferment under Section 1031 of the Federal Tax code, send a self-addressed stamp envelope to the International Reciprocal Trade Association, 1913 Beach Mill Road, Great Falls, Va., 22066. Or place an ad in Barter News at P.O. Box 3024, Mission Viejo, Va., 92690. Or contact the Metropolitan Area Real Estate Exchange Network in Bedford, N.Y., at 914-241-1290. Also review I.R.S. Publication 544, Sales and Other Dispossessions of Assets, to make sure that your swap meets I.R.S. regulations. Call (800) 829-3676 for a copy of the publication.
 
Refinancing a Mortgage
 
Question: I bought a home, which I now rent out, in Sante Fe, N.M., last October, obtaining a 7.5 percent, 30-year-fixed rate mortgage on $112,000, and I paid two points up front as well as $50,000 down. I am paying $816 a month on the mortgage, plus an additional $100 a month toward the principal. Would it make financial sense to refinance now that rates have dipped below 7 percent, considering closing costs and such? What about variable rates?
Also, my mortgage is an impound account. I would prefer to pay my property taxes and home insurance directly. Can I change the existing mortgage to do so or ensure that a new mortgage would not be an impound account? . . . Kay Lockridge, Manhattan
 
Answer: "Don't touch it," said Patrick B. Niland, managing partner of First Funding, a mortgage brokerage company in Rochester. He said you could possibly do better by refinancing to another fixed-rate mortgage -- but only slightly better. Whether you want an adjustable depends on how long you intend to own the home, he added. If you keep the home for three years or less, an adjustable-rate loan at 5 percent or less with two points paid up front might save you some money.
"It is unlikely that interest rates will stay this low, so the blended rate over time will probably be higher than 7.5 percent particularly factoring in points and costs," he said. He warned, though, that again the saving with either type of loan might be so small that you should consider whether the time spent on the paperwork makes it worthwhile. "Why go through the aggravation," he said. "On an after-tax basis, the savings will be minimal."
As for impound accounts, Mr. Niland said they were more commonly known as escrow accounts. Generally, he said, secondary mortgage buyers require borrowers to pay taxes and insurance with their mortgage payments. There are some lenders, though, who do not have this requirement, and a mortgage broker can help you find one. "They are atypical," Mr. Niland said.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Tour Company Closes Its Doors

BYLINE: By Betsy Wade

 BODY:
Asti Tours, a New York wholesale operator specializing in tours to Mexico, has shut its doors after 38 years. Paul Kleepsies, the president, said that over the last two years, the recession, heavy competition in the Mexican tour business and consumer eagerness for discounts squeezed profit margins too tight to support the company. It stopped taking reservations Aug. 9.
Another specialist in Mexico tours, American Leisure of Houston, went into Chapter 11 bankruptcy in March and closed in May. 
 Travel agents were notified that all Asti tours booked for August were to be fulfilled by Apple Vacations in Newtown Square, Pa. Refunds were sent for tours booked after that, and Mr. Kleepsies, who had been president for nine years, said late in August that all but two or three of the refund checks had been cashed.
Asti provided tours for 40,000 people in 1992.
The company's New York office is closed; mail inquiries may be sent to Post Office Box 274, Cranford, N.J. 07016.

HEADLINE: Hands-On Summer in a Science Lab

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER

 BODY:
SCIENCE has always been Enelyn Solivan's favorite school subject and this summer the 17-year-old New Haven high-school student put it to work.
Ms. Solivan was a summer research assistant at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station in New Haven, where she worked with scientists conducting genetic-engineering experiments in plants. She was one of four minority students from New Haven hired for the summer by the station, which does agricultural and environmental research and tests food, consumer products and other materials. 
 The students said they had gained experience they would not have acquired working in stores or fast-food restaurants. William Matthews learned laboratory skills while testing serum samples for the presence of antibodies against the Lyme disease organism. He also helped scientists seeking an alternative to insecticides for controlling gypsy moth caterpillars. The exacting procedure demanded precision and tested his skill in math.
"In college, I get the book work," Mr. Matthews said before returning to The University of Findlay in Ohio. "Here I get the hands-on experience. I can put that on my resume."
The station's practice of hiring summer research assistants goes back at least to the turn of the century, said John F. Anderson, the station's director. A total of 29 high-school and college students were hired this year.
Dr. Louis A. Magnarelli, vice director of the station, said that although it had been difficult to find minority candidates interested in the work, the station had established contacts at high schools, colleges and social agencies, and the number of minority students hired had grown from one three years ago to four this year.
 
Enthusiasm Is a Factor
 While academic success is important in choosing a candidate, other qualities like motivation are essential, said Dr. Magnarelli, who has been interviewing applicants since 1987. "You must look at other things," he said. "Their enthusiasm and commitment in some situations overrides an academic problem."
Ingrid Johnson's eyes sparkled as she talked about her success on the job. An assistant in the analytical chemistry department, she analyzed the lead content in paint chips sent to the station by the New Haven Department of Health. The paint chips are taken from housing complexes, child-care centers and apartments in New Haven, Ms. Johnson said. The lead in the paint is dangerous to young children.
Ms. Johnson's supervisor, Dr. Mary Jane Incorvia Mattina, praised her work, saying, "I feel very confident about what she has done."
Ms. Johnson also worked with Dr. Mattina on a project involving taxol, an anticancer compound produced by the bark and needles of certain kinds of yew trees and shrubs. The purpose of her research, Dr. Mattina said, is to determine how cultivation practices affect taxol production in the plants. Ms. Johnson helped her by preparing the plant material for analysis.
The work in analytical chemistry has brought Ms. Johnson one step closer to her goal of studying medicine and becoming a physician's assistant in pediatrics, she said. "Some people don't get apprenticeships until later in college," she said. "I have one before college, so I have a jump on things. I am very happy."
 
A Meaningful Job
 Ms. Johnson and Ms. Solivan were paid $5.25 an hour under a United States Department of Agriculture program that awards summer jobs to minority high school students. Mr. Matthews was hired through the Private Industry Council in New Haven, which administers summer job programs for young people from low-income families, and was paid $4.27 an hour.
The chance to do meaningful work seemed more important than higher pay to the students, who said they enjoyed the hands-on experience and individual attention they received from their supervisors. "I'm doing things I wouldn't be able to do in any other setting," said Ms. Johnson, a student at the Cooperative High School in New Haven. "I can go as far as I want to go."
Being treated as a professional has helped her grow into adulthood, she said. "It's helping me break away from home, where I feel like a 17-year-old. I'm not a pupil here. I'm treated like an adult."
Ms. Solivan, who came to Connecticut from Puerto Rico four years ago and who is a student at Wilbur Cross High School, said her experience this summer had reinforced her desire for a career in biochemistry. The scientists she worked with are manipulating plant cells to increase the efficiency of photosynthesis. The result they are striving for is higher crop yields, said Dr. Israel Zelitch, director of the biochemistry and genetics laboratory. Ms. Solivan is an unusual student, Dr. Zelitch said. "I never had a person who learned so quickly and is so mature for her age."
The staff at the station has been an inspiration to her, Ms. Solivan said. "I am around people who went to college and want to make something of their lives," she said. "Four of my friends are married, pregnant or on drugs."
 
Parents Made the Difference
 Dr. Magnarelli said he would assign Mr. Matthews to a different project when he returns next year so he will be able to learn new skills. Dr. Magnarelli added that he tried to take the students' interests into consideration when placing them. "That way, their interest is high when they come on the job, and that translates into better performance."
Most of Mr. Matthews's friends did not work this summer, and when asked what made him different he replied: "My mother and father. They wouldn't put up with my hanging out on the streets at night. They always motivated me to go to school, get a master's degree and get a decent job. That's what got me through high school and my first year of college. They're very proud of me."
Many teen-agers did take summer jobs, although with low pay and little chance to learn substantial skills, according to Frank Milone, training manager for the Private Industry Council. The council received 2,800 job applications and only 1,890 were filled.
 
Fast Food and Retail
 Most of the openings were in fastfood restaurants and retail stores, which paid about $5 an hour. The higher-paying opportunities of previous years in banks and lawyers' offices were eliminated by the economic recession. Furthermore, cuts in Federal financing limited the number of jobs the council was able to offer, Mr. Milone said.
Dr. Magnarelli noted that some summer research assistants returned to full-time jobs at the station after graduation from college, and he added that he would like to see more students offered challenging summer jobs.
"The seed is planted, and the plant is coming up," he said. "If it were at all possible it would be better for everyone if it could grow a bit."
But even in hard economic times, there is opportunity, Mr. Matthews said.
His philosophy about success is simple: "There is a lot of opportunity out there, but people won't hand it to you on a silver platter. You have to go out and get it. You have to show people you can do it."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2420 words

HEADLINE: As Schools Open, Many Ask if the State Knows How to Add

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

 BODY:
AS the 1993-94 school year opens this week, the focus is once again not on the classroom but on the more fundamental question of how much New Jersey should pay for public education.
To be sure, there will be a few differences in schools: 
 *The high school graduation test has been moved from a ninth-grade measure of basic skills to an 11th-grade level.
*Students will now face state-required assessments of their skills in science, in addition to the assessments of skills in reading, writing and mathematics already required.
*State monitoring of schools will resume after a two-year pause, and parents will receive report cards on their children's schools, detailing the scores on standardized tests, hours spent on instruction, incidence of substance abuse and other data. In the past, such information had been reported only for districts, not individual schools.
But these changes are tame compared with the implications that another potential major overhaul of school financing would hold for schools and taxpayers. The current system, under the Quality Education Act, has been under attack from the moment it was introduced by Gov. Jim Florio in 1990.
The act was Mr. Florio's response to a State Supreme Court ruling that called for spending in poor school districts to be raised to the level of wealthier ones.
The law has already gone through several major revisions, the most significant of which was to reduce the increase in state aid intended for 30 urban districts, known as special-needs districts. This, in turn, led to another constitutional challenge and a ruling last week by a Superior Court judge, Paul Levy, that the act as applied cannot meet the Supreme Court mandate.
This year's version of the act, a compromise package supported by Mr. Florio and the Legislature, guarantees that no school district will receive less state aid than it did last year. The accord also created the Education Funding Review Commission, a bipartisan panel of gubernatorial and legislative appointees and education representatives. Its mission is to present a new financing plan for consideration after the November gubernatorial and legislative elections.
The commission's report was scheduled for release after the election to prevent the highly charged subject of school financing from becoming even more politicized. Even so, the issue is expected to play a large role in the governor's race, since Mr. Florio's school financing plan fueled more than $1 billion of the record $2.8 billion tax increase three years ago that created so much fury.
While other states have been cutting support for education, New Jersey's state aid to education under Mr. Florio has grown to $4.85 billion for the 1993-94 school year from $3.65 billion in 1990-91. School spending now accounts for more than 31 percent of the state budget. New Jersey leads the nation in education spending per pupil, averaging $9,192 last school year. That compared with $5,216 per student nationally, according to the National Education Association's most recent data.
But Mr. Florio's efforts have won him little political mileage, even from education groups. The New Jersey Education Association, the state's largest teachers' union, has decided to make no endorsement in the gubernatorial campaign, underscoring a lack of consensus among its members on Mr. Florio's performance.
Voters, in addition to their anger over the tax increase, are saying they cannot see any value for the extra money that has been funneled into education. State officials concede that they have done a poor job selling the accomplishments of the financing plan.
"Part of the problem is that we don't define specifically for our stakeholders what we're trying to accomplish," said Dr. Mary Lee Fitzgerald, New Jersey's Commissioner of Education.
 
New Monitoring System
 To that end, Dr. Fitzgerald said her top priority this school year would be to oversee a new system of state monitoring of schools that holds individual schools accountable for the money they receive. If they do not spend it prudently, they face the possibility of closer scrutiny by the state.
"For the first time, report cards are being issued for each of the state's 2,200 schools, with a lot of data that attempts to measure outcomes," Dr. Fitzgerald said. "There is an increasing realization that the only real unit that can accomplish school improvement is the school itself."
Dr. Fitzgerald said urban districts had made important strides in the two years since the financing plan had been put into effect. Among the accomplishments she cited were lower class sizes, more guidance counselors, more science equipment and new early-childhood development programs.
"We're doing a lot of things right," Dr. Fitzgerald said. "But I just don't think we have been adequately explaining what we are doing."
The Education Funding Review Commission has been listening to background presentations on public school financing since the spring, but so far it has not addressed the hard part of its assignment: coming up with an actual financing formula to replace the Quality Education Act.
Albert Burstein, chairman of the commission, said that achieving consensus among the teachers' union, the New Jersey School Boards Association and other interest groups would be difficult.
"You go right down the line, in special education, vocational education and other areas," Mr. Burstein said. "Every one of them, if you add them up, would probably cost close to $1 billion over and above what we have now, just on a bird's-eye view of the requests. It's simply not in the woods."
The commission's recommendations, which are due by Nov. 15 -- a deadline Mr. Burstein said may not be met -- will carry no legal weight.
But Mr. Burstein, a lawyer and a former legislator who headed the Assembly Education Committee, said he thought the commission could come up with a solution that legislators could live with. One of the biggest challenges, he said, would be devising a formula that meets the Supreme Court mandate to finance urban districts adequately without compromising education in the state's 330 middle-income districts.
"They make a strong argument that the more we funnel off to special-needs districts, the less is available for them, and that there will consequently be far more of an imposition on their local tax efforts than is now the case," he said.
Now, state aid is distributed first to urban districts and specific programs, like special education and student transportation. Middle-income districts then receive their allotment from whatever is left over from the general appropriation.
Dr. Kenneth Hall, Superintendent of the Matawan-Aberdeen Regional School District, said that within five years middle-income districts would be left with almost no support.
"We're literally creating more special-needs districts by manipulating money at the state level," said Dr. Hall, president of an association of 100 middle-income school districts that is seeking revisions to the school finance law legislatively and through the courts. "There are a whole lot of districts who were decimated and are in exactly the same position."
In the last five years, the portion of money in Matawan-Aberdeen's budget coming from state aid has declined to 20 percent from 40 percent. Even with an equalized property tax rate that is substantially higher than the state average, the district has had to cut advanced placement and foreign language courses, virtually eliminate vocational education, increase class sizes and move from a nine-period school day to eight periods to save on teachers.
Frustration over the current system is not limited to middle-income districts. Urban districts charge that spending disparities between rich and poor districts have actually increased since the current financing plan was introduced. Judge Levy, in his ruling, determined that it "does not assure that funding for regular education for the 30 special-needs districts will be substantially equal" to that of wealthier districts within five years, as required by the State Supreme Court.
"Progress in providing programs to ameliorate disadvantages of pupils in special-needs districts is unacceptably slow," he added, concluding that "further judicial intervention at the highest level is necessary." He indicated that it would take at least $450 million more in state aid to close the gap between poor and wealthy districts.
Further complicating the issue for the Governor and the Legislature, wealthy districts are saying the law threatens their educational programs. Dr. Mark Smith, Superintendent of Westfield schools and president of the Garden State Coalition of Schools, a group of mostly wealthy suburban districts, said his organization was seeking to insure that aid for specific programs like special education continue to be distributed outside the formula and that caps on local school budgets be made more flexible.
In addition, the coalition is concerned about a bill recently introduced by State Senator John H. Ewing, Republican of Bedminster, who is chairman of the Senate Education Committee, that extends the deadline for the Education Funding Review Commission report until May 15 and outlines another one-year compromise for school financing.
"The language in the bill seems to suggest that local schools may have to share, mostly in the form of reduced aid, some of the increases in teacher pension and Social Security costs," Dr. Smith said.
As Mr. Florio confronts criticism by school districts of all socio-economic levels that it does not provide enough support, and by taxpayers for raising taxes to record levels, Christine Todd Whitman, his Republican opponent, is contending that New Jersey schools need leadership, not money.
Carl Golden, Mrs. Whitman's chief spokesman, said the candidate "is critical of the view that, to improve education, all you have to do is pour ever-increasing amounts of money into the system."
"It hasn't worked in the past, and it isn't working now," Mr. Golden said.
In her position paper on education released in April, Mrs. Whitman outlined her own initiatives, some of which have already been accomplished. Among the changes she wants are a return to a five-year term for the commissioner of education, instead of having the commissioner serve at the pleasure of the governor, and requiring students to pass their classes before participating in athletics.
Some of Mrs. Whitman's ideas, like grants to finance innovative teaching techniques, are reminiscent of themes that Gov. Thomas H. Kean sounded during his administration. That's not surprising since several Whitman education advisers were part the Kean administration's Department of Education. Also, a former Commissioner of Education, Saul Cooperman, reviewed her position paper before its release.
Because her children attend private schools and she has never voted in a school election, Mrs. Whitman has been dogged by the perception that she has taken up the cause of public education rather belatedly. Mr. Golden insists that charge is unfair.
"In this state one does not run for governor without an interest in and support of public education," he said. "The largest single item in the budget is aid to public education."
Mr. Golden said Mrs. Whitman was supportive of Dr. Fitzgerald as Commissioner and would want to sit down with her after the election to discuss staying on. But Dr. Fitzgerald said she might not be interested in the job if Mrs. Whitman pursued a pilot voucher program she has proposed. The program would allow inner-city parents to use public money to finance their children's education at parochial or private schools. The pilot city most frequently mentioned is Jersey City.
"I don't support vouchers and don't believe public money should be extensively used in private and parochial schools," Dr. Fitzgerald said, expressing a position shared by most of the state's education groups. "If that's a big part of her agenda for a commissioner of education, I would have some reservations about serving under that kind of governor."
On the other hand, Dr. Fitzgerald, a former Superintendent of Montclair schools, agrees that more money will not necessarily improve education. "The biggest problem now isn't money," she said. "It's managing money and focusing it on priorities."
Dr. Fitzgerald said the New Jersey Department of Education had been in part responsible for the high cost of education by imposing an array of unnecessary requirements. She said a review of state regulations now under way should eliminate many needless expenses.
While politicians haggle over a financing plan, many school districts are faced with the immediate problem of what to do with rapidly rising enrollments.
In the Flemington-Raritan Regional School District, which experienced an enrollment increase of nearly 10 percent last year, voters in June approved an $18 million bond issue for the construction of a new school and additional classroom space for a school that was opened just two years ago.
In the West Windsor-Plainsboro Regional School District, where enrollment has tripled in 10 years, voters will be asked to approve a $55 million bond issue in October to finance the construction of a second high school, another elementary school and an addition to a middle school.
Paterson, which expects to gain 500 students this year and will be busing its some children to an unused school in Ridgefield Park, is negotiating with a synagogue for space and hopes to build four more elementary schools.
Over all, public school enrollment in New Jersey is projected to rise by 25,000 students this year, to a total of more than 1.15 million. This is the fourth straight increase, a trend that is expected to continue into the next century.
At the same time, school officials are seeking to make their buildings safer. In December, a task force on violence and vandalism in schools is scheduled to recommend ways to protect students and faculty from disruptive students.
Specifically, the Department of Education is looking for ways to lengthen short-term expulsions beyond the period set by special education regulations.
"I'm much more interested in discussing student responsibility than has been debated recently," Dr. Fitzgerald said. "Public education is a right, but there are certain responsiblities you have being in school that I'm not sure we have effectively communicated to young people."
