HEADLINE: An American Workplace, After the Deluge

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

DATELINE: LYNN, Mass.

 BODY:
This is the city where the General Electric Company was born a century ago. But its factories this Labor Day invite suspicions that the company might not be here much longer. Weeds grow in the fissured asphalt of the plants G.E. has closed around town, and most gates to the ones that remain open are chained shut because the gatekeepers have been dismissed. At G.E.'s main site here, the green stuff bordering the visitors' parking lot is not grass but a low-maintenance plastic coated with grit.
G.E.-Lynn has been reduced to a single business, making engines for small jet aircraft, and the work force here has been halved since the mid-1980's, to 6,200, with more cuts to come soon. 
 But within the somber old walls of the plants, a decade of upheaval is producing an extraordinary transformation. Here, as at much of G.E. and for that matter in much of American industry, the ways people work and the tone of the workplace have been altered by the brutally competitive environment -- the recessions of the past decade, the drift of jobs abroad and social changes like the surge of working women. People are working smarter, harder, more flexibly and more cooperatively -- and they're working scared.
Take working smarter. Here, as in Detroit and Buffalo, Cleveland and Scranton, Henry Ford's dumbed-down assembly line is fading fast; employees are being freed to use their heads.
Peter J. Baglioni, 53, is an example. For years an ever-more-bored operator of ever-more-automated lathes, he is the newly trained master of many machines. He can make aircraft engine parts from start to finish.
Then there's Laura A. Kozol, who has built bridges between the engineers who design the products and the machine operators who make them.
Here too, as at many "downsized" and "delayered" companies, the nonunion salaried staff has shrunk even more than the unionized blue-collar force. In some of G.E.-Lynn's plants, chains of command have collapsed to a single link between the plant manager and the worker. Operations managers like Joseph D. Reece have been routed from carpeted offices and stuffed into cubicles in cinderblock bunkers in the middle of the production floors. In the parts of G.E.-Lynn where foremen remain, they lead and coach the troops; they no longer command or discipline them.
 
The Cultural Changes
 Women, while still less than 10 percent of the work force here, are changing the culture. Catherine Lyons, 35, has broken a glass ceiling, having become a plant manager overseeing nearly 100 workers in a multiskilled shop like Mr. Baglioni's. Natalie Henry, a 23-year-old engineer a year out of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, supervises 36 workers, most at least twice her age. Standing at her cramped booth, her knapsack on the chair because there's no time to sit, she hands out work assignments with offers of cookies. Men, her boss says, return the favor, bringing cookies to her.
The culture is changing, too. The old pinups of scantily clad women are out. Ms. Kozol, a design engineer, came across one once. "I said, 'Whose is this?' " she said. " 'Whoever's it is better take it down.' He did, right away."
Like the pinup, the old shield of authority, the necktie, has gone. The head of G.E.'s operations in Lynn, Timothy J. Noonan, puts his on only for trips out of town. Hourly workers can now park inside the factory gates, once the privilege of salaried workers. G.E.'s new I.D. tags carry first names in big black type and last names in agate.
Perhaps the most striking change is in labor relations. Seven years ago, workers here stormed out in a six-week "strike for respect," in part over a foreman's alleged swipe at worker. Local 201 of the International Union of Electrical Workers, G.E.'s principal union, once routinely rejected the national wage agreements the parent union had negotiated with company headquarters, mostly for the fun of the fight.
Today Local 201, aroused by the continued disappearance of jobs, has mellowed. To let Mr. Baglioni take his new assignment, it agreed to set aside the rigid job classifications that restricted a worker to a single task, like running a milling machine.
"We have lowered our rhetoric," said Jeff Crosby, president of the local. "We can't afford the luxury of hot air."
Management is mellower, too. "Once it was, 'Do it my way, no arguments,' " said Randy Yetts, 54, who overhauls broken machines with three other men. This year, for the first time, they are working without a foreman and deciding for themselves how to schedule and perform their chores. "Now we have little meetings with management," he said, "and they listen to our ideas." Charles Ruiter, Local 201's business agent, said grievances have collapsed from 300 a year in the mid-1980's to 30 or so now.
There's a somber side to all these changes, however. In reducing its work force to survive and compete, G.E. must honor a seniority system that puts the youngest and newest workers on the street first. As a result, the women and minority workers who began landing unionized production jobs here in the late 1970's are losing them now. Walter J. Vick, a black benchworker, figures he will be laid off any day; the company has eliminated the training program that might have led to a better job that might have insulated him.
What remains is a blue-collar work force once again composed almost entirely of white men, most over 40. And with little probability of a significant expansion of jobs even if production of jet engines improves, women, blacks and anyone finishing high school in Lynn these days could wait a decade or more before retirements begin making room at what is still the city's biggest employer.
And while the changes seem to be improving quality and productivity at the plant, workers worry that however more skilled and efficient they become, the deck is still stacked against them.
Lynn has been looking vulnerable because of the cuts in Pentagon spending and the losses that are choking the airlines. From its headquarters in Fairfield, Conn., General Electric sells or buries ailing businesses and moves others around like ships, to wherever production is cheapest. How long will it be, wonders Wayne Starratt, a multiskilled machinist who earns about $16 an hour, before G.E. decides that Mexican workers who are paid $5 a day can learn the skills and do his work?
Hardly anyone here has not been touched by the upheaval in the workplace or had something to do with bringing it on. The experiences of the following six workers illustrate the changes sweeping American manufacturing.
 
 
PETER BAGLIONI
A NEW MAN OF MANY SKILLS
PETER J. BAGLIONI, 53, arrived at G.E.-Lynn 30 years ago. "You were set for life," he said. Or so he thought until G.E. began letting other workers go.
Then opportunity opened after the colossal failure last year of an experiment in workplace innovation. In the early 1980's, G.E. built a $42 million "Automated Factory of the Future" here. Robots shuttled materials to computer-driven lathes that made parts for helicopter engines.
But when orders slipped, the machines' lust for metal did not. They built up mountains of useless inventory because they were too inflexible to be switched to other tasks.
So a year ago G.E. closed the factory of the future and decided to use the plant to see whether people could work smarter than computers. It established a six-week course for machine operators so they could learn to run the gamut of machines -- lathes, milling machines, grinders, drills, polishing machines. It also taught them maintenance, and statistical process control so they could catch bugs in production, and inventory control to prevent waste.
Since December, when Mr. Baglioni completed the course, he and five other retrained machinists have been working in a rearranged factory of U-shaped "cells." Each of four cells contains all the gear needed to take a part from start to finish. Each worker can do all machining operations. And when orders slip, the cell can turn to other products.
There's no foreman. A "cell leader" on each shift oversees all four cells. The workers manage the job and call in help only when problems arise. The old shop-floor animosities have evaporated. "In the old days, they blamed the operator for a mistake," Mr. Baglioni said. "These days, they look at the process."
After he made a mistake recently, "I went to the office and got the manufacturing quality engineer. I told him about it. In this new environment, it's real easy to be honest. In the old days, I would have made up some yarn so I wouldn't get disciplined. I explained to him exactly what I did. He gave me coaching."
With the apparent success of this plant, the company has expanded the cell system to two others. And Mr. Baglioni has devised a Monopoly-like game to show how a cell works. "The corporation is using it to train other divisions," he said. "I got a $1,200 payment for it."
"I enjoy coming to work," he added. "In 30 years at G.E., I never thought I'd say that."

 
 
CATHERINE LYONS
WHERE WOMEN HADN'T BEEN
 IN G.E.'s truncated chain of command, Catherine Lyons, 35, is the manager of Building 64, which adopted the cell system in July. She supervises close to 100 salaried and hourly workers. As a woman in an overwhelmingly male culture, she says she has few complaints after 13 years with the company. But as a mother for 15 months, she is feeling a strain.
On the job, Ms. Lyons comes across as methodical and cool. She once had a job with a company that made solar collectors, and "I saw a lot of inefficiencies," she said. "It sparked my interest in manufacturing. I got a B.S in operations research and industrial engineering from Cornell. And once I was working at G.E., I got a master's in manufacturing engineering from Boston University. I went nights."
Working among men has come easily. "I have felt comfortable," she said. "There were comments here and there, but nothing that made me very uncomfortable. What you are is how you get where you're going to go. It doesn't really matter if you're female or male."
The top corporate and divisional management of G.E., like that of most companies, remains monolithically male. Down below, at the plant level, she has not come up against a glass ceiling. "I haven't seen it or felt it," she said, adding quickly, "but I wouldn't want to make that judgment for women who are closer to the top."
Right now, a tougher issue is family life. Five or six years ago, Ms. Lyons was in a class at G.E. with another woman, a manufacturing manager, and recalled a discussion they had. "We were talking about families," she said. "I said, 'It's really tough in manufacturing because every woman I know who had a baby ended up not coming back.' But that woman took three months off and came back into her job and since then has been promoted. That was a breakthrough."
Ms. Lyons and her husband, Michael Lyons, who owns an auto-glass replacement business, had their first child, a daughter, 15 months ago. "I planned to take 12 weeks," she said. But after eight or nine weeks, G.E. called. " 'There's an opportunity coming up that you might be interested in,' " she said she was told. "It was this job here. I was very interested." She cut her leave to 10 weeks.
But there has been a toll. "I feel the tug now to do everything the right way and not having enough time to go around," she said. G.E. does not provide day-care services in Lynn, so she makes her own arrangements.

 
 
JOSEPH REECE
THE CORNER OFFICE IS HISTORY
 ONE more step and Joseph D. Reece would have been the plant manager. Now 40, he started as a machinist at G.E. and, after earning a degree in manufacturing engineering, ascended in the hierarchy. He reached the level of operations manager of G.E.'s ill-fated factory of the future, with 11 people and more than 20 lathes reporting to him.
But Mr. Reece was swept into the "delayering" strategy of the corporate reorganization imposed by G.E.'s chairman, John F. Welch Jr. Today, all the rungs between machinist and plant manager have been removed. Mr. Reece is called the production leader of Plant 3.
It is a senior staff job overseeing procurement, production control, shipping and supplies. He says he has kept his salary, but no one reports to him. Everyone, including the sole clerk who works with him, reports to the plant manager, Jerry Labadini.
Rather than supervise the shipping crew now, for example, he advises it. "We break the schedule down for the guys," he said. "We say, 'Here's what's on the book for next week.' From that point on, the guys manage the shipping." And if Peter Baglioni's team feels a need to bypass Mr. Reece to procure some forgings, he said, "It's fine by me. We've never been burned."
He said he has put the pecking order behind him. "You have to look at the big picture," he said. "You can drive yourself crazy if you get hung up on 'Where am I in the organization chart?' and 'Who's reporting to me?' The only reason for managers is to give directions and orders. You don't need that anymore."
Mr. Reece now works at a desk inside a crowded cinderblock structure in the middle of the production floor. In his last job, he had a corner office on the second floor of the plant and an adjacent conference room. Except for Mr. Labadini, and his secretary, Joan Lattanzio, the floor today presents an eerie gray vista of vacant offices and cubicles with unattended computer terminals.
It was harder, Mr. Reece said, to lose another emblem of authority. "I stopped wearing a necktie in January 1992," he said. "That was tough." He had been wearing neckties since his days in Roman Catholic schools. "I got real comfortable with a necktie on," he said. But shedding the tie, like the office, has helped production by bringing the staff closer to the real work of the plant. "We were just isolated from each other," he said.

 
 
LAURA KOZOL
BUILDING BRIDGES OVER TROUBLE
 G.E.-Lynn had a crusty old practice that often delayed the introduction of new products and processes: Engineers who drew the designs for engine parts did not talk to the workers who had to read the designs to make the parts. Laura A. Kozol, 27, is fixing that.
Ms. Kozol, one of the few workers here whose speech is untouched by the broad a's of eastern Massachusetts, grew up in Ohio and got her B.S at Ohio State. After she joined G.E., the company sent her to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for a master's in design engineering.
Ms. Kozol seems very rushed. Her walk is a run. She has a cubicle on the now partly vacant second floor of Building 69 but is rarely there. She is often downstairs, where there's a conventional production shop, a machine overhaul shop, an engine reworking shop and a cell of multi skilled workers who develop processes to pass on to other plants.
"I used to sit in a different building and have meetings with these management and manufacturing guys," Ms. Kozol said. "We would go over the introduction of a part or problems with a part, but we never talked about it with the people in the shop."
She would hear that the workers in Building 69 had difficulty adapting her designs to their machines. "I used to get mad at them," she said, "making these mistakes, requiring me to fix what were their problems."
Then she started coming over to Building 69. "Last summer, I came over full time," she said. "I can talk to the guys actually making the parts. That lets me see what they have to do to meet my requirements." Right on the spot now, she can fix a glitch in a design, rather than tie people up in meetings, paperwork and delay.
Unilaterally, said William A. Fitzgerald, the 32-year-old manager of the building, Ms. Kozol has introduced the concept of concurrent engineering to G.E.-Lynn. "She's the major driver behind concurrent engineering -- the designer-in-the-shop -- in all the Lynn plants," he said.

 
 
WALTER VICK
LIVING IN FEAR OF THE PINK SLIP
 
 
WALTER J. VICK, 35, went to an agricultural high school with the thought of becoming a veterinarian. Now he is a $14.45-an-hour bench hand on Building 74's huge production floor, and he is trapped.
In Building 74, cells of multiskilled workers have yet to displace the old manufacturing systems. But here, too, much has changed. The chain of command has been truncated, and Mr. Vick says the old climate of us-versus-them has nearly evaporated.
As a bench hand, Mr. Vick sits at a small counter removing burrs from machine-cut engine parts and sub assemblies. He has been doing it for five years. "I've just gotten bored," he said. "The mind goes numb some days, just deburring. But there aren't any jobs to advance yourself."
In better times, G.E. would post openings for jobs to which people like Mr. Vick could aspire. But with the work force shrinking, better jobs rarely crop up. G.E. also once ran a three-year program to train workers for better jobs. But the company has abandoned it because it could not find jobs for the graduates.
The only option now is assignment to a "multiskilling" class and joining a cell like Peter Baglioni's. But as a bench hand, Mr. Vick lacks skill in machining, so he is ineligible. Instead, he faces the one thing he fears more than the tedium of benchwork -- a layoff.
The company uses a process it calls "peer pairing" to identify salaried workers for layoff. Managers compare workers with similar jobs and shed those who compare least favorably. But under agreement with the union, the company dismisses hourly workers according to their seniority -- last hired, first fired.
Mr. Vick, like all production workers a member of Local 201 of the International Union of Electrical Workers, started out at G.E.-Lynn in 1979. He is black, and the affirmative action programs of the late 1970's helped open the job market for him. But the years of layoffs at G.E. have eliminated nearly all semiskilled workers hired since 1979. "Another big cut comes through here," he said, "and I'm right on the line to go."

 
 
WAYNE STARRATT
UNION MAN WITH A QUESTION
 A UNION steward and a newly minted multiskilled machinist, Wayne Starratt, 46, feels he has landed in blue-collar heaven. But he is wary of G.E.'s chairman, John F. Welch Jr.
Sartorially, Mr. Starratt is an exuberant self-expressionist. Shanks of brown hair tumble past his ears to his shoulders, whiskers frame his mouth and one workday he was wearing trousers printed with stripes and dots and black suspenders with six buttons attached.
One button proclained: "Everyone needs a hero. I'm mine." Another said: "Enjoy life! This is not a dress rehearsal."
In Mr. Starratt's cell, a team of six men makes 40.929-inch-long drive shafts for the engines for the Navy's F18 fighters. "One operator can take that shaft all the way until it is shipped, where before it would take five or six people," he said. "It's a nice feeling."
He paused. "Then again, it's a means of reducing the work force. One of us can do the work of six." Like many workers here who have witnessed layoff upon layoff, Mr. Starratt fears that however efficient the plants in Lynn become, Mr. Welch will keep laying off people here or deem someplace else more efficient and shut down Lynn.
"I trust the people I work with, like Cathie Lyons [his boss]," he said. "I have faith in people who are part of this business, part of making aircraft engines. But I don't trust the upper-level management, people like Jack Welch. Those people scare me. They have never made anything themselves. They have never put blood, sweat and tears into the product. They don't see the product. To them it's just dollars and cents."
Maybe Mr. Starratt's concerns are overdrawn. The cells have been producing significant savings over conventional processes. "We can't say how much," said Timothy J. Noonan, head of G.E.'s operations in Lynn. "But you know the savings are there."
Indeed, because of the success here, G.E. has ordered some of the work done at plants in Evandale, Ohio, transferred to Lynn.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

LENGTH: 1589 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/August 29 - September 3

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:
THE ECONOMY
 
Dr. Clinton Writes a New, Shorter Prescription 
 
Speaking of health care . . . (aren't we always speaking of health care these days?), Dr. Clinton is, once again, prescribing some different medicine. The diagnosis is still the same -- the nation's health care system is a mess -- but he keeps thinking up different solutions. You can't really blame him, though: unlike other doctors, he not only has to cure the patient, he has to figure out how the bill will be paid. Here's the latest bow to reality (translation: money): only so much mental health care will be covered, and only children will be covered for dental care. The Administration also came up with the revolutionary idea that if someone goes to the doctor before she gets sick, maybe a lot of sicknesses can be headed off. Preventive medicine, said Ted Kennedy, "is the stitch in time that can save billions." But when it all got sorted out, routine physicals were on the list of things that probably wouldn't be available until 2000.
 
The Bush Economy, Refigured
 
"What if" can be a soothing game. Last week a lot of gloomy Republicans may have dabbled in it on hearing that the economy -- you remember, the issue that brought back those tax-and-spenders -- wasn't in such bad shape after all back in the Bush days. The Commerce Department, which no sooner puts out a number than it thinks better of it, said gross domestic product had been understated for three years. And in 1992's fourth quarter, G.D.P. was a lot stronger. What if voters had known? Would a different golfer have graced August's front pages? Who knows.
 
Earning Less, Spending More
 
And now, new figures. Americans earned less in July but spent more -- but who balances a checkbook when it's so hot? The Commerce Department said last week that personal spending rose for the fourth month, even as income fell (the costs of the Midwest flood figured in that). But clearly people were thinking day to day in July: they weren't buying big things like houses (new-home sales dropped 5 percent), but spending for little things -- "nondurables," the economists call them politely -- shot up the most since April. And spending for utilities was up -- it isn't cheap running air conditioners all day. What does it add up to? Still, an economy neither fish nor fowl, just chug-chugging along.
 
Your Cable Bill, Volume 1
 
Among life's minor irritants, is there anything that causes such fury as cable rates? Why, some ask, do I have to pay to watch television? Why does the rate make no sense? Why is it always going up? Last week new rates went into effect, and the F.C.C., it seemed, had tossed all the rates in the air to land where they may. The new formulas are intended to save viewers more than $1 billion a year, but they've certainly added confusion, with bills peppered with odd new fees, like a few pennies for the remote control. How much time will people have left to watch after figuring all this out?
 
Payroll Jobs Take a Tumble . . .
 
On the job front, things do not look promising. First, the good news, such as it is: the unemployment rate fell slightly, the Government said last week, to 6.7 percent in August from 6.8 percent in July. But the number of payroll jobs fell too, by 39,000 in August, the first drop in more than a year. And if the Government's main forecasting index is correct, things will get worse: the leading indicators edged down a tenth of a point in July. But those on the job worked longer -- 12 minutes more a week, the data-gatherers insist.
 
 . . . and Interest Rates Follow
 
As they often do, investors licked their economic wounds by buying bonds, and that crash you heard at week's end was the 30-year Treasury bond plowing through a threshold that many young Wall Street types have read about only in science fiction. The rate fell below 6 percent for the first time in a quarter century, ending at 5.94 percent. So is it 1950's here we come, complete with 4 or 5 percent mortgage rates?
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
At the U.A.W., Ford Is Target 1
 
There was a changing of the guard, of sorts, in Detroit last week, as the U.A.W. chose Ford, not G.M., to negotiate with in the final push toward a Big Three contract. In return for this dubious honor, Ford will probably face a strike first if this "pattern bargaining" fails (the current contract ends Sept. 14). But it could spell trouble for G.M. too, because G.M. is in worse shape than Ford or Chrysler, and thus cannot be as generous as its rivals -- it does not want to be pressured to take a deal worked out by Ford. One hot issue, of course, is in those two highly charged little words: health care. It costs too much, bosses want workers to pay more of it, workers want bosses to keep paying. Sound familiar?
 
Canadian auto workers, meanwhile, picked Chrysler to bargain with, no doubt reasoning that since Chrysler makes some popular models in Canada, it would sorely hate to have anything gum up those assembly lines.
Mr. Chrysler Downshifts Again
They must have been hard words to say: "It's time to let the younger people do the driving." But Lee Iacocca, who got so used to the driver's seat at Chrysler it seemed he'd be chairman forever, also gave up his board seat last week -- more than a year early. Perhaps, nearing 69, he's finally turning his attention to enjoying his spoils from Chrysler's remarkable turnaround. He's got 2.9 million shares and, as a director, there were restrictions on his stock sales. So is this that historic moment when Lee Iacocca is actually off the Chrysler payroll? Not quite. He's still a "consultant," whatever that means (can you imagine a 10-year-old, asked her fantasy career, saying "consultant"?), making a token $500,000 a year -- not to mention use of a corporate jet.
 
Delta, American Think Smaller
 
The nation's airlines are getting serious about putting their houses in order. Delta, which lost half a billion dollars last year, said last week that it was considering starting a low-cost, no-frills airline. And while other Delta employees have accepted 5 percent pay cuts, pilots have balked -- and now that'll cost some pilots their jobs. And American Airlines said it might lay off hundreds of managers and other employees, and there were reports that it might spin off some units as separate companies. The company would not confirm that plan, though, saying only that it was "constantly searching for ways to enhance shareholder value."
 
Paying for Superexpansion
 
Barnes & Noble is on a roll. Ever since it got the idea that a bookstore should be nearly the size of the New York Public Library, but as inviting as a snug den, it has been opening "superstores" right and left. The one on the Upper West Side of Manhattan has been a particular success. The company, which for good measure also owns B. Dalton, Doubleday and Scribner's, already has 168 superstores, and it hopes to open about 100 more in the next year. But this expansion costs plenty, and last week Barnes & Noble looked to investors; it plans to sell more than 8 million shares to raise about $130 million.
 
A $1.2 Billion Litton Victory
 
It didn't sound like a billion-dollar matter -- a patent fight involving a process to coat mirrors used in "ring laser gyroscopes." But those gyroscopes are keys to airplane navigation, and it's a $400 million market. Several years ago, Litton filed a lawsuit accusing Honeywell of infringing its patented process, and Honeywell filed a counterclaim. A Los Angeles jury was given the unenviable task of untangling this dispute, and last week it did so -- in a big way -- awarding Litton $1.2 billion in damages. The judge will decide soon whether to accept that verdict.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Honda Walks a Fine Line
 
Honda faced a delicate problem in pricing its spiffed-up Accord (on sale this week). The Accord has suffered since losing its top spot to Ford's Taurus, so the price had to be low enough to get it back in the game. But if it was too low, protectionist cries would surely ring out from Detroit. Honda picked the low-price road last week, holding the base price to its current level, $14,330. But, knowing the hazards, it rushed to justify that price, saying it had used more parts that were interchangeable, thus cutting design costs.
 
Kodak Gets Tough on Fuji
 
Trade tensions stirred elsewhere, too. With Kay R. Whitmore, the chairman who has long favored free trade, heading for the door, a tougher Kodak is taking shape. The latest sign: Last week Kodak asked the Commerce Department to slap huge tariffs on some Fuji film-processing products, asserting that its Japanese rival was selling at unfairly low prices. So once again the strong yen could hurt Japan: a higher yen means a higher dollar equivalent for prices charged in Japan, so the numbers are on the side of any American company making a "dumping" charge.
 
U.S. and Russia Mean Business
 
As the cold war gasped its last, a cooperative spirit began to form, and last week, on two fronts, that spirit became reality. As starters, Texaco became the first beneficiary of a joint fund set up to encourage American companies to invest in Russia, receiving loan guarantees on a project to revitalize 150 dormant oil wells in Siberia. In addition, in a stunning turnabout for a space program born amid cold-war tensions, Russia and the United States agreed to work together on designing and building a space station.

HEADLINE: Bringing a Slow-Moving Auto Maker Up to Speed

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
AT any other company a quarterly net profit of $889 million would be cause to open champagne. Not so, at the General Motors Corporation.
A reversal of horrendous losses, attributable mostly to a recovering United States economy and earnings from nonautomotive subsidiaries, surely was welcome when G.M. announced its second-quarter earnings this summer. Yet the biggest company in the country is by no means out of the woods. Despite cost-cutting, it remains slow, insular and ill prepared to contend with competitors like the Toyota Motor Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and even the much smaller, weaker Chrysler Corporation. 
 The current chief executive, John F. Smith Jr., has cut costs and streamlined management. But G.M. must still prove to the world that it can figure out what car buyers want and how to produce these models efficiently and with high quality.
From nearly a decade of interviews and reflection about what it would take to make this giant great again, a number of ideas stand out to this reporter as most sensible. G.M. knows these ideas well, and in some cases has slowly begun trying them. But the company will have to move more quickly and more pervasively if it is to right itself before the next recession squeezes it again.
Unfortunately, the G.M. penchant for studying issues copiously and trying to effect them humanely takes time. Ford and Chrysler have acted decisively because they faced immediate crises. G.M. did not deviate from its plodding style because its financial reserves obviated drastic, and sometimes risky, actions.
Among the ideas to revive G.M.:
1. Move faster to shrink the number of G.M. models and the distribution network. G.M. sells about 3 million cars a year in the United States, in 61 models and 7 brands. In 1978, when G.M. sold about 5 million cars, it offered 60 car models through 5 brands.
Sure, brand names have equity. But many G.M. models sell in such small numbers that they do not justify the costs of engineering and development, or those of advertising and rebates. For example, G.M. sold fewer than 13,000 of the Oldsmobile 98, which differs little from the Oldsmobile 88, in the first seven months of the year.
As for the distribution network, many G.M. dealers cannot make an adequate profit because of the competition from other G.M. dealers. Consider the average Buick dealership, which sold 181 new cars in 1992. That compares with an average of 654 new cars sold by every Honda dealership, 560 at Toyota and 337 at Nissan. The G.M. Saturn subsidiary is an exception: Each dealership sells more than 1,000 new cars a year, a big reason for the success of the franchise.
G.M. executives argue that state franchise laws prevent them from dropping dealers, even if they are marginal. But if G.M. was ruthless about reducing the number of its models -- cutting either the Buick LeSabre or Park Avenue, two similar midsize models, for example -- dealers would lose sales and the marginal ones might drop out, leaving healthier revenue and profit for the rest.
2. Create "platform teams" as the new paradigm for developing new models. G.M. has a number of groups with overlapping responsibilities working on the development of cars and trucks. Moreover, people in these groups rarely stay for the duration of a program. By contrast, Chrysler and some Japanese auto makers now assign platform teams that stick together and focus only on the creation of one vehicle.
Chrysler, for example, overhauled its engineering departments into highly focused teams of 800 or 900 engineers and planners so they would be more nimble and more closely attuned to customer desires. Each team is headed, start to finish, by a powerful leader who is immune to executive meddling. The highly acclaimed L/H family sedans were created by Chrysler's first truly independent team.
Despite evidence that this new system is very effective, G.M. in recent years has resisted independent teams, partly because it thinks they are inefficient for such a large auto maker. By most accounts this is a mistake.
3. Offer a new "mid-market" car. The heart of the United States car market is the basic family sedan, a category G.M. once dominated. The Buick Regal, Chevrolet Lumina, Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme and Pontiac Grand Prix sedans -- each built on the same "GM-10" chassis -- have been bitter disappointments compared with rivals like the Honda Accord, Ford Taurus and Chrysler L/H's.
G.M. could appoint a swat team of 900 top engineers and planners and its most talented leader with the mission of replacing the GM-10's in three years or less. The team's mission should be no less than to create a sedan that surpasses the Accord, Taurus and L/H.
4. End class distinctions among the employees. To convey the message that everyone is in the same boat, executives must erase distinctions that have historically divided G.M. workers.
For a start, executives could move their offices to the factories. If John O. Grettenberger, the general manager of Cadillac, worked from a desk at the Cadillac plant in Hamtramck, Mich., it would do wonders for esprit, shorten the lines of communication and probably sensitize the executives to the concerns of the workers.
Also, all workers, from the executives to cleanup crews, should be covered by the same health plans. G.M. complains about crushing health care costs, yet its union members still receive no-premium, no-deductible, no-copayment health plans. (They pay only for doctor visits.) Salaried workers, by contrast, pay a lot more out of their own pockets. G.M. may have to take a strike to pry that concession from the union. Then again, if a plan to make employees pay more for their medical benefits is part of a genuine effort to make compensation more equitable, the U.A.W. might go along.
5. Make pay more equitable. The enormous gap between what the top executives and factory workers earn alienates the groups from each other. Narrow the gap, but also make the compensation to every worker more dependent on the financial success of the company. This could be accomplished by substituting profit sharing or stock options for some straight pay. Because of the financial crunch, G.M.'s bloated executive pay packages of the 1980's have been suspended temporarily; they should be abolished until the company can afford to award every worker with proportionately more money.
6. Stamp out jargon, euphemisms and other impediments to clear thinking. In the G.M. culture, workers are discouraged from admitting that they have run into "problems" or "trouble." In G.M. language, an acceptable phrase would be something like "I'm facing a big challenge."
Until G.M. workers are eager to report trouble and offer creative solutions, important mistakes will not be corrected. These days, for example, the company talks about the "challenge" of keeping up with the demand for its light-truck models. This kind of talk is intended to make a shortage seem almost beneficial -- an outgrowth of popularity -- when it is actually harmful.
G.M. has consistently misread customer tastes. Consequently, it has planned for too many cars and too few mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles. As long as G.M. views such situations as "challenges" rather than problems, it will not look for their deep causes and try to correct them.
7. Seek more suggestions from workers, and act on them. Any factory that has not fully involved its work force is at a serious disadvantage. The United States factories of Honda and Toyota have made a religion of encouraging workers to make suggestions. The Toyota plant in Georgetown, Ky., counted more than 40,000 suggestions in 1992 -- about nine per employee and more than G.M. receives at all its North American plants combined.
Even more stunning than the number of suggestions at Toyota is the percentage it puts into effect -- 98 percent. Many were submitted after discussions by teams of workers, a practice that weeds out fanciful or impractical ideas. Toyota rewards most suggestions with gift certificates worth $10 or $15; serious money savers earn more expensive rewards.
As the workers receive more training in disciplines like statistical process control, suggestions will yield even better results.
8. Get rid of the old-fashioned Detroit mindset. The company's view on many topics, from the appropriateness of air bags to tastes in upholstery, is shaped mostly by white, male, middle-aged graduates of Midwestern engineering schools. To be sure, G.M. is trying hard to recruit more women and members of minority groups.
Transfer some of the important decision-making groups out of Detroit. To understand the California market better -- and maybe pick up ideas about style -- move one division to the West Coast. Perhaps another should relocate to the Southeast. More of G.M.'s most talented people should learn Japanese and study Japanese consumers, rather than complain about the impenetrability of the Japan market.
9. Hire agents of change. After the debacle involving Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, wherein Dr. Lopez jumped ship for Volkswagen, it might be tempting for Mr. Smith to avoid iconoclastic personalities who might further rile the G.M. constituencies. But Dr. Lopez cut costs and raised esprit after others had failed. As the head of worldwide purchasing, he smashed the cozy relationships between G.M. and its suppliers that for years meant G.M. was paying too much for materials.
G.M. has always had a deep-seated aversion to outsiders. But the few outsiders who have held important positions there have ultimately helped stir the company from its complacency. Ross Perot, for example, served on the G.M. board and spurred scrutiny of the performance of the top executives at the company.
10. From the chief executive down, require every employee who plans to drive a G.M. car to buy it just as ordinary customers do -- from a dealer at the best price that can be found. Now thousands of top executives and managers are given company cars and trucks at little cost. Executives will never address the hassles and disappointments of shopping for a car until they experience them.
The same goes for repairs and maintenance; Some G.M. executives now get it for free at company garages. A few top G.M. executives still use drivers, so they do not even have to feel how their cars drive.
Do not stigmatize employees who decide to drive non-G.M. or even Japanese brands. Most employees would probably want to patronize G.M. But if they do not, the focus should be on finding out why not and what it takes to satisfy them.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 11; Column 1; Styles of The Times

LENGTH: 834 words

HEADLINE: THING;
The Internet

BYLINE: By John Markoff

 BODY:
WHAT: The Internet. An unbelievably dense global matrix of 1.7 million computers, woven together by telephone lines, undersea cables, microwave links and gigabit fiber-optic pipes. Touching down in 137 countries, linking 15 million to 30 million people and growing by a million users each month, it's a super data highway that carries the freight of the information age -- electronic mail, digital video and sound, , computer viruses and more. 
 Forget Elaine's. Internet is currently the world's most fashionable rendezvous.
WHO USES IT: Well-known nerds like Steve Jobs and William Gates, pop folks like Todd Rundgren and Billy Idol, cyberpunks and yuppies, your mom.
WHY: It was really Vice President Al Gore who got the ball rolling. For the last six years Mr. Gore has told anyone who would listen that a nationwide high-speed computer network would create an economic revival. As more users have joined Internet, big business has paid attention. Last week, the News Corporation, owned by Rupert Murdoch, bought Delphi, a Boston on-line service that is connected to the Net. The goal: To publish interactive versions of his newspapers and magazines.
WHY ELSE?: What it's really about is cyberspace. Cyberspace describes a new kind of computer geography that maps the digital rather than the physical world. Jack into the Net (i.e., log in to your computer network) and you'll be transported into the cybernetic world that Marshall McLuhan was talking about when he conceived the idea of a global village. Right now, it's mostly displayed as text on your computer: as electronic streams of consciousness, odd 10-way playlets, you name it. Three-dimensional graphics are on the way.
HOW: To take a ride on the Internet you need a PC and a modem. Then subscribe to any of the dozens of local and national services offering an Internet connection. Hourly rates range from $1 to $4; monthly charges from $10 to $50. Software Tool and Die in the Boston area charges $20 for the first 20 hours each month; (617) 739-0202. Netcom in Santa Clara, Calif., charges $17.50 a month; (408) 554-8649. Others include: Panix in New York, (212) 787-6160, and the Well in Sausalito, Calif., (415) 332-4335.
THE ADDRESS: Signified by the "@" or "at" sign -- an Internet mail convention used to separate the user's name from his or her location (or "domain" in techie talk).
THE MOST EXCLUSIVE ADDRESS: president@whitehouse.gov.
THE LEXICON: ftp -- a k a file transfer protocol -- is the software that lets the user transfer software or documents from one computer to another. Telnet is a program that lets the user connect to another computer anywhere in the world. MUDs or MUSEs -- a k a multi-user dungeons or multi-user simulated environments -- are interactive adventure games that can be played by many people at once. Flame is an electronic tirade on one subject or another. Gopher is a software tool that retrieves from electronic libraries.
THE HIGHWAY PATROL: No longer a wild frontier, the Internet now has its own police and fire departments. The fire fighters: the Computer Emergency Response Team at the Software Engineering Institute, a group of programmers in Pittsburgh ready to respond to attacks by computer rogues and viruses. The police officers: Both the F.B.I. and the Justice Department have computer crime squads with links to Scotland Yard and the Canadian Mounties.
BED AND BREAKFASTS: The best haunts on the Internet are cozy little Unix computers. You can connect to the Well, a convivial gathering spot for the San Francisco Bay Area's digerati. The Well has dozens of computer conferences on just about every subject you can imagine. It's a keyboard stream-of-conciousness conversation that's a little like having an electronic chat with your neighbor over the back fence.
ROAD MAPS: John Quarterman's "The Matrix: Computer Networks and Conferencing Systems Worldwide" (Digital Press, 1990); Ed Kroll's "The Whole Internet: User's Guide and Catalog" (O'Reilly & Associates, 1992) and "The Internet Guide for New Users" (McGraw-Hill Inc., 1993) by Daniel Dern.
INSIDER'S GUIDES: Road maps are fine, but if you want to understand what the Internet means rather than where it goes, try the three science-fiction classics: William Gibson's "Neuromancer" (Gibson invented the term cyberspace), John Brunner's "Shockwave Rider" and Vernor Vinge's "True Names."
POTHOLES: Gigabits are great, but only those users who are logged into one of the nation's supercomputer centers in San Diego or Champaign, Ill., for example, have them. Most of the rest of us are still looking for the ramp to the freeway. The ramp is supposed to be built by the phone or cable companies who are planning to run high-speed fiber-optic cables right to your living room. Then you'll have plenty of bandwidth (billions of bits of data). The question is, will you use it to browse through the digital Library of Congress, or will you just get on line with the interactive home shopping channel?

HEADLINE: ANSWERS;
'What I Didn't Get to Do This Summer'

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
BE glad no one can see under your bed. For beneath it likely lie all the broken promises you made to yourself this summer -- all those things you said you were going to do and never quite got around to. Labor Day is designed to commend labor; yet, it also inspires guilt over not having had enough . . . something all summer. Following are the regrets of a random sampling of Manhattan subway riders:
BOBBY CARMAN , 35, photographer: "I didn't meet a nice companion. I placed a personal ad and I got some responses, but nothing good came." 
 JEFF GREEN , 28, musician: "I didn't break 100 on my golf game. I got close, but I need to work on my putt."
GABRIELLE BLAKE , 23, advertising assistant: "I didn't run every morning like I said I would."
NATALIE GORDON , 66, doctor: "I didn't clean out some of the stuff I've had in my house for 30 years. It's time for me to toss out articles I'll never read and clothing I should have given away years ago."
DIANE ROBERTS , 34, sales manager: "I didn't go on vacation. I wish I went to Italy to eat."
ANDREW GROSSMAN , 25, political organizer: "I didn't go to the beach once. It was terribly disappointing. I spent the whole summer shut up in campaign offices."
DAVID AXELROD , 78, Queens resident: "I didn't learn the fundamentals of bridge." (His wife, Ida, nodded in sad agreement, saying, "I'm the one who had to listen all summer to his bidding.")
HAZEL SILVERA , 40, nurse: "I didn't do enough reading. I wanted to read some science fiction, but I was too busy with daily life."
JASON RAMIREZ , 25, teacher: "I didn't get to see the Yankees once this whole summer. I try to get to five or six games a year, but the recession had hit us hard this time."
ANDY CAMERON , 35, auditor: "There were certain reports for work that I didn't do, so I'll be busy in the fall."
DONALD McHUGH , 33, police sergeant: "I wanted to go out to Southampton at least two or three times, but I didn't have the discretionary income. Root canal took its place."
DEE WOLFE , 54, art therapist: "Get done? I didn't even get in touch with summer. It went by so fast that I didn't get to do the things I wanted, like take a long walk home, see friends, seal my skis with wax."
TIFFANY ALEXANDER , 16, high school student: "I didn't get to go to Disney World because I got a job as a library pager."
 TIM SUTTON , 26, unemployed writer: "I didn't find a job."

HEADLINE: West Can Compete With East in Skilled Labor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a visitor from Britain, I have been interested to observe the debate over the minimum wage and other aspects of labor market regulation in the United States. At a time when Secretary of Labor Robert Reich is proposing an increase in the United States minimum, the British Government is altogether abolishing Britain's minimum wage system. For the first time in many years, the United States and Britain are moving in opposite directions on labor market policy. Which of them is correct? 
 The evidence of David Card and Alan Kreuger, the Princeton economists who are the subjects of your Aug. 22 "Conversations" (Week in Review), suggests that an increase in the minimum wage could create, rather than destroy jobs. There is no mystery to why this might be the case: when Winston Churchill first set up the minimum wage system that is now being dismantled, he did so in the belief that "decent conditions make for industrial efficiency and increase, rather than decrease competitive power."
He was also concerned that, without minimum wage regulation, "the good employer is undercut by the bad, and the bad employer is undercut by the worst" (quoted in Hansard's parliamentary debates for April 22, 1909).
As your Aug. 8-12 series on Europe made clear, the question of whether welfare and labor market regulation help or hinder economic prosperity is at the top of the agenda within the European Community. Britain accounts for one-quarter of the Community's poor. It is now also the only advanced industrialized country in the world without pay protection for the poorest.
Although Britain already has the lowest hourly wage costs in the European Community, it has almost the highest unemployment rate in the Community, according to your Aug. 9 and 12 Europe articles. Yet, to compete with Taiwan and South Korea on a labor cost basis, costs in Britain will have to fall a further 60 percent. United States labor costs, to compete on the same basis, would have to fall even more than that.
The lesson is surely that the only effective way for Europe and the United States to compete is as high wage, high productivity and high efficiency economies. Perhaps Churchill was right all along.
 
CHRIS POND
London, Aug. 23, 1993
 
The writer directs The Low Pay Unit, an independent, nonprofit research and advocacy organization.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Schools Open Soon (With Luck), To More Trouble Than Usual

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
IN these last days before school starts, the news has been less about innovation than desperation: New York City schools will not open on time because a previously botched asbestos inspection left them unsafe; a New Jersey state judge ruled that income gaps between rich and poor school districts are still unacceptable; and the absence of a balanced budget may delay the opening of schools in Chicago.
In what seems to be a collective throwing up of hands, the proferred solutions to the problems of American schools reflect both exasperation and radical reaction. Facing growing anger about the cost of education, Michigan will no longer use property taxes as a source of education money by 1994 -- but what will replace them is so far unclear. 
 In November, California voters will consider a voucher proposal that would give parents $2,600 in tax money that would be taken from public schools to spend on tuition in private schools.
Such solutions, which were politically unacceptable just a few years ago, are being contemplated today precisely because many have concluded that most public schools are ungovernable and hostile to change.
 
Why Systems Flounder
 Certainly average scores for students taking the Scholastic Aptitude Test did rise modestly in 1993, for the second year in a row. And even if those indicators are imperfect, many individual schools have improved remarkably, keeping more students in the classroom and bringing them more success. But most school districts that have tried to extend innovations to all their schools have been stymied.
A recent study of four geographically diverse school districts suggests why: Most systems are top-heavy with bureaucrats, mired in regulations that discourage risk-taking, buffeted by politics and filled with special interests. The study, entitled, "Divided Within, Besieged Without: The Politics of Education in Four American School Districts," was by the Public Agenda Foundation, a privately funded research group.
The status quo has few defenders of any political stripe.
"Gridlock is normal," said Terry M. Moe, a political scientist at Stanford University and a proponent of vouchers, which would allow schools to compete for students.
Educators almost universally agree that the system has to change. But they disagree about whether it can be changed from within or whether they have to start fresh: throw out the school boards and districts and substitute vouchers that would allow each school to operate independently.
The changes educators seek have been elusive in part because they are trying to do what American schools have never done before: hold every student to high standards. In the past, only a relatively small elite excelled in school, but even those who dropped out could find well-paying unskilled jobs. In a high-tech economy, those who fail in school are more likely to remain unemployed or in dead-end jobs.
Now educators want to raise expectations for every student and close the gaps between rich and poor, whites and minorities. They want to set standards for children, but free teachers and principals to choose approaches to meet them.
But the same educators agree with a basic finding of the study: The politics of reform are as important as its content. In New York City, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez lost his job because of political deadlock, parental anger at measures like condom distribution, and failure to win support among lower-level administrators. He was replaced last week by Ramon C. Cortines, the former superintendent of San Francisco's schools, who vowed to stick with educational basics.
In Los Angeles, rank-and-file teachers union members are rebelling against a broad initiative to change schools. In Rochester, where officials seven years ago agreed to pay some of the country's highest teaching salaries, the public is furious at the slow pace of change. They blame teachers who will not agree to link pay with student performance; teachers blame leaders for unrealistic goals.
Some educators, like Theodore R. Sizer, who heads the Coalition for Essential Schools, a consortium of 200 schools pledged to education reforms, believe that radical change is possible from within the system. "I'm more optimistic than I've been in years," he said. "I sense a real surge at the grassroots level -- from principals, superintendents, governors' aides. The policy people say reform has failed, but meanwhile there's this brushfire."
 
Dried-Up Financial Sources
 In Michigan, a new law abolishes property taxes as a source of money for schools. Indeed, how to finance schools remains one of the thorniest problems in American education. Property taxes have long come under fire as unjust to poor school districts. The resulting wide gaps in spending between rich and poor districts have been ruled unconstitutional in at least 11 states. But voters have also rebelled against raising taxes in many communities around the country. Michigan has a year to find another way to raise about $6 billion and the teachers union has already challenged the new law.
Other places, like Kentucky, Vermont, San Diego, Memphis and Los Angeles, are attempting to transform their schools both financially and philosophically. They share a different vision of a school system, one where parents, teachers and principals at individual schools make most decisions about teaching and money, and call upon a much smaller state and local bureaucracy for help and advice.
"The school should be the client, and you only have a client as long as you serve them well," said Judy Codding, who won a reputation as an innovative principal at Pasadena High School in California.
Britain is trying this idea, christened there "local management of schools." Schools receive 85 percent of their budget directly, with 15 percent paid to the district for certain administrative costs. Schools are free to buy services like curriculum development or teacher training. Bureaucrats' salaries are only paid, in effect, if schools really need them.
Some educators in the United States are embracing what could be a middle ground -- creating what are called "charter schools," public schools that will be exempt from most state regulations. If they don't attract enough students or meet stated performance goals they may go out of business. Six states have such laws, and legislation is pending in nearly a dozen others.
Another group believes the only hope for change is to dismantle what they call a monopoly answerable to no one -- and substitute marketplace competition in the form of vouchers. Parents would get tax money directly to spend on public or private schools. Schools, freed from bureaucracy, would compete for students.
 
The Voucher Debate
 In California, opponents of the voucher proposal say that public schools already staggering from budget cuts would be destroyed if parents could get tax money to pay private school tuition. They also say that vouchers abandon those students whose parents are unwilling or unable to choose good schools. Advocates say vouchers are the only way to break gridlock.
David Hornbeck, a former Maryland state schools superintendent, argues that a marketplace system will not guarantee that popular schools are good ones that produce students with needed skills. "If the point is to create rewards and penalties reflecting what we say schools should do, then just create them directly," he said. Kentucky's law includes rewards if schools meet standards and penalties if they fail.
Professor Moe said most educators simply cannot accept the ultimate logic of their critiques. "People don't want to draw the next conclusion," he said. "What they want to do is go back to the system that doesn't work and rely upon it to start working, and it's not going to."
In Britain, radical changes were imposed on schools by Government fiat. The open question in the United States remains whether those groups who would lose some power in the proposed changes -- teachers unions, school boards, state departments of education and local administrators -- will voluntarily cede it.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Nicaragua Has No War, And No Peace, Either

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua

 BODY:
AS Nicaraguans fought a civil war in the 1980's, family gatherings at the Chamorro home here were often uncomfortable affairs. One of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's sons was editing the newspaper of the governing Sandinista Front, the other working in exile for the American-backed rebels who fought to overthrow it. One daughter was a Sandinista diplomat, the other an editor of the family's anti-Sandinista newspaper, La Prensa.
Since Mrs. Chamorro was elected President in 1990, defeating the Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega, the tensions have eased. Pedro Joaquin, the son who joined the contra rebels, is back at La Prensa. Antonio Lacayo, Mrs. Chamorro's son-in-law and Minister of the Presidency, worked out an accommodation between her Government and the Sandinistas that sometimes allows her other children to support both. 
 "When people are not dying," said Carlos Fernando Chamorro, who still edits the Sandinista newspaper Barricada, "the political disputes are softer."
But for Nicaragua as a whole, reconciliation has been painfully elusive. After a peaceful ending to the hostage crisis in which former rebels and former Sandinista soldiers had each seized dozens of prominent captives, Mrs. Chamorro tried last week to open broad negotiations with the right and left. Within hours, her former allies on the right were demanding bitterly that she first address a long list of their demands. By Thursday, when Mrs. Chamorro took a step toward doing that by saying she would replace the Sandinista Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra as chief of the army, his brother, former Sandinista President Daniel Ortega, was all but screaming at her.
"You are not the owner of the country!" Mr. Ortega was reported to have shouted.
Despite all of the killing over the last 15 years in Nicaragua, it often seems that peace should not be so hard to come by. The country is tired to its bones of fighting and death, and the Chamorros are a mirror for its intimacy: families splintered by the war have been rejoined; old enemies have gotten used to seeing one another on the street again.
Nicaragua should at least have an easier time of it than El Salvador, where a dozen years of civil war ended more recently. Compared to El Salvador's governing party, whose founding hero, Roberto D'Aubuisson, helped formed the death squads that tortured and murdered thousands of suspected leftists, many politicians on the Nicaraguan right think like social democrats. Their Sandinista opponents have also tended to be more moderate than those who fought on the Salvadoran left.
But the two wars came to very different ends. In negotiations that stuttered over eight years, the Salvadorans reached a settlement on issues from the creation of a new police to the redistribution of peasant lands. When the rebels in Nicaragua agreed to a cease-fire in April 1990, Mrs. Chamorro's election two months before was their principal guarantee.
That left unresolved a series of complex and difficult issues, like the former combatants' land and security problems and the rights of people whose property was confiscated by the Sandinistas. The results have been a rearming on both sides, ambushes and assassinations in the countryside and endless fights over who owns what.
Such hatreds have been played out in the capital by Sandinista leaders and representatives of those they pushed into opposition or exile. In principle, the Sandinistas have fought to save some of the political power and social policies of their revolution from what they see as devastating economic policies demanded by foreign lenders. Their opponents have fought to keep the Sandinistas from "taking control," as Alfredo Cesar, one of their strongest adversaries, described it.
But after years in which revolution and counterrevolution were made to channel all of Nicaragua's energies, its politics have atomized. Walls that were once Sandinista or anti-Sandinista now seem to be covered by the graffiti of obscure political street gangs. Like a century's worth of Nicaraguans before them, groups like Mr. Cesar's have turned to the United States for help.
"The Sandinista period and the contra war emphasized what has been a long pattern," Kenneth Sharpe, a political science professor at Swarthmore College, said, referring to the years when the Reagan Administration created and re-created the contra armies to bring down the Sandinistas. "That makes it very difficult for people in Nicaragua to sit down now and settle their differences."
After fighting for a decade to defeat the rebels in El Salvador, the United States threw its weight behind peace and mostly left details to the Salvadorans. In Nicaragua, American officials mistrusted Mrs. Chamorro's alliance with the Sandinistas from the start and have increasingly fought to break it.
American pressure appeared to have been important in pushing Mrs. Chamorro toward the tough stand she took Thursday, and might come to be seen as an acceptable price for greater civilian control over the Sandinista People's Army. But if there were any doubts that that inflamed the Sandinistas, her exchange with Daniel Ortega after her announcement answered them.
"The gringos twisted your arm!" he was reported to have shouted at her before a group of diplomats and Government ministers.
"Nobody twists my arm, and don't yell at me," she answered.
In trying to consolidate its peace, El Salvador has at least had a growing economy. Nicaragua -- after two wars, an American blockade and wild management of state resources by the Sandinistas -- is bankrupt, its economic machinery a shambles. Trying to shrink the bloated state, Mrs. Chamorro's Government has left more than half of all Nicaraguans with little or no work. Most of those still salaried earn less than $50 a month.
Foreign economists say any recovery will take not only severe austerity but heavy private investment and great generosity from abroad. With the United States threatening to cut off $98 million in aid out of frustration with the Sandinistas' continuing power, and with growing concern that some Nicaraguan officials may have aided terrorists, potential investors, already skittish, are said to be stepping back. The question, then, is how much more turmoil Nicaragua can afford.

HEADLINE: Conversations: Robert M. Kimmitt;
An Envoy Departs Germany Upbeat Despite All the Sturm und Drang

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: BONN

 BODY:
THE Bush Administration sent Robert M. Kimmitt to be the United States' Ambassador in Bonn two years ago, but he has only just left the post because it took the Clinton Administration until this summer to name his successor -- Richard Holbrooke, who hasn't yet been confirmed by the Senate.
Mr. Kimmitt, a West Point graduate and ex-Army officer who spent most of his teen-age years in Germany growing up in a military family, has seen German euphoria over reunification turn to deep disillusionment as the economy has faltered and right-wing violence against foreign asylum-seekers has flared alarmingly. 
 But in a talk in the Ambassador's office on the Rhine before he left, Mr. Kimmitt made clear that he did not share many Germans' gloom over the future, nor the doubts of many people around the world about whether the demons of the German past have been exorcised after all.
"I don't think we're in Weimar again," he said as barges laden with coal and industrial products chugged past outside. "Democracy in my view is firmly rooted here."
Nevertheless, he acknowledged, he had felt shock and dismay at the upsurge in violence against foreigners that began a year ago in the eastern city of Rostock and has continued undiminished so far this year despite a crackdown on neo-Nazi parties by the German police and prosecutors.
"It must be clear to all right now that violence is a national concern," he said. Unlike many German critics of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who faulted him for not speaking out more strongly after the worst violence and charged him with trying to play to right-wing voters, Mr. Kimmitt diplomatically said he believed the Chancellor and other officials reacted properly for the most part.
"I have always been skeptical of the notion that there is some inherent anti-foreigner bias here in Germany," he went on. "On the day in 1989 when the Berlin wall fell, there were already over five million foreigners living in Germany. That number has risen sharply since unification. One million foreigners arrived in Germany in 1992 alone -- 70 percent of all migration into Europe, including nearly 450,000 asylum applicants, 250,000 Yugoslav refugees, 150,000 ethnic Germans claiming the right of return, and roughly 100,000 illegal immigrants.
 
Third Postwar Period
 "Yet Germany has at most 25 percent of the European Community's population and 20 percent of the total European population," he said. "I think Germany is prepared, as they've shown in the case of Yugoslav refugees, to bear a disproportionate share of the burden of migration in Europe, but whether it's fair to ask them to take three times as many people on a per capita basis as other countries raises to me a number of questions. This is a country that had enough challenges internally, and I think they're shouldering this additional challenge quite well."
Though the Germans changed their asylum law this year to keep more people out, they still have regulations that are as liberal as any in Europe, he said, adding that extremist right-wing political parties were insignificant, not on the rise. He said he expected that as the economic situation improved, the violence would eventually be quelled by the recent introduction of better and more efficient police methods.
After Rostock and subsequent incidents showed that there was disproportionately more violence against foreigners in the formerly communist east than in the western part of the country, he said, he was particularly insistent on reminding the people in the east that it was their peaceful mass demonstrations in the streets that had brought down communism. "My point to them was: Don't let the thugs and ruffians take those streets back from you," he said.
As for how long it would take the east to find prosperity, the Ambassador said, "The initial thought that we could see a tremendous turnaround in three to five years is now recognized by all the people as being too optimistic. It's going to take seven to 10 at least before some sort of parity exists. But the success of unification is only a question of when, not whether."
Mr. Kimmitt is a lawyer by training who served on the National Security Council staff at the White House from 1978 to 1985, first as an Army officer and later as a civilian; later, he was Under Secretary for Political Affairs when James A. Baker 3d was Secretary of State. He views Germany's present troubles in the perspective of history.
"I really do think we are in a third postwar period, in both Germany and Europe," he said. "My feeling is that they face a number of challenges, particularly over the next 18 months, but I think that they are now coming to grips with those problems."
Over the next year and a half, he said, he expects some "difficult transitions" -- for instance, painful cuts in social welfare programs the German Government plans to make in coming years to bring down public-sector debt. This swelled to $140 billion this year, 7.5 percent of gross national product, because of the recession and the huge costs of unification.
Germany is also finding it hard to come to grips with all the implications of the full sovereignty it won with unification. It would like a permanent seat in the United Nations Security Council, for example, but it also protests that its history and its special situation should exempt it from contributing to peace forces that could be involved in combat.
"We would expect that Germany should be in a position to discharge its obligations to multilateral organizations of which it's a member, whether that be NATO, the U.N., or something else," Mr. Kimmitt said, adding that the United States should consider Germany as its most important European ally.
"No bilateral relationship in the world, and certainly not in Europe, is more important than the U.S.-German relationship," he said. "To a considerable degree, as goes Germany, so goes Europe"
He said the United States has learned the hard way that it turns its back on Europe at its own peril. "We made an absolutely wrong set of decisions after World War I, returning home and turning isolationist and protectionist," he said. "And these decisions contributed to the Great Depression and the Second World War."
 
'Europe Whole and Free'
 Now, he said, "Our strategic interest here is to insure a Europe whole and free in the long term, and in the near term, a Europe that goes through this period of transformation in as peaceful a manner as possible."
But Mr. Kimmitt said that with only 100,000 American uniformed personnel likely to remain in Europe after 1995 -- a third of the number here in 1989 -- Germany's relationship with the United States, which has already lost the pupil-teacher character it had during the first years of postwar occupation, is bound to keep changing.
He said that in the future, private contacts, exchanges and business relations would be more important than the American military presence. Increased German investment in the United States will also produce more jobs for Americans, he said.
Mr. Kimmitt plans to work for that as an investment banker or lawyer in Washington. Explaining his optimism, he points to the prevailing German attitude: "There's a very quiet determination to succeed."

HEADLINE: At Riot's Epicenter, Housing Market Is Thriving

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4

 BODY:
It is only a few minutes' walk from the infamous corner of Florence and Normandie Avenues in South-Central Los Angeles, where last year's racial disorders started, to the two-bedroom green bungalow Estella and Jose Otero recently bought as their first home.
But to Mr. Otero, a 30-year-old immigrant from Honduras, the house behind a waist-high cyclone fence and a big ficus tree on quiet West 69th Street is the ideal place to raise his two little children. "I got my American dream already," he said with a broad smile in halting English. 
 The Oteros help explain what might seem the oddest paradox in troubled Southern California: Even as a punishing recession has devastated real-estate prices in such affluent districts as West Los Angeles, Pacific Palisades and Malibu, the housing market remains comparatively strong in the poorest parts of the region: South-Central Los Angeles, Compton, East Los Angeles and other mostly black and Hispanic neighborhoods.
The reasons speak volumes about the complex social topography here. They have to do with the huge demand for affordable housing by working-class families, with the heavy influx of Hispanic immigrants in recent years and with an underlying stability that is at odds with the headlines about murderous gangs and drugs.
 
Prices Rose in Poor Areas
 According to a recent study by the Business Forecasting Project at the University of California at Los Angeles, the median price of homes dropped by as much as 51 percent in richer areas of Southern California between the first quarter of 1990, when the recession started, and the first quarter of this year. For example, prices were down by 37 percent in Santa Monica, where even two-bedroom cottages were fetching $700,000 at the height of the superheated California boom.
But over the same period, the study found, prices increased in poorer urban neighborhoods, by 62 percent in heavily Mexican parts of East Los Angeles and by 43 percent in the ZIP code 90062, which includes some of the worst riot damage in South-Central Los Angeles and where one can still buy a three-bedroom house on a plot of land with a clump of orange trees for less than $150,000.
Brokers who work these areas say that the market has slowed in recent months as the recession deepens here and foreclosures mount. Even so, they say, prices have remained fairly steady, or dropped only slightly, because most of the people who live in the South-Central neighborhood have few other choices if they want to buy. And they are seeking basic shelter, not status symbols; not having inflated like prices in richer areas, prices did not have as far to fall.
"These are first-time buyers; they are buying out of necessity," said Ted Brass, a broker with the Service Company, a Century 21 affiliate in Inglewood, who sells homes mostly in black and Hispanic areas. "We are not talking about people moving up to a 4,000- square-foot house with a pool in Bel Air."
Helping to drive the market is a new infusion of loan money by banks that had tended to ignore the area before the disorders, low interest rates and higher loan limits for Government insured loans.
 
Growing Hispanic Clout
 But probably the the most powerful leavening force has been the growing economic clout of Hispanic families, who are increasingly replacing black residents. Nearly all brokerages serving the area have hired Spanish-speaking agents and advertise in Spanish-language newspapers. "Latinos are willing to buy," said LeFrancis Arnold of Arrow Realty, who is black. "They are good for the market and the community because they've brought in homeownership. During the last recession, you could not give property away in Compton. Now there is a high demand created by Latinos."
Norma Patton, a loan officer with the Funders Mortgage Corporation, said the Hispanic buyers often come up with down payments through "family clubs" that pool resources. Lenders, she said, often bend verification rules for Hispanic buyers who tend to shun banks and often come up with thick wads of what she called "mattress money" for their down payments.
Fairly typical of such first-time buyers are Estella and Jose Otero. She came from El Salvador 20 years ago, and works as an office clerk at a gym; he came from Honduras 10 years ago and is employed as a punch-press operator. Until last February they lived in a second-floor rented apartment near downtown Los Angeles that had become increasingly cramped with two youngsters, Ashley, 5, and Jason, 3.
For five years they saved their money and finally started to search for a house of their own. That search led them to the notorious Florence and Normandie area, which, despite its reputation, is coursed with quiet side streets of modest, well-kept owner-occupied homes, mostly by blacks. Before buying, Mr. Otero came every night and looked around until midnight.
"I saw it was a quiet neighborhood, very friendly," he said. "When we moved in, the black neighbors came to my house and gave me their phone numbers. They said, 'We protect each other.' They are very happy with us. We do not make any noise." The Oteros paid $120,000 for the two-bedroom, one- bath house, which may seem like a lot in the Midwest, but is cheap in California.
 
Fleeing Gang Warfare
 The other side of this coin is that homeownership is diminishing for younger blacks in the area. "When I sell my house, it will probably be bought by Hispanics," said Cleve Freeman, a black man who is the neighborhood block captain on West 75th Street near Crenshaw Boulevard and a veteran employee of the Southern California Gas Company.
Still, many of the more stable pockets of the South-Central neighborhood are considered havens by black families fleeing the gang warfare of the projects. And that is what drew Sharon Robinson, a home health aide and single mother of two, to West 75th Street. In July, she bought an 11-room Spanish-style stucco house for $250,000, just down the street from Mr. Freeman's well-kept bungalow behind a new cactus garden.
Before, she said, she lived in a more dangerous area farther south, where one could "stick your hand out" and touch a gangster. She feared for her 13 year-old son, DeLorean.
Still, like everywhere else in the South-Central area, 75th Street is not far from danger. The houses are mostly well kept, landscaped with oleander and bougainvillea. But there is a sometime crack house nearby, and drug dealing in the alley behind Crenshaw Boulevard, a commercial thoroughfare that suffered considerable damage in the riots.
Constantly vigilant, Mr. Freeman and his neighbors -- who include police officers, teachers and a real-estate broker -- keep a sharp eye out for trouble. They take turns trimming the foliage in front of the one vacant house, and there is seldom a burglary. "I feel safe here," said Ms. Robinson.
