LENGTH: 1103 words

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: Readers' Questions;
The Beekman Theater, a French School, Old Initials

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
This is another in a series of columns answering questions from readers about New York's changing streetscapes.
 
The Beekman Theater
 Q. Who was the architect of the Beekman Theater, on the East Side of Second Avenue between 65th and 66th Streets? It is similar to the 1952 Manhattan House across the street, designed by Mayer & Whittlesey and Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. . . . Thomas Mellins, Robert A.M. Stern, Architects, Manhattan.
A. Like Manhattan House, the two-story-high store, theater and bank building was built in 1952 by the New York Life Insurance Company. But its architects were Fellheimer & Wagner, often identified with bank design.
New York Life apparently decided on a low-rise development it to protect its investment in the apartment house across the street; the company also bought the entire northerly blockfront and key parts of the blockfronts on the west and south.
 
161 West 75th Street
 Q. My apartment house at 161 West 75th Street, like a number of others on the Upper West Side, has two intertwined initials over the door, an "A" and something else. Whose initials? And was it the architect or developer? . . . Ivan Berger, Manhattan.
A. Your building was built in 1924 to 1926 by Anthony Paterno -- they are his initials -- and was designed by Rosario Candela. Paterno was one of four brothers, all developers, who generally worked separately. Other brothers also used their initials on buildings they put up.
Joseph Paterno's architect on 905 West End Avenue, at 104th Street, designed an elaborate cartouche with "JP" over the door and annotated the 1917 drawing, "Architect is to approve the plaster model of this ornament before execution." Other developers, like the Halls, the Campagnas and the Crystals, also left such traces of their ownership.
I have never seen written accounts of this practice by developers, but after the turn of the century the architectural press often urged architects to "sign" their creations. However, only a few architects, usually designers of speculative apartment houses, regularly did this.
The Paternos started building modest walk-ups around 1900 but by the 1920's had become one of New York's reigning builder-families. Joseph Paterno built buildings like 1220 Park Avenue, at 95th Street, and 30 Sutton Place, at 58th Street; Charles put up luxury apartments as well as Hudson View Gardens and Castle Village, north of the George Washington Bridge; Michael built 775 Park Avenue, at 72d Street, and 2 East 67th Street, and Anthony built 1040 Fifth Avenue, at 85th Street.
Generally the Paternos' legible presence on their buildings decreased as their product ascended the economic ladder. On Michael Paterno's 1105 Park Avenue, built in 1922 at the corner of 89th Street, there is only the letter "P" and even such modest inscriptions largely vanished on their top-grade buildings on Fifth and Park Avenues. This is consistent with the development in the 1910's of a general upper-class preference for apartment houses known by their street addresses rather than by a name.
 
126 East 24th Street
 Q. In 1945 the real estate broker Charles H. Voorhees had dinner at my apartment at 126 East 24th Street. Mr. Voorhees said that as a child he had attended a French school in the same building and that it was converted to apartments only later. Was he right? . . . Kathryn Guyler, Manhattan.
A. Yes. What is now a single structure at 126 East 24th Street was originally built as a string of four-story rowhouses in 1847 by Lawson Carter, a lawyer. They were at first occupied as private houses, but in 1856 Elie Charlier moved his "French and English Institute for Young Gentlemen" to at least one of the buildings.
Voorhees was born about 1860 so he could have attended the Charlier school, which accepted boys at age 7. In 1875 Charlier moved up to Central Park South between Sixth and Seventh Avenues and the Carter family hired the architects Renwick & Sands to add a floor and change the building into modest apartments.
Frances Nightingale lived there from 1904 to 1909, just as she was establishing what became the Nightingale-Bamford School. In 1939 the architect Samuel Lichtenstein modernized the ground floor and the building now has a definite tripartite effect from three different eras -- a Moderne ground floor, the original Italianate middle section and a top section with an elaborate Victorian brick cornice.
 
3 East 81st Street
 Q. There is an interesting building (very tiny) wedged just behind 998 Fifth Avenue. Could this have been an old carriage house? . . . Sylvia Steinbrock, Manhattan.
A. The first building at 3 East 81st Street was one of a row of brownstones completed in 1879. In 1908 the actress Maxine Elliott bought the house and had the architects Hunt & Hunt redesign it with a limestone front. She occupied it with a cousin and five servants. Miss Elliott's obituary in The New York Times in 1940 described her as "one of America's most noted actresses," with a 30-year career beginning with her debut in 1890.
She retired around 1920 and moved to France.
In 1928 she sold the house to the owner of 998 Fifth Avenue, the apartment building at the corner. The house was then demolished but the first-floor facade was retained with a garden behind, apparently as a light protector for the larger building. This structure, with Maxine Elliott's doorway, is what survives on the site.
 
910 Fifth Avenue
 Q. Is it true that the white brick apartment house at 910 Fifth Avenue at 72d Street is really an older structure? The ceilings are pretty high for a postwar building. . . . John Foreman, Halstead Property Company, Manhattan.
A. You're right. Another giveaway clue is the surviving trace of limestone on the easterly lot line wall, toward Madison Avenue. In 1920 the developer Fred F. French put up a limestone-front apartment house of simplexes and duplexes of up to 18 rooms with a sheltered driveway. In 1955 the architects Sylvan and Robert Bien filed plans to add four new floors and rebuild the interior according to "new concepts of space utilization" as The New York Times put it in 1959.
These concepts meant apartments of three and a half to eight rooms renting for $500 to $1,415 a month. Robert Bien, now a partner at Eggers & Higgins, says changes in window patterns required the changes in the facade, which would have been done anyway.
"In those days," he said, "we wanted it to look like a new building, adding that "white glazed brick was the most expensive, and the most elegant" material available in the industry at the time.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 26, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The answer to a question in the Streetscapes column on Sept. 5, about the redesign of the apartment house at 910 Fifth Avenue in the 1950's, referred incorrectly to the architectural firm in which Robert Bien is a partner. It is the Eggers Group, no longer known as Eggers & Higgins.

HEADLINE: Always a Market For Luxury Housing

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
WHO buys those multi-million-dollar spreads in Bedford and those waterfront estates in Larchmont so enticingly pictured in glossy magazines? Japanese businessmen? Hollywood producers? Occasionally, but most often such well-heeled buyers come from no more than 30 miles away, say the people who know the market best.
"In Westchester, within a 40-mile radius of Manhattan, we have the highest concentration of luxury homes worth $1 million or more than almost anywhere else in the world," said Lisa Harness, director of previews, the Coldwell Banker division that markets upscale and antique properties for the Katonah office of Coldwell Banker Schlott Realtors and nine other of its offices in Westchester. "What's more," Ms. Harness continued, "88 percent of the buyers live in the state and almost all come from Manhattan." 
 "These are busy people who are buying second homes for weekend places in the country, but they want them to be accessible and be able to get to them quickly, not spending hours on the road," Ms. Harness said.
"They also value privacy and they want enough land so they don't have to see another house," she added. "The beauty of the land with its rolling hills and wonderful old trees is a strong selling point. Where else can you have a home on 40 acres with a pool, a tennis court such as the Sugar Hill estate in Bedford, which is easily within commuting distance to Manhattan, and feel as if you're thousands of miles away?"
In assessing the current market for high-priced homes, Ms. Harness said that although 1993 got off to a slow start, recently there has been "an incredible increase in sales."
 
A $2 Million Average
 Ms. Harness said that it has been "an odd year." "Perhaps buyers of luxury homes are finally feeling more sanguine about the economy because at the beginning of the year, in February and March, we hit an all-time high in the number of inquiries we received and so we predicted strong sales for April, May and June. The rationale being that 25 percent of inquiries normally translate into sales. But sales failed to materialize. Business was flat.
"I think that buyers were afflicted with a fear of the unknown. They didn't know what President Clinton had in store for them. Uncertainty is bad for business. But after the Administration's tax proposals were finally announced, sales began to increase and in July the average sale price for a luxury home was $1.5 million and rose to $2 million last month, which is a figure that has not been seen since the boom days of the 80's."
Ms. Harness emphasized, however, that the high prices of houses in the 80's have dropped considerably.
"The average listing price, $2 million, buys so much more house than it did in 1986 and 1987," she said. "There are real values to be had today and buyers are responding. The times seem better. In 1990, you could not get a buyer to the table on a $6 million home, even if it was appraised at $12 million. Today, while it is taking an average of 370 days to sell higher-priced houses, at least they are selling."
 
Waterfront and Traditional
 There are more houses in the million-dollar-plus category on the market than there have been in recent years, she noted.
"We have a $300 million inventory in luxury homes listed with us, which includes Sugar Hill, which is listed at $4.5 million and a $22 million asking price for a really fabulous home and an island on the Sound in Southport, Conn.," she said. "Most of our listings are for one-of-a-kind houses."
The houses that have retained the highest value, she said, are waterfront properties and traditionally designed houses.
"There are 10 buyers for a traditional home to one buyer for a modern one."
Ms. Harness said higher-price houses need higher-price marketing programs.
"Our specialized marketing program over a two-year period will cost sellers anywhere from $5,000 to $35,000," she said. "Eventually most will sell for about 80 percent of their asking price."
 
Upgrading in the Same Area
 James M. Whittemore, a partner in Burbank/Whittemore in Larchmont, noted that Burbank has 25 houses listed for sale at $1 million or more in the Larchmont-Mamaroneck area.
"Sales of higher-priced homes are keeping pace with 1992, which was a good year," Mr. Whittemore said. "I have my fingers crossed, but we may do even better in 1993, which is especially encouraging since business was slow during the first two months of the year."
Although buyers in the high end of the market are sophisticated in looking for values, Mr. Whittemore said: "There are no distress sales out there. Those houses that came to market because their owners lost their jobs have already been absorbed."
A profile of buyers of high-priced houses done by Burbank, he said, revealed that most buyers come from the immediate area.
"When a desirable luxury home, a waterfront Mamaroneck or a large house in Larchmont Manor for instance, comes on the market, inevitably we have found the buyer will be someone from the community," he said, citing as an example the recent sale to a family who owned a house on Beech Avenue in Larchmont Manor and then bought a spectacular waterfront property on Flagler Drive in Mamaroneck with the thinking that their teen-age children would be going to the same school.
"When customers are ready to upgrade, our clients rarely move more than two or three miles away," he noted.
 
Bidding Wars
 When asked if buyers were not put off by the high real estate taxes in Larchmont and Mamaroneck -- which can run as high as $30,000 for waterfront houses -- Mr. Whittemore, although conceding that the taxes were considerably higher than those for comparable properties in Fairfield County, said that for many buyers pluses still outweigh minuses.
"These are people who understand what they are getting. They pay the taxes because they value the community, the schools and the easy commute and they want to stay in the same neighborhood they have been living in," he said, adding that recent buyers have been orthopedists and executives in Wall Street investment firms that have the hefty incomes necessary to live where they choose.
"Overall, our business is good," he said. One indication is that bidding wars are taking place for the first time in years. We had two recently, for houses priced at $800,000 and above. Three buyers were bidding on one house, two on the other. All tendered sealed bids, which were opened at the same time and the owners took the ones that gave them the most favorable terms. Interestingly enough, three of the would-be buyers were on Wall Street."
P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors in White Plains, said the number of sales of houses for more than $1 million reported by his members has remained steady even through the recession year of 1990.
 
Always People With Money
 "Year in and year out, sales of very high-priced houses in the county have averaged 20 sales a quarter, or 80 to 90 a year," Mr. Mercurio said. "Which indicates that in good times or bad, there are always people who have money."
In terms of activity in sales, he added, the overall single-family market was strong during the last quarter.
"Pent-up demand on the part of buyers and relatively soft prices on the part of sellers, resulted in high volume -- 982 closings in the second quarter," he said. "The median $275,000 sales price was 7 percent below the 1992 second-quarter median," he added. "And the 172 condo sales were the second-highest total recorded by us. The median $160,000 sales price was the same as for the second quarter last year."

HEADLINE: Pressures on School Districts Continue

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
AS the school year begins Long Island districts face the continuing challenge of trying to maintain and improve programs and services with fewer resources and more students.
There were no significant cutbacks in state aid this year, and in some cases, small gains. But most districts are still feeling the effects from the drastic reductions in 1991. 
 The president of the Nassau-Suffolk School Boards Association, Dr. Bruce Brodsky, said that Island school boards were feeling pressure to keep their budgets down and that few districts had restored programs and services that had been reduced or eliminated in the last two years.
There are 127 districts on the Island. Eighteen of the 71 districts in Suffolk County and 7 of the 56 in Nassau County will start the school year on contingency budgets, leaving many uncertainties.
In Commack a vote on a revised budget, after its defeat in the spring, will be held on Thursday to decide on pupil transportation. Superintendent Joseph J. DelRosso said a bus company had agreed to donate buses for the first two days of school, until the election. If the budget is defeated, transportation would cease immediately. He added that the defeat of the budget would also mean the loss of interscholastic athletics, some activities, new computer equipment and new textbooks.
The Sachem School District, the largest noncity district in the state, with 14,500 students, will also open this week on austerity for the first time in its history. Superintendent James A. Ruck said there would be no transportation in state-mandated boundaries, two miles for pupils in kindergarten through the 8th grade and three miles for students in the 9th through 12th grades. In addition, he said, athletes have to finance their interscholastic programs, and no equipment will be bought.
"We've already had three budget votes," Dr. Ruck said. "We are a high-tax low-wealth district, and the community is saying no more tax increases. Because of the size of the district, having no transportation is a big problem. But we're working feverishly to get the school year started as well organized and safely as possible."
In Nassau the Hempstead School District is also starting the year on austerity, as it has for five years. Superintendent Eddy Bayardelle said the absence of an approved budget was just one of many problems. Hempstead High School and Middle School remain on the State Education Department list of the worst-performing schools in the state.
"It's been a tough year," said Dr. Bayardelle, who became superintendent last year. He had been administraor in the New York City schools.
"When I came here," Dr. Bayardelle added, "the district was in a crisis state and was cited for just about everything from mismanagement to not providing mandated programs for handicapped and non-English-speaking students. There was no organization and tremendous negativity."
The district had many staffing changes in the last school year, Dr. Bayardelle said, to try to improve performance. The district obtained additional money from the state for programs to upgrade services for students and began an adult-education program with an expanded program graduate-equivalency degrees, offering day and night classes and classes in English as a second language.
The newest hope for Hempstead is an early childhood center, financed by private donations, scheduled to open this month in a vacant parochial school. Dr. Bayardelle said it would include programs for children 16 months to 3 years old, a prekindergarten and kindergarten for 4- and 5-year-olds and a family center.
"The outlook in Hempstead is beginning to change," Dr. Bayardelle said. "But we certainly have a long way to go."
 
Optimism in Longwood
 The outlook is more positive in Longwood, which passed its budget for the first time in several years. After a 15 percent reduction in staff, the level stabilized this year, said Superintendent Candy Swenson. Although the district was unable to restore programs, administrators are optimistic.
"When you lose things, you have a unique opportunity to create something new and different, rather than to recreate the past," Dr. Swenson said. "This year we'll be developing long-range plans, studying what we need and where we should be going."
 
Shrinking Resources in Massapequa
 In Massapequa a revised and reduced budget approved in midsummer allowed the district to open this week on a normal basis instead of on austerity. To maintain programs despite shrinking resources the district offered a retirement incentive for teachers and increased classroom responsibilities for department heads.
"It's a tough time for all districts," Superintendent James Bruccia said. "We are all facing the continuing battle for support and resources."
A few districts look forward to restoring and even adding some programs. In Herricks four new electives will be offered in the high school, and the elementary schools will receive new computer laboratories. Superintendent Sidney Freund said the district could finally catch up on buying equipment. "The theme for this year," he said, "is looking to the next century and examining the relevance of what we're teaching."
In Syosset, new courses include Japanese, study skills for all 6th graders and a mandatory fitness and nutrition class for all 9th- and 10th-graders. Superintendent Carole Hankin said that after a conservative three years the district could buy additional computers, supplies and equipment and restore interscholastic sports in grades 7 and 9.
"If there are no new surprises on the state level," she said, "we're hoping next year to computerize the elementary schools, return class trips to the budget and do some other very exciting things."
 
More Instruction in English
 Enrollments on the Island have been slowly rising in recent years. The State Education Department says total enrollment in Nassau and Suffolk counties for 1991-92 was 387,734. Last year it rose, to 391,407. The projected number for this year is 397,356, and enrollment for the 1995-1996 year is projected at 404,741.
Although enrollment is slowly climbing, the significant increase in enrollment is among immigrants, especially from Central and South America, said Dr. Brodsky.
"We've seen a major influx of kids in their early teens who are totally illiterate," he said. "Many 12-year-olds are coming into the school districts not speaking or reading the language, and we must start them at the kindergarten level.
"This is a significant factor in driving up the costs of education, because under state law we must hire someone to teach them in their native languages."
In Brentwood minority members are the majority, said a spokesman for the district, Jerry Steiner. Of 12,000 students 45 percent are Hispanic, 39 percent white, 15 percent black and 1 percent are members of other groups. There are 59 languages that have to be taught in the bilingual program in the district, he said.
"One of the most difficult things we have to do is to find the staff to work with the kids in their native languages," Mr. Steiner said. "But aside from the language barrier many of these kids have other special problems. Some are 10 and 12 and have never before been in school. Their families are in an economic depression, and these factors compound the language barrier."
Glen Cove, one of the two cities on the Island, has also seen a swelling in the number of students from minorities. A spokeswoman for the district, Marjorie Linn, said the schools ran a program this summer for entering and current kindergarteners with little or no English skills. The district also added teachers of English as a second language and a social worker and psychologist to work with non-English-speaking students.
An influx of non-English-speaking students in Long Beach, the other city on the Island, prompted the creation of a language-immersion program to integrate Hispanic students into American culture and the school as quickly as possible, said Superintendent Elliott Landon. The program, financed by the state, pairs English- and Spanish-speaking students, he said, adding that the program, which has a waiting list, started with prekindergarten children and will be expanded to include students up to the second grade this year.
Multicultural education has become a growing focus. A student-exchange program with Russia created a new link for high school students in the Port Washington, Farmingdale and Hewlett-Woodmere districts. The youngsters will travel to Russia in the spring. The project was financed by a grant from the United States Information Agency, in cooperation with the Nassau Board of Cooperative Services, which operates special schools and training courses.
 
 Problems With Prejudice
 A number of bias incidents in the 1992-93 school year prompted educators to introduce more programs to combat prejudice. After several displays of anti-Semitism in the spring Commack began to develop a program aimed at reducing bias and encouraging multicultural appreciation for the curriculum by the spring, Dr. DelRosso said. A committee will plan staff workshops and explore the possibility of community meetings, he added.
The need to reduce prejudice is also a growing focus in Herricks, where a coalition of school and community leaders is involved in multicultural events.
"Prejudice reduction is not just a school issue, but a community issue," Dr. Freund said. "We've got to attack the problem from all angles."
Another new effort, the Longwood Diversity Institute, has been formed to train students as leaders in reducing bias. The program was financed by a $2,000 grant from the State Education Department. A group of fourth graders chosen by their peers was trained by a team from the State University at Stony Brook and Suffolk Community College.
"We've had our share of incidents that highlight the bias that exists," Dr. Swenson said. "We're hoping that this project will be a springboard for other activities."
Dr. Landon said the weak economy had contributed to conflicts. "When the economy is in a tailspin," he said, "you always see an increase in bias-related incidents. As educators we must be more sensitive to developing programs to reduce levels of intolerance and to try to sensitize our teachers and students to work with these issues."
 
Countering Violence
 Discipline is on the minds of many educators as the year begins. Concerns include the proliferation of graffiti, isolated but disruptive pranks and the increase in violence.
The State Education Department recently surveyed school safety and security and is collecting the data from a statewide sampling of districts. A spokesman for the department, Leonard Powell, said the survey was an attempt to understand violence and weapons possession in the schools and determine what programs had been successful. The results are to be published in the fall.
Violence is no longer confined to cities, Dr. Brodsky said. Local school districts are recognizing that there is a pressing need to deal with the problem. "Some districts will be drawing up stricter disciplinary codes," he added. "Others will increase security detectors and security guards. More districts will be implementing conflict-resolution and mediation training and trying to teach their kids racial and ethnic sensitivity."
In Syosset a handful of pranks at the high school last year, including bomb threats and false fire alarms, prompted tougher security measures. A new alarm and security system was installed in the summer, with cameras throughout the building and a two-way public-address system in every classroom. All incoming telephone calls to the district are recorded. The principal, Jorge Schneider, said the tougher policy helped make students and teachers feel more secure and would deter inappropriate behavior.
To fight the growing problem of graffiti Massapequa is participating in an adopt-a-building program with Oyster Bay. Dr. Bruccia said students would be assigned to keep an eye on different buildings. If graffiti are found on "adopted" buildings, he said, the students will be responsible for repainting it. The program is part of a townwide plan for tougher enforcement and stricter penalties for graffiti.
 
Beyond the Schoolhouse
 Community involvement has become a priority in many districts. The state's blueprint for education, the New Compact for Learning, calls for all districts to develop and adopt plans by February for parents, teachers and administrators to participate in planning and making decisions.
In Hempstead more than 60 partnerships have been formed between the district and businesses, bringing business leaders into the schools to teach courses, and providing internships for students in the community.
In Longwood the theme for the year is "Community Unity -- Be a Part of the Pride." A district is often the center of a community, Dr. Swenson said. "It is our responsibility to create opportunities to bring people together," she said. "Every school district and community have problems. Our goal is to work cooperatively to solve these problems together."

HEADLINE: County and State Offer Aid to Buy Hastings Site

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON

 BODY:
WITH the announcement last week of a county and state plan to help local officials preserve Hillside Woods here, this tiny Hudson River village moved a step closer toward reaching what has been an elusive goal.
The county has offered to contribute one-third of the $3.35 million cost of purchasing the 48-acre woods, and the state has indicated that it would contribute another third. That leaves the village with the task raising the other third through a bond issue, which is much less that it had originally thought it would have to pay. 
 The land was owned by Henry Gross, a New York City developer who purchased the property in 1987 and planned to build 82 homes on it. But when the real estate market fell upon hard times and Mr. Gross's corporation agreed to sell the site for about $5.5 million, the village was unable to raise the funds to buy it.
The property, thick with trees and hiking trails and much loved by residents here, will form part of a larger publicly owned greenbelt area in lower Westchester, where open land is scarce.
 
Calling In a Trust
 Under the plan, the woods will be jointly owned by the county and village, and access will be open to all Westchester residents, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said when the proposal was announced last week. The site of a former Algonquin trail will create an open-space link between the Old Croton Aqueduct Trailway along the Hudson River and the county-owned Putnam Right of Way near the Saw Mill River Parkway.
As in other southern Westchester communities, development pressures have been great in this village, where 8,000 people live in a two-square-mile area. The Fund to Preserve Hillside Woods, a grass-roots organization of local citizens, was formed six years ago, and its members raised some money to protect the woods through bake sales and special events.
There was little real hope, however, that the property could be saved until the San Francisco-based Trust for Public Land was called in three years ago. Late last spring the not-for-profit organization negotiated to purchase the woods, contingent upon its eventual sale to either the village or county, or both.
The mortgage on the property is currently held by Recoll Management Corporation, a collection subsidiary of the Fleet Financial Group in Providence, R.I., and an agent for the Federal Deposit Insurance Company, which took over the loan following a series of bank failures. Because Mr. Gross's company had defaulted on the loan, the public trust was able to negotiate a purchase price lower than the one the firm was originally asking, said Phyllis M. Reich, a project manager for the trust.
She said that the depressed real estate market has provided "a wonderful economic opportunity for trusts" to save open-space land.
 
Lobbying Efforts Pay Off
 Since 1989, the Trust for Public Land has worked in the county to acquire more than 520 acres of open- space property. Its acquisitions include the Kitchawan Preserve, a 208-acre site in Yorktown near the Croton Reservoir, which had been owned by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, and 164 acres surrounding Pocantico Lake in Mount Pleasant.
In Westchester, 46,000 acres of the county's 288,000 acres remain as open space, with the county owning 16,000 undeveloped acres, said P. Lynn Oliva, Commissioner of Planning. Mr. O'Rourke has calculated that there are about 18 acres of county-owned greenspace for every 1,000 residents, one of the highest ratios in the nation.
With the trust's deal for Hillside Woods close to completion last spring, Hastings-on-Hudson officials sought increased commitments from the county and state. As a result of the village's recent lobbying efforts, the county -- which a year ago said it would contribute only a fourth -- increased its share of the purchase price to a third.
State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, Republican from Yonkers, has pledged to secure $1 million through the state's Environmental Quality Bond Act, which is double the amount originally promised.
The last sticking point will be residents' support of an Oct. 12 bond referendum authorizing the village to raise the money for its share of the purchase price, will come to about $1.1 million.

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
British Rockers Trot Out the Flag

BYLINE: By Simon Reynolds; Simon Reynolds is the author of "Blissed Out: The Raptures of Rock."

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
In rock-and-roll just as in politics, the United States and England have a special relationship. Together, they have dominated global pop. Over the decades, rock's center of gravity has shifted back and forth between each nation. In the 60's it passed from swinging London to San Francisco, in the 70's from Southern California's soft rock to British punk. The rest of the planet has never had much of a look in.
Musical innovations generally originate in America, and in particular from black music (rhythm-and-blues and soul in the 50's and 60's, funk and disco in the 70's, rap and house in the 80's). But usually it's British bands that respond quickest to black American innovations, adding a vital element of art-school conceptualism, style and attitude, then promptly selling this repackaged black American music to white America. This is what happened with 60's white blues or 80's New Pop (funk given a video-friendly gloss). 
 But just as the special relationship in politics often engenders anxiety among the British, similarly the trans-Atlantic traffic in pop is fraught with rivalry and resentment. Right now, the British pop scene is convulsed by one of its periodic fits of anti-Americanism. All year long, there have been murmurings of discontent, which has swelled into a "Yanks go home!" uproar, in reaction to the deluge of music from Seattle grunge bands.
From the late 80's until quite recently, British indie bands had looked to American hard-core and alternative rock, envying and admiring the likes of Sonic Youth and Big Black. American underground bands seem to have an un-self-conscious and intuitive approach that was felt to be preferable to England's traditionally overtheorized and premeditated take on rock-and-roll. The best British bands of the late 80's, like My Bloody Valentine, took the slacker spirit and neo-psychedelic sound of Dinosaur Jr. and Husker Du, giving them an androgynous spin.
The explosive success of Nirvana changed everything. What was once cool and a trifle exotic became commonplace, oppressive. Even more resented are the home-grown plague of slacker-wannabes who've struggled to emulate the invaders, growing their hair shaggy, mumbling their lyrics, grunging up their guitars. As 1992 turned into 1993, a wave of bands emerged that reject the notion of an "English curse" (of pretentiousness and preciousness) and instead embrace the idea of being literate, self-conscious, stylized and ironic. The most successful and most volubly anti-American of the new patriots is Suede. The band is currently trying to conquer America with its first full-scale tour, which reaches New York on Sept. 18.
Suede's roots are the British art-rock and the glam of the 70's (David Bowie, T. Rex, Kate Bush) and the English nostalgia of the Smiths. Its front man, Brett Anderson, sings in an exaggerated London accent, a defiant gesture against a pseudo-American slacker drawl that so many British bands still mimic. His fey, flamboyant image and gender-bending lyrics are a resurrection of the English tradition of sexual ambiguity, a concerted reaction against grunge's machismo.
Other bands flying the flag for the imperiled legacy of English pop include Denim, Pulp, the Auteurs and Saint Etienne. The Auteurs herald a return to wordy songcraft. The group's singer Luke Haines worships what he calls the "wryness and dryness" of quintessentially English songwriters like Ray Davies of the Kinks. The band's debut album, "New Wave," released in America last spring by Caroline, even contained an anti-grunge anthem called "American Guitars." Saint Etienne is a stylish dance pop trio whose delightful, irony-drenched songs with titles like "London Belongs to Me" and "Avenue" often seem like reinvocations of 60's London.
The anti-American mood was prefigured by that most England-obsessed singer, Morrissey, formerly of the Smiths. On his 1992 glam-rock-tinged LP, "Your Arsenal," the song "We'll Let You Know" mourned the fact that "we look to Los Angeles for the language we use . . . London is dead." He also incited controversy when he draped himself in the Union Jack during a performance.
If there's a sociological backdrop to this mini-movement of bands that are proud to be British, it's that England is in the throes of political, social and cultural crisis. Economic recession, rising crime and the deterioration of public service have all fueled unease about where Britain is heading as a nation, and what it means to be British. On the one hand, Britons are nervous about merging with their neighbors on the Continent in a greater European Community; on the other, they feel inundated with American culture, from grunge to Hollywood blockbusters to television shows like "American Gladiators."
THE DEFIANT ENGLISHNESS OF this new crop of indie bands is a sort of perversely parochial response to global pop culture -- everything from Nintendo to sample-based music like techno (a truly international and rootless music). Since the future would seem to promise the loss of national cultural identity, these bands turn their backs to the future and rifle the back pages of England's pop glory.
This trans-Atlantic antagonism often cuts the other way, too: there's a long tradition of American skepticism toward the latest British trends. For some, Britain produces an endless stream of overhyped "haircut bands" that are seen as videogenic and weighted with conceptual baggage withoutmusical substance. Suede, for instance, has received a mixed reaction in America. While the college rock audience, which has always been Anglophile, has responded favorably, indie hipsters remain skeptical.
American critics have often suggested that the British lack a natural, "organic" relationship with rock-and-roll. There's an Anglophobic tradition that stretches from the critic Dave Marsh, who in the early 80's celebrated Bruce Springsteen's all-American populism while decrying the British New Pop invaders like Culture Club and Human League, to Joe Carducci's recent, influential polemic, "Rock and Pop Narcotic." In his Anglophobic theory of rock, Mr. Carducci argues that British bands quickly lost touch with the blues roots of rock-and-roll, and after Led Zeppelin and Black Sabbath, they made little contribution to the evolution of the form.
In recent years, only a handful of Britons have been given the critical red carpet in America. One is Teen-Age Fan Club, an Americanophile Scottish quartet that is influenced by the likes of Neil Young and Big Star. Another is My Bloody Valentine, which also initially took its bearings from American underground bands like Sonic Youth before radically transforming its sources.
The trans-Atlantic traffic in musical ideas often works by a process of innovation through misrecognition. This syndrome of unsuccessful imitation leads to all manner of ironic developments, like the way the northern English band the Fall has suddenly and inexplicably emerged as a major influence on a breed of lo-fi indie bands in America like Pavement. In a similar fashion, the Sex Pistols have been adopted by American metal bands, with everyone from Guns 'n' Roses to Megadeth to Motley Crue remaking their songs.
Misappropriation and miscegenation is the way that pop evolves. In view of this, the attempts of bands like Suede and the Auteurs to safeguard the purity of English pop seem shortsighted and futile. Insularity and inbreeding may ultimately condemn British pop to extinction.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
The Search for Jobs That No Longer Exist

BYLINE: By Michael S. Malone; Michael S. Malone writes frequently about Silicon Valley from Los Altos, Calif.

 BODY:
It is not an easy time to be a senior manager. Terms like "trim corporation" sound trendy, but they really mean you can now get fired even if you have done a great job.
"The first thing you have to learn is that nothing is forever anymore," said Sid Wilkins, president of the outplacement specialist Wilkins & Wilkins International in Palo Alto, Calif. "There is no such thing now as job security." 
 Mr. Wilkins is often used by companies in Silicon Valley to help laid-off chief executives and other top managers find new work. And until recently, Mr. Wilkins had a proven technique for these executives: get them through the depression and grief over losing their jobs, then start them down the path to finding new employment. The program updated resumes, taught job interview skills -- even found the client new clothes. It was a systematic process, and at the end was a new job for the client.
But Mr. Wilkins has noted a fundamental change lately that has forced him to rethink his business: For many of his clients, the new jobs are no longer there.
As an organizational revolution has swept one American industry after another, many firms have undergone management layoffs -- and the odds have grown longer against executives finding other job openings in their fields.
That was what Tim Hillary discovered when the claims administrator Adjustco closed its offices in Walnut Creek, Calif., in 1991 and moved Mr. Hillary's human resources management job to the East Coast. Mr. Hillary quickly discovered he was trapped in a buyer's market. "Recruiters either didn't have any jobs available or demanded seven very specific qualifications -- and knew they could get them," he said. "It was not a pleasant time for me."
A consolation, Mr. Wilkins said, is that in Silicon Valley at least, executives no longer seem surprised at being laid off, but take it as part of a career in high-technology. There is less post-firing depression, Mr. Wilkins said, although he said he had found that he must deal more with his clients' frustration down the line when no new jobs can be found.
In San Francisco, Sharon Gadberry, president of Transitions Management, the local office of Outplacement International of Chicago, found that her clients like Mr. Hillary, who were from more traditional companies, were getting a double whammy: shocked at being fired and depressed at being unable to find new employment. Like Mr. Wilkins, she rethought her work.
What both specialists discovered offers a path for executives nationwide:
* Realize that nothing is forever. Said Ms. Gadberry: "Get security out of your head. Think about it: is there really one company you can guarantee will always be profitable, that will never reorganize?" Added Mr. Wilkins: "You are totally responsible for your family's security. You can't delegate that. And until you recognize that fact, you can't be helped."
* Get involved. Start looking for your next job while you are still employed. Ms. Gadberry recommended becoming active in professional groups in your field and building networks you can contact for work if you need it. Mr. Wilkins recommended joining the United Way or the YMCA: "Rub elbows with people in other professions. See how other folks make money. "
* Know yourself. "Take a specific look at what you do best," Ms. Gadberry said. "The problem with most general managers is that they have lost their skills. You need a backup talent with which you can make money, even if it's by the hour."
* Dream. "Figure out what you'd like to do if you weren't doing this," Mr. Wilkins said. "Maybe you want to teach, or start your own business. Visit the career development center at your local community college or your alma mater and spend a hundred bucks on aptitude and interest tests. It might give you some alternative career ideas." Mr. Wilkins had one client, the former vice president of a bank that had been acquired by another, who decided that he really wanted to own a shop in a small town. He now owns a hardware store in a village in Northern California.
* Talk to your family. Often your spouse knows more about your needs than you do. Recalls Ms. Gadberry: "I worked with a guy with high blood pressure from beating his head against the corporate wall. I called his wife in who told me 'I don't want him doing this anymore.' The man was shocked. Turned out he was doing all of this for her."
* Cut the best deal. When you are fired, hold out for the best severance package. For compensation, the rule of thumb is still a month's severance pay for every $10,000 in salary. Ask for open-ended outplacement support until you find a new job. And ask for your benefits to continue for the duration of the severance.
* Do not panic, but work fast. Contact your outplacement person the instant you are fired. Start the ball rolling and then relax. You will probably have months of severance pay, and if you pace yourself you will have fun and a new career at the end.
* Be creative. Mr. Wilkins has his clients imagine what they would like to be. Ms. Gadberry has her more traditional clients look at mid-sized companies that want people with experience at big companies, even if only as a "rented" executive who is hired for a few months or so.
In the end, it usually comes down to the inventiveness of the unemployed executive. Mr. Hillary helped found a support group for unemployed human resource executives called HRx. They swapped notes on interviews and shared resume tricks. HRx now has two branches and 60 members. And Mr. Hillary, now the manager of corporate human resources for the health maintenance organization Take Care Inc. in Concord, Calif., remains in the group. After all, he said, "you never know when you'll be looking again."

HEADLINE: Somalis Work to Rebuild Their Country

 BODY:
To The Editor:
Michael Maren's "Good Will and Its Limits in Somalia" (Op-Ed, Aug. 27) is not an accurate reflection of the work being undertaken by CARE, the Cooperative for American Relief Everywhere, and other humanitarian agencies in Somalia. It also does a disservice to the Somalis who are struggling to rebuild their country. 
 Less than a year ago, each day as many as 3,000 innocent Somalis, mostly children, were dying horrible deaths from starvation. Thanks to the international relief effort, support by military intervention and the efforts of the Somali people, starvation ended. Life is slowly returning to normal for millions of needy people, but hunger is still a major problem.
Last spring, CARE distributed seeds and tools to thousands of farmers, who are now harvesting a good crop of sorghum. But domestically grown food is not enough to provide for even half the Somali population.
Also, in a country virtually lacking employment opportunities, our programs are designed to provide jobs and further economic rehabilitation.
Through the targeted sale of wheat -- a commodity not readily available in the Somali marketplace -- to a select group of local traders, CARE has raised the equivalent of about $1 million. We have channeled $564,000 into rehabilitation projects in water, health, sanitation and construction. These programs employ thousands of Somalis in rebuilding their country.
Some of our projects are the cleaning and repairing of the irrigation systems connected to the Juba and Shebelle Rivers. As a result of these projects, for which we pay people with food and provide them with tools, cement and other supplies, we will increase the agricultural output in these areas, providing permanent employment opportunties.
I lived in Somalia for months as United Nations coordinator for humanitarian relief at the height of the famine and into the beginning of rehabilitation efforts. Having witnessed Somalia in the famine, and now seeing the fragile regeneration, I urge you and your readers not to let irresponsible charges keep us from following the moral imperative to help the Somalis as they move toward self-sufficiency.
 
PHIL JOHNSTON
Chief Executive Officer, CARE
Atlanta, Aug. 27, 1993

LENGTH: 1183 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ADVISERS STUDY NEW MOVES TO SPUR ECONOMY

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Stuck with a tight budget and uncertain economic prospects, top economic advisers in the Clinton Administration are eyeing the same types of measures to stimulate the economy that the Bush Administration used during the Presidential election campaign last year.
The measures on the drafting table, which, by and large, would not require Congressional approval, are being discussed by Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the Council of Economic Advisers, and other high-level aides. The plans include speeding work on military contracts or easing regulations on Government lending. 
 Such steps are supposed to provide small but concentrated doses of job stimulus for selected industries, groups of workers and regions -- California, in particular -- in the event that the economy stalls or job growth fails to pick up.
"Several of us are developing ideas and exchanging memoranda with an eye toward advising the President on this matter," Mr. Reich said in an interview last week.
 
Should Affect Spending Schedule
 The measures are intended to affect the timing and the target of spending, loans and tax collections without changing the overall budget totals, as well as to stimulate private business activity by rewriting banking, airline and other regulations.
Since the defeat of the Administration's stimulus package by Congress, the economics team has been frustrated by the Administration's lack of fiscal tools to bolster the modest and uneven economic recovery. "Given defeat of the stimulus plan, given slow growth," an Administration official said, "the question became: What could you do? Are there ways to stimulate the economy with little or no on-budget effects?"
 
Still in Draft Stages
 Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader who worked to defeat the Administration's stimulus package during the spring, said Friday: "It's fine with me as long as they don't overreach. They've got the authority."
While the broad outlines of a plan have been spelled out, the specifics are far from final. "This has not reached the level of the full N.E.C.," said Mr. Reich, referring to the National Economic Council. "The President has made no decisions yet."
Last year, the Bush Administration used its discretionary authority to cut income tax withholding and to hasten Pentagon purchases of military hardware, both actions intended to lift confidence and economic growth. At the time the Clinton camp derided the moves as gimmicks, but now the Clinton economic advisers say the measures were effective in temporarily lifting growth and that their earlier criticisms had more to do with President George Bush's motivation -- re-election -- than with his methods.
Among the economic advisers involved, a range of views exists about when the contingency measures might be needed. With unemployment at 6.7 percent, some advisers said they did not think the contingency measures would be necessary, while others said they thought California's 9 percent unemployment rate justified the action now.
According to several officials, California is a focal point of the planning. The state's high unemployment rate is responsible for three- or four-tenths of a percentage point of the national unemployment rate. And, not coincidentally, California, with its large number of electoral votes, is the state without which the Democrats cannot hope to win a majority in the 1996 Presidential election.
"California is a special case," Mr. Reich said.
Indeed, both the Bush and the Clinton Administrations have used discretionary spending authority to aid California. After the Los Angeles riots, for example, the Bush Administration eased the terms for Government small-business loans.
Joseph Stiglitz, one of the three members of the Council of Economic Advisers, has been the main aide responsible for laying out the principles of the contingency plan and coming up with a list of promising actions.
 
Accelerate Job Creation
 According to several people familiar with the memorandums being circulated, the options being considered include accelerating spending that has already been authorized in the budget, like military procurement, research and operations outlays. That kind of spending, these people said, could also be arranged to, for instance, step up spending on programs that can create jobs faster than others, like highway resurfacing rather than highway construction, which requires more planning.
Mr. Reich spoke of using his discretionary authority over some fraction of the Federal training funds to expand the programs in California and other states with high unemployment.
The Administration might also ease the rules governing direct Government lending and banking regulations. That could encourage private-sector borrowing or spending. Altering tax rules is another option.
An advantage of trying to manipulate tax collections is that they can be used to affect incomes quickly, but the effects are very diffuse. Other measures, like providing temporary breaks that encourage businesses to spend now rather than later, may be effective, but would require Congressional approval.
One option under review, which would also need Congressional approval, is the widening of an existing capital gains rollover provision for sellers of stock who apply the proceeds to invest in poor urban areas.
But as the planners acknowledged, the potential impact of the possibilities they are considering is overshadowed by the slowing of Government spending and the tax increases in the 1994 budget.
As the budget official said, "The Government in its contractionary state doesn't have a lot of capacity to provide that kind of stimulus."
 
Leveraging a Limited Influence
 The rationale of the planners is to be prepared and to make better use of what they have to help the economy, parts of which are clearly struggling.
"It does make a lot of sense to have a contingency plan in place," said John Taylor, a Stanford professor who served on President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers.
But they are less sure that tinkering with timing and rewriting a few rules would have a significant effect or whether it would be worth it. For one thing, the scope might be smaller than the advisers think.
"I have a little less confidence on tax collections having much effect than the timing of defense expenditures," Professor Taylor said. "But both of them, relative to $6 trillion economy, are fairly small."
Tinkering with timing could come back to haunt the economy, as in fact it did in the case of the Bush Administration measures. In retrospect, they bolstered the economy as it was already gathering steam and then hurt it this spring as military procurement plunged in the first quarter and income growth stalled in the second.
"It's pretty clear that the Bush people tried to goose up defense and they did get faster growth for a quarter or so," said Jonathan Makin at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research organization in Washington. "The problem with doing that is that more now means less later."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
For Jefferson, the Presidency Held Second Place

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Thomas Jefferson
A Life
By Willard Sterne Randall
708 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $35. 
 Writing his own epigraph, Thomas Jefferson omitted the fact that he had served as President of the United States for two difficult terms. Instead, he listed as his achievements that he was author of the Declaration of Independence and the Virginia statute of religious freedom and father of the University of Virginia. To some modern historians, Jefferson doesn't quite make the summit of the very greatest American Presidents. In their view, Jefferson's true greatness -- his ideas about an enlightened people's government -- preceded his Presidency.
We learn why in Willard Sterne Randall's welcome one-volume biography, "Thomas Jefferson: A Life." It was hardly possible to surpass the language and power of the Declaration, written a quarter of a century before Jefferson became the third President. Have there ever been more idealistic phrases than "all men are created equal" or "the pursuit of happiness"? Both defined the new nation's aims.
Mr. Randall's frequently repetitious book shows that no President was better prepared for the job. Jefferson was a delegate to the first Continental Congress, the drafter of the Declaration of Independence and of a draft of a constitution for Virginia, a member of the Virginia House of Delegates, the Governor of Virginia, the Minister to France, an advocate of a Bill of Rights for the Constitution, the Secretary of State, a founder of the Democratic-Republican party, the Vice President of the United States and the president of the American Philosophical Society (an honor that gave him greater pleasure than the American Presidency). His succession to the White House almost came naturally.
Yet Mr. Randall, a popular historian whose previous books include "A Little Revenge: Benjamin Franklin at War with His Son" and "Benedict Arnold: Patriot and Traitor," points out that Jefferson was elected only after a vicious political campaign. He was pilloried for his unorthodox religious views, his scholarly interests, his devotion to democracy and his cultured tastes. The charge of atheism in a nation still dominated by its clergy was most devastating. The mudslinging included printed and whispered charges that Jefferson, a slaveholder, maintained a "Congo Harem."
Any life of Jefferson written today must confront the question of Sally Hemings. How much credence should be given to the theory that the slave girl was Jefferson's concubine and that he was the father of her children? In "Thomas Jefferson: An Intimate History," Fawn M. Brodie attempted to prove the rumors to be true by deduction and guesswork and, in "Sally Hemings," Barbara Chase-Ribaud wrote a novel that turned the theory into fiction.
Mr. Randall gives the fanciful tale of a Jefferson-Hemings sexual relationship the right amount of space: very little. In less than two pages, he argues that the original accusations were politically motivated and the "evidence" was built on a house of canards. "She was only 8 when Jefferson last resided at Monticello and was mourning his wife's death," he writes. "Unless Brodie was suggesting that Jefferson consoled himself by having an affair with an 8-year-old child, the whole chain of suppositions is preposterous."
On the far more controversial subject of Jefferson's ownership of slaves, the biography descends into hagiography: "Jefferson's views on slavery had evolved over the years as he wrestled with America's worst problem. As a young lawyer, he had argued in court the birthright of freedom of all men that he had imbibed from his study of the classics. As Governor of Virginia, he wrote in his 'Notes' racist views of blacks as inferiors who would need to be treated like children once they were freed gradually. Now, an old man, he worried about the growing dissension over slavery that had flared into angry debate in Congress over the admission of Missouri as a slave state."
After decades of public service, Jefferson was broke and in debt at the end of his life. Unlike Washington, who had been able to free his slaves in his will, Jefferson as a debtor had lost the ability to grant his slaves freedom as his dying wish. But he pleaded with his creditors to be generous and grant his deathbed request to free his personal servants, to give them the tools of their trade and to build houses for them near their work.
Mr. Randall's biography strikes a balance between Jefferson's personal and public life. His five years in France are filled with interesting facts; he was an intellectual match for France's philosophes. To be sure, the author devotes a good deal of attention to Maria Cosway, Jefferson's great amour in Paris. The secret letters that passed between them, their carriage rides, rendezvous and romance are described in loving detail.
But Jefferson worked hard as a diplomat; when he became President, his knowledge and contacts abroad enabled him to be, in effect, his own Secretary of State and led to his greatest triumph, the Louisiana Purchase in 1803. Jefferson's political opponents said it was unconstitutional, but the new western lands doubled the size of the United States and brought greater freedom and economic independence from the Old World that Jefferson -- America's preeminent aristocrat of the mind -- so distrusted.
The most original section of Mr. Randall's book describes Jefferson's underestimated years as a lawyer on the frontier and in many trailblazing court cases. According to his perfectly preserved casebook, Jefferson handled nearly a thousand cases between 1767 and 1774. Without Jefferson's training and knowledge of the law, the Declaration of Independence might not have been written with its brilliant legalistic as well as humanistic design.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Willard Sterne Randall (Nancy A. Nahra/Henry Holt & Company)

HEADLINE: Chamorro and Foes Settling Disputes, Smoothing Way for Talks With Sandinistas

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 5

 BODY:
In negotiations to resolve the political crisis consuming Nicaragua, the Government and its conservative opponents are reaching agreements on issues that have divided them for months.
The talks, which began last week, turned today to some of the most serious differences between the Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and the center-right coalition that supported her election in 1990, then broke with her last year. 
 If some key issues are resolved, officials say they will join in a three-way "national dialogue" on the country's most pressing political and economic problems as early as Monday. The third party involved is the leftist Sandinista National Liberation Front.
"The pressure of the people, the church and the international community is forcing us to move forward," said Nicaragua's Finance Minister, Emilio A. Pereira, one of the Government representatives to the talks.
Nicaraguans, impoverished by years of economic decline, have been demanding that politicians end the bickering that has destabilized the Government and scared off potential investors.
The infighting dates from early 1991, when the center-right alliance that brought Mrs. Chamorro to power began to withdraw its support, complaining of a continuing Sandinista presence, the Government's failure to return properties confiscated by the Sandinistas, and other issues. Conservative parties abandoned the National Assembly altogether last fall, forcing Mrs. Chamorro to govern with the help of Sandinista legislators.
Pressure for a political settlement rose last month when former rivals from the country's civil war each took dozens of hostages in a standoff that lasted nearly a week. But what appeared to have quickened the pace most was Mrs. Chamorro's sudden assertion of control over the Sandinista-dominated armed forces.
On Thursday, Mrs. Chamorro outraged Sandinista leaders by announcing that next year she would remove their main representative in her Government, Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra, as chief of the army.
A handful of Latin American and European Governments have been prodding the factions for months to work out their differences. The United States, which has threatened to cut $98 million in aid pending an investigation of possible Nicaraguan ties to terrorism, has also begun pressing for a settlement.
Heightening the uncertainty over the aid was an announcement by Nicaraguan officials late Saturday that they had found a safehouse outside Managua where hundreds of weapons and hundreds of thousands of rounds of ammunition were stockpiled. Officials linked it to the Guatemalan National Revolutionary Union, the alliance of small rebel armies that has been fighting the Guatemalan Goverment since the 1960's.
It was the most recent of 24 safehouses and arms deposits to be found in Nicaragua since one belonging to former Salvadoran guerrillas blew up on May 23 beneath a Managua auto-repair shop. Documents found in the cache suggested that Sandinista security officials may have aided foreign guerrilla groups involved in kidnappings and terrorist activities.
Mindful of the high stakes for Nicaragua, the Presidents of Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Costa Rica are sending senior envoys to Managua on Monday for the start of the three-way dialogue. The Secretary General of the O.A.S., Joao Baena Soares, is to arrive on Tuesday.
Nicaragua's Roman Catholic Primate, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, and Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations have agreed to join the Latin American envoys in overseeing the dialogue and verifying any agreements that emerge from it.
After agreeing to terms for the international verification, Mrs. Chamorro's Government and the center-right National Opposition Union reached an accord Saturday on expanding the country's Supreme Court to dilute the control of Sandinista justices. They have also made progress on plans that would give the coalition greater representation in the administration.
But negotiators have yet to resolve the most contentious issues, including a demand by the coalition for the resignations of nine centrist legislators who split from it last year to support a working alliance between Mrs. Chamorro and the Sandinistas. Mr. Pereira said Mrs. Chamorro had no legal autority to compel such resignations.

HEADLINE: From Signs to Pistols, Cash-Short Cities Sell Past

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Souvenir toe tags from the coroner's office. Espresso bars in libraries. Used manhole covers for sale as coffee tables. Inch-thick steel bars from an old jail, priced at $5 each. And a sheep parade.
As government budgets shrink in hard times, many cities and towns are looking for new ways to raise money, and they are finding them. 
 Old parking meters, traffic lights and fire hydrants that once were sent to the dump are becoming surprising sources of revenue as souvenirs. Government records and data like zoning maps that used to be provided free now often carry a price tag.
The concept of the "city store," pioneered in San Diego, is catching on, with items like old voting machines, stop signs or fire helmets on sale.
 
Bullet-Riddled Signs
 In the San Diego store, bullet-riddled signs reading "Discharge of Firearms Prohibited" sold out so quickly that replicas are now being manufactured and sent to a police firing range to acquire bullet holes.
Among the best-selling items at the City of Chicago Store are bricks from the old Comiskey Park, where the White Sox once played. Among recent customers, Bill Williams, a restaurant owner, bought one for $19.95 as an investment, saying, "When these things are gone, they're gone."
Doug Peterson, a senior policy analyst with the National League of Cities in Washington, said, "Cities and counties are discovering that consumers and businesses are willing to spend big money on things they never before thought they could sell."
The idea is to get away from taxes, said Dr. Costas Toregas, director of Public Technology Inc., a nonprofit company in Washington seeking to improve technology in municipal governments. "Instead of taxing individuals," he said, "the idea is to create economic activity which enlarges the revenue pile."
 
Cat and Dog Products
 In Los Angeles, a county official, Dusty Brogan, has received a grant to help create money-making schemes for agencies that include the Public Defenders office, which markets a new video conferencing system, and the Animal Control Department, which has begun selling carrying boxes for cats and designer dog tags.
"In the early 80's a lot of government agencies didn't want to touch this stuff," Ms. Brogan said. "But as the fiscal crisis continued, they've had to start thinking not just about spending money but about making money. It's the key to our survival."
Many municipalities have not yet ventured beyond tried-and-true auctions of stolen vehicles and "garage sales" of surpluses, including computers or library books or snowplows.
And some money-making schemes are drawing criticism. For example, police departments are selling off thousands of used revolvers as they upgrade weapons, buying semiautomatic pistols to match firepower with criminals.
 
Risks for the Taking
 But traditionally cautious bureaucracies must begin taking risks like companies in the private sector, Ms. Brogan said.
Her star example is the office of the Los Angeles County coroner, which has been overwhelmed by the demand for its $5 personalized identification toe tags reading "This could be you," its $20 beach blankets with the outline of a body and its $5 gold-and-white lapel pins bearing the coroner's seal.
The success of the sales may help keep alive a program, threatened by budget cuts, that gives educational tours of the morgue to teen-agers convicted of drunken driving.
Marilyn Lewis, executive secretary of the coroner's office, said that success had fired the imagination and that workers were considering expanding into body-bag sleeping bags, boxer shorts with the logo "the undertakers" and T-shirts that read, "When your day ends, ours starts."
She said departments around the country had called for ideas about starting similar programs.
 
Success in Atlanta
 Atlanta has had an unexpected success in selling tens of thousands of souvenirs bearing the "Whatizit," an odd-looking blue mascot for the 1996 Olympic Games, which are being held in the city.
In Arkansas, the little town of Evening Shade, 100 miles north of Little Rock, is capitalizing on being the namesake for a television series and has raised $430,000 through the sale of 195,000 cookbooks and 1,000 T-shirts.
The cookbooks have rescued the school district, which serves 300 students, after a cut in state financing left it with a $45,000 deficit. They have also paid to build a new gymnasium.
In keeping with the new spirit of municipal entrepreneurship, the 73-year-old Kanawha County jail in Charleston, W. Va., is being sold off in pieces after it was closed last July.
The county Administrator, Richard A. Atkinson, said the sale, scheduled to begin late this month, would include 100 brass cellblock keys, made in 1920, at $20 each; 170 steel doors weighing 350 pounds each, at $25, and "an infinite supply" of inch-thick steel bars, at $5.
"A fraternity could use it for their bathroom," Mr. Atkinson said of the doors. "Some people might want to wear the keys as jewelry. Someone who spent some time there could wear the key as a necklace and say, 'Wish I had this when I was in jail.' "
Some enterprising officials have converted their government agencies into thriving businesses. In San Leandro, Calif., a city of 75,000 people south of Oakland, the main library recently opened a 60-seat cafe in an outdoor atrium where bookworms can relax with coffee and pastry.
"Government libraries are all suffering," said David R. Bohne, director of the San Leandro library. "The money I make in the cafe we'll plow right back into books and tapes."
The cafe has been so successful that the library has hired two employees to run it, despite a $30,000 budget cut. And Mr. Bohne has begun branching out into a catering service and plans to open a for-profit business services center at the library in November.
Espresso is also saving a government program in Seattle. Operating in government buildings, young people from inner-city areas sell coffee from carts that have been donated by private companies.
Since June, the carts have been earning about $1,000 a week, which is being used to keep alive programs that provide inner-city recreational centers.
 
Stopping Street-Sign Theft
 Several cities are finding that replicas of street signs are big sellers. For example, New York's program, begun as an effort to pre-empt street-sign theft, has become a significant money-earner for the Department of Transportation, generating $60,000 over the last two fiscal years.
The most popular signs, said Joe DePlasco, a Transportation Department spokesman, are Broadway, 42d Street and Wall Street. The last, coincidentally, is also the most stolen street sign in the city, he said.
Smaller towns have their own approaches to raising money. In Reedpoint, Mont., home to just 90 people, citizens held a sheep drive today at which 2,000 sheep were paraded down the main street. Last year, booth fees and an auction at the sheep parade netted the town $9,000, which was used to buy a water truck for the volunteer fire department and double the size of Reedpoint's library.
All of this innovation may look a little laggard to the Woodland Park Zoo in Seattle, which has been turning its own detritus into profits for the last decade.
To avoid escalating costs of waste disposal, it began composting its daily tons of manure into "Zoodoo" and selling it to gardeners. The program pays for itself, said Lanayse Cipolla, a spokeswoman for the city, and contributes $20,000 a year into the general fund.

In San Diego, where the concept of a store's selling of municipal property as souvenirs was pioneered, Jean Wehrli, a tourist from Switzerland, browsed through city signs and banners. (Robert Burroughs for The New York Times)
