HEADLINE: Auto Talks Hang on Health Costs But Workers Are Loath to Chip In

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Since learning last year that he had multiple sclerosis, Andy Torok has become less and less steady on his feet, and his worries have accumulated along with the hand prints on his apartment's white walls.
But as Mr. Torok has shuttled among specialists, sampling different steroids and undergoing test after test, he has not had to give a single thought to how much his health care costs. 
 Mr. Torok, who had to stop working in March, is a member of the United Automobile Workers union, so he has paid nothing.
"Not a dime," said Mr. Torok, 39, who lives in Davison, Mich., just north of here. "I'd be downright scared to know what it's costing."
 
 
The Biggest Private Spender
 The automobile companies, which have kept careful track of the cost of caring for their workers, profess to be plenty scared. Mr. Torok's employer, the General Motors Corporation, is the largest private purchaser of health care in the United States, having spent some $3.7 billion last year. Just for its union members, G.M. health care costs amount to $711 for each car and truck that it builds in North America, or about what G.M. charges for air-conditioning on a small Chevrolet.
A total of more than a million hourly workers, retirees and family members from G.M., the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation pay little or nothing for almost all of their treatment, from an examination for a sore throat to open-heart surgery.
Now, as the Big Three negotiate a national labor contract with the U.A.W. this fall, the companies are insisting that workers chip in -- a proposal the union steadfastly rejects.
Union leaders say that their members paid for their benefits by accepting them instead of wage increases. For the aging workers, existing health benefits are not only a prized financial cushion but a stirring symbol of their union's accomplishments. In fact, union officials argue that their system -- which has held the rate of growth in health care costs for auto workers below the national rate -- could serve as a national model.
If there is a strike this year, union and company officials and financial analysts say, health care is the issue that will provoke it. "When the company says co-payment, a lot of U.A.W. members hear strike," said Harley Shaiken, a visiting professor at the University of California at Berkeley who specializes in labor relations. "We may be backing into a serious dispute."
The issue is how best, given existing benefits, to limit costs. The companies insist that asking workers to contribute each time they seek care will force them to be more selective. The union contends that the companies can better control costs by using their leverage as huge purchasers of health care -- much the way the Canadian Government controls prices.
Already, the union and the companies have made some progress controlling costs by encouraging workers to move into managed care plans like networks of doctors and hospitals or health maintenance organizations.
Meanwhile, the eyes of health care reformers are upon them. "Everyone interested in health reform is watching these negotiations," said Dr. Paul Elwood, president of the Jackson Hole Group, an influential coalition of health care industry executives and analysts. "It indicates how flexible the unions are going to be about health care reform" -- an important factor, he said, since the Clinton Administration has paid close attention to organized labor's health care concerns.
Health care experts, Dr. Elwood said, have long viewed the U.A.W.'s benefits package as contributing to rising health care costs because of its lack of controls. Without some mechanism for encouraging workers to choose the cheapest plan available, he said, costs would continue to grow.
As it is shaping up, the Clinton plan would have no effect on the auto workers' benefits during the term of the next contract. Down the road, it would force them to pay Federal income tax on benefits that exceed those in a standard package guaranteed to all Americans. In addition, in another sharp departure from current law, employers could not take tax deductions for money they spend on the extra benefits, Administration officials have indicated.
"The Clinton plan would not require auto workers to share in the cost of health insurance," Dr. Elwood said. "It lets labor off the hook."
The companies have repeatedly said they cannot wait for national health care reform to control their costs.
"It's the fastest-increasing item of our employment cost," said a top Ford executive who spoke on the condition of anonymity while the contract talks are under way. Ford is leading negotiations with the U.A.W.
On average, the Big Three pay about $5,700 a year per worker for health care, according to the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan. In 1992, the national average health care cost per employee was $3,968, according to a survey by A. Foster Higgins & Company. While no reliable figures exist for Japanese auto makers' average health care costs, they are believed to be far less than those of the Big Three.
Some form of cost-sharing, the companies argue, will discourage unnecessary doctors' visits by workers. But the union predicts that that approach will only generate greater costs later on -- when that slight chest pain, ignored by the penny-pinching worker, turns into cardiac arrest. Bargaining with providers and encouraging workers to go to health maintenance organizations, union officials point out, has helped the companies hold the rate of growth in health care costs for auto workers below the national rate in recent years. At G.M. for instance, where 36 percent of the work force is in some form of managed care, the annual increase in health care costs has averaged 8.7 percent since 1985 compared with 12.7 percent nationwide.
Union leaders and members are adamant that they will never pay more. "We fought too damn hard for health care," said Mr. Torok, who spent most of his 17 years with G.M. assembling housings for air filters.
And the comprehensive benefits, he said, were necessary, particularly for workers who spent many years laboring in conditions that can be miserable. "They're a lifesaver, there's no other way I can say it," he said. "Because of them, I'm getting the care I need."
Mr. Torok is young for an auto worker, and his generation, he said, is often criticized by older workers for taking their union and its hard-fought gains for granted. "But people my age are about to find out what it's like to fight for what we have," he said.
 
No 'Gift From Heaven'
 In a meeting with reporters last week, Owen F. Bieber, the president of the U.A.W., bristled when asked how he could expect the average American, with less generous benefits, to understand the union's ironclad position on sharing costs.
"This wasn't just a gift from heaven, or a gift from the companies," Mr. Bieber said. He argued that workers had paid for the benefits over many years, in effect, by taking them in lieu of wage increases. "If the American public understood that we paid for this, then I hope they would accept the fact that we're entitled to it."
Furthermore, Mr. Bieber pointed out, the union has been pushing Washington to institute national health coverage.
 
Wages Among the Highest
 The companies counter that while union members may have sacrificed for the benefits, they are nevertheless among the nation's best-paid manufacturing workers. At Ford, for example, the average assembly line worker makes about $17.01 an hour, or $48,065 a year, with 35 paid days off.
Mr. Bieber and other union representatives are now closeted with Ford negotiators, trying to replace the current three-year contract, which expires at 11:59 P.M. on Sept. 14.
The companies have taken steps to try to control costs on their own. Ford, for example, has used its influence as a big buyer of prescription drugs to try to cut drug prices, the company's fastest-growing health care expense.
But Big Three auto executives worry that they may have exhausted their ability to extract such savings.
Increasingly, these executives and union officials say, the union has cooperated in efforts to control costs, and their efforts have at least succeeded in slowing the rate of increase. Despite its blanket condemnation of co-payments, the U.A.W. has recently permitted minimal co-payments -- $2 or $5 -- for prescription drugs for many workers.
The union has also encouraged workers to join plans in which the companies can negotiate with the providers over prices. Mr. Torok, for example, can consult a specialist only after his primary-care physician has seen him and given him a referral.
 
 
Panels of Doctors
 The union and the companies have also held down the costs of foot care by setting up panels of doctors who perform specific treatments at set rates. Workers who go elsewhere must pay part of the cost. A similar approach has limited the cost of treatment for drug and alcohol abuse.
But the union has refused to force workers into more such programs. And many of the managed care programs that are in place have not come cheap; G.M. has found that most of them cost more than traditional coverage.
Efforts at the local level to root out the source of high costs have often been equally unsuccessful. "It's about like trying to grab an octopus -- he's going to grab you back," said Jim King, president of U.A.W. Local 663 in Anderson, Ind.
Mr. King spent two years on a joint union-management task force examining health care costs in Anderson, but the group finally disbanded. "I guess with the frustration of not being able to make a dent in it, it kind of gave out," he said.
Still, he added, "We do share management's concern, and we are working to try to get it down."
 
 
Shared Sacrifice
 For G.M., the need to control health care expenses is particularly urgent. Last fall, the company imposed co-payments on its salaried workers, and John F. Smith Jr., the company's president and chief executive, indicated he would see that the sacrifice was shared by the blue-collar workers. If the new contract includes no cost sharing, morale among G.M.'s salaried workers may suffer.
G.M. also has a far greater economic burden than Ford or Chrysler, according to an analysis by the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation. Because G.M. has so many workers and retirees relative to the number of cars it sells, it pays more than twice as much for health care per vehicle as Ford: $711 compared with $309.
"It's not the U.A.W. workers' fault that it costs so much more," said Sean McAlinden, a research scientist who worked on the study. "It's the fault of people who design cars that don't sell."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I'd be downright scared to know what it's costing," said Andy Torok, who learned last year that he has multiple sclerosis but has not had to pay any of his health care costs. His employer, the General Motors Corporation, is the largest private purchaser of health care in the United States, having spent some $3.7 billion last year. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)(pg. 8)
 
Table: "THE CLINTON HEALTH PLAN: COSTS AND COVERAGE"
 On Saturday, senior Administration officials presented an outline of the health plan President Clinton is to propose later this month. The plan would extend a standard package of health insurance benefits for all Americans.
 The standard package would be paid for by employers and employees through premiums averaging $1,800 a year for individuals and $4,200 a year for families. Employers would be required to pay 80 percent. Subsidies would be provided for small businesses with low-wage workers.
 Businesses would be able to offer more generous packages, but the extra benefits would be treated as taxable income to employees, and companies could not use them as tax deductions. This measure may be phased in over eight to 10 years.
 Employees would have a choice between high and low cost-sharing plans -- between traditional fee-for-service coverage vs. health maintenance organizations and other forms of managed care. Those choosing the high cost-sharing plan would pay deductibles of $200 for an individual and $400 for a family and 20 percent of the cost of most services beyond that up to a maximum of $2,000 a year for an individual or $3,000 a year for a family. The patient's share would be higher for some services, like psychotherapy. In the low cost-sharing plan, there would be no deductible, and comparatively small fees for some services.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1993
 
The Economy
The Administration's top economic advisers are considering the same types of measures to stimulate the economy that the Bush Administration used during the election campaign last year. Stuck with a tight budget and uncertain economic prospects, the White House may speed up work on military contracts or ease regulations on Government lending, among other steps. The White House hopes to provide small, concentrated doses of job stimulus for selected industries, groups of workers and regions -- California, in particular -- in the event that the economy stalls or job growth fails to pick up as expected. [Page 1.]
As the Big Three negotiate a national labor contract with auto workers, the companies insist that workers chip in for health care benefits. If there is a strike this year, union and company officials say health care is the issue that will provoke it. [1.] 
 Black-owned banks are reaching out to people in other communities as they face new competition for their traditional customers. Paradoxically, a main factor in the competition is a Federal drive to improve banking services to minority communities. [33.]
How much would citizens voluntarily pay to protect wildlife or prevent pollution? "Contingent value" measurements of "passive uses" of the environment are on the verge of becoming an accepted tool in setting policy. Economic Watch. [1.]
The art of fly-fishing has captivated thousands of new anglers and converts, producing record sales for equipment manufacturers, retailers and organizers of fly-fishing schools and trips. Many company officials attribute their good fortune to the popularity of "A River Runs Through It," a recent film version of Norman Maclean's memoir. Others see it as a sport that indulges a primordial urge in a generation uneasy about hunting. [33.]
Cities and towns are seeking new ways to raise money as budgets shrink. They are finding them in sales of souvenirs, library espresso bars and knickknacks from the coroner's office. [6.]
Residents of Metamora, Mich., prodded first the state and then the U.S. Government to clean up their dump, which had taken in wastes from some large companies. Now some of those residents say the cleanup may have made things worse. [7.]
 
Companies
Renault of France and Volvo of Sweden are expected to merge, with Renault controlling a 65 percent stake in the combined operation. The companies seek to forge a venture strong enough to weather a deep Europan slump and intensifying global competition. An announcement is expected today. [33.]
 
International
No progress was reported toward a U.S.-China textile accord after two days of talks. The chief American negotiator has warned that without a new agreement Washington could unilaterally and substantially reduce quotas for Chinese textiles. [33.]

The Media Business
Four leading music distributors have changed their minds about withdrawing millions of dollars in advertising and promotional allowances from retailers who sold used CD's. Although the sale of used CD's is legal in retail stores, distributors have objected that the practice reduces record company profits. In addition, recording artists protest that it deprives them of royalty payments. [35.]
Broadcasters have decided to start their own specialized cable channels, which hardly anyone will watch, joining the cable industry after months of trying to fight it. Bill Carter: Television. [35.]
Rupert Murdoch has burst back onto the British media scene, displaying his old touch for shaking things up. He has introduced expanded programming for B Sky B, a satellite and cable network, and slashed the weekday price of The Times of London. [35.]
Reed Elsevier will buy the assets of Official Airline Guides for $417 million. The British-Dutch publishing conglomerate struck the deal with the administrators of Maxwell Communication. [34.]
 Expectations are high for the premiere of Chevy Chase's late night show, despite David Letterman's strong showing on CBS. Indeed, a flood of publicity for Mr. Letterman may have helped. [35.]
When it comes to finding new spaces to sell to advertisers, USA Today is all ears. [34.]
 
Today's Column
A newly patented computer system will weigh and record the food consumed by people whose eating habits are under study. Teresa Riordan: Patents. [34.]

HEADLINE: Black Bankers Seek Broader Market

BYLINE: By VERONICA BYRD

 BODY:
Citizens Trust Bank, the largest black-owned bank in Atlanta, for the first time in its 72-year history is aiming at white, Korean and Hispanic customers.
Using a new advertising campaign with the slogan "Look to us . . . we listen," Citizens put up 13 billboards in English, Korean and Spanish in minority and predominantly white areas last year. Citizens said it also planned to open two branches next year in predominantly white areas. 
 "We are trying to diversify our base," said William L. Gibbs, the president of Citizens. "It's one way for us to gain a competitive edge."
Citizens is far from alone. In the shadow of growing competition, more black-owned banks are "reaching out for mainstream status," said Samuel L. Foggie, the president of the National Bankers Association, a trade group in Washington that represents minority-owned banks.
A principal factor in the competition, oddly enough, is the Federal drive to improve banking services to minority communities, an effort that some black bankers argue could hamper their efforts to expand and threaten their survival.
The black bankers said they were concerned about heightened enforcement of the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977, which mandates lending in underserved areas, and a Clinton Administration proposal to create a network of 100 community development banks. Under an Administration proposal disclosed in July, the existing community development corporations, loan funds and credit unions would also be able to compete for grants from the $382 million pool allotted over four years.
Sylvesta L. Jennings, the chief executive of First State Bank in Danville, Va., said community development banks "could be a problem to us."
"They target the people we have always served," Mr. Jennings said, adding that no provisions were made that "would give banks like mine the capital we need to reach the same people."
Some industry experts, however, said black-owned banks had been slow to develop methods of doing business with large companies and slow to see the potential in affordable-housing loans.
"They tend to wait for loans and deposits to come through the front door," said William M. Cunningham, the president of Creative Investment Research, a Washington-based company that monitors minority-owned financial institutions.
 
'A Very Profitable Niche'
 Community development banks, like South Shore Bank in Chicago, which is not black-owned, exist specifically to provide capital to rebuild low-income areas. These banks found a "very profitable niche in making loans in a black area," Mr. Cunningham said, "and proved that some black banks were not adequately meeting that need."
Indeed, many black-owned banks have tended to aim at the wealthiest and most creditworthy black customers while turning away poorer applicants for fear of losing money on risky loans.
Citizens, which had $127 million in assets in 1992, experienced problems with bad loans over the last three years. "We were slow to recognize the problems," Mr. Gibbs said. "People just were not paying their bills."
The challenges for Citizens highlight the precarious position of many black-owned banks. These banks were founded to serve low- and moderate-income blacks who were often ignored by mainstream banks, but they are now increasingly competing with the larger banks, which are responding to pressure from Washington to invest in inner cities.
 
Using Untried Ways
 In response, black-owned banks are turning to previously untried methods to gain strength. Founders National Bank of Los Angeles began aggressively seeking capital from large corporations. Seaway National Bank of Chicago recently entered the municipal bond trustee business, and United Bank of Philadelphia introduced a national credit card in July.
And some are now copying the trends of the larger banks: interstate mergers.
Omnibanc Corporation, the owner of Omnibank in suburban Detroit, said last month that it would acquire the Drexel National Bank, the fifth-largest black-owned bank, and Independence Bank, the third largest, both based in Chicago.
The acquisitions would make Omnibanc the largest black-owned bank holding company, with $288 million in assets, and the only multistate black-owned banking company.
William T. Johnson, the president of Omnibank, said black-owned banks must "gain a wider base of customers, offer more products and lower their costs" to remain competitive.
 
Profits Nearly Doubled
 There are signs of progress. According to Creative Investment Research, the profits at black-owned banks nearly doubled to $14.7 million in 1992, from $7.4 million in 1991. And nonperforming loans at black-owned banks decreased to $36 million in 1992, Mr. Cunningham said, from $43 million in 1991.
In 1992, the 39 black-owned commercial banks in the United States held assets of $2.3 billion and deposits totaling $2 billion, up slightly from $2 billion in assets and $1.8 billion in deposits in 1991. In addition, loans grew to $969 million in 1992, from $838 million in 1991.
The top 10 black-owned banks had return on assets last year ranging from a low of a negative 0.28 percent at Boston Bank of Commerce to a high of 1.59 percent at Seaway. That compares with an average return on assets of a little more than 1 percent for banks with less than $500 million in assets in 1992.
 
Loan Quality Problems
 Still, Mr. Cunningham said, while the banks are stronger financially and have "gotten a better handle on their loan losses," many continue to "experience some management and loan quality problems."
Banking services have gradually disappeared from inner cities. Between 1977 and 1989, for example, the number of banks in low-income areas declined 10 percent. Savings and loan institutions shrank by nearly a third, and mortgage companies declined by nearly a half.
And some large urban areas are without a major black-owned bank.
Since the collapse of Freedom National Bank in Harlem in November 1990, for example, there has been no black-owned commercial bank in New York. Carver Federal Savings Bank in Harlem, the largest black-owned financial institution in the country with $321 million in assets, is the sole savings and loan.
 
Criticisms From Fed
 That is particularly worrisome to black would-be borrowers aware of the longstanding criticisms of mainstream banks accused of not providing home loans in minority areas.
A report released by the Federal Reserve Board last year found that of the 7.9 million mortgage applications in 1991, more than a third of the applications from blacks were rejected, compared with 17 percent of those from white applicants. Even among blacks with high incomes, 23 percent were rejected, compared with 10 percent of wealthy white applicants.
In response, some large banks have increased their lending to members of minority groups. Chemical Bank and Bank of America reported recently that a larger percentage of their home loans went to minorities in 1992. But Citibank, which tightened its lending requirements last year, said that one result was fewer loans to minority-group members. It turned down 67 percent of all black applicants and 63 percent of Hispanic applicants for mortgage loans in 1992, Citibank said.
Gilda Haas, the founder of Communities for Accountable Reinvestment in Los Angeles, says black-owned banks have the clear advantage because they are "closer to the street and can act faster." Ms. Haas, who is white, and her husband obtained their mortgage loan from a black-owned savings and loan.
The bankers "know the community," Ms. Haas said. "And the community knows and trusts them. The banks aren't these huge bureaucratic voice-mail operations."
 
Cautious Lenders

 
 But that does not mean the institutions are quick to lend. Drexel National Bank, with $128 million in assets, for example, had a loan-to-deposit ratio of just 28 percent during its first quarter, which ended March 31, according to Ferguson & Company, a financial data publishing and consulting company. Independence Bank, with assets of $137 million, had a ratio of 31 percent. The loan-to-deposit ratio for all Chicago banks with less than $500 million in assets was 60 percent.
Jacoby D. Dickens, the chairman of Seaway, the largest black-owned bank with $202 million in assets, said it often lost loans in a fierce battle for the best black customers.
"The bigger banks get them because of their exposure and big advertising budgets," Mr. Dickens said. "That puts us at a great disadvantage."
He added: "The big banks can out- market us and out-advertise us in every way. When an individual thinks about a mortgage, they don't necessarily think about Seaway, they think about Citicorp."
Bruce A. Gottschall, the executive director of Neighborhood Housing Services of Chicago, agreed that Seaway lost some potential customers. But he said he felt "there needs to be more outreach and more counseling assistance to lower-income people who may have situations that need more attention, such as past credit problems or unstable employment."
 
Capital Is a Challenge
 Mr. Gottschall added that there was enough business to go around. "The costs need to be spread across the board," he said.
Maintaining adequate capital is a challenge for black-owned banks, said Carlton J. Jenkins, the managing director at Founders, because "none of the traditional sources of capital, such as investment bankers, large black corporations, high net-worth investors, pension funds and mutual funds have ever seriously focused their resources on minority banks."
Corporations have only recently focused on certain banks for deposits.
In December, the Atlantic Richfield Company invested $1 million in Founders in return for nonvoting preferred stock and said it would match new capital investments made by other corporations this year. Bank of America also recently purchased $1 million in nonvoting preferred stock in Founders.

HEADLINE: Coping With the Endless Summer;
Parents, Teachers and Students Are Left Scrambling

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
Thursday, the day school was supposed to begin, looks pretty good for the Watson family of Brooklyn: Terry Watson, a 45-year-old music therapist, has to work only three hours that day, so she figures she will take Peter, her 8-year-old son, along with her. For a few hours, Adam, 11, could fend for himself.
Friday gets trickier: Mrs. Watson's schedule that day prevents Peter from going with her again, so he might have to go with his father, David, to his job at Dun & Bradstreet, a financial information company. But Mr. Watson is uncertain how the bosses would feel about a third grader, whose temporary snake tattoo is flaking off his tanned arm, mingling with men in suits. So Peter could possibly go to work with Mrs. Watson's sister, or in a pinch, to the office of Mrs. Watson's mother. No one is sure.
 
Rush for Child Care
 Adam, however, would likely stay with a friend, Josh Pomerantz. Josh's mother is a public school teacher, and in this time of confusion and frustration brought on by the asbestos crisis and the delay of school, she will definitely be at home.
"I don't know," Mrs. Watson said this weekend at the family's home in Ditmas Park. "Maybe I'll send them all to Mayor Dinkins's house." 
 Around New York City, nearly a million children cheered last week at the news that school's opening would be pushed back at least until Sept. 20, as workers try to complete the monumental task of inspecting and cleaning up schools with exposed asbestos. But for parents and some students, the delay means trouble: a rush for child care, a few days off from work, worry about missing classes as exams for college or prep school loom or the prolonged anxiety of a new school year.
And among teachers, there is confusion about how the asbestos inspections are progressing at their schools, long-term concern about their health and more immediate questions about their paychecks. With little definite information but plenty of word-of-mouth, many are outraged at how the Board of Education has handled what some call the asbestos mess.
 
From Inconvenience to Chaos
 "What are we supposed to believe?" asked Claire E. Sylvan, a teacher at International High School in Long Island City. "The central board has done a typically ridiculous job informing people. It's unbelievable that they waited until three days before people were supposed to report to tell them not to report."
Until school opens again, pools will stay open, summer recreation programs will be extended, museums and zoos will offer free admission. But in ways large and small, the postponement -- the first in two decades -- has disrupted the rhythms and routines of hundreds of thousands of families. For some, the delay is inconvenient. For others, like the Watsons, it is a logistical nightmare.
 
A Mother's Worries
Disabled Son Will Miss Therapy
 Camelia Flye loves her three boys dearly but is quickly reaching the limit of tolerance. An unemployed single mother, Ms. Flye remembers a hot day in July when she passed through the entrance of her building in Morningside Heights -- scribbled with graffiti announcing "Crime Pays" -- and walked up five flights of stairs to her apartment.
Inside were more children than she could count. They were everywhere, listening to hip-hop, playing video games, being as loud as children are. The possibility of two more weeks, maybe more, of her children out of school in their cramped apartment, seems like more than she can take.
"I'm telling you, I'm looking for a rest," said Ms. Flye, 45, who moved to New York City 20 years ago from St. Louis. "With three boys, it gets to be kind of rambunctious around here."
Tired as she is, her main concern is her 10-year-old son, Jamil, who has emotional problems and is on medication for hyperactivity. He was enrolled this year at Public School 188 in a new program for children with special needs. And like many parents of children with disabilities, Ms. Flye worries about the effects of his missing two weeks of therapy.
As she sees it, the recent problem is just one more sign of neglect in the public schools, a problem that she said ranges from a poor curriculum for special needs children to lead. Now it is asbestos that endangers already tenuous futures, she said.
"Nothing surprises me anymore with the schools," said Ms. Flye, whose other children are 11 and 17 years old. "Most public schools are dominated by blacks and Latinos, so who cares? Most of us are poor, so who really cares?"
"What I'm hoping is that when school starts, the schools are safe, that the repairs are done and nothing like this happens again," she said. "Because what has happened is like attempted murder on children."
 
Fears of Two Teachers
Years in Classroom With Asbestos
 Edie and Shel Haas grew up in the Bronx and have happily taught public school there nearly their entire adult lives. Now, a week after asbestos inspectors sealed off 18 rooms in Mrs. Haas's elementary school in Parkchester, she is looking back with a little worry at her 26 years there.
"A lot of adults have been there for a very long time," said Mrs. Haas, 55, who seems concerned, yet determined to brush it off like a good New Yorker. "I don't have the breath that I had 26 years ago. It could be age. It could be asbestos. We can't tell. I also have allergies I never had. Is that because of asbestos? We don't know."
Her health had never been an issue until last week, when the rooms at Community School 47, including room 213, where she taught for eight years, were closed because of asbestos. She is "not terribly worried," but outraged because she said the central board had issued a report about asbestos in the school two years ago.
"All of a sudden to make this big thing, it's ridiculous," she said, sitting in her home in Fort Lee, N.J. "Everybody knew about it and that's making people angry."
"This is part of a larger problem -- the upkeep of the schools," said Mr. Haas, 63, who last year was an acting assistant principal at Intermediate School 116.
The delay has not been a problem for the Haases, who said they had a relaxing summer of trips and visits with their three grandchildren. But like most teachers, they wonder how it will affect their students. Mr. Haas is concerned especially about students who must take the Preliminary Scholastic Aptitude Tests in October.
"It hasn't inconvenienced us," Mrs. Haas said. "But we're also in a state of limbo. When can we get into our rooms? When can we start our planning sessions? How are the kids going to react? That's our worry now."
 
A Mother's Doubts
Size of Problem Fully Recognized?
 This much was certain as Lillian Lopez set out on a school shopping expedition with her two sons on Saturday: Julian Albert, 12, needed a pair of high-tops, and Conan Albert, 8, needed scissors and construction paper. Less clear, after a roller-coaster week for Ms. Lopez, was exactly when school would start.
Ms. Lopez, who lives in Sunset Park, is a member of the Parents' Asbestos Steering Committee, a group that attends meetings of the officials directing the inspection. Last week, she received dozens of calls from frightened mothers and fathers. But even she had few answers.
"I seriously doubt that schools will open Sept. 20," she said as she ate at a diner with her sons before going shopping. "I've been to all the meetings, and let me tell you, nobody realizes the magnitude of this problem."
It is a problem that affects Ms. Lopez, a single working mother, as much as anyone. Even before the asbestos crisis, she wondered: Could she beg a friend to take them swimming? Could her daughter Sheri, 16, buy groceries and cook dinner?
"Now it's 100 times worse," said Ms. Lopez, director of a group providing technical assistance to parent groups in the city. "I can't believe that school's not going to start yet."
And she is not sure what to do for the next two weeks. She cannot afford a baby sitter so she may take a few days off, or take them to work or find spaces in a public recreation program. Either way, it will not be easy.
But her sons are overjoyed. As Julian piled french fries on top of his pizza burger, he ticked off his plans. "I can go to work with my mom and write stories on her computer," said Julian, an eighth grader at I.S. 136.
"I can watch TV," shouted Conan, who will be in third grade at P.S. 1. "I can mess around!"
By the time he finished eating, Julian had second thoughts. "If you want to know the truth, I'm sick of being with Conan," he said, giving his brother a gentle shove. "I'd rather be in a war than stay home with him for two more weeks."
 
A Teacher's Concerns
Will Postponement Affect Paycheck?
 Stacia Robbins, a teacher at International High School, was pleased with a two-week orientation for new students, many of whom do not speak English. Youngsters from countries like Poland, China, Colombia and Russia started out shy and withdrawn, but by Friday, the last day, they seemed comfortable.
Then she had to tell them that school would not start for at least two weeks. "They were disappointed," she said. "I think it's hard on the kids because they are psyched up."
But Ms. Robbins has her own worries: A payroll problem has held up money she earned teaching summer school, and she has to pay $500 for a course to keep up her state teaching certificate. And she doesn't know if the delay in school's start will also mean a delay in her paycheck.
"I have to pay this and I don't have the money now," said Ms. Robbins, 55, who began teaching eight years ago. "I'm concerned about our paychecks. I'm a single mother and I live check to check."
Susan Amlung, a spokeswoman for the United Federation of Teachers, said teachers will still be paid as if school were in session. But Ms. Robbins's apprehension seemed to underscore the general lack of information echoed by parents and teachers alike about the asbestos inspections and when school will begin.
Ms. Robbins, who lives in Park Slope, counts herself generally lucky in this problem. Financial worries aside, it means she will get to spend a little extra time with her 15-year-old daughter, Alycen, who attends Edward R. Murrow High School. But she hopes the delay does not drag on.
"I just want them to stick with the 20th as the starting date and not move it back again," she said. If so, she said, "it would make everybody really angry and really crazy."
 
Student's Boredom
Eager to Return To Math and Plays
 Andrea Vialva, 12, has had it with summer. She is plenty upset that she will not be returning on Thursday to I.S. 227 in East Elmhurst, Queens, where she gets good grades, likes math and participates in plays.
"I want to get back to school," said Andrea, of Jamaica, Queens, who will be going into seventh grade. During summer vacation, she said, "you have fun for like two weeks and then you start getting bored."
Her parents are also upset, not for boredom, but because they want their daughter to get the best education possible. Her mother, Anne, said she thinks especially about the entrance exams to preparatory school, which Andrea plans to take to get into St. Francis Prep in Queens.
The exams are a year away, but with competition stiff from other students, some in parochial schools, which are not closed because of asbestos, Mrs. Vialva feels that every day of instruction counts.
"My whole concern is that she gets all that's due to her in the seventh grade," said Mrs. Vialva, a native of Trinidad. The family also has two other children, both in college.
The delay in school has also thrown off Mrs. Vialva's own extensive preparations for school. She already bought her daughter a new pair of dress shoes, new Nike sneakers, two book bags (one for strength and durability, the other because it was a little more fashionable), two flannel shirts and six pairs of pants. She also had to change plans because she intended to take off the first day of school to get to know her daughter's bus driver.
Now she said she feels a sinking confidence in public schools, which she said have long been the victim of neglect and poor administration. Echoing the opinion of many parents, she said asbestos is just one problem.
"I blame the whole school system," she said. "They had the whole summer to take care of this. It's nothing that just happened yesterday."

HEADLINE: Running for Governor As a Spectator Sport

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Governor Jim Florio and his Republican challenger, Christine Todd Whitman, are paying consultants big money, so they probably won't be seeking free advice on how to run their campaigns for governor this year.
But if they did . . . 
 Mr. Florio would be told that he should loosen up, and Mrs. Whitman would hear that she should stop listening to her family and be more confident. Although their subjects vary, fashion consultants and former governors give advice that sounds remarkably similar.
Both candidates scheduled visits to the shore on the last big holiday weekend to meet voters and to say goodbye to what former Gov. Thomas H. Kean called "summer training" for the "tough, tough grind" of long days crisscrossing the state until Nov. 2.
As the gubernatorial campaign begins in earnest the Whitman strategists hope to revive voter anger over the $2.8 billion in new taxes that Mr. Florio pushed through the Legislature a few months after taking office in 1990. The Florio campaign wants to portray Mrs. Whitman as being out of touch with New Jersey voters and lacking the experience and the policies that could solve state problems.
 
Big Taxes vs. Big Wealth
 In her stump speech, Mrs. Whitman says the Governor showed poor judgment in raising taxes as the state was heading into a recession. She said his decision killed jobs and elevated the unemployment rate.
The ensuing tax revolt enabled Mrs. Whitman to come within a few percentage points of upsetting Senator Bill Bradley in 1990, even though she was little known.
The Florio campaign is determined to define Mrs. Whitman's image this time, and to make it unflattering. Mr. Florio has called her both soft on crime and the candidate of the National Rifle Association. He also frequently refers to her wealth.
 
Style Tips for the Road
 Voters still expect to be wooed in person by the candidates, even though television ads are supposed to do most of the heavy lifting when it comes to molding opinion and building support. And as long as they must take their campaigns on the road, Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Florio might benefit from some tips on how to improve their appearances, keep their energies up and sharpen their campaign strategies.
Both Neil Upmeyer, director of the Center for the Analysis of Public Issues, a nonpartisan public interest group in Princeton, and former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne, a Democrat, said Mr. Florio should interject more humor in his public appearances.
"My advice to Jim is to lighten up and try a little self-deprecating humor, to smile more and to try to make government more understandable, something people can relate to," Mr. Upmeyer said.
"He should try to not be so formal and serious. He also should avoid sloganeering, which he seems to be a master of."
 
The Wit of Brendan Byrne
 Mr. Byrne, who in two terms acquired a reputation as a master of the one-liner, often aimed at himself, also urged Mr. Florio to try a bit of humor. "I remember in one of my campaigns I visited a sewage treatment plant in Camden that had a concrete floor and I said, 'I'm finally standing on my opponent's platform.' "
Mr. Upmeyer said his first piece of advice to Mrs. Whitman "is to stop listening to the family kitchen cabinet and start following your own instincts." He said that Mrs. Whitman, who has been under withering attack by Democrats in recent months because of her wealth and the tax breaks she received on her rural estate, should try to avoid being put on the defensive by the Governor.
Mr. Upmeyer attributed the perceived overreaction to Florio tactics, in part, to the influence of her brother, Webster B. Todd Jr., who is her campaign manager. He said some of her gaffes could have been avoided if she had made more decisions herself.
"She has to be more self-assured about how she would run the government and exhibit confidence in her ideas about the direction she would lead the state," he said. "She should lay out ideas and defend them."
Mr. Byrne said his advice to Mrs. Whitman would be not to be too detailed and specific, something he said hurt the campaign of his 1977 Republican opponent, Raymond H. Bateman, the former State Senate President. Mr. Bateman spent much of the campaign explaining a 17-point plan to replace the state income tax signed by Mr. Byrne.
 
It Worked for Annette
 "If she gets too specific it will just be a setup for Florio," Mr. Byrne said. "He knows the job and how to pick it apart." The former Governor also said that the state's clean beaches were the first thing people mentioned when they said they told him they intended to vote for Mr. Florio. "He should get his picture taken on the beach and use it often," he said.
But analysts and ex-governors aren't the only people with ideas for Mr. Florio and Mrs. Whitman. Domenic Santucci, owner of the Leading Man and Woman hair salon in Montvale, said Mrs. Whitman should adopt a different hair style. "She a very attractive woman, but her hair style makes her look older," he said. "She needs to be softened up a bit."
Mr. Santucci said, however, he wouldn't change a hair on Mr. Florio's head. "He has what we used to call a sculpture cut," he said. "It's the brush-back, conservative style, an image that is very, very corporate, stylish and businesslike. It helps him and, along with the way he dresses, improves his credibility."
Wardrobes that resist wrinkles and can be mixed and matched are important during long days on the campaign trail, said Joan Phillips, the personal shopper manager for the Nordstrom Menlo Park store.
 
'8 Easy Pieces'
 Ms. Phillips said Mrs. Whitman should think of "eight easy pieces" built around a jacket, two skirts -- straight and pleated, a pair of trousers, a casual shirt, a blouse, a sweater and a string of pearls. Throw in some scarves and belts to change color accents and a candidate could survive days of campaigning without going home for a wardrobe change.
Cynthia Wheeler, Nordstrom's Northeast regional fashion director, said sturdy, comfortable shoes are a must for both candidates and said newer models of women's shoes have stronger heels that should make it easier for Mrs. Whitman to endure long hours on her feet.
Ms. Wheeler said the Governor should consider wearing a vest as the weather turns cooler to cover shirts that may become wrinkled. She also suggested that he buy heavier ties to hold knots better and those with a woven and not a printed pattern.
Before they leave home each day the candidates should eat a good breakfast high in carbohydrates and low in fat, said Kathy Tigue, a registered dietician at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, "like a bagel without the cream cheese, whole-wheat bread or cereal and fruit instead of juice to get some fiber."
 
And Skip the Junk Food
 Also, get some exercise, even in short bursts, like a walk around a building or up and down a couple of flights of stairs. And, skip the junk food and doughnuts, she said.
Still, appearances can only go so far, and Mr. Kean voiced the hope that the two candidates would take a serious approach to the issues, saying the state's problems with school financing, taxes, housing, and government integrity need to be resolved. "They have a lot to talk about."
Dr. Clifford Zukin of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University used the analogy of size, depicting the campaign as a contest to see which candidate is taller or bigger in ability, with Mr. Florio's stature being better known.
"The only way for him to be bigger than she is on Election Day is to make her smaller, to go after her credibility, to cut her down," he said. "He's pretty fixed on how tall he is in the eyes of the voters."
 
'Is She Acceptable?'
 Mrs. Whitman's task is to show she is a credible alternative to the Governor, and can do the job.
"If the question is 'Do I like him for four more years?' and the answer, as in Reagan's case, is, 'Yes,' then he has no problem," Mr. Zukin said. "But if, as in Bush's case, the answer is, 'No,' then the only question remaining is, 'Is she acceptable?' "
"She's should campaign on the gut level and not be distracted by bond investigations -- people don't understand bonds -- or school formulas," Mr. Zukin said. "She should say he made bad decisions and the economy is bad; he used bad judgment and I can govern."
"Florio should say, 'I stood up to the N.R.A.; some people may not like what I've done, but I'm a tough guy and I'm right for New Jersey'," Mr. Zukin said.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Drops by Queens On the Endorsement Trail

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins took his campaign to the far northeastern corner of Queens yesterday to pick up an endorsement and to try to sell himself to a somewhat skeptical crowd.
Mr. Dinkins received the enthusiastic endorsement of Borough President Claire Shulman, speaking to a white, largely Jewish audience at the Deepdale Gardens Community Center Pool in Little Neck. Ms. Shulman said Mr. Dinkins "has integrity, he has decency, he has honesty and he really cares about the people of this city." 
 The endorsement by Ms. Shulman, a longtime supporter and ally of the Mayor, was expected. It followed what has become a pattern in the Dinkins campaign, a strategy of rolling out almost daily one prominent public official or union leader after another to endorse the Mayor and cultivate the image of a bandwagon of support.
For the Mayor, such endorsements have been virtually the only source of favorable coverage in recent weeks, during which he has been hit with a succession of crises.
Last week, for example, Fire Commissioner Carlos M. Rivera resigned and defected to the camp of the Mayor's opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate, accusing unnamed mayoral aides of being anti-Hispanic. Before that, the Mayor was reeling from troubles over a contract in the city's Parking Violations Bureau, an uproar that led to the resignation of his budget director and the demotion of another aide.
 
Carefully Timed Support
 Leah Johnson, a spokeswoman for the Dinkins campaign, said that the endorsements were mostly unsolicited. But she added that the campaign has been involved in their timing, placing them close together, day after day. That timing, she said, was intended to remind the public that Mr. Dinkins has a broad appeal.
"The idea is to build momentum," Ms. Johnson said. "It's a show of support, a show of the diversity and the breadth of support he has around the city."
In recent weeks, endorsements have come from such officials as former Mayor Abraham D. Beame, Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer, New York Attorney General Robert Abrams and City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone. And more endorsements are scheduled, Ms. Johnson said.
At yesterday's endorsement, the Mayor received polite applause from about 200 people, who sat in swimming attire beneath large, colorful sun umbrellas on a deck below the pool. He offered his stump speech about how crime had diminished during his administration, how the libraries were open six days a week for the first time in decades and how he had made difficult budget choices during a bruising recession.
Before the Mayor's arrival and even during his talk, many in the audience quietly criticized the Mayor for what they considered a deterioration of city services and dismissed his visit as a meaningless attempt to get votes.
But Mr. Dinkins took what was, for him, the unusual step of spending nearly two hours chatting informally with people on a leisurely stroll through the pool area. The Mayor not only engaged in the typical campaign rites of kissing babies and shaking hands, but he also took questions about crime, services and the racial disturbances in Crown Heights.
Some who said they had been inclined to vote against the Mayor said they were nonetheless impressed that he had spent so much time in their community.
"This is precisely what the Mayor needs to be doing here," said Sheldon S. Leffler, a Democratic City Councilman who accompanied the Mayor and whose district includes the Little Neck area. Mr. Leffler, who said he had not yet made an endorsement of a mayoral candidate, said that "there is some skepticism about him here, but this might help a little bit."

HEADLINE: Deal Seen For Renault And Volvo

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Renault of France and Volvo of Sweden are expected to announce on Monday that they will merge, seeking to forge a combined operation strong enough to weather a deep downturn in the European automobile industry and intensifying worldwide competition.
Industry executives said that the two sides continued to meet today and that the long-rumored deal had yet to be completed. But the companies scheduled a news conference for Monday afternoon at Renault's headquarters outside Paris.
 
Fourth Biggest in Europe
 News reports from Stockholm and Paris said Renault, the much larger company, would have a 65 percent stake in the merged venture, to be known as Renault-Volvo Automotive. Renault's chairman, Louis Schweitzer, would hold the title of executive chairman and wield primary control over the new company. Volvo's chairman, Pehr G. Gyllenhammar, would become chairman of the supervisory board. 
 Assuming it does not fall victim to a last-minute snag, the deal would create the world's sixth-largest car company and the fourth largest in Europe, after Volkswagen, General Motors and Peugeot. The merger will be the latest example of a trend that has seen smaller auto makers like Volvo seek links with the largest manufacturers.
 
 
U.S. Sales Are Down
 The merger, however, would have little impact on car sales in the United States. While Volvo continues to enjoy a reputation for safety and durability, its sales in the United States have fallen by nearly half in the last five years. Last year, Volvo sold about 65,000 cars in the United States, giving it a market share of less than 1 percent. Renault withdrew from the United States car market in 1987, when it sold its stake in a joint venture with American Motors to Chrysler.
Renault and Volvo have been closely linked for three and a half years through investments in one anotherand a strategic alliance intended to capitalize on their respective strengths. Volvo is stronger in larger, more expensive cars and is most established in northern Europe. Renault is stronger in small and midsize cars; France, Italy and Spain are its core markets. The companies have put particular emphasis on using their combined influence to reduce costs in buying components from suppliers.
 
 
Rivals in Trucks
 The fit is not so neat in trucks, a big business for the two companies. They are fierce competitors in many markets, including the United States, where Renault owns Mack trucks and Volvo controls 83 percent of a truck-making venture with General Motors, the Volvo GM Heavy Truck Corporation. It was unclear whether the overlap in trucks would raise antitrust concerns in the United States or Europe.
The deal comes at a time when European auto makers are scrambling to survive the steepest downturn they have suffered in decades. Sales of passenger cars are expected to fall at least 16 percent in the European Community this year. European auto makers have been laying off workers and seeking to squeeze more efficiency out of their production lines, components-purchasing operations and design programs.
If the cyclical downturn alone were not enough to motivate them, European auto makers also face a competitive onslaught from Japan. Toyota Motor, Honda Motor and Nissan Motor have invested heavily to build plants in Britain to make cars for the European market and have been able to capture 11 percent of the market despite an agreement by Japan to limit its auto exports.
Under the agreement with the European Community, however, restrictions on Japanese cars will be lifted in 1999, giving auto makers like Renault and Volvo even more urgency to search for lower costs and more design, marketing and distribution might.
For Renault, the merger would be the last big step in whipping itself into shape for privatization by the French Government in the next several years.
After years of losses that left its survival in doubt, Renault has turned itself around since the late 1980's. The company holds a little more than 10 percent of the European market and has had particular success recently with two new models: the Espace mini-van and the Twingo, a mini-car designed for the crowded streets of European cities.
While Renault has revived, Volvo has been growing sicker. At home, Volvo has suffered from the worst recession in Sweden since the 1930's. Abroad, the auto maker has found itself increasingly uncompetitive on price because of its high labor costs and low production volumes.

HEADLINE: Textile Talks With China Stall Amid U.S. Warning

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Two days of talks here have failed to make any progress toward a textile agreement that could cut an estimated $2 billion in Chinese exports to the United States.
On Saturday, Jennifer Hillman, chief textile negotiator for the Office of the United States Trade Representative, warned that without a trade agreement to replace the one that expires at the end of the year, the United States could unilaterally and substantially reduce quotas for Chinese textiles. 
 In addition, Ms. Hillman said at a news conference here, if the United States was confronted with unabated quota cheating by Chinese manufacturers using Hong Kong, Taiwan, Macao or other "transshipment" ports to hide the origin of their goods, the United States could in each case reduce China's overall quota by three times the value of illicit shipments.
 
U.S. Threat
 Chinese officials reacted strongly today to Ms. Hillman's warning, reported by the New China News Agency, that the United States would not sign a textile agreement that did not include stiff penalties for quota violations.
"The Chinese Government resolutely opposes the U.S. action to unilaterally reduce quotas for China without consultation with the Chinese side and without presenting clear evidence," Shi Guangsheng, the vice minister of the Ministry of Trade and Economic Cooperation, said in a statement carried by the agency.
"The illegal transshipment of textiles is a complicated issue involving importers, exporters and middlemen," he added, "and many such cases are plotted and conducted outside China. China and the United States, therefore, need to seek cooperation from third countries to crack down."
Ms. Hillman's comments cast doubt on whether China has been genuinely pursuing the quota violators who are among China's new tycoons. In many cases, these businessmen work hand in hand with public officials cashing in on the country's manufacturing boom.
She said United States officials had yet to see results from Chinese efforts to stanch the growth of quota violations and added that the Chinese "must do more."
"We very much believe it is in China's interest to get an agreement," she said, but no date has been set for the next round of talks.
 
$6 Billion in Exports
 Last year, China exported about $6 billion in textiles to the United States, of which $4.57 billion were allowed under a 1988 agreement. Ms. Hillman estimated that $2 billion in Chinese textiles reached the United States by passing through one or more of 40 countries or territories where transshippers could obscure the country of origin to help their Chinese supplier avoid quota restrictions.
Mr. Shi, the vice minister, said China had banned quota cheating and had formed investigation teams to deal with factories, trading companies and individuals involved in illegal shipments.
As for the talks themselves, the American negotiators tabled a proposal that called for cutting China's textile quota by 25 to 35 percent and eliminating all annual growth and flexibility clauses that have led to large increases in Chinese exports to the United States. The American proposal was described by Zhou Keren, the director of trade administration in the ministry.
Mr. Zhou, quoted by the official news agency, said Washington's demands for enforcement violated existing trade agreements as well as "the principle of cooperation" and "are definitely not acceptable to China."

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Disputed New Role for Polls: Putting a Price Tag on Nature

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
How much is a Pacific sea otter's life worth -- not someone's pet, but a wild animal that will never be studied by scientists or frolic in front of tourists? Could the Government find out by asking people in Plattsburgh or Peoria how much they would voluntarily fork over to keep the otter safe from unnatural hazards?
Until recently, such abstract questions have mostly been grist for academic debate. But now Federal regulators are under orders from Congress and the courts to figure ways to measure losses to people not directly affected by environmental problems like oil spills or haze in national parks. The first set of guidelines, from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, is due later this month and is widely expected to support the use of survey-based techniques. 
 So with little fanfare, "contingent value" measurements of "passive uses" of the environment are on the verge of becoming an accepted tool in the making of public policy. They may also become a potent weapon in large pollution-liability suits.
For three decades, scholars and environmentalists have suggested that failure to account for benefits for "nonusers" could lead to systematic underprotection. If passive uses are ignored, said Alan Randall, an economist at Ohio State University, it would encourage "the riskiest enterprises in the most pristine environments."
What is new is the ambitious use of opinion surveys to measure passive-use benefits. In 1989, a Federal appeals court ordered the Department of the Interior to rewrite regulations for assessing damages under the Clean Air Act and the Superfund toxic-waste cleanup program. The loss of passive-use value, the court said, was to be included if it could be "reliably calculated."
The subsequent drive to bring survey-based measurement into the corridors of power is drawing praise from environmental groups and has even gained the cautious imprimatur of some prestigious scholars. "You can learn quite a lot from a well-done contingent-value study," said Robert M. Solow, a Nobel Prize-winning economist who is advising the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration on the use of such studies.
 
 
Bitter Division
 But the approach has bitterly divided professionals. "Economists just don't want to admit there is stuff that cannot be measured," argued Zvi Griliches, a teacher of statistical methods in economics at Harvard University and a consultant to the Exxon Corporation.
Such surveys are anathema to industries that produce, use or transport toxic substances. If damages are measured by contingent-value surveys, warned Charles J. DiBona, the president of the American Petroleum Institute, "junk science will gain a companion -- junk economics."
But plaintiffs in big environmental- damage suits suspect that a pot of gold is waiting under the contingent-value rainbow. The State of Alaska commissioned a $3 million study of what Americans who will never visit Prince William Sound lost from the Exxon Valdez disaster, teasing out the numbers by asking more than 1,000 people in a random sample how much they would pay to avoid a similar accident over the next decade.
When pressed, the typical respondent put the figure at about $30. The state thus inferred that Americans would collectively be willing to pay about $2.8 billion. If that was true, Alaska argued, Exxon should be liable for $2.8 billion beyond the billions spent to restore oil-soiled beaches.
While the survey drew praise from some quarters -- Paul Portney, an economist at Resources for the Future in Washington, called it "far and away the best contingent-value study I've seen" -- Alaska's tactic was never tested in the adversarial setting of a courtroom; Exxon settled the liability suit for $1 billion before the survey was introduced as evidence. But the sums at risk focused businesses' attention on the threat posed to them by such surveys.
The oil industry, in particular, is sparing no effort to get across its message that contingent value is at best a gravy train for consultants, at worst a legal bomb that will blow apart the Great American Prosperity Machine. "If you applied this methodology to any human activity, you could stop it dead," Mr. DiBona said.
 
 
Saying, Not Doing
 Are the critics right? Most economists are indeed inclined to look at contingent value with a jaundiced eye. They have traditionally relied on market transactions to reveal value, and for an obvious reason: anyone who buys bananas at 39 cents a pound must think they are worth at least 39 cents a pound. Survey techniques, by contrast, are inherently limited by the fact that the conclusions are based on what people say they would do -- not on what they have done.
To demonstrate that contingent value does not reveal what courts and policy makers want to know, Exxon hired an army of brand-name economists to test its mettle. While the sponsor's bias must be kept in mind, the newly published research certainly does touch on a variety of widely acknowledged pitfalls in the technique.
Peter Diamond and Jerry Hausman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology point to the public's inclination to be overly generous with hypothetical outlays. They note, for example, that a mail survey found 6.6 percent of fishing-license holders in Montana would be willing to pay to protect healthy water flow in two rivers. But just 1.1 percent selected randomly from the same group actually responded to a request for donations.
 
 
Wide Range of Responses
 Another flaw is the extreme sensitivity of the results to the way the questions are asked. In particular, people seem willing to pay implausibly large sums if they are not carefully reminded of the broad range of possible environmental damages and the practical limits of their own incomes.
Walter Mead of the University of California at Santa Barbara points out that one major study pegged the nonuse value of saving old-growth forests in the Pacific Northwest at $119 billion to $359 billion. Sparing the whooping crane from extinction was valued at $51 billion to $715 billion.
 
Tough Standards Proposed
 Still another pitfall is the apparent irrationality of survey respondents. If a little preservation is worth something, both economic theory and common sense suggest that a lot ought to be worth a good deal more. Yet William Desvousges and a team of colleagues from the Research Triangle Institute in North Carolina found the public's willingness to pay to save 2,000 migratory birds from oil-coated ponds -- a well-documented pollution hazard -- was as great as their willingness to save 20,000 birds or 200,000. "No matter how you skin this cat, you get incredible anomalies," Mr. Hausman of M.I.T. concluded.
But practitioners are not about to fold their tents. "There are good contingent-value studies and bad contingent-value studies," insisted Raymond Kopp, an economist at Resources for the Future who worked on Alaska's study of Prince William Sound. "The technique works as well as any other empirical methodology."
And earlier this year, fans of contingent value got a big lift from a blue-ribbon panel of economists with no financial stake in the issue -- a lift that assures the technique will be treated with respect by the courts.
Acting under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990, which requires the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to write damage-assessment rules for oil spills, the agency invited six economists, including two Nobel Prize winners, to advise it on contingent value. Their January report lays out tough standards for credible surveys -- standards virtually no survey to date would meet -- and urges the Government to conduct benchmark studies of its own. The economists concluded, however, that "contingent-value studies can produce estimates reliable enough to be a starting point for a judicial process of damage assessment."
The regulators are not obliged to adopt the panel's recommendations when they issue rules. But it would be the bureaucratic path of least resistance. And if, as is widely expected, the agency does follow the recommendations, the Interior Department would probably adopt parallel standards for damage assessment on toxic waste and air pollution violations. Indeed, the failure of either agency to defer to the panel's expertise would open it to legal challenges from one side or the other.
 
 
Courts Are Reluctant
 The impact of the new rules is anyone's guess. Opponents take heart from both the heavy burden of credibility imposed by the panel and the reluctance of Federal courts to carve out precedents. Where big money is involved, moreover, defendants will have every incentive to hire experts to punch holes in the evidence. "I believe that no contingent-value study will ever meet the courts' standards," said John Seddelmeyer, associate general counsel of Exxon USA.
But Mr. Seddelmeyer may be whistling in the wind. "I see great potential for mischief here," conceded Mr. Portney of Resources for the Future, who was a member of the blue-ribbon panel and, in principle, supports the contingent-value approach.
Mr. DiBona of the petroleum institute is not shy in speculating about the potential consequences. While the chances of getting hit hard with a damage award for lost passive use may be low, he argues, the sums involved are so large that they are bound to affect commerce. At the least, the legal exposure would raise insurance premiums, he said, and the risk might well render it impossible for some industries to obtain insurance.
That might lead Congress to rethink the very idea of linking damage awards to the pain felt by Americans when they learn a wilderness has been sullied or a species endangered. But then again, maybe not.
"I can think of no instance in which Congress has relaxed environmental regulation," said Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute. "It's just not politically correct."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Carolyn Mark and William C. Stone

 BODY:
Carolyn Mark, a daughter of Arthur and Cecile D. Mark of Tannersville, Pa., was married yesterday to William C. Stone, the son of Howard Stone of Hoboken, N.J., and the late Dora S. Stone. The bride's parents performed the ceremony at their home, as permitted by Pennsylvania law.
The bride, 27, was until recently an economic development consultant at Jobs for the Future Inc., a research organization involved in economic and work-force development issues, in Cambridge, Mass. She graduated magna cum laude from Pennsylvania State University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a master's degree in city planning from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. 
 Her father is the supervisor of student teachers at Teacher's College of Columbia University in New York. Her mother is the director of the Mekeel Child Care Center at East Stroudsburg (Pa.) University.
Mr. Stone, 27, graduated summa cum laude from Tufts University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a law degree from Harvard University. He is to become an associate at the Portland, Ore., law firm of Tonkon, Torp, Galen, Marmaduke & Booth in December. His father is the publisher of Foodservice Yearbook International, a source book for hotel and restaurant professionals, in Great Neck, L.I.

HEADLINE: No to a Higher Tax On Capital Gains

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Raise Capital Gains Tax and Cut Deficit" (letter, Aug. 20), Harold Pepperell's plan to increase the capital gains rate to 40 percent, would have the opposite effect from what he forecasts. What incentive is there to sell an asset to take advantage of a 28 percent capital gains tax rate when you will have to reinvest your diminished proceeds with the happy prospect of having future capital appreciation, if any, taxed again at 40 percent? This is a losing game. 
 More likely, a lot of the "liberated" capital would disappear abroad to friendlier climates, such as Germany and Japan, where there are no capital gains taxes. Alternatively, the capital gains would stay unrealized and pass through the investor's estate, where there also are no capital gains taxes.
And what would Mr. Pepperell say to all those homeowners who might think of selling homes that over the years appreciated in value. This is the average American's most important asset. Like common stocks, it has been a hedge against inflation. Should homeowners have to hand the Government 40 percent of their inflation-induced gain? That isn't taxation. It's capital confiscation.
Perhaps the most distorted of all Mr. Pepperell's statements is that "raising the capital gains tax does not hamper economic growth." The incentive to invest is the prospect for profit. New money constanty comes into the market, seeding investment opportunities, but if the profit incentive is removed, new money, as well as profits generated by old money, will seek employment in other places.
If Mr. Pepperell wants to find a way out of the deficit morass, he should think of how to stimulate economic growth through attracting new saving and investment. The prescription for this is to eliminate the capital gains tax entirely or, at least, index capital gains on all types of assets, so that savers and investors are not taxed on upward valuations that reflect only the impact of years of inflation.
 
AUSTIN W. LOHSE
Short Hills, N.J., Aug. 25, 1993

HEADLINE: Health Care -- By-And-By

 BODY:
The autumn leaves won't be blowing across Lafayette Square for a while yet, but Washington is already aflutter with contradictory advice for President Clinton on his legislative agenda.
Some of it is malicious. The Republicans would like to scuttle health care. The Perotistas and a peevish lot of Democratic House members would like to humble Mr. Clinton on the North American Free Trade Agreement. 
 Some of it is confused. Senior economic aides want a big push on Nafta while the top political advisers want Mr. Clinton to stick with his health care mandate and not get sidetracked on a trade bill inherited from President Bush.
And on every side, one hears warnings of a rough new beast from Congress that lopes alongside the dread monster known as Gridlock. This new critter, called Overload, is said to batten on the unselective yearnings of an Oval Office novice.
So what's a President to do? Well, it wouldn't hurt to take another look at the worst-of-all-worlds agenda being pushed by his top advisers. Their plan calls for Mr. Clinton to put his prestige on the line to press for Nafta as the main must-pass legislation for the fall. His big health care address in late September would be used not to introduce legislation but to initiate deliberations that would not produce a vote until mid-1994. Some essential parts of the Clinton campaign package, like reforms to reduce the role of special interests, do not have a prominent place on this agenda.
Do history and current political realities suggest that this is a sound approach? Not really.
First, consider Nafta. The treaty is worth passing, but not at great cost. It could wind up looking like a Clinton version of President Carter's treaty on the Panama Canal. Mr. Carter spent huge political capital on the treaty. The problem was that no one really cared about the canal, except possibly Ronald Reagan, who used its surrender as a club against Mr. Carter.
So who cares about Nafta? Certainly not organized labor or environmentalists or the Democrats who represent them. This is, after all, Bush legislation rooted in the tradition of Republican free traders. A canny decision would be to let Senator Bob Dole and his fellow Republicans do some heavy lifting and to saddle House Speaker Tom Foley with the responsibility for the troubled House. Mr. Foley, after all, is supposed to keep order among the Democrats, and right now his whip, David Bonior, is rounding them up to oppose their President.
The next task is to get health care on a faster track. This issue, not trade, is where Mr. Clinton should risk defeat. We have just finished eight months of largely secret talks about how to reform health care. To promise another 12 months of deliberation invites public disenchantment. Yet the current plan is to use Mr. Clinton's health care speech to outline the principles of the program rather than its legislative design.
Something is amiss here. Mr. Clinton has a passionate commitment to create a health care system that would stand as a monument of American social legislation. The American people want that to happen. So by what logic does it follow that he should be gambling his less than abundant supply of prestige on Nafta rather than health care?
Here is one answer: Some White House aides fear that Mr. Clinton does not have the votes to pass his program. They hope that a victory on Nafta, with Republican and Democratic votes, will make him look like a bipartisan muscle man.
But it is really a strategy for the faint of heart. If Mr. Clinton sticks to it, that speech on health care better be a doozy. In it, he will have to explain why it was smart to throw out a do-nothing Republican for a by-and-by Democrat.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
