HEADLINE: In the Council's Court

 BODY:
New York's City Council will begin earnest consideration tomorrow of a proposal to expand the present National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens. The U.S. Open belongs in New York City and every effort should be made to keep it here. That said, this is a huge and complicated transaction. The actual lease has been available for study for only a few days. The Council must therefore approach the deal in a genuinely agnostic spirit.
The two main questions are these: Does the deal represent a wise use of valuable public land? And is it free of political logrolling? 
 There's no disagreement on one point: The Open generates more than $100 million for the city in economic activity annually and several million more in direct tax revenues. But what about the deal itself? The city will allow the United States Tennis Association to lease and develop 42 acres on the present site -- a small footprint in a park of more than 1,000 acres altogether, but a considerable investment of valuable public land. The city and state will also put up $15 million for roadway and other improvements.
For its part, the U.S.T.A. would provide the entire $172 million to build the facility and put another $8 million into a trust fund for the park. It would raise the money mostly through tax-exempt bonds and would be solely responsible for the repayment of principal and interest. Carl Weisbrod, the city official who hammered out the deal, says that this is an unusually attractive feature: Most new sports facilities are largely underwritten by host governments, at some cost to taxpayers.
The U.S.T.A.'s estimated tournament revenues are $74 million, from which it will pay debt service, other costs and rental fees to the city that will amount to about $1 million a year. Mr. Weisbrod says that's a fair price for the two months the U.S.T.A. will actually use the place. But the Council needs to press Mr. Weisbrod about the revenue downstream and to ask for figures from comparable deals.
There's also one troublesome catch -- a provision requiring the city to rebate part of the rent if the Federal Aviation Administration fails to divert the noisy air traffic above the center. In the past, the noise has led to threatened player boycotts, and tennis officials want protection. The F.A.A. has been redirecting traffic since 1990. But what if it changes its mind?
Numbers aside, the proposal is regrettably caught up in the backwash of the Parking Violations Bureau scandal. The main reason is the involvement of Sid Davidoff, a crony of the Mayor and a lobbyist for the U.S.T.A., and Ellen Baer, who was recently demoted from her job as chief of staff to First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel for allegedly improper behavior during the parking mess.
Ms. Baer is also a close friend of Mr. Davidoff and her resume describes her as the "primary liaison" in the tennis negotiations. Mr. Davidoff has taken the wholly unacceptable position that he will not talk about his dealings. The Council has an obligation to determine that Mr. Weisbrod was in fact the main negotiator and that Mr. Davidoff did not use his friendship with Ms. Baer to secure a cushy deal for the U.S.T.A.
The Open has brought and will continue to bring economic and psychic benefits to a city in considerable need of both. The Council's duty is to make sure those benefits are real; it should take this lease as the starting point for its inquiry, not the final word.

HEADLINE: Congress Facing Heavy Schedule Of Tough Issues

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Congress will return from vacation on Tuesday to confront the heaviest variety of complex legislative issues it has faced in many years, while hoping to improve its standing with the public by seeking solutions to the nation's toughest problems.
None of this fall's issues may prove to be as challenging as the budget bill, which barely passed in both houses last month. But the vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement may be as close, and the health care overhaul may be even more complicated, even though both may well attract a level of bipartisan cooperation all but unseen in the 103d Congress.
 
Heavy Fall Schedule
 The scope of the agenda awes many lawmakers. Even without health and trade, Congress will have a heavy fall schedule with commitments to act on these issues: 
 *Additional spending cuts, which will be needed because in August Congressional leaders fell $4 billion short of their goal of $500 billion in deficit reduction.
*Crime and handgun control, which will be back after a Republican filibuster killed the legislation in the Senate last year. The House passed the measure 205 to 203 in 1991.
*Campaign finance, with neither party wanting to give the other any possible advantage and incumbents generally seeing the current system as satisfactory because it elected them.
*Procedural changes within Congress itself, but like legislation on lobbying and campaign spending, this seems to many legislators like pandering to noisy reformers.
*Immigration, but while there is widespread agreement on the need to tighten up on phony claims of asylum, the agreement begins to unravel with the tugs of civil liberties claims.
The priority list does not stop there. The savings and loan cleanup still needs money. The extension on unemployment benefits is about to expire. Republicans fear that education legislation is aimed at too much national control. And abortion is almost certain to cause sharp legislative battles.
One reason the 103d Congress faces so many contentious issues is that once the Clinton Administration was in office, Congress quickly disposed of the easy ones -- all the bills that it had agreed on last year but that President George Bush had vetoed, like family leave and simplified voter registration.
Once the Senate passes the final version of the national service bill on Tuesday or Wednesday, Representative Barbara B. Kennelly of Connecticut, a chief deputy whip, said, "I don't think anything easy is left, even appropriations."
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Committee, worries that if all the Clinton Administration priorities are acted on, "You're going to have us fighting battles all over the Congressional map."
 
Drowning Other Issues?
 Attracting sufficient public attention for issues beyond trade and health is the frequently voiced Congressional concern.
Among those expressing concern is Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is seeking action on crime, immigration and access to abortion clinics. "I just hope the whirlpools of Nafta and health care won't drown everything else," he said.
One of the capital's serious students of Congress, Thomas E. Mann of the Brookings Institution, said he thought legislators might be selling themselves short. Mr. Mann said that while it would have been impossible to do the budget and health care simultaneously, the current agenda is not too big.
"Congress can walk and chew gum at the same time," he said. "The Congress always handles many things at once."
Although "the media is all hyped to the story of 'overload,' " Mr. Mann said, "Congress is a decentralized body, capable of processing a whole lot of things at once."
An internal view of the problem of "overload" was offered by the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, who said last week that he had just returned from climbing Maine's mile-high Mount Katahdin.
"You were up so high and it was so forbidding," Mr. Mitchell said, "so if you looked beyond the next rock, you might not take a step." He said the lesson that veteran climbers gave him to take back to the Senate was, "Take it one step and one handhold at a time."
If Republicans are true to their word, some of the steps this fall may prove less slippery than the legislative terrain Mr. Mitchell had to tramp through this spring and summer with President Clinton's economic stimulus and budget bills. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, said home-state residents he had been talking with were "pleased that we have some issues we may work together on."
The trade agreement is one. Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House minority leader, said of the pact, "The President can count on more support on our side than his side."
It is more than an opportunity to appear cooperative, although Republicans have been concerned that their antagonism to many Clinton programs was stamping them as obstructionists.
The trade agreement, basically negotiated by Mr. Bush, is a measure that Republicans can approach with enthusiasm. Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, said that the last six months were "a real downer," but that the trade agreement would show "it's a good thing to have Republicans engaged in the business of governing."
Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, said of the trade agreement: "It's good for the nation, and it's good for jobs. There is a certain wry pleasure we will get out of seeing the Democrats lash their President."
The trade agreement is a special case in bipartisanship because of its Republican origins.
On health care, Republicans will be responding to a Democrat's proposal, and Mr. Chafee says he believes there is enough "commonality" in Mr. Clinton's ideas and those of Republicans to offer hope of success. Among those who seem to share that hope is Mr. Dole, who said, "I've been telling everyone to keep their powder dry" so there would be an atmosphere conducive to compromise when the time comes.
Some House Republicans have been less diplomatic, criticizing the program in advance as one that will raise taxes and cost jobs.
Even some Democrats are wary. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, who heads the Senate Finance Committee, said he would prefer to deal with welfare legislation before health care. Although he accused some Administration officials of treating welfare reform like "bait for the bubbas," he said it was a manageable issue that the public really cared about.
Cooperation will not be realized without political gamesmanship. For example, when Congress gets around to considering more spending cuts, as leaders promised before the budget vote, Republicans will be ready to score points by proposing things like changing the law that keeps payments for Federal construction projects high and keeps unions happy.
But something more may happen with spending cuts. And even internal changes, once derided as eyewash, may actually get a push from House leaders.
There are hints of a lesson in the August reception of Representative Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky, the freshman Democrat from a Republican district outside Philadelphia who cast the 218th and decisive vote for the budget bill.
At the time, Republicans mocked her by chanting, "Bye, Bye Marjorie," and they ridiculed the promise she had extracted from the President before voting with him: that a conference would be held on how the big-benefit programs could be cut.
But she said the reaction from her constituents had improved as the August recess wore on. After news reports of how one member or another had sought a tax break or some special consideration for constituents, she said, "To exchange a vote for what amounts to principle is not what people readily expect of us."
She said, "It surprises people that I would put my seat on the line" by casting an unpopular vote for tax increases and spending cuts. But the current large group of Congressional freshmen, far more than its elders either now or when they were freshmen themselves, does cast risky votes.

HEADLINE: INVESTMENT SOARS IN MUTUAL FUNDS, CAUSING CONCERNS

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
As millions of Americans pour money into mutual funds at a record rate -- nearly $1 billion a day -- concerns are growing that the funds are bringing new risk to the savings of many people and instability to the markets in which they invest.
A whole generation of savers, seeking alternatives to the 2 and 3 percent returns available at banks, is now being transformed into investors. Since the start of the current bull market in stocks, at the end of 1990, more than $450 billion has poured into mutual funds -- which include stock, bond and money-market funds -- bringing their total assets to nearly $1.8 trillion.
 
 
First-Time Investors
 But as the money mounts, so do the concerns. In large part, people putting their money into mutual funds are middle-income and often first-time investors -- betting a larger part of their savings on increasingly uncertain and unstable markets. One in every four American households invests in mutual funds and nearly half of all fund owners earn less than $50,000 a year. 
 "Mutual funds are becoming increasingly responsible for people's savings," said Arthur Zeikel, president of Merrill Lynch Asset Management, the nation's second-largest mutual fund group. "This is a cultural change. There are so many unknowns. Given the huge flow of dollars, more of these people's savings will become more volatile and less stable."
 
Stock Market's Gorilla
 Most of the money for mutual funds has come from the banking system. Nearly $350 billion has been drained from banks since mutual funds took off. And unlike bank deposits, which are Government insured and guaranteed never to lose a penny, mutual funds are bets on the far riskier financial markets, where there is no certainty that investors will ever see all their money again.
There are now twice as many mutual funds -- about 4,300 -- than stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange, and the demand for funds has brought many more into existence, 1,000 in the last year alone. Mutual funds are the biggest buyers of municipal bonds and are an important source of capital for corporate America and for emerging companies, and they provide billions of dollars to the home mortgage market.
But on Wall Street, the worry is growing that mutual funds have become the gorilla of the stock market. Statistics compiled by Laszlo Birinyi Jr., head of his own market analysis firm in Greenwich, Conn., show that the major reason for large price changes in the stock market in recent months has been investments of mutual funds, pushing up prices, rather than the fundamental health of the economy or of the companies whose stocks are traded.
During the 1980's, the stock market was propelled by two dominant players -- pension plans investing on behalf of future retirees and corporations buying back their own stock through leveraged buyouts and takeovers of other corporations.
But that has changed since 1990, as mutual funds have invested nearly $140 billion in the stock markets. Mutual funds account for as much new money going to the stock market as do pension funds and individuals combined.
While mutual funds account for about 10 percent of all stock ownership, they account for 30 percent of the trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange, Mr. Birinyi said, and, on hectic days, for more than 40 percent of all trades.
This high volatility results from a troubling aspect of mutual fund behavior: unlike pension funds and individuals, which tend to buy and hold, mutual funds are generally short-term traders. Pressured by yield-hungry investors, mutual funds are more prone than pension funds or individuals to sell a stock when it begins to drop and buy those on the rise -- lest they miss the latest trend and investors flee.
"Funds jump in and funds jump out of the market," Mr. Birinyi said. "This is creating a major degree of stock volatility because all these funds are doing it together. Funds face real pressure on daily performance and this leads to a great deal of short-termism."
Adding to this is the fickle nature of many mutual fund investors. Panicky shareholders can overwhelm a mutual fund with redemption orders, forcing fund managers to sell shares to raise cash, even if they do not think it is wise. Market analysts worry that investors' demands can force more stock sales, pushing down stock prices and fueling the demand for more redemptions, promoting a destructive downward spiral.
"I worry about 1-800-redemption," said Richard Hoffman, chief investment officer at Cowen & Company. "In the old days, an individual stock buyer would go to a broker, who would be a buffer and slow the process down. Now, if the market hits an air pocket, they can run helter-skelter and take the investment decision- making out of the hands of portfolio managers by overwhelming him with redemptions."
Mutual funds are in effect pools of capital that enable an individual investor to divide a single investment among many stocks or bonds, which can be safer than choosing one particular company to invest in.
 
 
Congressional Hearings
 The shift into mutual funds has not gone unnoticed: Congress is holding hearings examining this explosive growth. While this inquiry is described as a "checkup" of an otherwise healthy patient, it is the first time in recent years that Capitol Hill has examined the industry.
Mutual fund leaders have been calling on Congress to increase inspections by the Securities and Exchange Commission to protect an industry that so far has been tightly regulated and free from scandal -- despite infrequent inspections. The industry fears that the explosive growth may entice marginal players into the business, bringing shoddy products and scandal with them.
Industry executives are also worried that the average investor who is benefiting from -- and causing -- the mutual fund boom, may be in for a rude awakening when the markets turn sour. Just as these investors suffered when crumbling real estate prices diminished a large portion of their net worth, the same thing could happen with mutual funds, in turn shrinking their personal net worth.
Arthur Levitt, chairman of the S.E.C., said: "It is essential that individual investors understand what they are investing in. But I worry."
 
 
'They Get Mad, Too'
 And John Bogle, chief executive of the Vanguard Group, based in Valley Forge, Pa., the third-largest mutual fund seller, commented: "Not enough people are aware of the risks. And if investors don't understand risk, they not only lose money, but they get mad, too."
In a series of hearings headed by Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat, members of Congress, industry representatives and regulators appear to have agreed on an approach to better police the industry, and protect investors by hiring 150 new inspectors -- pending Congressional financing. Now, 107 inspectors oversee the entire industry, or one examiner for every $16.8 billion of assets. The industry wants more. It contends that it pays $81 million to the S.E.C. in fees, but only $18 million of that goes to mutual fund inspection.
Because of scarce resources, inspections are generally limited to only the top 100 mutual fund families. Many smaller and medium-sized funds -- the ones with fewer resources and, hence, the greater chance for intentional or unintentional wrongdoing -- have their books inspected by the S.E.C. only once every four or five years.
 
 
Worry Over 'Fringe Player'
 "There is a lot of concern that new entrants in the business have not been brought up in the mutual fund culture," said James S. Riepe, managing director at T. Rowe Price Associates, based in Baltimore. "We're worried about some fringe player coming in and blowing it. I'm not worried about Fidelity or Merrill Lynch."
One reason for the industry's clean history is that it is the most tightly regulated player in the securities business. The Investment Company Act of 1940, which applies specifically to the mutual fund industry, is considered one of the most comprehensive and successful pieces of regulatory legislation.
Unlike other Federal securities laws, which protect investors primarily through disclosure requirements, the Investment Company Act is far more comprehensive in specifying what mutual funds can and cannot do. Mutual funds face more public reporting, stricter prohibitions and more independent board oversight than other types of securities, and the law gives them a very detailed road map on how to manage day-to-day operations.
Last year, the S.E.C. undertook a major study of the act and concluded that no significant changes were necessary -- although the industry is vocal in its demand for more inspectors.
 
 
'Chilling Effect'
 "Any negative publicity about any fund could have a chilling effect on the warm feelings that the investing public has for the mutual fund industry today," said Mr. Zeikel of Merrill Lynch. "For this reason, S.E.C. resources should be increased."
But the biggest worry for policy makers and the mutual fund industry is that when financial markets go down, new investors will be shocked.
No one, of course, knows when the stock and bond markets will go down and by how much. But all know that they will. "It's like everything else," Hugh Johnson, chief investment strategist at the First Albany Corporation, said. "You know it's coming, you just don't know when. You can't avoid bear markets forever."
No one in the industry feels that the October 1987 market crash was much of an indicator of future behavior. Redemptions of mutual funds soared but were tempered by clogged phone lines and, within three months of the market drop, stock prices were back at pre-crash levels. Besides, less mutual fund money was in the market in 1987. The industry worries far more about a long-term bear market that grinds down agonizingly and whose downward slide is accelerated by the rush to sell the huge number of mutual fund shares bought since 1987.
"The 1987 experience was not a good prototype," Mr. Zeikel at Merrill Lynch said. "It was a one-time shock to the system. My concern is what happens if you have a long-term bear market like 1973-74." During the 1973-74 bear market, stocks lost about 40 percent of their value, on average.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Municipal bond insurers bask in the glow of falling interest rates.

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
FALLING interest rates have created a warm feeling through the bond market that has spilled over to companies that specialize in insuring municipal bonds.
Shares of MBIA Inc. and Ambac Inc., the largest and third-largest companies respectively in the municipal bond insurance business, rose sharply Friday to close at their highest prices in a year. 
 For MBIA, the gain on Friday of $2.125, to $79.125, extended a streak in which it has increased 16.6 percent, from $67.875, on Aug. 6, the last business day before it held meetings with stock analysts. Ambac stock has been lagging in that period, though it rose $2, to $48.50, on Friday, an increase of 11.5 percent from $43.50 on Aug. 6.
The second-largest bond insurance company, the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, is owned by GE Capital of Stamford, Conn., a subsidiary of the General Electric Company.
The benefit of falling interest rates for bond insurers is twofold.
First, lower rates have led local governments to issue bonds at a record rate. Through August, $194 billion of municipal bonds have been issued this year, up 27 percent from last year's record pace, according to The Bond Buyer, a trade publication. At the same time, the demand for insured bonds has grown to about 40 percent of all new issues, from 15 percent in 1993, largely because the individuals who buy three-fourths of new tax-exempt municipal bonds seem to crave the triple A rating and extra level of protection from default that insurance provides.
Steven Schwartz, an analyst at the Chicago Corporation, said the additional business could be handled with very small increases in staff and expense. At Ambac, whose stock he recommends, expenses in the second quarter were only 17.4 percent higher than a year earlier, while premiums collected from new bonds rose by 74 percent.
Second, about two-thirds of the new bonds are being issued to refund older, higher interest bonds. Bond insurers collect premiums when bonds are issued but they count as income each year only that part of the premium that matches that year's share of the bond issue's principal and interest payments. Ordinarily that means premiums are counted as income over a period of 20 years or more. But in the case of an insured bond that is refunded, all the remaining premium counts as income in the year of the refunding.
At Ambac, which had about 28 percent of the new insured bonds in the first half, refundings made up about a third of its profit, analysts said. At MBIA, with 39 percent of new insured bonds, refundings accounted for about 20 percent of profits.
The greater prominence of profits from refunding at Ambac is one reason its stock is not valued as highly as MBIA, said Joan Solotar, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, who has a buy recommendation on MBIA. "They both are very attractive companies," she said, but the potential slowdown in earnings at Ambac is greater.
While the decline in bond yields has clearly been a catalyst for the recent gains in profits and stock prices, bond insurance executives are keen to explain -- and many analysts agree -- that refundings are only part of the story. They claim that the future earnings from the rapidly increasing pool of insured bonds, plus the interest from MBIA's $2.8 billion investment portfolio and Ambac's $2.7 billion, are enough to assure investors of gradually increasing earnings.
"We look at the refunding activity as simply the frosting on the cake that makes a good year even more spectacular," David H. Elliott, the president of MBIA, said.
Looking beyond the furor created by declining rates and refunding, analysts at Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers said bond insurers stood to benefit in coming years from their central role in a security -- tax-exempt municipal bonds -- that local governments would continue to issue in large amounts and which would be in greater demand from individuals facing higher tax rates.
That condition, as well as expectations of continued low losses from defaulted bonds, and the steady income from investments and insurance premiums collected in the past, has led many analysts to predict that insurers' stock prices should rise to a higher multiple of their earnings. Even after recent gains, MBIA's stock is only about 14 times its expected earnings in 1994; Ambac's about 11 times. Stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 index trade at about 16 times the next year's earnings.

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TAKES PLANS TO VOTERS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 6

 BODY:
His Administration under strain and his leadership questioned over his efforts to advance several sweeping and disparate initiatives simultaneously this fall, President Clinton opened a public relations campaign today to portray the diverse aims as interlocking parts of one grand plan.
"In the next few weeks, you're going to see the Congress deal with an enormous number of issues, but they all have one thing in common," the President said here in a brief speech that was styled and delivered like a campaign address. "We've got to deal with them to pull our country together and move our country forward." 
 Mr. Clinton linked passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement with several other Administration measures -- the health care program, the recently announced crime bill and the plan for government assistance in college tuition and job training -- with a rhetorical flourish he repeated four times.
If any of the measures fails to win approval, he said, "we will never be the nation we ought to be."
 
Ambitious Legislative Agenda
 Mr. Clinton's speech echoed the message of his national radio address last Saturday, but today was the first time the President had developed his argument in a campaign-style stump speech. Delivered to a small audience under a broiling sun at an apartment complex in South Miami Heights, the speech was intended to set the theme of the Administration's fall push to win its ambitious legislative agenda.
Lorraine Voles, a White House spokeswoman, said that over the next few weeks the Administration would try to weave a thematic whole out of the free-trade pact, the health care program and the "reinventing government" plan, which is to be unveiled on Tuesday by Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore.
"We're working on three very important things that we know some people regard as disparate, but which we think are unified in the way they affect the economy," she said. "What the President will try to do over the course of the coming month will be to try to talk about how all three things fit together and to make the case that they aren't disparate."
The plan to streamline the Government may get the bulk of the attention this week, beginning Tuesday, when it is presented at a White House ceremony. Mr. Gore will go to New York on Wednesday to talk about the plan on "The Late Show" with David Letterman on CBS television, and the President and Vice President will travel together later in the week to promote the proposal.
Ms. Voles said that White House strategists were aware that persuading the public to focus on several initiatives at once and in relation to one another was difficult, but that it was essential. "If we don't, the danger is that people will begin to focus on one thing or the other, that they will say, 'There's the Administration focusing on Nafta when they said they would focus on health care,' " she said.
With his relations with organized labor strained over his support of Nafta, the President eschewed an appearance at the Labor Day parade of the sort that is traditional with Democratic leaders, and instead used his speech here to send a friendly message to labor.
He cited a program between his Administration and the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Housing and Building Partnership that is being used to rebuild 102 apartments at the Caribbean West apartment complex here as an example of "a new partnership between government and labor." The apartments were damaged last summer by Hurricane Andrew.
Earlier in the day, Mr. Clinton met with residents of Homestead, Fla., the city that was at the heart of the hurricane damage. There, he listened to generally warm thanks for government assistance that has totaled more than $3 billion, numerous suggestions for more aid, and a few minor complaints from more than a dozen residents selected by the White House to participate in a campaign-style "town meeting" with the President, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and the Housing Secretary, Henry G. Cisneros.
 
Waiting in the Heat
 Afterward, Mr. Clinton toured a few blocks in a neighborhood that had been heavily damaged and then spoke briefly to a hundred or so residents who had waited several hours in the oppressive heat to hear him speak.
"I just want to say to all of you, we are all in this for the long run," the President said. "I heard today about some things that still need to be done. And we will not have our work done until everybody in this part of our country who wants a job has one, until people are back in their homes, until these communities are rebuilt."
While much of the area that Mr. Clinton visited today has been rebuilt since his last appearance here, in the hurricane's aftermath, it was clear much remains to be done.
The hurricane destroyed 100,000 homes and left 250,000 people homeless. Mr. Clinton's motorcade, leaving Miami Beach for Homestead early in the morning, passed through a countryside still strewn with headless trees and roofless homes, past unplanted farms and abandoned apartment buildings. Local officials said more than 100,000 people remain displaced and 27 percent of the pre-storm population had left southern Dade County.
 
Debate on a Street
 By and large, Mr. Clinton received a pleasant welcome on his two-day visit to the Miami area, although his Labor Day crowds were surprising for their modest size. But if Mr. Clinton thought he could emulate his fellow citizens and leave the ways of his work behind for a day, he was disappointed.
As the President shook hands among the crowd gathered along a rope line in Homestead, a man who declined to be identified as anyone other than "a disgruntled voter" initiated what soon turned into the Presidential equivalent of a street-corner fight.
"Can you name one country that taxed and spent itself into prosperity?" the man shouted at the President, using a line that Rush Limbaugh, the talk show host, often suggests that listeners ask the President.
Mr. Clinton shouted back, "Can you name one country that has borrowed and spent itself into prosperity, went from a one- to a four-trillion-dollar debt?"
He then moved on, shaking more hands as the man shouted rejoinders at his back. Clearly irritated, Mr. Clinton could not resist returning to the engagement. "Let me ask you a fact question," he shouted. "One fact? One fact? Did the last two Presidents or the Democratic Congress recommend the largest amount of spending and the biggest deficit in the last 12 years? Answer: the last two Presidents."
The opponent hollered: "The Democrats did! The Democrats did!"
Mr. Clinton moved away, then turned to toss off another comeback, then moved on and turned back again, as the argument degenerated into the sort of did-so-did-not spat familiar to mothers of young children and viewers of "The McLaughlin Group."
"You didn't answer the question," the President shouted. "Answer the question. The Presidents or the Congress? You never answered the questions. The Presidents did."
As Mr. Clinton turned away for the final time, the man said: "Good luck, sir. Good luck."

HEADLINE: Midsize I.B.M. Line Upgraded

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
I.B.M. will introduce more powerful minicomputers today in the company's latest effort to defend its profitable midsize computer business against increasing competition.
The three new models of the I.B.M. AS-400 minicomputer will be up to 80 percent more powerful than the current machines. The International Business Machines Corporation will also introduce new software and disk storage features to make the AS-400 better able to operate as a "server" -- a central machine feeding and collecting data to and from many work stations linked by a computer network. 
 The arrangement, known as client-server computing, is the technological support structure for the new style of team-based work that is increasingly popular in Corporate America. To enhance the AS-400's appeal as a server, I.B.M. also plans to introduce a special model of its Valuepoint personal computer, called a "graphical work station," which can be a client machine linked to an AS-400, according to analysts who were briefed by I.B.M. last week.
 
Fortifying Against Rivals
 The I.B.M. introductions are part of an effort to thwart the stiffening competition in the mid-range computer market, broadly defined as machines that cost from $10,000 to $1 million each. Traditional rivals like Hewlett-Packard, Digital Equipment and NCR now offer minicomputers with the Unix operating system, an industry standard software, or "open" system. New companies like Sequent Computer Systems and Pyramid Technology have entered the minicomputer market with machines based on lower-cost microprocessor technology.
Like the rest of the industry, the minicomputer business is inevitably converting to microprocessor-based machines, and the only real question is how quickly the transition will occur. Making the transformation to the microprocessor world is a huge challenge to I.B.M.'s minicomputer business, and a real threat to one of the company's few recent bright spots.
The I.B.M. minicomputer business, including related software, storage disks and maintenance fees, generated revenues of more than $13 billion last year and pretax operating profits of more than $2 billion, according to estimates by ADM Consulting Inc., a research firm in Cheshire, Conn.
"The AS-400 is one of those horses that I.B.M. is going to have to ride into a more prosperous future," said Bob Djurdjevic, president of Annex Research in Phoenix. "And these moves in the client-server field are evidence that it is going in the right direction to sustain its minicomputer business."
 
Recent Recovery
 Even before the announcements, analysts say I.B.M. started to see a recovery in its minicomputer business from the falloff in the second half of last year and early in 1993, down a disturbing 10 percent in the first quarter. Helped by a previous round of product improvements and economic recovery in some crucial markets, the business is growing slightly again, even gaining market share.
"I.B.M.'s minicomputer business is doing well in a very difficult environment," said Peter Burris, a senior analyst for the International Data Corporation.
I.B.M. is also beginning to tell customers of its strategy for moving to new generations of microprocessor technology. Its next-generation minicomputer, with the code name Superior, will have a 64-bit operating system and use the PC Power chips the company is developing with Motorola and Apple Computer. These chips are advanced microprocessors employing a technology now used only in work stations called RISC, for reduced instruction set computing.
Some I.B.M. microprocessor-based minicomputers are scheduled to reach the market by next year, with the remainder to be ready by 1995, analysts say. The AS-400, they add, will be able to handle 64 bits at a time -- a bit is the smallest unit of data -- without rewriting large amounts of its operating system. "That could give I.B.M. a real advantage in that next generation of computing, if they manage it and market it properly," David Andrews, a managing partner of ADM Consulting, said.

HEADLINE: 'National Dialogue' in Nicaragua Hits Obstacles

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Plans for internationally supervised negotiations to end Nicaragua's political crisis foundered today as conservative leaders refused to join talks with the Government and the leftist Sandinista Front.
The planned "national dialogue" was to have begun this afternoon, and senior envoys from other Central American nations and the Secretary General of the Organization of American States, Joao Baena Soares, all arrived in Managua today to oversee it. 
 But at a news conference this morning, leaders of the country's center-right political coalition, the National Opposition Union, said the talks would not go forward until the Government met some longstanding demands.
Most important, they insisted that the Government restore the control they won in the National Assembly in the 1990 elections that brought their candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, to the presidency.
To do that, they said, Mrs. Chamorro must compel the resignations of nine legislators who split from the Opposition Union and threw their support to the improbable alliance that Mrs. Chamorro fashioned with the Sandinistas after the Opposition Union turned against her. Before he was ousted last year, Nicaragua's Comptroller General reported that aides to Mrs. Chamorro gave large bribes to the nine legislators to pry them loose from the opposition union.
Government officials said today that they could not possibly meet the demand because the executive branch had no authority to force the legislators to resign. The center-right coalition leaders respond that the Government must resolve the problem and that they will not budge until it does.
The pressure for a broad settlement has risen steadily in recent months as the fighting among political groups has dragged on and economic problems have grown more severe.
Some 60 percent of all Nicaraguans are now jobless or underemployed, and many social programs have dried up as the Government has cut spending. By most estimates, Nicaragua's poverty is now rivaled only by that of Haiti and Cuba.
"The politicians debate their problems on and on, but they aren't the problems of ordinary people," said a European diplomat who has sought to bring the contentious political groups together. "It is as though they live along parallel lines that never meet."
The Clinton Administration, which has threatened to suspend $98 million in American aid to Nicaragua in part because of the continuing influence of Sandinista officials in the Government, called on all sides to press ahead "vigorously" with the dialogue.
Government and Sandinista leaders did not dispute the argument of the Opposition Union, which is known by its Spanish acronym as the UNO, that changes needed to be made in the Assembly. But after offering to continue Government-UNO talks simultaneously with the dialogue, this afternoon Mrs. Chamorro called Government and Sandinista leaders to a meeting with the foreign observers anyway.
"The moment compels us to put aside our differences for the good of the fatherland," she said in remarks that were broadcast live on television and radio. "I am ready and I hope both political forces, the Sandinista Front and the UNO, are as well."

HEADLINE: Nigerian Union Of Oil Workers Suspends Strike

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Leaders of the Nigerian oil workers' union today suspended their 10-day-old strike, which has paralyzed factories and businesses across Africa's most populous nation.
But the Government did not give in to the main worker demand, which was to publish the results of last June's presidential elections, which were annulled by the former military leader, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida. 
 The annulment of the election, widely believed to have been won by Moshood Abiola, a wealthy publisher and industrialist, has thrown Nigeria into its worst political crisis since the Biafran civil war of the late 1960's.
Still, union leaders insisted that they had scored a symbolic victory by demonstrating their ability to cripple the nation's economy. And they vowed to strike again if their demands continued to be ignored.
 
Millions Backed Strike
 The oil workers' strike, which millions of Nigerians supported by staying in their homes, transformed normally teeming towns into ghostly places.
Indeed, virtually all gasoline pumps in Nigeria's biggest cities have been dry since tanker drivers, who belong to the oil workers' union, refused to carry petroleum products from depots.
The wide adherence to the strike across ethnic and regional lines suggested that many Nigerians opposed the largely civilian but unelected interim government that was created by General Babangida and is headed by Ernest Shonekan.
The attitude of the oil workers is of great importance because their industry earns more than 95 percent of Nigeria's hard currency.
"If today, we are suspending our present nationwide strike," the union said in a statement, "let it be seen as a tactical withdrawal, because we believe that this period of truce" will allow the authorities to reconsider the decision to annul the election.
On Sunday, Nigeria's largest human rights group, the Campaign for Democracy, said it planned future actions to force the government to hand over power to elected civilians.
On Sunday night, security agents at the international airport here confiscated the passport of Wole Soyinka, the Nigerian Nobel Prize laureate. Mr. Soyinka, an outspoken critic of Nigeria's military authorities, was returning from a trip to the United States.
In recent days tens of thousands of Nigerians, particularly from the East, a region dominated by the Ibo ethnic group, have fled Lagos, Ibadan and other major southwestern cities, fearing outbreaks of violence.
But while the strike and the exodus from the southwest have dominated news reports here, perhaps the most talked about topic is the continuing absence of Mr. Abiola from Nigeria.
Mr. Abiola hastily left Nigeria in early August after what his aides said were reliable reports that he might be killed. Since then he has toured Europe and the United States in an effort to rally opposition to General Babangida.
There is growing talk now, however, that Mr. Abiola has stayed away too long, and is squandering the political capital he has built up in recent months. He should be at the forefront, his supporters say, of the movement to oust Mr. Shonekan, whose interim government is widely regarded as a puppet regime created to perpetuate General Babangida's grip on power.

HEADLINE: Defending the Nonprofit Motive;
Tenants Decry Sale of Troubled Buildings to Private Owners

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Maria Fernandez wants control.
The open door to her building at 2312 Loring Place North in the Bronx constantly reminds her how out-of-kilter things have become: drug users slip up to the roof at night, leaving behind trashed mailboxes and strewing garbage and human waste under stairwells. Inside her apartment, brown spots dot the living-room ceiling from a steam leak last winter, cheaply made doors are falling apart and leaks plague the bathroom. 
 She and her neighbors tried to get the building's former owner, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, to sell it to a community group, thus assuring local control. Instead, the five-story brick building ended up in the hands of a private landlord who tenants say has overcharged them on rent, reneged on promised repairs and allowed the building to deteriorate.
"We wanted to maintain the building ourselves," she said. "To have control ourselves. To control who enters."
 
A Cautionary Tale
 Community-based housing groups say that 2312 Loring Place North is a cautionary tale of the difficulties the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation faces in administering the 150 buildings in New York City that it has been forced to take over after their owners defaulted on loans.
Over the last three years groups affiliated with the Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition have lobbied Freddie Mac to sell them the buildings, saying that local control is the best way to insure a neighborhood's vitality.
After the original landlords defaulted, the buildings were taken back by Freddie Mac, a stockholder-owned corporation established by Congress in 1970 to buy mortgages and repackage them as marketable securities. Freddie Mac, after putting the buildings into the hands of a court-appointed receiver, makes some improvements before trying to sell them again.
And while Freddie Mac officials say that they are willing to sell the buildings to community organizations -- and have, in fact, sold five buildings to Bronx-based groups -- they say they usually get a better price on the open market. Moreover, because Freddie Mac is a publicly traded company, officials say they have a responsibility to shareholders to get the best price for the properties.
The agency is also concerned about whether the neighborhood groups can put together financial packages not only to buy the buildings, but also to make necessary repairs.
 
Community Groups' Skills
 Ron Shiffman, the director of the Pratt Institute Center for Community and Environmental Development, which helps local development efforts, dismisses such concerns, saying they represent a persistent attitude among some lenders that community groups are less capable than private landlords.
"If you have a community improvement motive, they look at it as somewhat suspect," Mr. Shiffman said. "A lot of bankers have been addressing that issue, but Freddie Mac and others have been somewhat isolated from what's been going on."
He said that, over the years, community-based housing groups have developed the skills to buy, renovate and manage properties in the areas hardest hit by abandonment and decay. They have also involved tenants in managing buildings through associations active in tenant selection, maintenance and building patrols.
Freddie Mac officials said they were heartened by some improvements made by community-based housing groups. But they said that some private landlords had also turned around problem buildings, most recently at 1800 University Avenue, which had been overrun by drug dealers.
The building, which once had more abandoned apartments than occupied ones, has been scrubbed clean, with new windows and security gates. The drug dealers have been forced out and the apartments repaired.
Members of various Bronx community groups said they first approached Freddie Mac about three years ago, when landlords started defaulting on buildings whose mortgages were held by the agency. The pattern was familiar: repairs went undone, crime crept in and hard-working tenants moved out.
 
Financing Problems
 H. L. Van Varick, director of Freddie Mac's New York office, said the agency financed about 2,500 buildings throughout the city in the mid- to late-1980's, with about 150 winding up in foreclosure. Of those, a third were in the Bronx.
He acknowledged that overfinancing had been a problem, with landlords borrowing more than they should have, hoping that the economy would turn around. The buildings became financial burdens, he said, when the co-op market soured and growth stalled, or when other publicly financed housing projects lured tenants away from older buildings.
Mr. Van Varick said that most of Freddie Mac's transactions are in cash, and that prospective buyers are screened both by his agency and a network of local brokers.
"We're interested in making sure the rest of our assets in a neighborhood survive," he said. "It doesn't make any sense to unload one property when we have 10 others on a block and that sale would drag down the other buildings on the block."
Several neighborhood groups affiliated with the Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition thought they had a way to insure a block's viability: sell the buildings to them and allow tenants a say in how the building was run. They approached Freddie Mac with a list of a dozen foreclosed buildings.
Dalma de la Rosa, the coalition's president, said officials at first were cool to the idea.
"They thought we didn't know what we were talking about," she said. "We figured the tenant had been victimized first by the landlord, then by Freddie Mac. Freddie Mac owed them the chance to buy the building."
 
Demonstrators' Victory
 Their breakthrough came in 1991, when a busload of Bronx residents demonstrated at Freddie Mac's offices in McLean, Va. A smaller group met with Freddie Mac's chairman, who promised to sell them three buildings.
In what is seen as a pilot program, Freddie Mac has sold five buildings to coalition-related groups over the last two years, with officials saying that future deals hinge on the community groups' ability to obtain adequate financing.
But James Buckley, the director of the University Neighborhood Housing Program, which has helped package some of the deals, complained that the Freddie Mac buildings were overpriced and in worse condition than expected.
He said that while Freddie Mac sets a price of about $17,000 per apartment, his group often offers less than $10,000 per apartment, limited in part by city loan program guidelines and a desire to keep rents reasonable.
"We look at it from what is going to be affordable and what people living in the apartment can afford to pay," he said. "A private owner can look at it from a different perspective and does not need to be as sensitive to the rent people pay."
Mr. Van Varick said the coalition was depending too much on public loan programs and had not yet shown it could line up other financing.
"We can't afford to sell the properties at severely reduced prices," he said. "We are a stockholder corporation and we look at what they're valued at. We have a fiduciary responsibility not to give stuff away."
Members of several Bronx community groups said the result is that foreclosed buildings sometimes end up in the hands of landlords with poor track records. In the case of 2312 Loring Place North, the building was sold by Freddie Mac to a landlord who in turn sold it to Jacob Selechnik, a landlord whom Freddie Mac had already declined to do business with.
Since his purchase, several tenants have complained about the building's maintenance, citing a lack of radiators in some apartments, leaky ceilings and poor security. Two tenants, including Mrs. Fernandez, who filed rent overcharge complaints with the state, said the landlord tried to trick them into dropping the complaints by having them sign a form that an associate of his claimed was an authorization for repairs. The state Division of Housing and Community Renewal is investigating.
Mr. Selechnik did not respond to repeated requests for comment, including one left during a visit to his office.
Mr. Van Varick said that while his agency was not pleased with the way Mr. Selechnik had obtained the building, there was no way to prevent it.
"We try to determine if an individual is a decent landlord," he said. "If he turns around and sells the property again, there's not much we can do in that case."
While most of the tenants who had wanted to buy the building have since moved, those who remain said the experience left them bitter.
 
A Renovation Success
 That is in stark contrast with the situation at 1985 Creston Avenue, which Freddie Mac sold to the Mount Hope Community Housing Corporation. At the time of foreclosure the building was a virtual wreck, according to Pelqin Pinales, the building's superintendent for the last four years.
The roof leaked so badly that when it rained, water cascaded down the stairs. In some apartments, floor beams were near collapse and radiators leaked constantly.
Intruders often entered the basement at night, splicing into phone lines to make long-distance calls, while some tenants tapped into others' electric lines. Drugs were often sold and used in the hallways.
Since the community group took over, said Steve Yacullo, the construction manager overseeing the renovations,, repairs have proceeded on schedule, with new walls, shored-up floors, new appliances and security systems in place. Rents have been kept in line, although a slight increase may be needed.
"We achieved a lot and we're happier and calmer," said Felix Nunez, a member of the building's tenant association. "And we got away from Freddie Mac."
Tenants said repairs were now done quickly, and that the dealers whom the previous landlord had tolerated have been pushed out.
"You can look up to going into the building and coming home," said Melvin Scott. "You don't have to worry about if you're going to make it to the third floor."

HEADLINE: China Riddle: Life Improves Though Repression Persists

SERIES: A Giant's Evolution: Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; The writer of this article recently completed nearly five years as chief of the Beijing bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
What is intellectually irksome about China, for anyone who values human rights, is that a Communist Party that is often brutally repressive should be so stunningly successful in raising living standards.
The party torments many of the nation's bravest and boldest thinkers, sometimes locking them up in insane asylums or imprisoning them with criminals suffering from infectious diseases. Yet at the same time, the party is presiding over one of the greatest increases in living standards in the history of the world. 
 The Government fights leprosy as aggressively as it attacks dissent. It inoculates infants with the same fervor with which it arrests its critics. Partly as a result, a baby born in Shanghai now has a longer life expectancy than a baby born in New York City.
 
Annoying to Democrats
 For those around the world who cherish democracy, China's success in generating prosperity and well-being is just a bit annoying -- and certainly challenging to explain. It offends Western humanitarian values to think that a repressive Communist state can do more for its people than a democratic Government like India's.
Yet a Chinese woman is almost twice as likely to be literate as an Indian woman, and the risk of her baby's dying in the first year is less than half as much as in India. As a matter of priorities, many people would probably prefer a healthy baby to a meaningful vote.
"The first measure of any Government or administration is to ask, 'Is there any period in our previous history in which you would prefer to live,' " said David M. Lampton, the president of the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations. "And I think the answer for the overwhelming majority of Chinese would probably be no."
This makes moral condemnations of China much trickier than denunciations of the former East bloc, which impoverished its citizens at the same time that it repressed them. The Clinton Administration periodically complains about the Chinese Government's abusing its citizens, yet there is no question that the Communist Party is overseeing a far greater rise in prosperity and general well-being than any Democratic or Republican administration has ever achieved in such a short time.
This is not to say that criticism of Communist repression is necessarily misguided.
"When Hitler held power, the German economy enjoyed a boom," Zhang Weiguo, a dissident journalist now living in California, noted drily. "And Japan grew very quickly during the militarist years before World War II. So we shouldn't regard economic development as our sole objective."
The point is simply that with China's economy the fastest-growing in the world, moral judgments about the Communist Party's role become more complex. Particularly in the Chinese countryside, the issues sometimes seem more textured, the assessments more nuanced, than they do to casual observers abroad.
From afar, it sometimes seems as if the fundamental dynamic in China is brutal repression of dissent. In reality, political dissent plays an inconsequential role in most people's lives, particularly in the countryside. Three quarters of China's population of nearly 1.2 billion lives in the villages, and it is a world of its own.
 
One Village
Big Grievance Is Corruption
 Take K. G. Sun's little village at the end of a winding dirt road in northern China. Chickens rush across the path, and a few cows and goats are tethered to the trees. It is a peaceful little place, although there was a bit of excitement in January when someone celebrated Chinese New Year by heaving a brick through the village chief's window.
Mr. Sun and the other peasants have their complaints, of course. Everyone hates the man in charge of enforcing restrictions on births, and eight different people reported him anonymously to the township when he tried to shield his son who was trying to have an extra baby.
A lean and muscular man in a ripped tank top, Mr. Sun seems to have stepped out of a painting by a Chinese Norman Rockwell. Asked his age, he says he was born in the Year of the Dog, 1958. As for his children: "I don't know which one's what age. I just know one's a 'dog' and one's a 'pig.' "
For peasants like Mr. Sun, the big grievance is corruption, including the way the village and township cadres take bribes and squander public money to live it up.
"The big officials eat big, and the little officials eat a little," a middle-aged man said, using "eat" as slang for taking bribes or misusing public funds. "And if you're not an official, you don't eat."
The peasants knew enough to be suspicious when the village chief abruptly took 12 acres of the village's best land out of production last fall and announced that a brick factory would be built on the site. The rest of the village's land was redivided so that everybody got a bit less.
 
Flurry of Protest Letters
 The peasants protested, particularly when it became clear that the brick factory would be privately owned by the village chief, a police official from the county seat and a few other outsiders. The villagers wrote letters to everyone they could think of: to provincial leaders, to Prime Minister Li Peng, to People's Daily, even to The New York Times.
When an American showed up -- the first Westerner ever to visit the village -- the peasants delightedly poured out their complaints. Unfortunately, the village chief noticed and took his revenge.
The next day, the township police station summoned the peasants who had talked to the American and subjected them to a full day of grueling interrogation. They were told that it was illegal to make contact with foreigners and that in the old days they would have been beaten to death for the offense.
The police accused them of "leaking state secrets" and suggested that they were "counterrevolutionaries." The county police have summoned the peasants for interrogations in the county seat, and officials there apparently are still deciding how to punish the villagers.
Those peasants, in other words, have plenty of reasons to be furious at the authorities. And yet one of them, interviewed later in secret, has this to say of the mood in the village:
"Overall life has gotten much better. My family eats meat maybe four or five times a week now. Ten years ago, we never had meat."
"Now the peasants can go into the cities and earn 18 yuan a day doing odd jobs," he added, referring to the equivalent of about $3.15, a munificent sum in such places. "Of course the peasants are content."
In the Chinese countryside of the 1990's, Communist Party officials often bully and cheat the peasants, yet life is getting better so rapidly that many still support the system. Most Chinese say that if the Communist Party were suddenly to announce free elections, it could count on the votes of peasants to win overwhelmingly.
 
Progress
Sufficient Food And Better Goods
 The improvements are greatest in the most obscure sector of society: the poor mountain villages of central and western China where peasants still live in mud hovels and are lucky if they can send their children to elementary school for more than four or five years.
Life in those villages is still awful, but not so miserable as it used to be. Women may not give birth in clinics, but at least they are likely to have a trained midwife so that mother and infant alike have a fighting chance of surviving. Poor peasants may not be able to afford luxuries like brick houses or wrist watches or toilet paper, but at least they have enough rice so they do not have to choose which of their children to feed.
The World Bank reported in a study published this year that the proportion of Chinese living in absolute poverty -- lacking decent food, housing and clothing -- dropped from 220 million in 1980 to 100 million in 1990. In other words, a group of people equivalent to almost half the population of the United States can now potentially enjoy life instead of merely fight to subsist.
"What the peasants need above all is to fill their bellies," said a Chinese journalist who is often critical of the Government. "Only when they've got food to eat and a place to live will they start demanding political changes."
He cited an ancient Chinese proverb that only when men have enough to eat and a place to sleep do they run after women. The same, he said, holds for their desire for democracy.
 
Consumer Economy Emerges
 One of the huge gains in the quality of life over the last 10 years is also the most difficult to quantify: the emergence of a consumer economy in which Chinese no longer have to stand in line everywhere, no longer have to wear shoes that pinch because the right sizes are unavailable, no longer have to put up with the scorn of rude shop clerks, no longer have to endure the indignity of pants that split or zippers that break.
"In a shortage economy, you always have to struggle for life; you have to struggle to get your daily necessities," said Huang Yasheng, a political scientist who grew up in Beijing and is now conducting research about China at Harvard. "It makes a tremendous difference if you can spend half an hour a day shopping instead of four or five hours."
Though Chinese no longer spend much time waiting in lines these days, no easy calculus is available to weigh that gain against the torture inflicted on Catholic priests. This reflects a broader issue. The improvements over which the Communist Party has presided tend to be in material and sometimes mundane areas, while the party's abuses touch directly upon issues of human dignity and freedom that the West says it cares most about.
The torture of a protester pressing for democracy arouses more empathy in the West than, say, the deaths of the 2,000 to 3,000 Chinese peasants who drown in floods in an average year.
 
The Party
Publicizing Its Worst Side
 One of the Communist Party's problems is a phenomenal incompetence in self-promotion. Not since coup leaders in Liberia, in West Africa, invited journalists to watch and photograph the execution of 13 ousted Cabinet ministers in 1980 has a Government shown off its worst side with such relish.
"They are incredibly inept at public relations," said John T. Kamm, a Hong Kong business consultant who has campaigned to free political prisoners.
On the other hand, what the party does well it does quietly. For instance, a comprehensive system of prenatal checkups and free maternal health care has sharply reduced the infant mortality rate over the last decade. In 1980, for every 1,000 live births, 56 babies died in their first year of life. Now only 38 die in every 1,000 live births.
That amounts to saving the lives of 378,000 babies each year. But that is a statistic, while the Government's repression is usually an anecdote -- and sometimes a highly publicized one at that.
In a typical such anecdote, last month the authorities banned the country's most prominent independent labor leader, Han Dongfang, from returning to China. The authorities had earlier imprisoned him, tortured him by running a needle through his hand, and intentionally locked him up with tuberculosis patients until he became infected himself.
 
Which Is the Real China?
 So which is the real China? Is it the nation where police deliberately expose Mr. Han to the tuberculosis that almost kills him? Or is it the country that offers free prenatal check-ups and infant inoculations?
For four decades, Westerners have been debating that question. But no sooner does a consensus emerge about which is the real China than the other one emerges to confuse everyone.
In fact, it is difficult to describe either vision of China as the fundamental one. Both exist side by side, the yin and yang of the China of the 1990's.
"Both faces of China are real ones," said a Chinese woman who has ties to the leadership and yet is privately critical of the party. "You can't pick out one element and say this is the important one."
All countries and all people contain some mix of good and bad, but in China the gulf between the two sides is particularly striking. To come up with a meaningful judgment is a bit like assessing Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.
Why is it that the party tries to destroy people the way it attacks disease?
 
Analyzing Deng Xiaoping
 To answer that question, it helps to try to enter the mind of Deng Xiaoping and other Communist leaders. As far as anyone can make out, Mr. Deng, the paramount leader, is not just out for himself. He has genuine and profoundly held hopes for China, but these concern collective prosperity and national strength rather than individual freedom.
This is not surprising, for Chinese thinkers traditionally have emphasized the common good rather than individual rights. The expressions in Chinese for "democracy" and "freedom" were coined only 100 years ago, and terms like "human rights" have been used in a positive context by the Government for less than five years.
Mr. Deng has a desperate fear of chaos and conflict, inspired in part by his memories of the wars, famines and upheaval of the first part of this century. By some accounts Mr. Deng's father was beheaded by bandits in 1938, and two other family members were killed or driven to suicide during the Cultural Revolution that began in 1966 -- and that, to people like Mr. Deng, sums up the terrible price of disorder.
The combination of this mental orientation and practical experience is that Mr. Deng places a huge premium on order and that he is willing to destroy anyone who he believes might unravel it. Dissent, in his view, challenges not just the Communist Party but also China's best hope for modernization. In a talk to other leaders in 1987, he warned that if the proponents of democracy were not crushed, then China would again become simply a "dish of loose sand."
So if the price of saving China from disorder is that dissidents and their families are destroyed -- or that demonstrators are mowed down by machine gun fire near Tiananmen Square -- well, Mr. Deng has never been a squeamish man.
Still, many young Chinese believe that Mr. Deng is making a colossal miscalculation. They see his stability as that of a pressure cooker: when the top comes off, as it must some day, the explosion will be all the greater because the lid was so tight.
In any case, one open question is how much credit the Chinese Communist Party should get for the increase in living standards. One reason China is growing so rapidly is simply that it lagged in previous decades, and furthermore the boom seems to have more to do with private initiative than with public policy.
The problem of assaying virtue is not, of course, limited to China. Even child molesters can be polite and caring 99 percent of the time, as their mothers tearfully point out at sentencing. Iraq, Libya and the former Soviet Union all raised living standards for a time, yet none got much credit for it because they were simultaneously engaging in what much of the world regarded as repulsive behavior.
On the other hand, most of China's neighbors -- Taiwan and South Korea, among others -- have also had their share of massacres and repression, yet the brutality gradually abated and a measure of democracy has begun to bloom in each place. In retrospect, one can make a case that the crucial historical process unfolding in each place a dozen years ago was not the torture of democracy campaigners but the emergence of a middle class that demanded and supported a more democratic system.
In the long run, then, recollections of China in the 1990's may depend on how the country develops in the coming years. If it manages to follow the East Asian model and transform itself into a prosperous and pluralistic nation along the lines of Taiwan or South Korea, then historians may regard the economic boom and the growth of a middle class as the crucial developments in China in the latter part of the 20th century.
On the other hand, if China collapses into chaos and civil war, historians are sure to find that this was predictable. They will argue that the biggest victim of the repression was ultimately the Communist Party itself, for in stifling criticism the party lost its bearings and its ability to correct itself.
 
Focusing on Repression
 In that sense, repression may not be nearly as peripheral as it seems initially.
In the Soviet Union of the 1960's, for instance, dissidents were also on the fringe of society. Yet in retrospect, their voices turned out to be prophetic, and it was clearly worthwhile to focus attention on them instead of on infant mortality rates.
Repression is important in a larger sense as well: dictatorships are often more aggressive and militaristic than democracies. An authoritarian China might be more likely than a democratic one to try to "liberate" Taiwan, or "recover" Mongolia, or "secure" the South China Sea.
Mr. Zhang, the dissident journalist now living in California, suggests that in this respect the political repression, even if it directly involves only a small proportion of people, is still of crucial importance in understanding China. For all the economic strides of the last 15 years, Mr. Zhang said, the nation could lurch into chaos -- or threaten its neighbors -- unless the party opens up and turns to more democratic methods.
"If China develops its economy rapidly but fails to carry out political reform, there will also be a fundamental problem of safety to the international community," he warned. "In the past, we've seen the examples of Germany and Japan."

HEADLINE: More Diversity Than Harmony at Religious Assembly

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 5

 BODY:
In a world where violent conflicts in dozens of nations are stoked by religious differences, it is easy to make the case for greater understanding among religious groups. But the road to such harmony, as the organizers of a Parliament of the World's Religions discovered last week, is filled with pitfalls. Even the word "God" can raise objections.
The parliament, which closed Saturday with an open-air address by the Dalai Lama, drew hundreds of religious dignitaries and more than 7,000 enthusiastic participants from around the world. Most appeared to leave stimulated by the dizzying array of spiritual wares displayed in hundreds of lectures, meditation sessions and performances of ritual dance and music. 
 Organized by Chicago-area religious leaders to commemorate a landmark World Parliament of Religions held at the Chicago World's Fair a century ago, the parliament met at least one of its goals: Nearly a hundred spiritual leaders from more than a dozen faiths signed a declaration outlining a common "global ethic."
 
Rifts and Hurdles
 But a series of deep rifts, some very public, some behind the scenes, demonstrated the obstacles in the way of some participants' ambition of putting interreligious relations on a new footing.
Evangelical and fundamentalist Christian groups were absent from the gathering, and more liberal Protestant denominations took a back seat.
In the course of the week, Eastern Orthodox Christians and four Jewish groups disassociated themselves from the gathering, the former protesting the participation of self-styled "neo-pagans" and goddess-worshipers, the latter upset by the inclusion on the program of Louis H. Farrakhan of the Nation of Islam, whom they characterized as anti-Semitic.
 
The Spiritual Wares
 The parliament's public face was a kind of spiritual bazaar. There were more than 700 sessions at the Palmer House Hilton hotel, where eminent Hindu, Buddhist, Muslim, Sikh and Jain masters were on the program along with enterprising but less recognized gurus and even an investigator of abductions by unidentified flying objects.
Meanwhile, much of the parliament's most important activity was occurring several blocks away at the Art Institute of Chicago where an Assembly of Religious and Spiritual Leaders, a group of about 100 eminent figures, deliberated for three days in closed sessions.
On Saturday, reporters were invited to witness a formal signing of the Declaration of a Global Ethic by nearly the entire assembly. But several members reported that the preceding session had been tense and chaotic, with representatives of one religious group after another vying to get the body to recognize their grievances, from attacks on Muslims in the former Yugoslavia to the subjugation of American Indians.
 
Many Months, Few Words
 The Declaration of a Global Ethic itself illustrated the difficulties of interreligious agreements.
"I never worked so many months for so few words," said the Rev. Hans Kung, the Catholic theologian who spent more than a year preparing the nine-page, 5,000-word document.
The statement does not claim to be creating a new ethic but extracting a common one from existing religious traditions. It argues that ethical or legal principles must be sustained by the kind of change in attitude that religions can inculcate.
Much of the declaration restates the commandments not to kill, steal, lie or commit adultery, but does so in general terms of nonviolence; economic justice and respect for the environment; truthfulness in politics, culture and the media, and an end to sexual discrimination and exploitation.
The declaration condemns genocide, torture, "ethnic cleansing" and the use of religion to stir hatred, but it avoids specific examples. It also avoids issues like abortion and euthanasia.
It does not use the word "God," coming closest in one reference to "Ultimate Reality," a step necessitated, Father Kung said, to respect Buddhism and other faiths that recognize a spiritual dimension but not a personal divine creator.
Asked whether the demands of reaching consensus made the document too general to be meaningful, Father Kung replied, "We have here a minimum ethic," a baseline to which all religions could hold themselves and others accountable.
After being circulated for comment to a number of religious leaders, the declaration was submitted to the assembly here as the basis for an exchange of ideas but it was not open to revision. Leaders could simply sign or not sign. That restriction was unavoidable, the organizers said, because of the limited time for discussion and the fact that the assembly was not meant to be a voting body.
But with assembly members vocally chafing under this constraint, the organizers agreed to present the declaration publicly as simply an initial step toward a common global ethic, one that might be revised or refined in years to come. That halted the growing irritation about the declaration, but it did not curtail the rush on Saturday to win assembly backing for particular causes in a session where the rules of procedure were unclear.
"It was bedlam," commented one member.
 
History's Complications
 For example, Thomas Yellowtail, a Crow Indian leader, introduced a statement that attributed the deaths of 145 million indigenous people in the Americas to a 1493 papal statement granting extensive rule over newly discovered lands to Christian monarchs. The Yellowtail statement was approved by a show of hands, although Dr. David Ramage Jr., chairman of the Council Parliament and presider over the assembly, later overruled the vote.
To some religious leaders, who questioned the historical accuracy of this claim, the incident illustrated the dangers of dealing with a complicated historical question in a body that lacked information and experience in interreligious discussions.
Sunday, at a post-parliament meeting, the organizers ruled that all resolutions passed in that session had no standing, since the assembly was meant to be strictly a body exchanging insights, not taking group actions.
Woven through the tensions at the assembly was another delicate question: Would the parliament give birth to some permanent forum for cooperation among world religions? Some of the organizers clearly counted on such a development, but veterans of interreligious discussions, mostly outside Chicago, raised objections.
They asked whether another organization would siphon off resources or replicate the efforts already being devoted to interfaith work by groups like the World Conference on Religion and Peace, which has offices on four continents.
In an interview on Sunday, the Dalai Lama was asked whether the parliament would have an impact beyond the personal enrichment of the thousands of participants. "At this moment, I don't know," the Tibetan leader said. He had repeatedly appealed to people to carry on the parliament's work, he said, but now he could only add, "We will see."
