HEADLINE: New Catalogue Company Banks on House of Windsor

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
As a prospective brand name, the House of Windsor might seem a bit tarnished, what with the late unpleasantness about Charles and Di, Andy and Fergie, the Queen's taxes and so forth.
But a new British-American company is convinced that at least to consumers in the United States, the royal family is still synonymous with class and quality. Later this month the company will introduce the House of Windsor Collection, a catalogue to be distributed in the United States through which it will offer British glassware, picture frames, jewelry, knick-knacks and the like, at prices ranging from $50 to several thousand dollars. All the merchandise will be made by holders of the Royal Warrant, a designation indicating that members of the royal family consider the manufacturers to be the best in their field in Britain. 
 As marketing ploys go, this one might be easily dismissed, except that the House of Windsor Collection has the backing of the House of Windsor itself.
Although neither the Queen nor any other member of royalty stands to profit from the venture, the family has agreed to let its name be used, and Prince Michael of Kent, a cousin of the Queen, will conduct a promotional campaign in the United States later this month to introduce the goods.
The royal family's involvement is an attempt to help British exports and promote the tradition of craftsmanship represented by the Royal Warrant holders, most of which, as small businesses, have never before tried to sell their products abroad. But for the profit-seeking owners of the venture, the royal family's involvement, and support from the British Government, is a marketing coup of notable proportions.
"This is something the royal family can do in a tangible way to help the economy," said Bradley R. Larschan, an American who left his law practice in Washington to become the president of the company, E.A.C.C. Ltd. "They believe it to be in the public interest. We, of course, are in it for purely commercial reasons."
Of course, the Windsor name itself is something of a marketing invention. It was adopted by the royal family in 1917, when George V was on the throne, because the family name, Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, sounded too German at a time when British troops were fighting in World War I.
The family is by no means unaware of the money-making potential of its name. To raise money for the renovation of Windsor Castle, badly damaged in a fire last year, Queen Elizabeth II has opened Buckingham Palace to tourists for limited periods for the next several years, charging admission of about $12.
The Duchess of York, the former Sarah Ferguson, has sold to a cartoon producer the rights to "Budgie, the Little Helicopter," a children's book she wrote. Merchandise, including "Budgie" toys, will be available in the United States next year.
Before proceeding with plans for its catalogue, to be sent initially to 300,000 homes in the United States, Mr. Larschan said the company tracked the perceptions of the Windsor name among American consumers carefully over the last year or two, and liked what they found, screaming tabloid headlines about the royal family's travails notwithstanding.
"The American people still take a highly romanticized view of the English monarchy," Mr. Larschan said. "Despite the blips that various members of the royal family have experienced, I believe the American consumer will say that if it's good enough for the Prince of Wales, then I ought to give it some consideration."
In the "all publicity is good publicity" vein, Mr. Larschan said that recognition of the Windsor name -- not synonymous with the royal family among all consumers in the United States -- increased last year after the Windsor Castle fire.
"Our sales will benefit, unfortunately, from the publicity," Mr. Larschan said.

HEADLINE: Black Baptists Gather to Rally the Faithful Against Social Ills

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES

 BODY:
The nation's largest black religious organization will gather in New York City this week, filling the halls of Madison Square Garden with song and sermon and proclaiming a message of self-empowerment that its leaders hope will filter throughout black America.
Up to 50,000 members of the National Baptist Convention, USA Inc., are expected to attend the 113th annual gathering, which starting tomorrow will bring together ministers, ushers and others among the faithful for five days of communion and celebration. National Baptist officials expect the meeting to be one of the biggest in the group's history. By comparison, the Democratic National Convention last year drew 20,000 participants. 
 The convention comes in the midst of a continuing transition for the National Baptists, who in the last few years have evolved from a conservative group whose leadership once disagreed with the tactics of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to a more progressive organization that opposed the Persian Gulf war and actively sought to address social ills plaguing blacks.
 
Backing Dinkins's Bid
 This is the first time since 1935 that the National Baptists have convened in New York City, and organization officials said reasons for the choice ranged from the pragmatic to the spiritual.
One major factor was Mayor David N. Dinkins, whom the organization is supporting in his bid for a second term, and whose presence made the city and its bureaucracy less daunting, said the convention chairman, Dr. W. Franklyn Richardson. He is the pastor of Grace Baptist Church in Mount Vernon, N.Y.
"We feel he knows us, he'd be sensitive to our concerns," Dr. Richardson said. "His leadership was crucial, symbolically and literally."
By bringing their membership and message to the media center of the nation, Dr. Richardson said the organization hoped to put the country on notice that its 8.5 million members are a force to be reckoned with.
"It's time the largest black organization has a large presence," Dr. Richardson said. "So we come to New York hoping the message of the gospel will have a better airing than if we had not come here."
The organization, first organized in 1880, has more than 33,000 churches and is the third-largest Protestant denomination in the nation. Its officials say it is the largest black organization in the world.
During general sessions, informal gatherings and official meetings, convention organizers say the assembly will provide an opportunity for ministers to share advice on how they and their congregations are addressing issues like drug addiction, homelessness and AIDS.
The group's leadership hopes to re-emphasize its message that political and economic self-empowerment are critical to the survival of blacks. "The next frontier for black people is economic empowerment, and the black church must make economic empowerment its agenda," Dr. Richardson said. "The issues of paramount importance are how dollars get invested, and how corporations that get black money use black accountants and advertise in black magazines."
Dr. Richardson also said the organization wanted to emphasize the need for blacks to show their power at the ballot box. "The church must not decide for the people who to vote for, but they must make sure that every black person who can vote, does," he said.
Pomp and circumstance will be among the week's activities. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is scheduled to speak, a breakfast and shopping spree is planned at Bloomingdale's and the group will present its highest honor, the Cross and Crown, to Mr. Dinkins and to the former N.A.A.C.P. executive director, Benjamin Hooks.
 
Politics Within the Church
 But though the official speeches and dinners will take place in midtown, the National Baptists went to Harlem, where on Sunday they held a march and worship service decrying drugs, violence and the waste of black lives through crime, poverty and other problems.
As informal campaigning heats up in anticipation of the organization's presidential election next year, Dr. Theodore J. Jemison, president of the organization since 1982, said yesterday that he had not yet decided whether to run for a third term. If he does, his support of Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion, during the boxer's rape trial, is very likely to raise controversy. In July 1992, Dr. Jemison was indicted on perjury charges for denying an allegation that he offered Mr. Tyson's victim $1 million to recant her testimony. The charge was later dropped.
Another controversial element is the construction of a $12 million organization headquarters in Nashville, which was opened in 1989. Some critics felt the headquarters was unnecessary and a waste of money. About $4 million remains to be paid on the headquarters, Dr. Jemison said.
 
Politics Aside for Others
 Among Dr. Jemison's critics was the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, who questioned whether Dr. Jemison's support for Mr. Tyson hinged on the boxer's pledge of $5 million to the orgnization.
Such political questions were the last thing on Grace Cobbs's mind yesterday. As Mrs. Cobbs, 72, sat in the lobby of the New York Hilton hotel, selling tickets to a gospel concert at the convention, she expressed love for her organization's leaders and concern for black children.
"I know the black church has got to speak out more to our young people, and let them know God's way is the best way," said Mrs. Cobbs, the organization's assistant musical director. "And if we don't take a stand, we're going to lose them."
Some others thought that the black church was losing sight of its primary mission, that of helping people find salvation through Jesus.
"We've lost our focus," said the Rev. James Waller of Philadelphia. "We are to go and tell people that they can be reconciled to God. That's our mission. Not to build hospitals, not to build schools."
Social problems should be addressed, Mr. Waller added, but secondarily to the task of spreading the Word. "There are social agencies," he said. "If the church does not spread the gospel, will the lawyer? Will the school teacher?"
But Dr. Richardson believes it is important that the church reinforce black Americans' moral fiber and show them solutions that are within their grasp.
Dr. Richardson reached into the Scriptures to explain. He spoke of Moses leading his people to the Red Sea, asking God how to get across, and being told to use the rod in his hand to part the waters.
Those are words to live by, Dr. Richardson said, and the message of this convention. "What we have in our hand is the dollar," he said. "What we have in our hand is the vote. We must use what we have in our hand."

"RELIGION: Major Black Baptist Groups"
 
THE NATIONAL BAPTIST CONVENTION, USA, INC., with headquarters in Nashville, Tenn. It was organized in 1880, when it broke with the white Baptist church, and was incorporated in 1915. It is the nation's third-largest Protestant denomination, and claims to be the largest black organization in the world, with a membership of 8.5 million people and more than 33,000 churches.
 
THE PROGRESSIVE NATIONAL BAPTIST CONVENTION, with headquarters in Washington. It was formed in 1961 after splitting with the National Baptist Convention USA over a contested presidential election. It has a membership of approximately 1.5 to 2.5 million.
 
THE NATIONAL BAPTIST CONVENTION OF AMERICA, with headquarters in Shreveport La. It was organized in 1880 after a split with the National Baptist Convention USA. It has reported membership of approximately 2 million.
 
THE NATIONAL BAPTIST MISSIONARY CONVENTION, with headquarters in Texas. A breakaway group from the National Baptist Convention of America, the organization has a reported membership of approximately 500,000.

HEADLINE: Smiling and Relaxed, Giuliani Puts Polished Image Forward

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
In his 1989 campaign for Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani was a political rookie who struck many New Yorkers as both stiff and unpredictable, an unnerving mix for a man who wanted to lead the city. Now a veteran, he is more relaxed and less defensive, dancing the two-step at a hoedown in SoHo, grinning without end through countless parades, and even, disarmingly, poking fun at himself.
As Mayor David N. Dinkins reeled in recent weeks from one crisis to another, Mr. Giuliani offered a bit of advice that he could have used himself in his last bid for City Hall: "You know," he said, stopping just short of condescension, "the Mayor should really take some time out, cool out and relax a little bit."
 
Learned the Hard Way
 Is this mellow politician the same man whom hard-edged veterans of city politics dismissed in 1989 as not ready for prime time, a candidate visibly stunned in the klieg lights of his first campaign who screamed "shut up" at supporters as they booed the newly elected Mayor while Mr. Giuliani was conceding defeat. 
 Indeed he is.
Recast since his agonizingly narrow 1989 defeat, more polished on the stump, more measured and self-confident, Mr. Giuliani has been tested in the flames of city politics and comes to this race as a candidate who has learned the hard way -- through losing. And though he is still sometimes booed by detractors as he was yesterday during a stop at the West Indian-American Day parade in Crown Heights, the improvement shows in television appearances, in radio interviews and in person.
His intensity is muted. His pallor is gone. He sports a tan now and even his hair, which one political consultant called the "radical forward comb" of 1989 rests more easily across his balding head.
"I have been amazed at the change," said Tanya Melich, a veteran of Republican politics in New York. "Last time you could just see that he wasn't ready for it. It showed every day in 1989. But I have been watching him this time, and, honestly, I've been impressed with what I see. He's more mature. I've been surprised."
It has been a major change. Orchestrated by David Garth, the political consultant who has helped in five of the last seven mayoral elections to move a candidate toward victory, Mr. Giuliani's new polish shows in high relief against the image he cast in 1989.
"Last time he just flipped out," said Kathleen Severin, the president of the Republican consulting firm Severin Aviles Associates. When allegations about past business links between Mr. Giuliani's law firm and Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega were revealed in the course of the campaign, Mr. Giuliani snapped. "He called Dinkins a liar," she said. "And then, of course, it turned out that it all was true."
This time he steps with caution as the administration battles criticism over the awarding of city contracts, the troubled cleanup of asbestos in city schools and the blow of losing one of its own, Carlos Rivera, the Fire Commissioner, to the Giuliani camp. So far, he has been careful to neither gloat nor add much fuel to the fires, instead preferring to let local headlines do his work.
But Mr. Giuliani's new style is made of more than the good luck of having the wind of City Hall's troubles at his back. He has made a conscious effort to reach across the five boroughs, to soften his bitterness, never to shout and to smile, smile, smile.
He has been helped in that by a campaign team assembled early last spring and dedicated to avoiding the chaotic jump-start of 1989 in which he did not really get organized until late August. And he has been helped by having an operation so coordinated that it has already opened branch offices throughout the city and expects to meet its fund-raising goals within the month.
 
'Personality Transplant'
 "He is like one of those cartoons," said Mrs. Severin's husband, Jay, a partner in Severin Aviles, "where the lump of mud becomes a monkey and the monkey becomes a man and the man gets up and walks and then is on a skateboard with a Walkman. He is a fully equipped modern-age candidate this time."
Not everyone has been convinced by this conversion. "He's trying to effect a personality transplant," said Douglas E. Schoen, a partner in an independent polling firm, Penn & Schoen Associates, and watcher of city politics for more than 20 years. "I don't think he's changed that substantially. But whether it will be convincing to the undecided, that's all that counts. Now, he just has to keep it up for the next 60 days."
It has been a long road and a long time since November 1989. Although Mr. Giuliani declined to be interviewed on the subject, he admitted during conversations between campaign stops in June that in 1989 he had a lot to learn and that he had spent much of the time since then studying issues and image.
Despite his inexperience and mistakes, Mr. Giuliani lost by only two percentage points and briefly considered challenging the results. But the loss was crushing. "In his work," said his wife, Donna Hanover Giuliani, "he had always seen himself as protecting the innocent and vulnerable." The acid bath of that campaign cut deep. "There was a problem last time with people not feeling they knew him," she said. "They had a character picture of him as this stern guy."
 
Is He Really Mean?
 She says he never fit that mold and that on the night of his defeat he crumpled at the foot of the bed and asked, "Do they really think I'm mean?" It is a question he has been trying to answer for voters ever since. And it is, perhaps, the motivation for his campaign overhaul.
Yet this time voters may be more in the mood for the "tough guy" of 1989. No longer seduced by Mr. Dinkins's promise of New York City as a "gorgeous mosaic," they are instead watching an embattled incumbent deal with immense problems and are giving the opposition a serious second look.
"He has compassion and pragmatism at the same time," said Fran Reiter, the state chairwoman of the Liberal Party who has become one of his deputy campaign managers. "Compassion without leadership results in failure."
There have been some awkward moments. His epithet-filled outburst at a raucous police rally last year raised fears among some New Yorkers that Mr. Giuliani has a wild side. The campaign is aware of that and has worked hard to avoid rekindling those concerns.
 
Staff Is Not So Suave
 Inside the campaign headquarters, staff members blame the press for voters' long memories and belittle reporters as incompetent, irresponsible, biased and unfair. Even at a time when Mr. Giuliani is showing a smoothed out style in public, his staff is less suave, joking with one reporter that they will answer specific issues questions on Nov. 3 -- the day after the election -- and then threatening to choke off communications altogether.
Bitterness toward the press may be a holdover from the last campaign. And it goes to the core of where many people think he lost it. "I think he was bewitched, bothered and bewildered by the media," Mr. Severin said. In 1989, he said, Mr. Giuliani "telegraphed his uneasiness."
"He didn't know what to do with his eyes," Mr. Severin said. "He didn't know what to do with his hands."
Voters, he said, "saw a guy who seemed uncomfortable, and I think that made New Yorkers uncomfortable." He said Mr. Giuliani believed then that he could win by being right, not by being convincing. "He was naive enough to think that substance was everything," he said. "In America that's not true. And in New York City it's grotesquely not true."
 
Scrutiny Intensifying
 But now, in a campaign that has swept restlessly from one borough to another (though seldom touching down in the predominantly black neighborhoods expected to broadly back Mayor Dinkins), Mr. Giuliani is often well received.
"Yeah, he's a little stiff," said Anthony Kalabacas, a 36-year-old video shop owner from Queens. But, he added: "It's New York! People are going to walk all over you if you're not."
While undecided voters wrestle with their choice in the coming weeks, Mr. Giuliani and his staff hope to keep attention on issues. But as they do so, they are bound to come in for some harder knocks than they have yet.
Last spring, Mr. Giuliani endlessly made the rounds, munching through chicken and paella and pork, telling voters he wanted a city with more jobs, better education, less crime and improved health care. Nobody could disagree.
Now that he is being pressed to back those promises with plans he is more likely to face the kind of scrutiny and attack that caused some of his outbursts last time. "His biggest risk," Mr. Schoen said, "is that something will happen and he will make another gaff as he did in 1989." As he takes a slight lead in the polls, that scrutiny intensifies as voters consider the four years ahead.
 
Having a Little Fun
 So far, though, he has met that scrutiny with good humor. When Mayor Dinkins's office tried to deflect blame for the Parking Violations Bureau trouble onto him, Mr. Giuliani made fun of administration officials for producing a letter that they claimed proved he would have made the same decision.
"The letter !" Mr. Giuliani moaned with mock horror about a 1987 letter in which he argued that the Lockheed Information Management Services should be allowed to complete a standing contract. "The letter ! The Mayor must be carrying it around with him!" Then he smoothly segued into a detailed account of why the letter did not condone new contracts with the company.
That aplomb may not always be so easy, especially after Labor Day, when both sides expect the race to get nastier and as deadline pressures act like a tourniquet upon both candidates' souls and psyches. How well Mr. Giuliani performs under those pressures could well decide the race as New Yorkers watch to see if he is, in fact, the man they want as mayor.
In the meantime, though, he has his fun. Interrupted during an endless round of handshaking in the Bronx by a woman who wanted to sell him a raffle ticket, Mr. Giuliani patiently listened to her pitch, then looked alarmed. "What if I win?" he asked. "If I win there will be an investigation!"
Once, he wore blue jeans and a hand-painted shirt and greeted supporters with a broad if awkward "Howdy!" at a hoedown. The next morning he was his same old self in a suit and tie. Looking out at a room full of people waiting to hear him talk about the city's economic troubles he stared sheepishly at his audience and then tugged at his lapel.
"I have to admit it," he said. "I feel more comfortable this way." It was a rare moment of total candor and, in its way, a charming admission that even total overhauls can go only so far.

HEADLINE: Big Funds Giving China A First Look

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 6

 BODY:
The rainmakers are coming to China, and Philip A. Schaefer is one of them. "That's what I do," he said. "I make rain."
So he has no apologies for his breathlessness in announcing to a reporter over the phone: "We're coming to town with $500 billion in municipal and corporate pension funds, and I am just so excited. This is the first public pension fund conference ever in China." 
 Two days before the opening here of the pension fund conference organized by his San Francisco-based Pensions 2000 firm, Mr. Schaefer, 52, is sitting in the lobby of the Palace Hotel, a few blocks from the Forbidden City and Tiananmen Square, suffering a little from jet lag, wearing a casual blue shirt from the Rancho Mirage Ritz Carlton in California, a Mickey Mouse watch and baggy green slacks.
He is dropping names like a tree drops leaves: "Yeah I've got to get back because I'm doing a fund-raiser for Ted Kennedy," and "I was a Clinton delegate" at the 1992 Democratic National Convention; "Gary Hart will be here with the head of U S West" and "I wouldn't have come here without first checking with Nancy Pelosi about the political aspect," referring to the Democratic Representative from San Francisco.
 
'Here for the Long Haul'
 It is just a few days since the news conference when Mr. Schaefer stood beside a top official of the People's Construction Bank, one of China's four largest, and said, "We are looking at ways to increase our investment in China" and "We are here for the long haul."
The "we" are the 100 American pension fund and investment managers and about 100 Chinese banking and Finance Ministry officials whom Mr. Schaefer is bringing together, for a fee, at an investment conference entitled, "The Chinese Century -- From Wall Street to the Great Wall."
Participants listed on the conference agenda include: Donna Anderson, principal investment officer of the New York City Comptroller's Office; William Crist, board president of the California Public Employees Retirement System; Robert Scott, executive director of the Public Employees Retirement System of Colorado, and Randy Stalnaker, chairman of the board of the Dallas Employees Retirement Fund.
"Believe me, I know an A list when I see one," Mr. Schaefer said. The Chinese will give a banquet at the Great Hall of the People, with a final dinner on Saturday at Diaoyutai State Guest House, where former President Richard M. Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger stay when they are here.
Mr. Schaefer acknowledges that as a rainmaker, someone who specializes in drumming up new business and putting together deals, his salesmanship is prone to slip the bonds of earth, especially when he croons about China's booming market and "the pioneers" he has gathered here "on the last frontier of capital."
Jet lag has not kept his promotional efforts out of the stratosphere.
"When the history of the next century is written, much of it, I believe, will be about the relationship between China and the United States," he said. "It will be about two countries with different traditions, each influencing the world, each bound up in each other's future."
 
A History of Knocks
 Over coffee he seems a little less confident about the roadshow he has brought to town and what its seminars might actually accomplish.
"No one should come here with euphoria," Mr. Schaefer said, acknowledging that recent Chinese history has had a few knocks. He also said he was not concerned that Chinese officials seem to think that American pension funds are interested in helping China build railroads, highways and other infrastructure projects that might take decades to show a return, if they ever would.
"They are thinking one way, and the reality is the other," he said, adding that marginal increases in pension fund investments in Asia could help further China's development and support the economic changes that have been under way since 1978.
"I believe that economic reform produces political reform," Mr. Schaefer said, adding that he was a little uncertain whether China's poor human rights record might draw criticism to the conference and its participants.
"We are not here as diplomats; we are here as business people representing pension funds," he added.
 
Marginal Investments
 American pension funds invest 10 percent or less of their capital overseas, Mr. Schaefer added, and only a small portion of those overseas investment funds go into emerging markets like China.
So, this conference is not about bringing $500 billion in capital to China. The most likely result, he said, would be that the American pension funds would increase their marginal investments in Asian mutual funds, whose money managers are beginning to invest directly and indirectly in Chinese companies.
"But that is worth the price of the ticket to come" for money managers hoping to pull down management fees from pension fund trustees looking to shift more investments to Asia, he said.
The conference and Mr. Schaefer's fee are paid for by those money managers like First Boston; J & W Seligman, and NCM Capital Management, which have the opportunity to sit in close quarters for a few days with pension fund trustees who will be making investment decisions and who might be hiring money managers in Asia.
For the Chinese, Mr. Schaefer said, their banking and finance technocrats, will get a Business Administration 101 course in what pension funds are and how they work.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Asbestos and Schools: In Crisis, Opportunity

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Amid crisis, there is opportunity. And the school system's crash program of asbestos inspection and removal, which has delayed the start of school, is no different.
Never mind the boost to the economy of the $40 million or so the city will pay laboratories, asbestos inspectors and work crews to clean up the mess. 
 The asbestos crisis has provided a wealth of political and public-relations opportunities for city officials, from the Mayor to his deputies, commissioners and opponents, and even sometime warring factions of parents.
It gave Mayor David N. Dinkins a chance to be outraged at one of his favorite targets, the Board of Education. He took command, reassured the public and tried to portray himself as the opposite of the aloof and unfocused chief executive he was depicted as being in the report on the 1991 racial disturbance in Crown Heights.
 
Stepping Into Spotlight
 It gave the School Construction Authority, an obscure state agency set up to build new schools, a chance to step into the spotlight and indirectly make its case for greater authority and resources to take over repair and maintenance responsibilities from the Board of Education.
It gave environmentalists, particularly Albert F. Appleton, the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner, a chance to show their mettle and ride herd over a crisis of public confidence over the safety in the schools. And it gave parents, some of whom have spent years criticizing the Board of Education as being unresponsive, an audience at last and a chance to press for more money for school maintenance.
About the only place that has not seen an up side to the crisis is the Board of Education itself, which is struggling to set up recreation programs, find emergency classroom space and explain why for four years in the 1980's its staff produced unreliable and possibly fraudulent reports.
For the Mayor, the asbestos crisis gave him another chance to become the education Mayor, something that has eluded him through his four years in office.
During the heydays of Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, mayoral aides quietly seethed over Mr. Fernandez's unwillingness to share the glory with Mayor Dinkins. Before the battles over condoms and gay and lesbian acceptance, Mr. Fernandez was treated like a conquering hero -- and got all the credit for anything positive that happened in the public schools.
Mr. Fernandez sparred with City Hall over budget cuts, and there was even talk about a Fernandez campaign for Mayor. But when Mr. Fernandez was ousted as Chancellor, Mr. Dinkins's standing eroded further -- he was shown to have no control over an independent and sometimes hostile Board of Education that ousted the Fernandez team.
 
Chance to Take Charge
 To make things worse, his longtime allies in the United Federation of Teachers spent around $1 million on a television campaign assailing the city administration.
When word of the asbestos scandal percolated through city government, it provided a chance for the Mayor to take charge.
"I am outraged," Mr. Dinkins declared at City Hall, surrounded by a phalanx of educators and investigators. He announced a monumental inspection and repair campaign to restore confidence and show the muscle of his administration and its managers.
But later, when the inspection program bogged down, through miscalcuations and ever more aggresive double- and triple-checks, delaying the start of school, Mr. Dinkins left the announcing to others, and gave his opponents an opening.
The Republican candidate for mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, soon was questioning the handling of the asbestos effort. "Missteps and blunders," he said, "have further undermined public confidence." He called for a "tangible plan of action that won't change every 48 hours."
 
Parallel Agendas
 The crisis brought to life other parallel political agendas as well. Michael J. Petrides, a Board of Education member from Staten Island and a Giuliani supporter, blamed not Mayor Dinkins but his First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel, for "jumping in with both feet" and holding more news confereces than there are schools that have been declared safe.
Mr. Steisel responded by suggesting that Mr. Petrides was disengaged and insensitive to the fears of parents, especially by observing recently that he was more concerned about the quality of the food in the cafeterias than the health risks of asbestos.
"He has to answer to parents for his totally insensitive comments about asbestos and food -- he thinks the whole thing is a hoax," Mr. Steisel said. "He has never come to a single one of these meetings we have had and said anything pro or con."
Mr. Petrides said he stands by his remarks about cafeteria food. "Mr. Steisel did not invite me to be a member of the operation," he said.
 
Marriage of Convenience
 The crisis brought environmentalists and construction officials into a marriage of convenience.
When the asbestos problem surfaced, Mr. Appleton, the Environmental Commissioner, jumped in.
"The Mayor has often said publicly that he appointed me because I was an environmentalist and he wanted me to be aggressive about it," Mr. Appleton said. For days he has all but camped out at the School Construction Authority's offices, attesting to the quality of the work but slowing the reopening of schools, school officials said.
At every step, school construction officials said, the Environmental Protection Department insisted on ever more rigorous standards, requiring hundreds of hours of work to be redone. "Protocols were changed four or five times," one official said. "
"He's an environmental cowboy," one longtime city official said. "He allows no potential crisis or disaster to go by without the participation of his department. He is always willing to jump four-square into any situation and dramatize it. He is a public-relations person's dream."
But environmental officials say Mr. Appleton was forced to act when field audits found more than a third of all asbestos inspections to be flawed. And he responded with a laugh to the suggestion that he was using the asbestos problems to build his credentials with environmentalists and to help his job hunting in case Mr. Dinkins is not re-elected.
He said that if that were so, everything he has done, including programs to protect harbor herons, create greenbelts and restore waterways, was a job-hunting tool.
 
Two Distinct Factions
 Parent groups basked in the spotlight too, testifying before the City Council and at board meetings and participating in the task force running the cleanup.
But there were two distinct factions with distinct agendas. One group, which emerged from a series of environmental skirmishes, has made the environment their only issue. The others came from the ranks of the longstanding parent-group leaders, who see the asbestos crisis as an opportunity to get rid of "Kids Week," an extra weeklong vacation in the winter added at the request of teachers and over the objections of parents.
The parents have proposed a "Children's Charter of Environmental Rights" intended to "define the standards and efforts required to protect our children from environmental hazards." Mr. Appleton supported it, and with him the Dinkins administration has taken up the cause.
School officials worry that such a charter could shift too much spending from basic education to various environmental concerns and would give parents new rights to take public officials to court, but in this moment of crisis they are unwilling to speak up publicly.
The asbestos crisis may fit into other agendas as well. Many educators say it will press the city and the state to provide more money for basic school maintenance. Others say it shows the failure of large bureaucracies, and the need to totally decentralize the school system.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Risk in Riding Bonds' Bandwagon

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Millions of Americans are betting more and more of their money on longer-term interest rates. For many investors, that is becoming the only option as they search for higher returns at a time when rates are at their lowest in recent history.
But to portfolio managers who have been making the same bets recently, the strategy is getting riskier. 
 The problem for investors who are rushing into longer-term securities is that they are doing it after a strong rally in the bond market. Not only has the long bond yield dropped to 25-year lows, but yields have fallen sharply on the 2- , 5- and 10-year notes, which are among the other securities bought by bond mutual funds. Investors have been pouring their savings into these funds at a record rate.
Corporate bonds are also at the high end of prices, which move in the opposite direction of yields. And some analysts are worried that the junk bond, or high yield, market may be nearing a peak.
 
 
'A Lot Less Room' for Returns
 "It is pretty scary," said Thomas A. Shively, a senior vice president at State Street Research, a money management firm in Boston. "There is a lot less room to generate returns going forward."
As the yield on the 30-year bond breached the 6 percent level on Friday, falling to 5.94 percent, some portfolio managers who had been betting on the long bond for a long time were talking of altering their strategies.
"If we go through 6 percent, I am going to get more defensive," said Stephen S. Smith, executive vice president of Brandywine Asset Management in Wilmington, Del. "If the bond now goes back up to 6.50 percent, you get zero return."
And although many managers believe that long-term interest rates will move even lower, the chance to obtain the kinds of returns of this year are disappearing simply because interest rates across the maturity spectrum are already so low.
A 30-year bond that was bought in February, for example, will produce a total return of 23 percent if prices and yields can hold until early next year. But even a move to 5.5 percent on the long bond's yield in the near future will mean a return of around 12 percent to investors who are buying them now.
 
 
Money Still Pours In
 Such possibilities make some money managers concerned as investors seem to be stepping up the pace of their move to bond funds. With a total of $673.7 billion in June, bond funds were larger for the first time than the popular money market funds, which pay much lower interest rates because they invest in short-term securities. In July, billions more flowed into bond funds as the total reached $690.4 billion, up 30 percent in a year, according to the Investment Company Institute.
"I don't think a lot of people buying bond funds realize that they can lose money," Mr. Smith said. If the investment is concentrated in long-term bonds, "the risks are pretty significant that they don't get any return on their investment in the next year," he said.
David H. Glen, a portfolio manager at Scudder, Stevens & Clark, said: "We know people are pouring money into our funds because they want more yield. But we don't like it when they come in thinking it is a sure-fire risk."
Some managers say investors are moving out of short-term securities at a time when it may be a little safer to stay in, even though the yields are lower, because there is less risk of a collapse in prices.
 
A Difference a Year Makes
 "Bond fund yields look a lot less compelling to money market funds than they did a year ago," Mr. Shively said. The yield on the 30-year bond, at 5.94 percent on Friday, was twice the rate on the three-month Treasury bill. A year earlier, however, the bond was yielding more than two and a half times the yield on the Treasury bill.
But there is the counterargument that yields will move lower, particularly on long-term maturities, given the weakness of the economy and low inflation.
"The economic scenario that is unfolding is very favorable," Mr. Glen said, adding that it would take some "exogenous factor that we cannot anticipate" to change the outlook.
In addition, some of the negative talk has been from professionals in the market, many of whom were doubtful about the rally all along only to find that they missed much of it.
"Professionals think it is going to come to a bad end but don't want to bet against the rally," Mr. Shively said.
 
 
Risk in Moving Too Quickly
 Mr. Glen added this caveat for small investors: "If they are moving from certificates of deposit to long bonds, that is too much risk. They should not be moving that quickly."
The major factors that are going to determine where rates go and what risks investors face are inflation, the pace of economic growth, and technical factors like purchases of securities by local governments regardless of the price or yield
For investors who have sought higher yields by buying longer-term debt up to 30 years, the risk is the greatest. This is because the price move on longer-term debt is much greater when interest rates rise than it is for shorter maturities like five-year notes.
John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, expects long-term rates to move lower in the near term. He said the move down in rates, with a corresponding jump in prices, would be smaller but longer lasting if it was based on expectations of continued low inflation and economic growth in the range of 3 percent, which is about a percentage point and a half faster than in the first half of the year.
Long-term rates will fall even lower, he said, if traders and investors decide that economic growth will be much slower.

HEADLINE: Bergen Wary Of Shopping On Sundays

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARAMUS, N.J., Sept. 6

 BODY:
If voters decide to repeal Bergen County's 34-year-old ban on Sunday shopping, there's no trick to predicting the most obvious result: highways will be awash in cars for seven days instead of six as shopping centers and strip malls fill with customers.
But the future of Sundays on Main Street in dozens of the county's 70 towns is much harder to foresee. Will these downtown merchants -- many began business in a mall-less America, when Sunday was for Sabbath observance only -- remain steadfast and stay closed on Sundays? Or will they bow to pressure from the shopping centers and from merchants in neighboring towns by opening up a seventh day? 
 In about a week, the County Clerk is expected to determine whether the petition campaign to put the matter on the November ballot was successful. But the issue is already on the minds of local retailers, though merchants and chamber of commerce officials say no consensus has emerged on what will happen if shoppers are let loose on both weekend days.
"To me it doesn't make sense," said David Linden, who owns Lowits, a men's clothing store in Hackensack, the county seat. "I'm strongly opposed to being open on Sundays. It's a 'quality of life' issue. I live in Bergen County and I would like to see Sunday kept the way it is."
Some retailers, like Mr. Linden, say they are unlikely to spend extra on overhead for a seventh day, especially after working a six-day week. Others say the rivalry between malls and downtown shopping districts has been so well defined for so long that one more shopping day will not make much difference.
And still others wonder if shoppers, accustomed to weekend mall-going, could ever be enticed to break behavior patterns and return to the downtown stores that have been closed on Sundays for so many years. Unless all its stores are open, no town will easily gain a reputation for being "open" on Sundays, some retailers say.
Mr. Linden, who is also president of the Hackensack Chamber of Commerce, said he thought that a Sunday opening would merely spread six days of shopping over seven, and would be incompatible with a small business built on personal service.
"It's easy for the big stores to open, but it's different for most of the independents," he said, adding that he and most of his staff of 10 work six days a week. "We are truly a service store, which consists of all full-time people. If you open seven days, you might have to hire part-timers. Our customers want to find a familiar face. They don't want to hear that the person they expect to see is off today."
Ed Baczewski, who owns Herbert's Camera House in Englewood, said: "We just can't afford it. It's difficult for small businessmen like us. If staying open increased your business by one-seventh, it might be worth it. But we have tremendous competition from the malls already."
He characterized the campaign to lift the so-called Sunday blue laws as mall versus mall. The malls in Bergen, he said, would recapture more business from competing malls in neighboring Rockland County, N.Y., and Passaic County, N.J., than they would take from local merchants.
Although Bergen permits the sale of food, drugs, liquor, and newspapers on Sundays, businesses that sell cars, clothing, jewelry, furniture and home-improvement products are closed. With only slight changes, this has been the law since 1959, when the State Legislature allowed each of the 21 counties to decide on Sunday closing. Initially, 10 voted to limit shopping. But over the years, in a bow to competition and the shopping habits of busy two-income families, all but Bergen abandoned the restrictions.
A major factor in the debate has been the government and citizenry of Paramus, which is, in effect, ground zero for mall shopping in northern New Jersey. Although this borough of 25,000 has no central shopping district of its own, five major shopping centers and dozens of strip malls line Routes 4 and 17, which are to traffic here what the swollen Mississippi and Missouri were to St. Louis.
Paramus, along with Ridgewood and Wyckoff nearby, are the only communities in the county that maintain their own stringent closing laws. As a result, a repeal at the county level would be meaningless in these towns, unless the local governing body or its citizens take separate action to amend or repeal their ordinances. This puts enormous pressure on Paramus -- which has vowed to block repeal at the county and local level -- but it has added a new wrinkle to discussions in Ridgewood.
The chamber president there, Samuel P. Pimm 3d, who owns the Seavers & Parker gift shop, says that he and some other merchants have begun tentative discussions with the village about possibly opening on Sundays between Thanksgiving and Christmas, the most lucrative shopping season of the year.
He said the smaller, long-established merchants tend to oppose Sunday openings, while others would open around Christmas or for special promotions, and still others -- especially chain stores -- would prefer weeklong operation.
"I wish I knew what it meant," Mr. Pimm said of the prospect of repeal. "It puts us under tremendous pressure because having the availability of stores open so close, Ridgewood people who normally shop in Ridgewood would be able to go one town over on a Sunday and do so."
Since Bergen is New Jersey's blue-law holdout, merchants have few examples to guide them.
In Summit, N.J., in Union County, merchants can't remember when they weren't allowed to open on Sundays. But not all of them do open, even though they are just minutes from two of the state's busiest shopping centers, the Mall at Short Hills and the Livingston Mall.
John McElgunn, whose family has operated a men's clothing store since 1923, said he and most other merchants in Summit are open on the four Sundays between Thanksgiving and Christmas. In addition, he says, he opens up for special promotions two or three other full weekends each year.
"When I do direct mail to regular customers, it's a busy day for me on that Sunday," Mr. McElgunn said. "Those days we're open, we do business. But would seven days bring you more business? That's hard to say."
 
Main Street Not United
 If most or all of Summit's stores were open all the time, he said, shoppers might be more inclined to stop by. But most of them equate Sunday shopping with mall shopping, he said.
And getting all the merchants in one town to open all the time is not easy. The Englewood Chamber of Commerce, in a survey of its members a month ago, found no consensus on Sunday openings, said Linda Taub, the chamber's executive director.
One hundred seventy of 250 members responded. Of these, Ms. Taub said, 24 percent said they were legally open on Sunday and 76 percent were not; 55 percent would support repeal of the blue laws, the rest would not. But if the laws were repealed, she said, 56 percent would not open on Sundays.
Mr. Baczewski, of the camera shop, said it was his understanding that merchants who favored abolishing the blue laws did so for their personal shopping convenience, not because they wanted the chance to work a seventh day.
 
Economy May Be Crucial
 Ms. Taub said she wondered whether merchants, particularly at the malls, would really see more business or if shoppers would just browse and not buy in a depressed economy.
"Obviously it's a responsibility for business people to create a more conducive environment for purchasing, and if that means a seventh day is a part of that, that's one theory," she said. "But the reason people aren't shopping is not because they can't get out and shop. It's because of the economy."
Big retailers dispute that, saying that Sunday is one of their two or three most profitable days along with Friday and Saturday.
Duncan Muir, a spokesman for J. C. Penney in Dallas, which has a store in the Garden State Plaza in Paramus, said that while Sunday is a shorter day, with most Penney stores nationwide open only from noon to 5 or 6 P.M., customer volume is high, largely because of pre-printed inserts in Sunday newspapers.
"For retailers who use a circular that runs with the Sunday newspaper, it becomes one of the biggest days of the week," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
To a company that sells mutual funds, a return on its image is the goal of a new campaign.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
A COMPANY that sells billions of dollars of mutual funds is about to begin advertising something it values even more highly: its name.
T. Rowe Price Associates, the fourth-largest direct marketer of mutual funds in the country, is introducing its first corporate campaign intended to burnish its image rather than sell financial products. The broadcast and print campaign, by McCaffrey & McCall in New York, carries the company's long-running theme, "Invest with confidence." 
 "We're looking to cast a broader net to raise awareness," said Ed Bernard, the vice president of retail marketing at T. Rowe Price in Baltimore. "And, perhaps, to influence perceptions of us when there's unprecedented numbers of people paying attention to mutual funds."
The reason for that interest is, of course, interest, as in interest rates. Their decline has sent investors fleeing into mutual funds from fixed-rate investments like certificates of deposit.
For instance, Fidelity Investments reported that August was its best month ever. Fidelity, with $157 billion in retail assets, leads the Vanguard Group ($114 billion), the Dreyfus Corporation ($42 billion) and T. Rowe Price ($30 billion).
"Ours is a business of windows of opportunity," Mr. Bernard said last week in a telephone interview. "Typically, you've got to make hay while the sun shines." (Those windows must be in a barn.)
The campaign supplements harder-selling, product-focused ads created by McCaffrey & McCall for T. Rowe Price, which has been a client of the agency's direct marketing subsidiary since 1982. It is intended to complement the tenor of the company's product-oriented pitches, which have been praised by independent raters of mutual-fund performance like Morningstar Inc. for their rational, lucid tone.
"The more honest the ads are, the more direct they are, the more likely customers are to stay with T. Rowe Price," said Dany Khosrovani, the executive vice president of client services at McCaffrey & McCall.
"As more new mutual fund investors come into the market, who may not be familiar with specific company names," she added, "we had the hypothesis we should do something that associates all the core values of the company with the T. Rowe Price name."
For instance, the 30- and 45-second television commercials in the campaign, which begin running today, eschew the braggart's voice many companies assume as they hyperbolically flog the purportedly outstanding performance of their funds (while they pray earnestly for investors to ignore the type at the bottom of the ads with its microscopic disclaimers.)
Instead, as prosaic methods of measurement like scales, thermometers and beakers appear on screen, a plain-speaking announcer says: "While man has invented an instrument to measure virtually anything with great precision, the same can't be said for the performance of mutual funds. To that end, T. Rowe Price suggests a different way of thinking. It's an approach to investing that says you can achieve attractive returns without unacceptable risk."
That approach, which T. Rowe Price calls "risk-adjusted performance," is described in a brochure, part of a kit offered in the commercials as well as in the campaign's print ads, which will appear in publications like Business Week, Forbes and Money.
T. Rowe Price plans to spend $1 million on the first phase of the campaign, which is scheduled to last five weeks. In keeping with its assiduously careful practice of periodically measuring the response to the toll-free telephone numbers and coupons in its direct-response ads, on which it spends about $15 million a year, Mr. Bernard will gauge the reaction to the image campaign before proceeding further.
"My bottom line is always that until you do it, you don't know if it will work or not," Mr. Bernard said.

HEADLINE: Napoleon Invades Big Southern City

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, Aug. 29

 BODY:
When Napoleon wanted to do something, he wanted to do it big.
In his swift rise to power at the end of the 18th century, the soldier turned emperor dazzled Europe with his taste for the ornate and monumental. Short of stature but long on confidence, he dressed up traditional themes to suit himself, then declared them part of his legend. 
 The city of Memphis has been trying a little legend-building of its own with "Napoleon," its latest in a series of large-scale exhibitions.
Last spring, this city of just under a million people on the bluffs of the Mississippi River mounted what it called "the largest exhibition on the life and times of Napoleon Bonaparte ever presented in North America." Filled with paintings and drawings, clothing and jewelry, documents and furniture -- all from the life of Napoleon -- the exhibition offers history buffs and curious visitors a peek inside the world of the Little Corporal.
The exhibition has provoked nostril-flaring from a handful of other museum curators and art critics, who find it overly commercial. But those responsible for "Napoleon" -- part of a continuing city-run arts program called Wonders: The Memphis International Cultural Series -- have said it has accomplished its main objective: to provide regular folks a chance to see art and artifacts from faraway lands while helping the city's economy.
Jack Kyle, the marketing director for Wonders, said "Napoleon" has drawn more than 350,000 visitors since it opened in April.
 
From Jewels to Tapestries
 In scope at least, the exhibition is impressive. Housed in the city's downtown Cook Convention Center, it includes artifacts ranging from ornate porcelain artifacts and large pictoral tapestries, to Napoleon's uniforms, including the coat he wore at the battle of Marengo, to the luxurious jewels he bestowed on Josephine and his second Empress, Marie Louise. There are marble busts of Napoleon and his family by his court sculptor, Antonio Canova, and portraits of the emperor, including Antoine-Jean Gros's "Gen. Napoleon-Bonaparte at the Bridge of Arcole."
For museum watchers, however, the real wonder is how this Southern city has in the last few years been able to land not only "Napoleon," but several other large, and sometimes exclusive, exhibitions, including "Catherine the Great: Treasures of Imperial Russia," "The Etruscans: Legacy of a Lost Civilization" and "Splendors of the Ottoman Sultans."
The first show, "Rameses the Great," in 1987, was conceived under former Mayor Richard Hackett as a way of attracting tourist dollars and cultural exchange to Memphis. Two smaller exhibitions on Egyptian art had drawn a total of 100,000 visitors, largely because of local interest in the ancient land from which this city gets its name. The site of ancient Memphis is near Cairo, so city officials asked if "Rameses," an exhibition organized for two Canadian exhibitions, could come to Tennessee as well.
It drew 675,000 visitors and $80 million, and city officials decided to create a department to organize more shows like it. They created a cultural affairs department, and encouraged to develop an arts series. The result was Wonders, which is operated with only a handful of full-time city employees as managers. Volunteers serve as ticket-takers, gallery guides and docents.
 
'An Economic Coup'
 Not all of the shows have been profitable. The "Etruscans" exhibition lost money. "Napoleon," with a budget of $9.1 million, may not break even, organizers said. But Jon K. Thompson, the city's director of cultural affairs, says that by the time "Napoleon" closes on Sept. 22, the series will have brought two million visitors and $350 million into the city.
"It has been an economic coup for Memphis," said City Council Chairman Jack Sammons, who said the city and its Mayor, W. W. Herenton, plan to continue supporting future shows, including exhibitions featuring Peruvian gold in 1994 and Chinese imperial tombs in 1995.
"There was a fair amount of reluctance early on from the art community, which frowned on the mass marketing of the arts," Mr. Sammons said. But as the series has proved successful and profitable, he said, "they've come around."
Indeed, the secret of Wonders' success, according to series officials and museum curators, has been its ability to win financial support from the city, woo curators and appeal to foreign governments.
To pay for the exhibitions, Wonders pulls money from a city-financed interest-free loan and from local corporate donors. More than half of the money for the shows comes from ticket and gift shop sales.
 
Trading on Good Will
 Unable to trade on prestige as a big-city art museum or the promise of reciprocal loans, Wonders has had to forge a reputation as a friendly collaborator. To do that, in addition to promising tight security, Wonders has offered to restore pieces used in the show, a tempting offer for cash-strapped museums. In the case of "Catherine," Wonders spent $125,000 restoring her royal carriage. In "Napoleon," the series paid $200,000 to restore some furniture in the council chamber of the Chateau de Malmaison, Napoleon's country estate in France. The chamber now appears in replica in the exhibition.
Wonders has also been free to recruit special curators for each show. In "Napoleon," for example, the series officers enlisted Bernard Chevallier, the director of Malmaison, to be curator of the show and to write the catalogue. Mr. Chevallier pulled together more than 175 pieces of art from Malmaison and nearly 50 other museums, including the Vatican and the Louvre, many of which had never been shown in the United States.
Despite tepid critical response, a number of museum officials and art-world professionals have praised the Wonders' shows.
"In Memphis, they are not stuck up in an ivory tower like most of the museum people," said Thomas Hoving, the former director of New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, whose book, "Making the Mummies Dance," (Simon & Schuster) chronicled his stormy 10-year reign at the Met. "As a result, they've had extraordinary success. Their exhibits are reaching a whole section of the country that doesn't have much and they are getting big shows, year after year."
Eileen Harakal, a spokeswoman for the Art Institute of Chicago, was similarly upbeat. "Good for them for having the imagination and economic resources to be able to do this," she said. "Most of us in the field can't afford to do it anymore."
Not that others aren't trying. Ned Rifkin, the director of the High Museum in Atlanta, said he had been asked by patrons to emulate Wonders' effort.
"It's been good for Memphis, I know," said Mr. Rifkin, a former chief curator of the Hirschhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden at the Smithsonian Institution. "And I'm constantly being bombarded with, "Why can't High Museum do this?' But physically, we can't. We don't have the large halls."
But Mr. Rifkin, like others from the museum world, also voices his concern about such shows, saying it can feed into a kind of herd instinct.
"It's a mixed blessing," he said. "People come to expect and demand these big shows, when they may be missing profound experiences they can get from smaller exhibitions from permanent collections or modest loan exhibitions of very special material. It feeds that part of people's need not to miss the big movie of the summer when there may be this wonderful little foreign film down at an old movie house."

HEADLINE: Pollsters Enlist Psychologists In Quest for Unbiased Results

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
SHOULD laws be passed to eliminate all possibilities of special interests giving huge sums of money to candidates? Or do groups have a right to contribute to the candidate they support?
The first question comes from a survey by Ross Perot last March; the second is part of a more neutral rephrasing of that question as asked by an independent polling concern. When Mr. Perot put the question his way, 99 percent of those responding answered "yes." But in the alternative form, 40 percent favored limits on contributions. 
 The Perot poll has become a textbook case of how readily results of a survey can be manipulated by the pollster, a point too easily forgotten in a day when polls have become a fixture of the information landscape as a quick pulse reading of the body politic.
But survey researchers, seeking to minimize such biases in their results, are continuing to raise questions about the way they ask questions. In pursuit of greater methodological sophistication and accuracy in polling, one of the main tools of social science, they have formed a research alliance with cognitive psychologists.
Those at the forefront of the science of polling confront longstanding challenges in asking questions that are free of bias:
*Words can mean different things to the people who devise a survey and to those who answer it. For instance, in a 1981 poll about television, respondents said the meaning of the questions was clear to them. Yet when 51 respondents were queried further about one phrase, "over the last few years," 7 said "few" meant "no more than 2 years," 19 said it meant "7 years or more," and 19 took it to mean "10 years or more."
*Respondents can offer opinions on issues they know nothing about. In a 1981 study in which respondents were asked their views of a fictitious law, 30 percent said they opposed or favored it. And in a classic study done in the 1940's, college students willingly gave their opinions when surveyed about three nationalities that do not exist: Danireans, Pireneans and Wallonians.
*The options presented as answers can strongly affect the response. In one survey, for example, people were asked if they felt "the courts deal too harshly or not harshly enough with criminals." When offered just the two options, 6 percent said "too harshly" and 78 percent answered "not harshly enough." But when a third alternative was added -- "don't have enough information about the courts to say" -- 29 percent took that option, and 60 percent answered "not harshly enough."
*One question can influence the next. In a classic example, during the height of the Red scare in the 1950's, only 36 percent of respondents answered "yes" to the question, "Do you think the United States should let Communist reporters from other countries come in here and send back to their papers the news as they see it?" But "yes" answers jumped to 73 percent when the same question was preceded by one asking if Russia should let American reporters in.
Much of the current interest by survey researchers in cognitive science stemmed from the wish among government agencies for greater accuracy in several Federal surveys that are used to guide policy, like the Current Population Survey, done monthly to estimate the national unemployment rate.
"I'm hopeful that the cognitive sciences can help with many of the perennial problems of survey research," said Dr. Judith Tanur, a sociologist at the State University of New York at Stony Brook and editor of the book "Questions About Questions: Inquiries Into the Cognitive Bases of Surveys" (Russell Sage Foundation).
In 1980, the first of a series of meetings intended to address these problems brought together two professions that had rarely talked: survey researchers and cognitive scientists, whose expertise is in perception, memory and the nuances of comprehension.
In recent years that collaboration has begun to bear fruit in suggesting new ways to design surveys to get more accurate answers. One innovative method, for example, is a "think-aloud" protocol in which pollsters have people tell them what they are thinking as they answer questions.
"The think-aloud method allows you to see if a question is too difficult to understand or answer, and if you are getting at the concepts you want to," Dr. Tanur said.
A similar method, in which a group of people talk over the questions in a survey, has recently led to a change in a standard question in the Current Population Survey. The question, asked of those who say they are currently not working, has been, "Is there a job from which you are on lay off?"
 
Inaccurate Answers
 To those at the Department of Labor who composed the survey, "lay off" has a specific meaning: being temporarily suspended from a job to which a person expects to be called back. Such people are tallied differently than those out of work but not laid off from a specific job.
But the research showed that many people took "lay off" to be a euphemism for having been fired. A new version of the question adding the phrase "and expect to be called back" is now being used.
"During the past 12 months, about how many times did you see or talk to a medical doctor?" is one of the questions posed to the 50,000 people queried in the National Health Survey, the results of which are used to formulate government health programs.
But research by Dr. Elizabeth Loftus, a psychologist at the University of Washington, found that when people's health records were checked, their answer to this question was highly inaccurate; people failed to remember 60 percent of their doctor visits in the preceding 12 months.
Drawing on other studies of memory, Dr. Loftus found that asking a question in ways that offered more cues for recall improved the accuracy. One method asks people to recall specific visits, starting with the most recent ones. This improved the accuracy of the responses by about 15 percent, Dr. Loftus said.
One problem that has defied cognitive psychologists is that people give incorrect answers to pollsters. For example, experts on surveys say that when people are asked if they voted in the last election, about 20 to 30 percent will say they did when they did not. The experts say the percentages for misleading answers is about the same when people are asked if they plan to vote in a forthcoming election.
Both types of inaccurate answers introduce error in pre-election surveys, which use varying formulas to identify, as best they can, who will truly vote.
 
Accounting for False Answers
 A research team led by Dr. Robert Abelson, a psychologist at Yale University, has tried several approaches to reduce the rate of false voting responses. One assumed that because many people view voting as socially desirable, some people gave false answers because they wanted to appear virtuous in the eyes of the pollster
But when researchers reworded the question to offer people ready-made excuses for not voting -- suggesting, for instance, that circumstance had prevented them from voting -- there was no drop in the numbers who made false claims.
Testing whether faulty memory could be an explanation for the misleading answers, the researchers tried another technique that asked specific questions about past elections. But they still found no drop in the numbers who gave inaccurate answers on whether they voted in the most recent election.
The cognitive psychologists did discover, however, that part of the problem was a tendency to overgeneralize from past events to current ones. For example, people who usually vote were more likely to say they had voted in the most recent election, even when voting records showed they had not. And those who usually did not vote were more likely to make the opposite error, saying they had not voted in a recent election, even when records showed that they had.
As members of the survey profession struggle to solve such problems, they also face a battle against shoddy polling methods by special-interest groups trying to advance their causes. There are about 1,500 members of the American Association for Public Opinion Research, about half academics and half independent polling companies.
"Our members agree to abide by an ethical code that requires that you disclose details of how you did a survey," said Dr. Stanley Presser, a sociologist at the University of Maryland who is president of the association. "But there's less agreement on how you should ask questions, so the code is largely silent on particulars of how to conduct a survey."
Still, said Dr. Tom Smith, director of the General Social Survey at the University of Chicago and a past chairman of the ethics committee, "there is an elaborate procedure for bringing charges of violating ethics like biasing your survey to support a vested interest."
 
Critiques of Surveys
 The profession polices itself through peer review and open critiques of surveys, Dr. Smith said. The main journal in the field, Public Opinion Quarterly, features a column called "Poll Reviews" pointing out defects in methodology, especially those that have received wide publicity.
One critique was of a poll conducted on the night of Jan. 9, 1991, which seemed to show that 39 percent of Americans favored going to war against Iraq immediately. Because that poll was conducted overnight, no effort was made to reach people who did not answer their phones the first time. Such a poll, survey experts say, may include disproportionate numbers of retired people and fewer young men, who are less often home than other groups.
Another poll on the same topic, which was conducted over a four-day period and thus had more time to reach more people, found that 30 percent of the respondents favored going to war immediately.
The Perot poll was the topic of a similar critique in the June issue of The Public Perspective. Professional pollsters said the Perot poll had two major flaws: a skewed sample and biased questions. The questionnaire was published in TV Guide and asked the magazine's readers to reply. Thus the poll was not a random sample of Americans. Critics also said the Perot poll consisted of questions that were apparently composed by Mr. Perot's own political organization, rather than by an independent survey researcher.
"A lot of us in the survey profession were bothered by the Perot poll," Dr. Presser said. "But the practice is getting more and more common, with special-interest groups wording questions their way and letting anyone respond who wants, rather than gathering a random sample."
