HEADLINE: Churches Increasingly Join the Concert World

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
Last year, the conductor Jens Nygaard disbanded his Jupiter Symphony concerts because the cost of presenting them far exceeded the money he could raise for them. But a few months ago, Mr. Nygaard's series was revived with help from Christ and St. Stephen's Church, near Lincoln Center, which let him use its sanctuary as his concert hall for a fraction of the cost of Alice Tully Hall, the orchestra's former home. When the first concerts sold out, the church let Mr. Nygaard add a second series.
Across town, at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on the Upper East Side, and in Greenwich Village at the Church of the Ascension, new series of choral concerts have sprung up because the churches' music directors wanted to show off their choirs to the public. And at Corpus Christi Church in Morningside Heights, at St. Paul's Chapel near Wall Street and at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin near Times Square, ensembles of international stature are regularly presented. 
 Just when the directors of New York City's concert halls are looking for ways to attract new listeners and worrying about raising money to pay for their presentations, an alternative concert world is flourishing in the city's churches. In the last 10 years, as the expense of renting conventional concert halls has increased, the number of religious institutions opening their doors to performers or even sponsoring their concerts has increased significantly.
 
'All Music Is Sacred'
 Moreover, audiences are paying attention to their growing schedules. In buildings that seat from 250 to more than 1,500 people, concerts are regularly attracting nearly full houses. Tickets go for as little as $2 to as much as $50. And the music directors of several of these institutions say that their parishioners account for only 10 percent of their concert audiences.
The concerts are presented as secular events, and many feature repertory that is entirely secular. Sometimes the lines are blurred. At the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the stated policy is that "all music is sacred," and a visitor is likely to hear anything from a medieval passion play or a Baroque Mass to the ritual chanting of the Tibetan Gyoto monks or a festival of American Indian music and from Romantic chamber works to jazz.
One might expect there to be some strain between churches and their music directors over repertory, but that seems not to be the case. Recently the Vatican recommended that secular music not be performed in churches, but although some Roman Catholic churches have chosen to make that a matter of policy, others say that such decisions are made at the diocese level. Thus, at Corpus Christi, a Catholic church, the Music Before 1800 series frequently presents ensembles like the Classical Quartet, Fretwork, the Baltimore Consort and the Ensemble Rebel, which play secular instrumental works, as well as choirs that sing sacred repertory.
 
Drawing the Line at the Bawdy
 "We are careful about what we present," said Louise Basbas, the director of Music Before 1800. "I don't think the racier body of music, like certain English Renaissance lute songs, is appropriate to hear while you're sitting in a church."
The Episcopal Church, by contrast, seems to embrace the notion of presenting music of all kinds, hence the eclectic programming at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. "What I feel is part of my and the cathedral's agenda," said Bruce Fifer, the cathedral's music director, "is the idea that in the Middle Ages the cathedral was at the center of the community. We believe that artistically this manifests itself in the relationship of our services and music to the community's needs."
Indeed, many music directors see their programming in terms of form meeting function. "We do sacred music because that's what's written for our kind of outfit," said Gerre Hancock, the music director at St. Thomas Church in midtown. "But we see our concerts as having no liturgical function at all, and not as an extension of our religious responsibilities. We have no problem with other people presenting secular programs here, although the acoustics do not lend themselves to, for example, a violin and piano recital."
Kent Tritle, the music director at St. Ignatius Loyola, which has just installed an imposing new organ, adds a philosophical current. "The bottom line," he said, "is that people can go to a concert hall if they want to hear secular music. And to a degree they can hear sacred works in concert halls, too. But the experience of hearing sacred music in the kind of space it was written for is very different, and that's what we want to offer, in a nonproselytizing way."
 
Handling the Finances
 Most directors of these series say that although they have either free or inexpensive access to church facilities, they cannot depend on church largesse to keep their programs running. Like commercial concert presenters, they raise money for their programs, depending on a combination of ticket sales and donations from "friends of music" organizations. Several are taking a more modern route: they are incorporating as independent, nonprofit organizations and are therefore eligible for endowment and foundation grants that are not available to religious institutions.
"When we started our series," said Ms. Basbas at Corpus Christi, where her critically acclaimed Music Before 1800 program is in its 19th season, "we drew on the activities of the early-music co-op at Columbia University. It was very much of its time, and we were able to be casual about our financial structure and organization. But as the series developed, we needed to rethink that. State money was accessible, but in order to get it, we had to incorporate as an organization separate from the church, with a board and bylaws."
Incorporation is also a way to insulate a concert series from the financial life of the church. Indeed, some churches that do underwrite their music programs, including several with long histories of concert presenting, have been forced by the recession to curtail their activities. Trinity Church and St. Paul's Chapel, for example, have presented daily noontime recitals and chamber music programs for a quarter of a century. But three years ago, Trinity cut its programs back to three a week and has moved them and the rest of its programs to St. Paul's. Owen Burdick, Trinity's choral director and organist, explained that Trinity's economy was based on its real estate holdings in lower Manhattan. When the market softened, the church cut back on both programming and staff.
"For the first time in our history," Mr. Burdick said, "we are soliciting funds from corporations." Still, with a budget of $250,000 and a schedule of 170 concerts and recitals this year, Trinity leads the pack. Most churches present four to a dozen concerts a year and have budgets of $50,000 to $150,000. (The apparent differences in the cost per concert have to do with the kinds of music presented: recitals and chamber music are less expensive than choral concerts with orchestral accompaniment.)
 
A Bargain Rental
 Many churches and a few synagogues fill yet another kind of musical need. Small opera companies, young recitalists and shoestring chamber music and orchestral operations have found homes in churches all over New York where they can present concerts without breaking their budgets. One church that does a thriving rental business, in addition to presenting its own concerts, is Christ and St. Stephen's Church, near Lincoln Center.
Its sanctuary seats 300, and it can be rented for $350 to $500, compared with the $1,300 to $1,500 it can cost to rent Merkin Concert Hall or Weill Recital Hall. Several contemporary music and early-music groups call the church home, and in recent years Jerry Grossman, the principal cellist of the Metropolitan Opera, has presented regular recitals at the church. David Labovitz's Choral Symphony Society has presented its concerts there for years, and this year Mr. Nygaard's Jupiter Symphony joined the fold. All told, the church has about 100 concerts a year.
"One of the main reasons we make the church available," said Carol Wilson, the director of programming at the church, "is that we want to offer an artistic and spiritual home to musicians at all levels. We are available to groups that have been established for many years, like the Jupiter Symphony, and also to newly formed groups like Ex Umbris, an early-music ensemble that made its debut here in April. And musicians like to play here because the sanctuary is a lovely, intimate, warm setting, both visually and acoustically. We're very committed to this as a form of outreach to the community."
 
 
 
SOME MUSICAL OFFERINGS, MANY EARLY
 Once home mainly to organ recitals and amateur choral concerts, churches have expanded their musical offerings to include secular music and performances by internationally famous ensembles, most of them early music groups. Here are some of the most inviting programs scheduled for the fall:
Galatea, a chamber orchestra, will play works by Mozart, Bizet and Strauss at Christ and St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th Street, Manhattan, on Thursday at 8 P.M. Tickets are $7. Information: (212) 787-2755.
Todd Palmer, a clarinetist, and Carol Archer, a pianist, open the Noonday Concerts series at St. Paul's Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street, on Thursday at noon. Their program includes works by Mendelssohn, Debussy and Gershwin. Suggested donation is $2. Information: (212) 602-0747.
Just Friends, a vocal ensemble, will perform with Timothy Smith, organist, and Diana Solomon-Glover, soprano, at the Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, at 121st Street, Morningside Heights, on Sunday at 3 P.M. Suggested donation is $10. Information: (212) 222-5900.
The Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue, at 84th Street, installed a new pipe organ last season, and has some of New York's most highly regarded church organists to perform on it this season. Kent Tritle, the church's music director, opens the series on Sept. 19 at 4 P.M. Other recitalists are Tim Smith of the Riverside Church (Oct. 17), Alan Davis of St. Patrick's Cathedral (Dec. 19), David Hurd of All Saints Church (Jan. 16), William Trafka of St. Bartholomew's Church (Feb. 20), Dorothy Papadakos of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine (March 20) and Christopher Creaghan, Mr. Tritle's associate at St. Ignatius Loyola (April 17). Suggested donation is $10. Information: (212) 288-2520.
The Consort of Musicke, an English early music ensemble, will perform works by Purcell, Bartlett, Johnson and Blow at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 145 West 46th Street, Manhattan, on Oct. 15 at 8 P.M. Tickets are $20. Information: (212) 921-2939.
Pomerium Musices, with Alexander Blachly conducting, will open the Music Before 1800 series at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, Morningside Heights, on Oct. 17 at 4 P.M. The program, "For the Queens of Heaven and Earth," includes choral works by Lassus and Byrd. Tickets are $12 to 15. Information: (212) 666-0675.
Dennis Keene will conduct the Ascension Music chorus in Russian works, including excerpts from the Rachmaninoff Vespers, at the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at 10th Street, Greenwich Village, on Nov. 14 at 8 P.M. Tickets are $15. Also at the Church of the Ascension, Marie-Madeleine Durufle will play French organ music of the 19th and 20th centuries on Nov. 21 at 3 P.M. Tickets are $10 to $25. Information: (212) 254-8553.
Frederick Renz will conduct his Ensemble for Early Music and members of the Grande Bande Orchestra in the Monteverdi Vespers of 1610 at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, Morningside Heights, on Nov. 27 and 28. Mr. Renz's group is one of several ensembles resident at the cathedral. Tickets are $20. Information: (212) 749-6600.

HEADLINE: Supercomputers Update Leonardo, Redesigning the Parachute

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
FIVE HUNDRED years after Leonardo da Vinci sketched out a parachute and elucidated its principles, scientists are harnessing the most powerful computers on earth to probe the secrets of these air brakes so advanced versions can be made for tough new jobs in the 21st century.
The lowly parachute, it turns out, is a surprisingly complex object from the standpoint of aerodynamics. 
 Packed to the density of oak, a parachute emerges from its container and rapidly changes shape from a cylindrical log, to a streamer, to a hemispherical cup -- all in a matter of seconds. The flow of air in and around a parachute changes swiftly and repeatedly through the various phases of its flight, unlike the airflow over a speeding missile or an airplane wing, which in comparison is rather steady.
Because of this complexity, the design of parachutes for decades has been more of an art than a science. The work has been characterized by a trial-and-error approach, with spectacular successes and failures, excitement and death, rather than the orderly application of engineering rules derived from first principles.
Recently, however, supercomputers have acquired enough processing power to tackle the problem of exactly how air and fabric interact to make parachutes work. Quirky aerodynamics have been modeled with growing accuracy, yielding complex sets of equations that are beginning to disclose the inner dynamics of fluid-like airflows. These equations are also suggesting new kinds of parachute designs.
The goal, scientists say, is to make commonplace parachutes lighter and safer and to lay the foundation for more advanced ones. Roles envisioned for parachutes of the future include lowering the products of space factories back to Earth and slowing planetary probes as they speed through the atmospheres of alien planets.
"We want to increase our confidence that what we design is going to work," said Dr. Carl W. Peterson, head of defense and space programs at the Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M., where a dozen or so experts are trying to unravel parachute mysteries.
William J. Everett, head of engineering at the Pioneer Aerospace Corporation in South Windsor, Conn., a parachute maker, said of the Sandia work, "They're doing things that people 10 years ago thought were impossible."
But Dr. Peterson said that the advances made at Sandia to date were too limited to affect parachute design a great deal and that making such improvements would require years of work.
"The nature of the physics, the aerodynamics, is quite different from anything else that flies through the air," Dr. Peterson said. "We're struggling with it. Many people have said the problem is too hard to solve. We still have a ways to go."
"Leonardo had the right shape for a high-drag chute," he added, "and we're finding out how difficult the fluid physics of that inflating shape is, even once it's fully opened."
Sandia's supercomputers often run for days as they struggle to model real-world action that occurs in seconds. Even so, the answers can often be plainly wrong.
"I'm afraid to jump out of a perfectly good airplane, knowing what we don't know about parachutes," Dr. Peterson said. (He admitted that he had never parachuted himself, and that neither had -- to the best of his knowledge -- any member of Sandia's parachute research team.)
Parachutes were first used by Chinese acrobats to slow their falls, according to 12th-century Chinese archives. Da Vinci, in his famous notebooks on the possibilities of human flight, sketched out a parachute design in 1495, saying that "a tent of linen" can allow a man to "jump from any great height without danger to himself." The chute he illustrated, however, was too small to make for a truly safe landing, and it is unknown whether da Vinci himself ever built or tested one.
It was nearly 300 years later, in 1772, that a man named Canon Desforges took the first known leap of modern times, jumping off a tower with a parachute-like gadget and hurting himself only slightly. Decades later, a Frenchman named Andre-Jacques Garnerin became the first person to make repeated jumps, some from substantial heights..
 
Swinging Violently to Earth
 In 1802, he ascended in a balloon to an altitude of more than a mile and jumped with nothing more than a silk canopy. He landed safely. But his canopy had a tendency to swing so violently from side to side that he often had a bad case of motion sickness by the time he reached the ground. The historian Charles J. Cleary says that Garnerin once became violently ill in front of a crowd that included members of the royal family.
It was the conventional wars of the 20th century that provided the stimulus for the rapid evolution of the parachute from curiosity to reliable tool, mainly for delivering men and materiel behind enemy lines. During the cold war, further advances let parachutes perform feats like slowing manned capsules and mock warheads speeding back into the Earth's atmosphere from outer space.
At Sandia, one of three Federal centers for the design of nuclear arms, recent research on parachutes began to encounter major snags as designs became more advanced. For instance, engineers began to make prototype parachutes out of tough, light materials like Kevlar, a synthetic fiber with a tensile strength 10 times greater than stainless steel. Its lightness meant more parachute could be packed into a given space, providing greater stopping power than all-nylon parachutes.
But fast braking produced sudden waves of aerodynamic instability, with chutes often collapsing as air rushed around the edge and hit the outside of the canopy like a sledgehammer. The complexity of such problems, plus the fact that trial-and-error methods were costly and time-consuming, prompted Sandia aerodynamicists in the 1980's to begin to develop computer models of parachute opening, inflation and performance. The hope was that expensive test flights one day might be replaced by computer models.
The main challenge in such simulations is that even very small changes in a parachute can have a surprisingly large effect on its workings, making its behavior very hard to predict. Still, the Sandia team is making some headway, with its computer programs able to disclose complex vortexes swirling about an opening chute. Such computer predictions, continuously checked against real-world data, are slowly getting better.
 
Parachute in Jupiter Mission
 "If we work together internationally, perhaps in three years we might have the basic computational tools," Dr. Peterson said in an interview. "Right now, no designer would hang his hat on this stuff."
The current state of the Sandia work is outlined in an article by Dr. Peterson in the current issue of Physics Today, published in Woodbury, L.I., by the American Institute of Physics.
Though lacking a complete set of equations to describe the workings of a parachute, the Sandia team has produced enough new knowledge to become a magnet for commercial designers. Mr. Everett of Pioneer Aerospace said that his company had sent a team to Sandia last year to study the work there.
It was Pioneer that made the high-tech parachute now hurtling toward the planet Jupiter aboard the $1.4 billion Galileo spacecraft. In 1995, Galileo is to fire toward the giant planet a 760-pound mini-probe that will deploy a 12.5-foot parachute as the apparatus sails into Jupiter's poisonous atmosphere, making measurements as it descends until crushed by intense atmospheric pressure.
Although Galileo's main antenna is stuck and the craft will produce fewer pictures than originally planned, other parts of the planetary mission, including the mini-probe and its parachute, are in excellent shape and should give scientists a wealth of new information about the icy mysteries of the solar system's largest planet.
In the future, Sandia expects to help the National Aeronautics and Space Administration make parachutes for a variety of other planetary probes, including ones to whiz through the thin atmosphere of Mars.
"Leonardo," Dr. Peterson wrote in his article, "would be pleased."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A bomb dropped from a speeding plane first travels horizontally at great speed; as the parachute opens, drag increases, slowing it enough so that the bomb drops vertically onto its target. (Sandia National Laboratory)(pg. C10)
 
Diagrams:
The empirical approach to parachute design: Leonardo da Vinci's theoretical chute probably would not have worked, but by the end of the 18th century, the trial-and-error method had led to Garnerin's practical silk parachute.
 
Understanding the soft landing: World War II saw the first widespread use of parachutes. A trefoil of parachutes lowers the shuttle's used rockets to Earth. A chute to land the Galileo probe on Jupiter in 1995 is among today's most advanced parachute designs. (The Bettmann Archive/Safe Parachute Company (1941)/Pioneer Aerospace)(pg. C1)
 
Finding Out Why a Parachute Collapses
In the early phase of inflation, the canopy captures air, creating a pressure differential that causes "drag" and slows the descent. By the time the chute is fully inflated, it has transferred substantial energy to the air, creating a wake behind it. As the chute slows, air from the wake can overtake the canopy, pushing it from behind and making it collapse and accelerate. (Source: Scientific American)(pg. C10)

HEADLINE: Renault-Volvo Marriage Is On

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 6

 BODY:
After two years of partnership and several months of complex negotiations that were concluded only on Friday, Renault of France and Volvo of Sweden announced today that they will merge on Jan. 1 to form the world's sixth-largest automotive group.
The merger, which had long been rumored and became widely anticipated over the weekend, is aimed at allowing the two companies to weather the severe recession buffeting the European automobile industry. It will also strengthen them as they prepare for the tougher competition that will come when all restrictions on Japanese auto sales in the European Community are lifted in January 1999. 
 Sixty-five percent of the new group, to be known as Renault-Volvo RVA, will be owned by Renault and 35 percent by Volvo until Renault -- currently owned by the French Government -- is partly privatized, perhaps as early as next year. In 1992, the two companies produced a total of 2.45 million vehicles, had combined sales of about $37.5 billion and employed 200,000 people.
 
$5.2 Billion in Savings
 The group will continue to market cars and other vehicles under the Renault and Volvo brands, but they will merge their research, planning, production and distribution operations as well as their corporate structure. They predict that this will result in $5.2 billion of savings by 2000.
"The engagement was long and well thought out," Industry Minister Gerard Longuet of France said today, referring to the Renault-Volvo "alliance" that began in 1991, "and I think it will lead to a successful marriage, a genuine marriage of complete cooperation."
For Sweden, the "marriage" is perhaps more painful, since Volvo has long been a symbol of the country's industrial prowess. But the merger marks another step in Sweden's gradual economic integration with the European Community, which it hopes to join as a full member in 1995.
Measured by its 1992 sales, the new group will rank sixth globally after General Motors, Ford, Toyota, Nissan and Volkswagen. Within Europe, in the production of cars and trucks in Europe it will rank second after Volkswagen and ahead of Fiat and Peugeot Citroen, with a share of about 12 percent of the Western European market. Further, it is likely to be the largest industrial group in France and the 20th largest worldwide.
The merger will have little impact in the United States, since Renault withdrew from the American car market in 1987 and has no plans to return, although it will continue to sell trucks through its Mack truck unit. Volvo still sells cars and large trucks in the United States. But with American sales of some 65,000 cars last year, it controls less than 1 percent of the American auto market.
Volvo controls 83 percent of a truck-manufacturing venture with the Gneral Motors Corporation, the Volvo GM Heavy Truck Corporation.
The new group's main focus will be on the highly competitive -- and currently depressed -- European auto market. New car registrations across the European Community last month ended up only 5.6 percent lower than in August 1992, because of a surge in British sales, but they were down 16.7 percent from January to August, compared with the period a year earlier.
Over the weekend, under pressure from European manufacturers, Japan agreed again to lower its exports of cars and light trucks to the community in 1993, this time to 980,000 units, down 18.5 percent from 1992. But the community is already committed to removing all controls on Japanese car sales in Europe in 1999.
Renault is, in fact, one of the few healthy European auto manufacturers, having recoverd from a crisis that prompted a Government bailout in 1986 to earn profits of about $1 billion on sales of $26.7 billion in 1992. Volvo, in contrast, showed losses of $435 million on sales of $10.87 billion last year, though it earned $5.6 million in the first half of 1993.
Mr. Longuet presided over the news conference announcing the merger today because the French state currently owns Renault. But he also used the occasion to confirm that Renault was one of 21 big state-owned companies marked for privatization by France's new conservative Government.
Asked when this privatization could take place, Mr. Longuet said it would depend on market conditions. "It's difficult to imagine it can happen before the second half of 1994," he said. "But I would like to see it happen before the first semester of 1995."
Much of the negotiation between Renault's chairman, Louis Schweitzer, and Volvo's chairman, Pehr Gyllenhammar, revolved around creating a corporate structure for the new group that both anticipates Renault's privatization and insures continued control of management by the French state and Volvo.
This has been done through creation of a holding company, RVC, of which Renault will own 51 percent and Volvo will hold 49 percent. RVC, in turn, will own 35 percent of the shares of Renault-Volvo RVA, the company that will control the two manufacturers' car and truck building operations. This share is likely to be a larger stake than any other single shareholder, even after the privatization of Renault.
Thus, with 17.85 percent of Renault's 65 percent total share in the new group held through RVC, only the balance that it will own directly -- 47.15 percent -- will be subject to privatization. Volvo, on the other hand, will own 17.15 percent through RVC and 17.85 percent directly. The two companies pledge not to sell their shares in RVC without mutual agreement.
Although Mr. Longuet stressed that Renault would be the "driving force" in the new group, the delicate problem of how to find places for both Mr. Schweitzer and Mr. Gyllenhammar was resolved by creating a supervisory board and a management board.
Mr. Gyllenhammar is expected to head the 14-member supervisory board, which will have a voice over important financial matters. It will also appoint the management board, comprising three Renault and two Volvo representatives, which will run the group; Mr. Schweitzer seems likely to be chairman of the management board.
"You wanted this merger as much as we did," Mr. Gyllenhammar told his French partner at today's news conference, noting that the alliance between their companies the past two years proved "better than hoped and much better than expected."
France's communist-led CGT trade union, the largest at Renault, called the deal an unacceptable threat to jobs and national independence and said workers would "do everything to render this merger inoperative."
 In January 1991, through an exchange of shares, Renault acquired 8.2 percent in Volvo A.B., the Swedish conglomerate's holding company, as well as 25 percent of the Volvo Car Corporation and 45 percent of the Volvo Truck Corporation. Volvo, in turn, obtained 20 percent of Renault S.A. and 45 percent of the Renault V.I. truck company.
The merger will involve only Volvo's automotive operations, leaving Volvo A.B. as a large shareholder in the Procordia pharmaceuticals giant as well as in companies in the food, beverages, tobacco and aircraft, marine and industrial engine sectors. Renault, though, will retain its share of Volvo A.B.
The proposed merger must still requires the approval of the Renault and Volvo boards as well as by the French Government and the European Community's Executive Commission. Formal approval by the Swedish Government is not required, but the move has already been endorsed by the conservative Government of Prime Minister Carl Bildt.
With completion of the deal, large stakes in both of Sweden's auto companies will have passed to foreigners; General Motors owns half of Saab Automobile A.B. in a joint venture with Saab-Scania of Sweden.

FORD CUTS IN BRITAIN
 LONDON, Sept. 6 (Reuters) -- The Ford Motor Company said today that it planned to cut 1,400 more jobs in Britain this year to help it compete in Europe's weakening auto market. A company spokesman said Ford of Britain, which employs 31,350 people, will try to complete the reduction by year-end through voluntary means. In 1980, the British unit had 72,000 employees; its vehicle output is virtually unchanged from that time.

HEADLINE: Observer;
The Big Sizing Down

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
If your ambition is to be fired, this is a great time to be an American.
Most of the big companies -- Eastman Kodak, I.B.M., Procter & Gamble and lots more -- are firing as though unemployment is going to be the biggest thing since Madman Muntz brought television to the American parlor. 
 The boss of any large corporation that hasn't fired at least enough people to make up an army division has a lot of explaining to do to his buddies down at the C.E.O. Club.
"What's the matter, fella? Don't you believe in the end of the American future?"
In modern mushmouth, which now passes for English throughout America, the firing trend is called "downsizing." Downsizing makes a business "lean and mean."
"Lean and mean" is not mushmouth lingo. It's sports jabber, a teen-ager dialect spoken by grown-ups who want to sound dynamic.
"Lean-and-mean types gonna leave cleat marks all over your face, man." And so forth. If they run once big, now downsized companies, those companies gonna leave cleat marks all over the famous "worldwide competition."
"Worldwide competition" is a euphemism. Means foreign companies are beating American companies by using such devices as good national educational systems, government-approved cartel arrangements, superior management skills and/or sweated labor.
To review: Downsizing makes America lean and mean against worldwide competition.
And yes, puts army-size human masses out of work, raising the question that's hardly ever asked. Why not? Maybe because it's naive.
"Never be naive, no matter how naive you are." The law is as old as the story of the child who pointed out that the emperor had no clothes on. In fact it was enacted by that very same emperor as soon as he put some clothes on, made retroactive and cited as justification for giving the naive kid a good caning.
Nowadays of course we are too civilized to cane, so the punishment for asking naively pertinent questions is to be dismissed as a fool whose question doesn't deserve an answer.
Enough digressing. What is the shamefully naive question? This: "Doesn't all the firing mean there'll be even fewer people with money to buy stuff from lean, mean companies, thus making hard times worse?"
I trust nobody here will think I, personally, would ask a question as stupidly naive about economics as this. However, the ruin that was California needs mention.
The ruin seems to result from the downsizing of the national war machine, which results from the end of the cold war. Downsizing in this case was morally delightful, but not otherwise uplifting for California, which turned out to rest on a vast plate of Pentagon contracts.
It's a little awkward to mention California's need for munitions money. That's because it brings up the highly awkward question of whether Hitler didn't also do us a lot of good by forcing America to arm for World War II.
Until then the Great Depression of the 1930's seemed determined to last forever. Hitler, war and munitions contracts put us back on the track to boom times, especially California, which seemed destined to boom eternally until the eternal cold war suddenly turned as un-eternal as everything else.
Downsizing California's defense-contract work force has obviously made California lean and mean, though not yet in the cleats-in-the-face style. Lean, yes: the out-of-work usually get lean before prolonged bad diet fattens them up. Mean, too: the new immigrants, welcome when they were cheap labor, are a bone in California's throat now that all labor is cheap.
Now comes more ominous news for the as-yet unfired. Vice President Gore, who is reinventing government, is reportedly going to call for cutting the Federal payroll by some 250,000 jobs.
Putting the ax to the payrollers sounds dandy. After the joy of the axing subsides, what will the 250,000 latest unemployed contribute to the economy? Not to worry. The North American Free Trade Agreement, though a threat in the immediate future to the still-employed, will create a new boom in the long run, and, as John Maynard Keynes noted, in the long run we are all dead.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Why Going Back to School Is Like Jet Lag;
Faulty Comparison

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article on the lagging of American teacher salaries behind those elsewhere (Education page, Aug. 18) is deceptive. All of the salaries have been blindly converted to a dollar standard, using current foreign exchange rates, without even mentioning how far these salaries might go in costs of living and tax burdens. 
 Your accompanying chart shows American midcareer teacher salaries lagging behind those of the Netherlands, Germany, Hong Kong, Ottawa and Zurich, all places that have much higher costs of living and the tax burdens associated with welfare states. American teacher salaries lead those of Britain, Japan, Sweden and France, where the costs of living and tax burdens are also much higher. Teacher salaries in India are bound to be last on the chart, as the cost of living and tax burden are lowest among the places surveyed.
It has taken the International Monetary Fund and World Bank half a century to figure out the meaninglessness of using a dollar standard at market exchange rates to compare economies.
 
ADITYA BHATNAGAR
Columbia, Md., Aug. 25, 1993

HEADLINE: Low-Income New Yorkers to Have Day Care

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Capital for Human Services" Op-Ed, Aug. 23) by Senator Carol Moseley-Braun provides recognition of the role public-private partnerships play in providing nonprofit child care to low-income families, primarily in the Midwest. New Yorkers should know that similar alliances among community leaders, government and the private sector are flourishing to the benefit of this city's children. 
 The same community development corporations that have transformed hundreds of vacant city-owned buildings into thousands of affordable apartments in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan are involved in a plan to develop child care facilities for 900 children in 10 city neighborhoods. New York's community groups are the best resource to maximize Federal and local funds and harness private support to provide day care for low income families.
Working with these grass-roots community development corporations is the city's Human Resources Administration, which will contract for and support day care providers and help leverage Federal funds; my organization, which is a national nonprofit, providing funds and technical help to community groups and arranging bank financing, and Child Care, a nonprofit advocacy and referral organization, which is furnishing expertise in early childhood education programs.
In many cities, including New York, self-help and citizen-led initiatives -- when linked to innovative programs and even modest amounts of capital -- can make a difference in people's lives.
 
PAUL S. GROGAN
President, Local Initiatives Support Corporation
New York, Aug. 27, 1993

HEADLINE: Finding Gold, of a Sort, in Landfills

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LANCASTER, Pa., Sept. 1

 BODY:
While most cities are still struggling to recycle today's trash, officials here have taken a novel approach to the waste problem -- they are mining yesterday's garbage.
At a municipal landfill nestled in rolling farmland along the Susquehanna River about 10 miles west of here, the detritus that is dug up helps feed a nearby incinerator that supplies electricity for more than 15,000 homes. 
 And landfill space once crammed with garbage is now available for trash that cannot be recycled or burned.
"Some people mine coal for energy, but when we mine, we mine garbage," said Herbert W. Flosdorf, executive director of the Lancaster County Solid Waste Authority, which operates the landfill.
 
Expense of Closing Dumps
 The number of communities and businesses that are turning the trash-disposal process on its head is small but growing. They not only recover usable resources and extend the life of dumps, but may also reclaim some that pose environmental threats.
Interest in such activities is heightened by Federal regulations taking effect in October that will require communities, which have been able to essentially ignore dumps they had filled and closed, to monitor shut landfills for 30 years.
Mining can delay the expenditure of millions of dollars in closing costs. Officials in some states like California, where there are already tough landfill closing laws, have begun to investigate the practice.
"This is all about economics," said Randall Forbes, manager of refuse disposal for the Department of Public Works in Mendocino County, Calif., which has begun studying whether to mine its landfill. "The real benefit may be that we can recover landfill space and use it again."
Proponents of garbage mining, however, caution that in many places the cost of digging up garbage can easily exceed that of simply buying new land. And some environmentalists note that it is far easier to recycle materials before they are buried.
"This is not a waste management strategy of the highest order," said Allen Hershkowitz, a senior scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, which has its headquarters in New York City. "It underscores the absurdity of entombing everything we throw out."
Federal environmental officials said that it was far too soon to draw any conclusions about mining's benefits or speculate about the impact of new regulations. "This is really cutting-edge stuff that we have not had a chance to evaluate," said Bruce Weddle, director of the municipal waste division of the Environmental Protection Agency.
But it appears that in some cases, mining garbage may save a community money. For example, Collier County, Fla., which includes the city of Naples, has been excavating a landfill to recover an unlikely commodity: the dirt that is spread each day over newly dumped garbage to hold down odors and discourage rodents. This dirt, or cover soil, is extremely expensive in Florida, and officials estimate that they save about $500,000 a year by using the dirt extracted from old garbage mounds to cover newer, smellier, garbage.
As the dirt is excavated, metals, tires and other recyclable materials are also recovered and the rest of the exhumed trash is reburied in a newer part of the landfill that has better environmental protections, said William Lorenz, the country's environmental services administrator.
Some businesses are also looking to landfill mining. Mr. Forbes, the Mendocino County official, told of a lumber company that was hoping to sell dirt and decomposed bark from its landfill to the county for cover soil, and in the process clean up the site and turn it into a marketable piece of property.
Elsewhere, state officials like those in New York are investigating mining as a way of reclaiming problem landfills. In a bid to rejuvenate six dumps that have been ordered closed by state officials, the New York State Energy Research and Power Authority is financing mining projects at the landfills.
The move follows a 1990 experiment at a landfill outside Edinburg, N.Y., near Saratoga Springs, that indicated that some older dumps could be mined safely without releasing toxic materials like asbestos, said Eugene Salerni, an environmental engineer in Albany who directed the project.
But other experts cautioned that such mining could release buried hazards. "This is not much different than what is being done at Superfund sites," said William Rathje, a professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona in Tucson who has studied the history and environmental aspects of landfills. "It does not strike me as something that most local communities would want to mess around with."
The project here in Lancaster County appears to reflect both the potential and limitations of mining garbage. The project's roots stretch back to 1986, when the county decided to close five smaller landfills that no longer meet state standards and opened a 100-acre dump outside the village of Creswell.
Until January 1991, the landfill took in garbage from the county's 425,000 residents and businesses and buried it, producing mounds that were soon 60 feet high. But that month, a garbage incinerator was completed, and there was not enough new trash to run the incinerator at capacity. So officials started excavating 18 acres of the landfill to recover waste that could be burned at the incinerator, said Mr. Flosdorf.
Bulldozers and backhoes dig up old trash at the landfill and dump it into a cylinder-shaped sifter that separates dirt from household waste. Nearly 60 percent of the trash excavated, a hodgepodge of crushed milk cartons, shredded plastic garbage bags and soggy newspapers still showing the headlines of many yesterdays, can be burned in the incinerator.
About 10 percent -- trash like like rubber-backed rugs and bedsprings -- cannot be burned and must be reburied. And the remainder is the dirt, which is used to bury incinerator ash and other waste.
Mr. Flosdorf said the county makes a weekly profit of $4,000 from the electricity produced by the excavated waste, money that offsets the cost of mining. But more important, he estimated that the excavation had decreased the volume of garbage at the 18-acre site by 78 percent, a gain that would extend the dump's life by about four years.
"We don't want to build any more landfills in this county, so we want this one to last as long as possible," he said.
Still, Mr. Flosdorf's enthusiasm about mining is offset by the skepticism of other experts. "Even if this is a viable option, it could be commercially costly," said Mr. Hershkowitz of the Natural Resources Defense Council. "You still have a lot of residue to discard and a lot of buried material that has been contaminated and degraded."
Mr. Rathje, the University of Arizona professor, said he was also cautious about the technique, adding that he believed society's emphasis should remain on recycling new garbage and reducing waste.
But he said that for communities that have decided to use incinerators, mining might make sense. And it could have an even broader appeal if the market for recyclable materials improves enough to make garbage mining cost-effective even without incineration.
"I do believe that somewhere down the line -- perhaps 5 years or perhaps 50 -- mining landfills for resources like aluminum, steel, plastic or the energy in paper is definitely going to be economically viable," he said.

An article on Tuesday about mining landfills to recycle old garbage referred incorrectly to a New York State agency that is financing mining projects at dumps. It is the Energy Research and Development Authority.

HEADLINE: Clinton Health Proposal Includes New Program for Long-Term Care

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
President Clinton's health plan will call for a new Government program to help finance long-term care for people with severe disabilities, regardless of their age or income, Administration officials said today.
The program would help pay for medical and social services that disabled people receive in their own homes, in adult day-care programs and at other sites outside nursing homes. The program would not cover services in a nursing home or an institution for the mentally retarded. 
 The plan is intended, in part, to meet the needs of elderly people, who already have coverage for hospital care and doctors' services under Medicare. By proposing the new benefit, Mr. Clinton increases the chances that he will win support from the elderly for his overall health care plan.
In the final days before it releases its health plan, the Clinton Administration is working to shore up support among such political constituencies by disclosing aspects of the plan that will appeal to important groups.
At other times, the Administration has appeared to be testing the waters for particularly controversial ideas. The Administration seemed today to back away from one such idea, to limit tax deductions that employers may take for the cost of their workers' health benefits. [Page B11.]
 
Paying 20 Percent of Cost
 White House documents on the proposal for long-term care say that disabled people would, on the average, have to pay 20 percent of the cost of services they get under the new program. But there would generally be no charge for people whose incomes fall below the official poverty level ($11,187 for a family of three in 1992).
Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for 32 million elderly and 4 million disabled people, now covers very limited amounts of long-term care. Medicare beneficiaries could also qualify for the new benefit, providing "home and community-based services" outside a nursing home, if they paid a premium of $20 a month, beyond the standard Medicare premium, now $36.60 a month, the documents say.
The Clinton proposal would also establish Federal standards for private insurance covering the costs of long-term care, in or out of a nursing home. Sales of such insurance have been increasing rapidly, but Congressional investigators and consumer advocates have reported abuses in its marketing.
While Administration officials could not specify the cost of the new program, they said that it would be financed partly through premiums and cigarette taxes. The Government would make grants to each state, with the Federal share varying from 70 percent to 95 percent of the cost, the documents say. Each state's contribution would be "roughly equal to current state Medicaid spending on the severely disabled," the documents say.
 
'A Real Breakthrough'
 John C. Rother, chief lobbyist for the American Association of Retired Persons, said the Clinton proposal would be "a real breakthrough in covering home and community-based services for people of all ages with mental and physical disabilities -- not just older people, but also victims of accidents and children with birth defects."
The proposal on long-term care will be formally presented, with the rest of Mr. Clinton's health plan, in a speech that he intends to deliver to a joint session of Congress later this month, probably the week of Sept. 20. Congress is expected to make many changes in Mr. Clinton's plan before approving legislation.
White House documents describing the President's plan say the program for long-term care has these components:
*Expanded home and community-based services.
*Improvements in Medicaid coverage for institutional care.
*Standards to improve the quality of private insurance for long-term care and tax incentives to encourage its purchase.
*Tax incentives that support the efforts of individuals with disabilities to obtain employment.
*A demonstration study intended to pave the way toward greater integration of acute and long-term care.
Administration officials see community care as a way to tend to people in their own homes, where they want to be, at lower cost than in nursing homes. But Linda Keegan, vice president of the American Health Care Association, a trade group for nursing homes, said: "The Administration is perpetuating a myth in trying to sell this as a cost-saving measure. Studies over the last decade show that expanding home and community-based care adds to health costs. It costs more money because it doesn't substitute for nursing home care but serves a different population."
Still, Stephen R. McConnell, senior vice president of the Alzheimer's Association, praised the presence of long-term care in the package, saying 1.2 million of the 4 million Americans with Alzheimer's disease might be helped by the new program.
 
Providing Care to All
 The White House documents say that the proposal, to be known as the American Health Security Act, "increases Federal authority to provide home and community-based services to individuals with severe disabilities without regard to income or age."
States would decide which services should be available. They could include assistance to help people with daily living, adult day care, rehabilitation services, physical modifications of the home and technology to aid the disabled.
Administration officials say it is neither desirable nor possible for the Government to finance all long-term care. Accordingly, White House documents say Mr. Clinton will propose a wide range of tax breaks to encourage people to buy private insurance.
Americans have bought more than 2.9 million insurance policies covering the cost of nursing home care. Such costs on average are more than $31,000 a year per person and are much higher in big cities like New York. Many elderly people without such insurance have been forced to exhaust their savings to become poor enough to qualify for Medicaid.
Under Mr. Clinton's plan, there would be a Federal tax credit for people with disabilities who work. They could use the credit to help pay for equipment or "personal-care services" that help them perform their work or daily activities.
To combat abuses in the sale of insurance for long-term care, Mr. Clinton will propose that the Government set "minimum standards" for such insurance within two years, the documents say.
The rules, to be enforced by state insurance commissioners, would require insurers to offer "inflation protection," so the value of a policy would not be eroded by the rising cost of long-term care.
Under the Clinton plan, the Government would also prohibit "improper sales practices." Insurers could not deny coverage because of an applicant's medical problems existing before a certain date. And consumers who have paid premiums for years would be entitled to some benefits even if they later let their policies lapse.

HEADLINE: FEDERAL CUTBACKS PROPOSED BY GORE IN 5-YEAR PROGRAM

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore today unveiled a set of more than 800 recommendations that he said would streamline "old-fashioned, outdated government," save $108 billion over five years and cut 252,000 Federal jobs by 1998.
The report recommends eliminating thousands of field offices for the Departments of Agriculture and Housing and Urban Development and combining the enforcement and regulatory functions of various agencies. For example, the Drug Enforcement Administration would be absorbed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. 
 The document says that eliminating some 252,000 jobs -- about 12 percent of the Federal payroll -- could save more than $40 billion over five years. It recommends drawing up the Federal budget every other year instead of annually. And it says $22.5 billion could be saved in five years by giving Government managers greater procurement authority on a broad range of purchases.
 
Looking to Business
 White House officials used the broadest possible brush in making the recommendations, drawing unabashedly from the experiences of corporations like General Motors and emphasizing how government can emulate private business and industry. Companies have come up with mixed results in their efforts to cut payrolls and other costs by making drastic changes in the way work is done. [Page B10.]
President Clinton immediately embraced the findings of the report, the National Performance Review, and pledged to act immediately to carry it out. But White House aides also cautioned against raising expectations about the ability to make sweeping change when some of the most significant suggestions would require Congressional consent and many of the savings would not be realized for years.
 
Suggestions From Past
 Mr. Gore's report, prepared over six months with the advice of thousands of Federal employees, incorporates suggestions made by past government-reform commissions with an upbeat assessment by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore that the system can actually be changed this time.
Mr. Gore said the report represented "a new customer-service contract with the American people, one that demonstrates to the taxpayers that their tax dollars will be treated with respect for the hard work that earned them."
And Mr. Clinton anticipated criticism that the report would be another in a series of government reviews that have had little practical effect. Later this week, he is expected to announce the first in a series of executive orders to force agencies to set up customer-service centers.
 
'Make No Mistake'
 "Make no mistake about this," Mr. Clinton said as he stood on the South Lawn of the White House with two forklifts piled with Government documents parked behind him. "This is one report that will not gather dust in a warehouse."
"To meet the challenges of the global economy and to better use new technology, our most successful companies have been through this process, many of them starting more than a decade ago -- eliminating unnecessary layers of management, empowering front-line workers, becoming more responsive to their customers and seeking constantly to improve the products they make, the services they provide and the people they employ," Mr. Clinton said. "Meanwhile, I have seen too little of this happen nationally."
 
Weight for Other Demands
 Mr. Clinton is planning to use the report as an underpinning for the other demands he plans to make on Americans this fall, including support for his health plan.
Mr. Clinton's political advisers have been assessing the mood of voters who have declared themselves disgusted with government. The advisers that a realistic effort to change will win support from disaffected citizens attracted to the anti-government message of Ross Perot and the movement to limit the terms of elected officials.
The key to winning, these advisers have said, is to provide convincing evidence that dramatic action is possible and at the same time to convince Federal employees and their unions that all job reductions -- or "simplification," as one official termed it today -- will be achieved through attrition.
"We do not think it will be extraordinarily painful, but we cannot say there will be no pain at all," the official said of the job reductions, adding that no political appointees would lose jobs. Middle managers would feel much of the effect of the recommendations, and their union has already objected.
 
Winnings Initial Praise
 The official spoke at a briefing on condition that she would not be quoted by name. Asked why some officials were being permitted to describe the plan for quotation and others were not, Mr. Gore's press secretary, Marla Romash, explained, "We set the rules."
Administration officials have told members of Congress that roughly two-thirds of the recommendations can be initiated by executive order. And the effort won plaudits from Republicans, Democrats and the representatives of the three major Federal labor unions today.
Almost everyone called it a first step in a difficult process.
"This is going to be a long, tough slog, even if Congress cooperates," said David Osborne, a consultant to Mr. Gore and co-author of the book "Reinventing Government" on which much of the review was based.
 
'Stronger Momentum' Seen
 Still, the endorsements were swift and bipartisan.
"There is a stronger momentum to change government today than there ever had been before," said Senator John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat who heads the Senate committee on Governmental Affairs.
Representative Bob Michel of Illinois, the Republican leader, joined Mr. Glenn in calling for swift action and noted that many of the suggestions have been made by past Republican administrations.
As most parties were striving to present a united front, Mr. Clinton prepared to embark on a week of travel to Virginia, Ohio, California and Texas and Mr. Gore planned to appear on network talk shows, including David Letterman's new late-night television program on CBS.
As they worked to sell the recommendations, some muted objections surfaced. The report, for example, still included a recommendation to fold the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms into the F.B.I. Both Attorney General Janet Reno and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen have expressed reservations about the plan.
But today, it seemed evident that Mr. Gore's planners had taken the initiative away from the Attorney General, going forward with the idea before Ms. Reno completed her review.
At the same time, Administration officials went out of their way to shift the blame for any inaction on the report to Congress. And Clinton advisers stressed that the changes being recommended were complicated and could take several years to accomplish.
 
'Marbeling in Meat'
 "You have a lot of political demagogues that run around and say that this fat in government is something that's stuck out over in the end, and you just take a hacksaw and chop it off," said John Sharp, the former Texas comptroller who oversaw a similar state streamlining effort there. "It's not. It's like marbling in meat, and you have to have very good people to get inside those agencies and work."
The recommendations Mr. Clinton is making could have a greater effect on Federal offices around the country than in Washington; both the Agriculture and Housing departments and the Army Corps of Engineers would dramatically scale back regional offices.
Individuals would also see the effect of the proposed changes at tax time, when the Internal Revenue Service would be forced to speed up its tax return system and accept credit cards for tax payments.
"The Government is broken, and we intend to fix it," Mr. Clinton said. "We can't do it unless we all understand that this isn't a Democratic goal or a Republican goal. This is an American imperative, and we all need to be a part of it."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Vice President Gore unveiled more than 800 recommendations that he said would streamline "old-fashioned, outdated Government," save $108 billion over five years and cut 252,000 Federal jobs by 1998. [Page A1.] The Administration's efforts to "reinvent" Government face the same inherent tensions that thwarted its predecessors. [A1] Similar efforts in the private sector have produced decidedly mixed results. [B10.]
President Clinton's health plan will call for a new Government program to help finance long-term care for people with severe disabilities, regardless of their age or income. [A1.] The White House appeared to back away from limiting tax deductions that employers may take for the cost of employee health benefits. [B11.]
 
Markets
The stock market retreated from its record-setting summer rally, pulled down by concerns about the economy. [D1.] 
 Gold prices took a tumble, hammered by reports that European central banks were selling bullion. [D1.]
Municipal bond regulators recommended that sharp curbs be placed on political contributions from underwriters. Meanwhile, the 30-year Treasury bond continued to rally. [D16.]
The dollar slumped against the German mark amid speculation that Germany's interest rates would remain high. [D15.]
Oil prices fell to a three-year low after forecasts for demand were lowered and OPEC output continued to grow. [D15.]
 
Companies
The special-orders business is gaining popularity in the clothing industry. [D1.]
Dresser Industries will buy Baroid for about $1.1 billion in the energy service industry's largest acquisition. [D2.]
A Japanese mining company will write off $900 million to restructure Gould, its troubled U.S. electronics subsidiary. [D3.]
Chrysler is introducing a small, inexpensive car aimed at younger buyers. [D4.]
Olympia & York's American arm reappointed its president and named a head for its new board. [D4.]
Abbey Healthcare Group will acquire Total Pharmaceutical Care for $197 million in cash and stock. [D4.]
Apple Computer announced three new multimedia kits for personal computers, including the first for non-Apple PC's. [D4.]
Maxwell Communication agreed to sell its Collier encyclopedia business for about $43 million. [D19.]
Lockheed faces crucial questions about a subsidiary's activities in a report by New York City investigators. [B9.]
 
Business Technology
Cable TV businesses may outrun phone companies by linking wireless communications services to their lower-cost cable networks. [D1.] One such cable business is Comcast [D13.]

International
Japan will offer a new kind of loan guarantee to persuade reluctant Japanese financial institutions to make large new loans and investments overseas. [D1.]
Western Germany's economy is growing for the first time in more than a year, raising hopes that the country's deepest postwar recession has finally bottomed out. [D2.]

HEADLINE: With a Gala, Barneys Opens Madison Ave. Store

BYLINE: By AMY M. SPINDLER

 BODY:
Here's a tale the Pressman family, owners of Barneys New York, will be telling for a while.
In September 1993, in the midst of an economic recession, Barneys opened a new store in New York, amid the toughest competition in town. And they had to fight to keep people away. 
 Well, from the opening at least. Last night, the crush of invitation-wielding guests was more Shubert Alley than Madison Avenue. There was the sort of shoulder-rubbing that retailers these days can only fantasize about. And this Barneys, which takes up almost a block, is the largest new specialty store to go up in Manhattan since the Depression. Its creators, the Pressmans, are among America's last retailing dynasties, having opened the first Barneys in 1923 at 17th Street and Seventh Avenue.
Inside the new French limestone store last night were the guests that Barneys hopes will be customers today when it opens to the public on 61st Street and Madison: Bianca Jagger, Joan Rivers, Barbara Walters, Lorraine Bracco, Bobby Short, Peter Gabriel and Barry Diller. And there was Mayor David N. Dinkins, who said, "It's a vote of confidence for our city by very smart business people."
The opening culminated a three-month publicity blitz. Those who made it past the velvet ropes found inside the customary sea of cosmetic and accessory counters. But as martini-wielding waiters threaded by, exotic fish floated in tanks amid the merchandise and camera flashes bounced off familiar faces, the glossy pages of this month's magazines touting Barneys came to life on cue.
"It's like a movie set of what retailing is, like what Mel Gibson would want if he went shopping," said a somewhat dazed Christian Francis Roth, a young New York designer.
They shopped as they socialized. Barneys didn't turn away a sale, even on opening night. Isabel Toledo, a New York designer, sold a sweater at 7:30. "My heart was pounding," said her husband, Ruben, an illustrator, who witnessed what may have been the evening's first transaction.
Designers gathered here from every fashion capital to admire their merchandise on display, with the hope that they were seeing the future of retailing.
Calvin Klein, who had not yet seen his selling space, said: "We have to keep moving ahead. When business is tough, it helps to separate the men from the boys. The competition is good for everyone."
That has been the drama surrounding the opening of the uptown Barneys. Chanel, for instance, decided earlier in the year not to compete with its own 59th Street boutique by supplying Barneys uptown. After more than an hour of browsing, the guests were squired through a passage to the Pierre hotel ballroom, where martinis gave way to all the other trappings of a 1940's supper club, including cigarette girls and a tuxedoed band. There was an old-fashioned bandstand, on which Barry White and Taylor Dayne sang a duet of Mr. White's hit, "Can't Get Enough of Your Love, Baby," which Ms. Dayne recently re-recorded. .
The downtown contingent seemed happy to have made the trek. "Fortunately cabs go uptown," said Holly Soloman, the doyenne of the Soho art dealers.
Gene Pressman, store co-president, was happily escorting visitors, a job he plans to continue well into the year. "I can't wait to get on the selling floor," he said. "That's where the fun begins."

GRAPHIC: Photo: From left, Kelly Klein, Ian Schraeger and Calvin Klein last night at the new Barneys store on Madison Avenue and East 61st Street. When asked about the risk of a new upscale retail venture during a recession, Mr. Klein said, "When business is tough, it helps to separate the men from the boys." (Stephanie Berger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Stocks Hit By a Surge In Selling

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
Retreating from its record-setting summer rally, the stock market fell farther and faster than it had in more than a month yesterday, pulled down by concerns about the economy and a feeling by some analysts that the market is overheated and overpriced.
The Dow Jones industrial average sank 26.83 points to close at 3,607.10, after bouncing off the 3,600 level in late afternoon trading. The Dow's retreat was its largest since July 30, when it fell 27.95 points. Broader market indicators also fell yesterday. 
 Among the biggest losers were gold mining stocks, which were pulled down by a steep selloff in gold.
 
Analysts Discount the Slide
 Still, analysts were not extremely concerned about the drop, suggesting that its effects were likely to be temporary.
"Basically, you had a market that's had a pretty good run recently, that had moved pretty high above its short-term moving average," Philip H. Smyth, an analyst at Birinyi Associates, said. "We would call that somewhat extended, and say it was due to settle back a little bit."
Dennis E. Jarrett, chief market analyst at Kidder, Peabody, attributed some of yesterday's selling to concerns about the strength of the economy. On Friday, the Government's weak employment report raised fresh doubts. Still, he predicted that these concerns would evaporate within the next several weeks, leaving the market strong.
"There are just too many favorable things occurring -- interest rates, precious metals heading down, and so on," Mr. Jarrett said. "The economy may be perceived to be a trifle weak, but it's no worse than it's been over the last six months."
Besides, Mr. Jarrett noted, in the last 21 years, the market fell on the first session following Labor Day two-thirds of the time.
 
Other Indicators Decline
 Among market indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 2.82 points, to 458.52. There were steeper losses among secondary stocks, with the American Stock Exchange composite index falling 5.29 points, to 456.28, and the Nasdaq composite index sliding 10.36 points, to 739.35. Trading volume rose to 229.5 million shares, from 197.2 million on Friday.
Mr. Smyth said that Birinyi had tracked one major program trade, defined as 15 or more issues and a million dollars or more of stock. The program began at 3:18 P.M. and ended at 3:37 P.M., he said, knocking the Dow down 8.94 points, to the day's low, before it rebounded a few points to its close.
"Other than that, it's mostly consistent selling going on -- nothing in the way of standout programs," he said.
The top five percentage losers on the New York Stock Exchange were all gold stocks. Among them, preferred shares of Sunshine Mining lost 1 1/8, to 6 1/8 a share; Hecla Mining, fell 1 3/4, to 10 5/8, and Glamis Gold, was down 3/4, to 5 1/2.
Gold losers on the Amex included Granges Inc., off 3/8 to close at 21/16 a share; Republic Goldfields, down 1/2, to 2 5/8; Pegasus Gold, falling 2 7/8, to 18 1/4, and Echo Bay Mines, off 1 3/8, to 9 3/8.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for October delivery fell $14.50 an ounce, settling at $350.80, its lowest price since spring. Gold is often viewed as a hedge against inflation. But with few signs of inflation, demand has evaporated.
Interest-rate developments did not give the stock market the support they have supplied in the past. Long-term interest rates fell sharply in the bond market. After breaking through 6 percent on Friday, the yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.90 percent yesterday, from 5.94 percent Friday. But short-term rates rose slightly.
Among other decliners were some technology stocks, including Cisco Systems, a manufacturer of computer networking equipment, which closed down 4 at 43 3/8 a share in Nasdaq trading. Cisco was recently downgraded by analysts over concerns about its market share.
Microsoft fell 1, to 74 3/4. Microsoft announced a publishing venture today, a day after reports were first published saying that an inquiry into Microsoft's business practices had been extended into Europe.
Oil prices dropped today after the International Energy Agency made new, lower predictions of worldwide demand, even as OPEC announced that production of oil rose in August. Among the oil stocks, Pennzoil lost 2, to 66 3/4 a share.
The lower oil prices bolstered some airline issues. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, gained 1 1/4, to 144 1/4.

HEADLINE: Greenspan's View on Rates

BYLINE: Reuter

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, said in written remarks released today that short-term interest rates, adjusted for inflation, were "lower than necessary" to help the economy over the long run and would eventually have to rise.
But Mr. Greenspan was quick to caution, in answers to written questions from the Senate Banking Committee, that changes in such so-called real interest rates do not necessarily mean that nominal interest rates must rise. 
 "Current real short-term interest rates of about zero are below the levels toward which they ultimately will need to move to be consistent with achievement of the nation's economic objectives over time," he said.
The nominal interest rate on 90-day Treasury bills was below 3 percent today. The real interest rate is the nominal rate less the rate of inflation. If inflation is about 3 percent a year, the real rate is zero.
"A change in real interest rates does not necessarily imply a commensurate movement in nominal interest rates," he said. "Real interest rates can rise either because nominal rates increase or inflation expectations decrease."
Mr. Greenspan's remarks on short-term interest rates were similar to those he made when he appeared before the Senate Banking Committee on July 22.
In response to other questions from the committee, Mr. Greenspan wrote that economic activity in Europe and Japan was likely to recover only moderately, if at all.
He stated that continuing problems might include depressed consumer confidence, lackluster business spending because of weak profits or slow credit growth and, in some countries, falling property values.
In addition, Mr. Greenspan wrote that he opposed making it tougher for foreign financial institutions to do business in the United States, even though such sanctions might pressure other countries to open their markets more to American financial institutions.

HEADLINE: Gold's Downhill Ride Shifts to Higher Gear

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Gold prices, which have been sliding steadily for about a month, took a tumble yesterday, helping push down long-term interest rates and lower the dollar against other major currencies.
The drop of nearly 15 percent in gold prices from as high as $411 an ounce on Aug. 2 to as low as $350 an ounce yesterday has analysts wondering if the run-up of the spring and summer was an aberration. 
 Yesterday, gold for October delivery ended trading in New York down $14.50 an ounce, to $350.80, from Friday's price on the Commodity Exchange. (There was no New York trading on Monday because of Labor Day.) The trading was fueled by unconfirmed reports that European central banks, including the Bank of France, were selling gold bullion.
The more actively traded December contract dropped $14.60, to $352.50 an ounce. In London, gold was selling at $354.80 an ounce at the afternoon fixing, down $9.45 from Monday.
After falling to nearly $325 an ounce in early March, a level not seen since the mid-1980's, gold prices staged an impressive and almost relentless advance to the $411 price, a 26 percent climb and a level not seen since September 1990, soon after Iraq invaded Kuwait.
In some respects, the rally helped restore gold's image as a financial instrument and as a harbinger of inflation, a reputation badly tarnished the last three years as prices had registered steady declines.
But memories of the rally are dwindling fast, and analysts say they expect to see prices soften further.
"It took us five months to get from $325 an ounce to $411 an ounce, and markets tend to go down faster than they go up," said James R. Steel, a senior commodities analyst at Refco Inc., a Chicago commodities trading firm.
"I don't suspect we will get back to the lows of the year, but there is a good chance gold could fall to $335 an ounce."
A number of factors have contributed to gold's recent decline, Mr. Steel and other analysts said.
Currency traders, who were buying gold as the crisis over the European Exchange Rate Mechanism mounted in July, began selling in early August after a solution was found.
As gold prices rose the last few months, demand from important Asian markets like China began to dry up.
Perhaps most important, gold commodity funds, which were heavy buyers, began taking profits.
"Quite plainly, the commodity funds were the reason gold went up in the first place," said Warren G. Myers, a vice president and precious metals analyst at Merrill Lynch.
"They pushed it up, and now they are getting out and taking their profits." As prices slipped, commodities traders who chart prices in great detail, automatically sold out their gold stakes either to preserve their profits or halt losses.
 
Inflation Concerns Dwindle
 In addition, economists noted, much of the worry about inflation that accompanied and perhaps stimulated the rise in gold prices in recent months all but evaporated.
"Gold is making a real strong statement on disinflation," said Edward S. Hyman, president of International Strategy and Investment, a New York money management firm.
"Around the world, the policy picture remains conservative, with the German Bundesbank talking about gradualism, the Bank of Japan saying they won't cut the discount rate and the American Congress raising taxes."
In light of those conditions, Mr. Hyman said he expected the inflation rate to be about 2 percent this year. That sort of forecast, if borne out, is hardly conducive to a resurgence in gold prices.
Still, gold analysts and traders remained hopeful.
"From early 1988 until March of this year, we had a bear market in gold," Mr. Myers said. "I tend to view the recent correction as a healthy consolidation in what may be a healthy bull market. But that is more of a gut feel than anything else."
 
Still Above Costs
 Despite the recent decline, gold remains above the level of $290 to $325 an ounce that analysts say represents marginal production costs for many producers.
But Mr. Myers said that for some producers, gold should be left in the ground if prices stayed near $350 an ounce.
One gold trader, who asked not to be identified, said: "Market sentiment is that we are still in a downturn, and that there should still be further liquidation. I wouldn't be surprised to see it trade down to $345 an ounce."
