HEADLINE: Japan Offers to Back Loans To Help Trim Trade Surplus

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Worried by anger over Japan's huge trade surpluses and eager to use its capital to earn some good will overseas, the Government has decided to offer a new kind of loan guarantee to persuade reluctant Japanese financial institutions to make large new loans and investments overseas.
Officials said the Government-owned Export-Import Bank of Japan planned to announce on Wednesday that it would guarantee a 12-year loan of 8 billion yen, the current equivalent of about $77 million, by Japanese life insurance companies to Greece's state-owned railway. 
 The guarantee means that should the railway be unable to repay the loan or meet interest payments, the Export-Import Bank will. The guarantee thus lowers the interest rate the lenders charge and encourages them to make the loan for a longer term than they would otherwise permit.
The amount of the loan, the first to have such a guarantee, is modest but it is significant for several reasons. It is part of a quiet campaign the Japanese Government is waging to convince other countries that by "recycling" its surpluses in the form of aid, investments and loans to needy parts of the world the surpluses are actually beneficial.
"The policy implications are important," said Yuichi Ezawa, a senior executive director at the Export-Import Bank. "We have been making great efforts to use our excess savings. This new project will enhance the international flow of private funds."
Japan's relations with Europe and the United States have been increasingly strained by the country's soaring trade surpluses. From $63.5 billion in 1990, the surplus hit $132.3 billion last year and it is expected to come to more than $150 billion this year. About a third of that is with the United States and another third with the European Community, of which Greece is a member.
The loan guarantee is aimed directly at easing some of those tensions. "This loan to a member of the E.C. will help improve the Japan-E.C. economic relations, which are clouded by the trade imbalance," the bank said in a statement.
This is also in line with the theory held by some economists here that Japan's surpluses give the country the wherewithal to supply funds to needy areas of the world, which they say is a net plus for the world economy.
"I don't think Japan's trade surplus is hurting other countries," Ryutaro Komiya, a respected economist and head of a research institute at the Ministry for International Trade and Industry, said recently. "It enables us to export capital."
Many other economists argue, however, that a sustained reduction in Japan's surpluses would do more to help bring some balance to the world economy and improve two-way flows of goods and capital in the global trading system.
In 1987 Japan announced with much fanfare a five-year, $65 billion program to "recycle" its surpluses through aid grants, loans and investments. The Export-Import Bank played a major role, providing more than $20 billion in loans to developing countries that were not tied to the purchase of Japanese goods or services.
But foreign governments and economists have argued that Japan did not need its huge surpluses to provide this financing. Perhaps more important, the Government's efforts have been undermined by the fact that Japanese banks and corporations have cut back sharply on their overseas investments.
Thus, a Government plan to make another high-profile announcement of a second five-year "recycling" program in July was quietly scrapped. Fearing a backlash abroad, the Government made little effort to win publicity for its announcement that it plans to provide $120 billion over the next five years, and it dropped the term recycling from the title, which is now "funds for development."
Whether the new loan guarantee program can encourage Japanese institutions to invest more abroad is an open question. A recession at home and the crash of the stock market here has forced the private sector -- which holds most of the surpluses -- to pull back from the international realm.
After sending more than $130 billion a year abroad in the form of long-term private investments in the late 1980's, the private sector made just $28.5 billion in such long-term investments last year.
The new loan guarantee is aimed directly at trying to enhance this outflow of capital, since the actual loan is being supplied by private institutions.
Export-Import Bank officials said that though few other loans of this type are being considered now, they hope more will be made and that their size will grow. They also said they would look to poorer areas of Europe as well as the United States for providing such financing, not just the developing world.

HEADLINE: 0.5% Growth For Western Germany

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BONN, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Western Germany's economy is growing for the first time in 15 months, the Government said today, raising hopes that the country's deepest postwar recession had bottomed out.
Germany has the world's third-largest industrial economy after the United States and Japan. Its return to economic health would mean a better market for American and other foreign goods and could help end the worldwide recession. 
 But Economics Minister Gunter Rexrodt said Germany's second-quarter growth of half a percent was not enough to signal the end of the recession.
 
'Slight Movement'
 "The first signs of light for overcoming the recession are unmistakable," Mr. Rexrodt said. "But it is premature to see a signal for an economic turnaround from this slight movement upward."
Germany's proposed 1994 budget contains $13 billion in spending cuts, which would allow the Government to contain the heavy borrowing it undertook to pay for rebuilding the former East Germany.
Finance Minister Theo Waigel said the spending cuts would allow Germany to hold its borrowing to about $41 billion. That would give the German central bank greater room to lower the country's interest rates, which are seen as a drag on the economies of other nations.
Germany has kept its interest rates up to protect the mark from inflationary pressures.
 
Quarter-to-Quarter Rise
 Second-quarter figures released by the Federal Statistics Office for western Germany showed gross domestic product fell 1.9 percent compared with the level for the comparable period last year.
But G.D.P. grew by half a percent compared with 1993's first quarter. It was a small rise but the first since the first quarter of 1992, when G.D.P. rose 1.5 percent compared with the last three months of 1991.
G.D.P. measures the total value of goods and services but excludes income that western Germany generates abroad. The data do not include G.D.P. for eastern Germany, which merged with western Germany nearly three years ago. Unemployment in the east is running at 15.4 percent, while in the west, 7.5 percent of the work force collects unemployment pay.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
HEINZ (H.J.) CO. (N)

 BODY:
Despite sluggish sales growth and volume declines in several brands, including Starkist tuna, H. J. Heinz Company's fiscal first-quarter operating earnings improved 5.8 percent.
Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, the company's chairman, president and chief executive, said he was pleased with the first-quarter results, "given the current economic environment in the United States and overseas." 
 Ted Smyth, vice president for corporate affairs at Heinz, said that a company policy not to use price promotions to reduce retailers' inventory discouraged the retailers from ordering new stock. Mr. Smyth said the decision was made to give Heinz more pricing freedom.
The food maker had operating earnings of $152.18 million, or 59 cents a share, in the quarter ending July 28, compared with operating earnings of $143.79 million, or 55 cents, in the same period a year earlier. Revenues increased 1.2 percent, to $1.58 billion from $1.56 billion. Earnings for both periods exclude accounting charges.
Heinz ended fiscal year 1993 on a regimen of cost-cutting, layoffs and internal changes intended to increase profits from its line of condiments, Ore-Ida frozen potatoes, Starkist tuna, Weight Watchers entrees and other brand-name products.

HEADLINE: Coup Weary, Venezuelans Await a Vote

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Plaster and white paint have touched up bullet holes in the Presidential Palace, and democracy seems to be back on track in Venezuela, for now.
Carlos Andres Perez, facing trial on a corruption charge, packed his bags and boxes and moved out of the presidential residence on Wednesday, ending his rocky four-and-a-half-year stay. On May 21 Congress had suspended his presidential powers, a move that it made permanent on Aug. 31. 
 An independent caretaker President, Ramon J. Velasquez, is minding the store until a new President is elected in December and inaugurated in February.
Although a month never passes here without a coup scare, a tight electoral calendar and a 50 percent military pay raise promised for January seem to have defused major threats from Venezuela's restive armed forces. After two violent coup attempts last year, 80 percent of Venezuelans polled say they oppose a third uprising.
 
A Major Source of Oil
 "There have not been any military conspiracies," President Velasquez, a 76-year-old former historian and journalist, said in an interview. "This city lives off rumors."
But just the way art restorers failed to camouflage a bullet hole in an oil painting in the President's waiting room, the rips and tears in Venezuela's social and economic fabric are easy to see.
Increasingly, Americans follow developments here with keen interest. After Saudi Arabia, Venezuela is the second largest source of imported oil for the United States. After Mexico, Venezuela is Latin America's second largest importer of goods from the United States.
Over the last six weeks, eight small bombs have exploded around this capital. Coupled with bomb scares provoked by anonymous telephone callers, the incidents seemed intended to keep the city on edge and to intimidate judges who are investigating high-level corruption.
In the nation's biggest clean-government drive in memory, Mr. Perez and his predecessor, Jaime Lusinchi, face trials on separate corruption charges. An anticorruption court is investigating Cecilia Matos, a longtime companion of Mr. Perez who now lives in New York.
In the armed forces, 12 general-level officers are either awaiting trial on criminal charges that range from drug trafficking to rebellion to stealing public money or are under investigation.
 
Economic Growth Slows
 Helping drive the anticorruption campaign is deep resentment over the humbled economic status of Latin America's largest oil exporter.
Inflation is running at 37 percent a year. Economic growth, after averaging 9 percent over the last two years, is slumping this year to 3 percent.
The inflation stems from a $3 billion budget deficit pried open by falling oil prices. Holding the world's largest oil reserves outside the Persian Gulf, Venezuela relies on state oil company exports for two-thirds of federal Government income.
In 1981, a golden age remembered as "Saudi Venezuela," oil sales added up to $19 billion. This year, they are expected to hit $11 billion.
To close the deficit, Congress delegated decree powers to President Velasquez last month to institute a sales tax and a company assets tax. But no politician here dares to plug one gaping fiscal hole: the pricing of gasoline at 22 cents a gallon.
Retreating from 20 years of stubborn nationalism in the energy field, Congress also approved $10.4 billion worth of joint ventures last month between foreign companies and the state oil company, Petoleos de Venezuela. One joint venture, a $5.6 billion liquefied natural gas project, ranks as the largest single energy project ever undertaken here.
 
State Sector Cut Further
 Faced with few choices, President Velasquez is continuing his predecessor's policies of cutting Venezuela's state sector. Over the next six months, the Government plans to privatize a dozen state companies, including Aeropostal, a major airline.
The delicate job of guiding this volatile nation through 1999 will fall to the winner of the Dec. 5 elections. With the field crowded by 17 candidates, Venezuela's next President will probably take office endorsed by no more than one-third of voters.
All polls currently forecast that the winner will be Rafael Caldera, a former President who is running as an independent candidate with the support of 16 small and largely left-wing parties.

HEADLINE: In the Inner City, a Hungry Scramble for a Few Choice Classroom Seats

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 7

 BODY:
There is a powerful hunger among parents in America's big cities for a quality public school. Last spring, Wayne State University announced it would be starting a new middle school, open to any Detroit child in sixth to eighth grade. More than 6,000 applications were submitted in two months -- for 330 spots.
At the selection lottery, Gov. John Engler noted that one child, Calvin Walker Jr., had applied 100 times. 
 "I didn't realize we did 100," said Calvin's mother, Diane, a nurse's aide. "I thought maybe 60 or 80. I lost track."
Karen Terry, a single parent, anointed her application with blessed oil from her church, Ever Increasing Faith Ministries. "I prayed every day," Ms. Terry said. "When I heard Gerard got in, I screamed, I yelled, I jumped, I praised God and thanked Jesus."
Frank Gillespie, chief of staff for a state legislator, tried speaking with a Wayne State dean about his daughter, Nicole. "I'm no fan of the Detroit schools, so I wanted this bad," he said. "I've always been able to get something done in this town by knowing somebody. This dean said, 'I wish you all the luck in the world but it's not going to work that way.' I was impressed. I couldn't grease them."
 
What Attracts Parents
 As social pressures on cities mount and the Federal financing share of urban education drops (from 12 percent in 1980 to 9 percent today), many parents say their search for a trustworthy city school is growing more frantic. These special public schools may be called magnet, choice or alternative schools, and while some require entrance exams or auditions, most do not. They are someplace special for a child who is not necessarily a star. A cherished spot comes from the luck of the draw or being first in line.
Because a seat at the Wayne State University Public School was so coveted, university officials hired Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, to run a computerized lottery so there would be no question of favoritism.
The lottery means that parents come from all social classes, including Judy Kelley, who is on welfare; Marvin Davis, an assembly-line worker at Ford, and Mr. Gillespie, a lawyer (even without "grease," his Nicole made it). The two things most parents share is race -- the school, like Detroit's population, is mostly black -- and an uncommonly strong motivation to have their children succeed.
All this excitement over the new school is remarkable, when one considers that the school that does not provide bus transportation, is surrounded by homeless shelters and crack dealers downtown, and will receive the same state financing per pupil as a regular Detroit public school. Furthermore, the school had not taught a single student until today, when classes started at 8 this morning.
The parents who mailed in all those applications believe that the new Wayne school will have a more motivated staff than most city schools (300 teachers applied for 14 jobs), that it will benefit from its association with the university, that it will be a magnet for philanthropy (before opening it had attracted $575,000 in corporate donations), that it will be smaller (city middle schools have 600 to 1,000 students) and have smaller classes (25 students versus 35 for city middle schools), and that it will demand more from their children.
 
Longer School Year
 In Los Angeles, 107 of 700 schools are now magnets. This year, 38,000 students in Los Angeles applied for 8,000 vacancies at those magnets. The most popular, Sherman Oaks Center, had 2,000 applicants for 340 slots. In the Miami-Dade County schools in Florida, 11,000 students applied for 4,500 magnet vacancies. In New York City last spring, after the high school selection was completed, officials announced 32 new specialty schools. In two weeks, 8,000 students applied for 4,000 slots -- at schools that were still essentially ideas on a piece of paper.
And while the Wayne school can be seen as a commentary on the sad shape of the city school system here, 53 of Detroit's 256 schools are now choice schools with their own long waiting lists. Last year, when it opened here, the Mae C. Jemison Academy, an "Afro-centric" public school, had 800 applications for 120 slots.
The Wayne school's day is longer than most public middle schools, from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M., and so is the school year, 200 days rather than 180. As Kathy Neumann registered her son Peter, she said, "It's good that they'll go to school in the summer."
"What?" said Peter, looking like Cobo Hall had just been dropped on his head.
Ms. Neumann said, "Peter hasn't heard all the details yet."
"What?" said Peter.
 
Interested Parents
 Ms. Terry, a program scheduler at radio station WQBH, says because she knows what a bureaucracy can do in an urban system of 170,000 students, she always takes a week off when school starts and another when it ends "to make sure there are no slip ups for Gerard."
At registration, Kathleen Walker, a cook for a vending company, signed up for the school's parent dress code committee. "I'm letting them know I'm one of those interested parents," she said." She was the 96th parent to join the dress code committee in a school of 330 students.
Ms. Walker's son, Demitirius Porter, an eighth grader, had attended Columbus Middle School where, she said, gangs hassled him. "Tell the reporter you're an honors student," his mother said, "and stop fidgeting."
"Oh yeah," Demitirius said, "I'm an honors student."
"Tell him what you did this summer."
"I worked at a car wash."
"Tell him your other little jobs."
"A little paper route."
"And your other little job."
"I cleaned up at a metal shop."
To get to school, Demitirius left his house at 6:30 this morning, taking two city buses. "I'm very proud of my son," Ms. Walker said. "Now don't get me wrong -- he's a typical boy."
 
More Hours for Less Pay
 Teachers clamor for a school like Wayne, where they can start fresh and work with children like Demitirius. New York City's new specialty schools typically had more than 200 teachers apply for eight positions at a school.
Most Wayne teachers are working more hours and earning the same or less than they would in a city school. Carolyn Glover, a speech teacher who just graduated from college, says she will make $5,000 less, John Harris, the principal, is making $52,000, $20,000 below his city salary.
If Claude Tiller Jr. had kept his job at a Detroit middle school, he would have had the summer off, reporting for work on Aug. 30. He said he started planning sessions at the new school in June. "It's worth it," he said. "This is a big thing to put on your resume."
The teachers' backgrounds at this new school are less conventional. Maura Lobos spent a decade in children's education at a science museum. This morning her room was decked out with a boa constrictor, three mice, an African clawed toad and dozens of stuffed animals. "We'll be getting South American cockroaches," she said, and all the students went "Oooo!"
 
$1.2 Million Startup Grant
 Wayne State had hoped to run several Detroit schools. Beginning in 1989, university officials spent two years negotiating with public school leaders. But Detroit officials and leaders of the teachers union were not receptive to the idea. They felt Wayne State would draw off the city's most motivated teachers and students, and siphon off grant money.
There would be no Wayne public school today if Governor Engler had not signed a bill last year permitting universities to bypass local districts and create their own public schools with state financing.
Wayne was awarded a $1.2 million startup grant from the state. The Detroit Superintendent of Schools, Deborah M. McGriff, complained that she does not get that kind of money to renovate her "choice" schools.
Ms. McGriff's concerns are legitimate, says Dr. Judith Stein, president of Magnet Schools of America, which represents 5,400 magnets. In Miami, where Dr. Stein works, magnets get $900 more per child than regular public schools. "Good education costs money," she said. "We've downgraded public education so far. It's not like magnets are that special; they should be standard.
"Magnets get tons of private contributions, too. We are a niche within this vast sea of public education. A lot of businesses do not want to give to the traditional big-city school. They see it as throwing money down a well."
The Wayne staff is aware of the resentment among city school officials, and everyone interviewed at the school recited the same mantra: nothing they said was meant to reflect badly on the city schools.
 
'Violence and Trouble'
 But that is not how parents see it. Diane Walker, who sent in the 100 applications, said, "There's so much violence and trouble in the schools, especially if you have a boy." She had also applied to one of the city "choice" middle schools, but Calvin was not selected.
Mrs. Walker started her large mailing with an application for the Wayne school printed in the Detroit newspapers. She called the school and requested more. "My friends at work kept bringing them in," she said. "They said this is perfect for you, Diane."
In June, she received a notice of an information meeting at North Rosedale Community Center near her home. "I was excited," Mrs. Walker said. "I thought it meant he'd get in. When I got there my heart sank. It was standing room only with lines out front. The principal made a speech inside and someone else spoke to the people outside. They talked about the arts, music, language. They didn't talk about sports, which was fine."
After the meeting, she said, she and her husband, a butcher, each grabbed another stack of applications.
When the lottery was held in July, she learned that officials had decided to allow one application per student; duplicates were eliminated.
Calvin was not picked. Today he was at Murphy Middle School. "Maybe it will be all right," Mrs. Walker said. "You know, all this time I've been afraid that because we filled out so many duplicates it actually hurt Calvin's chances somehow. I've been a little afraid it was my fault he didn't get in."

GRAPHIC: Photos: When Wayne State University announced it would open a new public middle school in Detroit, there were more than 6,000 applications for the 330 spots at the school. On opening day yesterday, Fred Borowski, the assistant principal, directed some of the students to their classrooms.; In an effort to improve the chances of their son, Calvin Jr., being chosen in a lottery to attend the new school, Diane Walker and her husband, Calvin, filled out 100 applications. Shortly before the drawing, it was ruled that only one application per student would be allowed. (Photographs by Peter Yates for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "A New School Year: More Students, More Spending"
 Students around the nation are returning to school in circumstances vastly different from those of a decade ago.
 PUBLIC SCHOOL ENROLLMENT is rising, especially in the lower grades and even more so in kindergarten. "There's a mini baby boom," said Chris Pipho of the Education Commission of the States, a private research organization in Denver. A leading reason, he added, is the influx of children of immigrants.
 At the same time, PRIVATE SCHOOL ENROLLMENT, which fell in the mid-80's in part because many Catholic schools closed, has been gaining rapidly in the 90's. And so has COLLEGE ENROLLMENT, especially in two-year colleges. "Because of the downturn in the economy," Mr. Pipho said, "many unemployed or underemployed people went back to school."
 SPENDING jumped in the 1980's, far outstripping the rise in the number of students and teachers. That was a time of growing state and Federal demands on schools and colleges alike - required curriculums and laws requiring that buildings be accessible to the handicapped and free of asbestos.
 But with the recession, schools have come under great pressure to curb their costs, and the spending increase has slowed.
 
(Source: National Center for Education Statistics, U.S. Department of Education)

HEADLINE: Washington Takes Leaf From Business Manuals

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
In its drive to streamline the Federal Government, the Clinton Administration is following the path that Corporate America has been on for years. It is called "downsizing" or "re-engineering," in business jargon, while the code phrase among policy makers is "reinventing government." Whatever the terminology, it means drastically changing the way work is done -- and it also means significant job cuts.
In the private sector, the results have been decidedly mixed. Companies like General Electric and Xerox have become leaner, more competitive forces in the global economy, while the jury is still out on struggling giants like I.B.M. and General Motors. 
 The companies that have succeeded, management experts say, have strong leaders who are willing to keep pushing for change for years and who can convince the rank and file that a new order is both necessary and possible.
 
A Best-Selling Topic
 "Coming up with ideas is the easy part, but getting things done is the tough part," said Michael Hammer, a management consultant who is the co-author with James Champy of a current best seller, "Re-engineering the Corporation."
"The place where these reforms are going to die is not at the Cabinet level, but down in the trenches," said Mr. Hammer, who sat on one of Vice President Al Gore's panels on overhauling the Government.
The Federal bureaucracy, to be sure, has been the object of management theories and reform commissions since 1905, with little apparent effect. But this time, some analysts are encouraged by the high-level commitment from President Clinton and Vice President Gore, and a genuine sense within the Government that real change is both necessary and possible if Washington is to continue providing services when budgets are crimped.
In the past, they say, attempts to make the Government more efficient have foundered because most politicians regarded such efforts as the boring side of politics, while marketing new policy ideas is where the headlines and the votes are. In truth, the management side of government still is less exciting than policy making, but the opportunity for saving money and raising revenues to protect pet programs is simply too large to ignore any longer.
Most Government agencies can trim 15 to 30 percent of their budgets, David Osborne and Ted Gaebler estimated in "Reinventing Government," a best seller last year and a book that President Clinton has called a blueprint for overhauling the Government.
 
Less Emphasis on Policy
 "That's a very lucrative target to go after," said Mr. Gaebler, who runs a government consulting firm in San Rafael, Calif. "And that is why we're seeing real interest from leaders at every level of government in how governments do things rather than what the policies are."
Yet the proposals produced by the Vice President could mean a wrenching adjustment for the Federal bureaucracy and possibly for the economy as well. The Government is the country's largest employer, with about 4.4 million workers, and the 250,000 Federal jobs that Mr. Gore intends to eliminate equals the payroll of 10 average Fortune 500 companies.
Management experts question whether Government leaders, so much more susceptible to interest group pressures than corporate executives are, will continue to push for difficult changes in the months ahead. Examples from the private sector show how lengthy and difficult even the successful transitions can be, taking years and often proving quite unpopular early on.
 
A Corporate Example
 The General Electric Company, under John F. Welch Jr., its chairman, is often cited as a success story. Since 1981, G.E.'s work force has dropped to 230,000 from 418,000, while revenues have more than doubled, to $60 billion, and profits have increased more than fourfold, to $4.6 billion.
"You can be successful at transforming large enterprises, but at the same time you've got a lot of painful dislocations of people," said Noel Tichy, a professor of business at the University of Michigan, who headed G.E.'s management development program in the mid-1980's. "And you don't win any popularity contests in the early going."
A crucial factor in the Clinton Administration's effort, Professor Tichy added, will be whether senior civil servant managers can be removed for poor performance. "You've got to make sure the right incentives for government to save and earn, not just spend, are injected into the bureaucracy," he said. "And to accomplish that, you've got to have the freedom to move senior people around or out."
The basics of the current management theories, like re-engineering, tend to sound like little more than common sense. One popular edict is to "focus on the customer," which is presumably what all businesses are set up to do. Also high on the list of current management virtues is to "empower" workers, which means giving employees responsibility and rewarding them for taking the initiative in improving products or practices. Again, it seems like a firm grasp of the obvious rather than a startling insight.
 
Making Do With Less
 Re-engineering an organization amounts to abandoning old ways and doing things smarter. Although it tends to be referred to as "core process redesign," it typically means removing layers of middle management, eliminating reporting requirements and holding fewer meetings. When successful, the result is using fewer people to process insurance claims or cutting in half the time required to bring out a new generation of personal computer.
"Even re-engineering, let's face it, is not rocket science," said Michael Watkins, an assistant professor at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. "This stuff isn't deep; it's hard to implement."
Still Professor Watkins, a specialist in organizational change within business and government, points to examples of Federal agencies, like the Internal Revenue Service and the Bureau of Engraving and Printing in the Treasury Department, where managers are increasing efficiency through re-engineering programs.
"It is quite possible to make significant improvements," he said. "And the best public-sector managers have learned to succeed despite the more restrictive framework of government."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New Curbs Urged for Municipals

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The chief regulators of the municipal bond industry recommended yesterday that sharp restrictions be placed on political contributions from underwriters and others to help clear the clouds now over the industry.
They also urged more mandatory disclosure of financial information on bonds trading in the secondary market. 
 The recommendations came in reports from the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board and the National Association of Securities Dealers to the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance.
 
 
A Basis for Action
 The recommendations, which will be discussed at a committee hearing tomorrow, may become the basis for legislative or regulatory action in response to recent scandals that have raised questions about the influence of money in the municipal market.
Investigations are under way in New Jersey, where the Governor's chief of staff resigned after questions were raised about dealings involving a New Jersey Turnpike bond issue. The dealers of Massachusetts Water Resources Authority have also come under fire over secret agreements between financial advisers and underwriters that allowed for fee splitting.
The S.E.C.'s report concludes that "although the municipal market generally functions in an effective manner, there are significant areas where improvements can be made."
In a statement, Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, chairman of the subcommittee, said: "In recent months, considerable attention has been focused on questionable practices relating to the underwriting and sale of municipal securities. With these reports, the regulators have now weighed in with a comprehensive package of suggested regulatory and legislative solutions."
 
 
Reporting Contributions
 The Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board has proposed a rule that will require bond dealers to report their political contributions made two years before and two years after they are involved in a municipal bond sale. The proposal is endorsed by the S.E.C. and the N.A.S.D.
The S.E.C. is also continuing its review of political contributions by underwriters "to determine the nature and extent of improper campaign contributions and influence-peddling practices in connection with municipal offerings."
The Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board's proposal includes a ban on contributions to state and local officials from underwriters and others involved in the municipal bond market. But such a ban will be difficult to enforce, analysts say.
 
 
Mandating Disclosure
 The S.E.C has proposed new legislative authority to allow it to mandate disclosure of new financial information about issuers after bonds have been sold and are trading in the secondary market. This would require repeal of the so-called Tower amendment, which protects the authority of local governments on what they choose to disclose to investors.
If new legislation is not possible, the S.E.C. proposes using existing regulations that can prohibit dealers from recommending municipal bonds unless the issuer continues to provide important financial data.
The Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board and the N.A.S.D. endorsed a voluntary approach to financial disclosure. The S.E.C. report, however, says this approach has not worked. The commission must approve regulations proposed by the rule-making board.
The S.E.C. report also proposes changes to make the data on the trades of actively traded municipal bonds available to the public.
 
Treasury Market
 The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell yesterday as prices continued to rally on the belief that inflation would remain low and economic growth would stay slow. A sharp decline in gold prices and other commodities helped the low inflation environment.
But the price of the bond, which was up more than a point, tailed off late in the day, apparently after comments by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. His comments also turned earlier gains at the short end of the market into losses on the day.
In a written response to questions from the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan indicated that short-term interest rates would have to begin rising some time. While this remark was similar to what he said in July, when he testified before Congress, it seemed to be enough to worry investors after a blistering rally that carried the price of the long bond up three points in just three days.
"I don't know why they are paying attention to that now but for the dizzying heights the bond is at," said Alan Levenson, money market economist at UBS Securities.
The price of the 30-year 6.25 percent bond ended up 17/32 at 104 28/32 as the yield fell to 5.90 percent, down from 5.94 percent on Friday and 6.04 percent on Thursday. Before the remarks by Mr. Greenspan were made public by the Senate Banking Committee, the yield had dropped as low 5.86 percent.
The price of the two-year note, which was up 1/32 with the yield down to 3.68 percent, ended down 2/32 with the yield at 3.73 percent, up from 3.69 percent Friday.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
At the age of 1, New York 1 News keeps trying new sales ideas.

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
SOMETIMES in advertising, success can be measured in cockroaches.
Seeking to overcome the Clorox Company's reluctance to buy commercial time for its Combat line of insecticides, the advertising sales executives at New York 1 News, the 24-hour local news cable television channel, produced a sales package tailored to the giant marketer's particular needs. 
 Not only do Combat's spots run before and after New York 1's environmental news reports, but coupons and brochures for the brand are included in a free "welcome kit" delivered to homes that order service installations from the parent Time Warner Cable.
"We did an analysis on cost per roach instead of cost per thousand," said Allen N. Blum, a sales director at New York 1 News, using the term for the benchmark measurement for media buys.
"We just don't sell spots and dots," he added. "The people we're successful with understand we think out of the box."
And so it goes for New York 1 News, which turns 1 today. Though the fledgling channel has been making progress on the advertising front, its growth efforts have been retarded by the sour local economy and the intensely combative New York television market, where broadcasters and cable operators joust in a battle far fiercer than any household's war on pesky insects.
For instance, New York 1 News's rates for 30-second spot commercials have ranged from $100 to $200. A year ago, the channel had planned to charge $200 to $750.
And there is the occasional setback like the decision last week by Howard Koeppel to withdraw about $50,000 worth of commercials for his Infiniti, Mitsubishi and Nissan auto dealerships in Queens. Mr. Koeppel, a supporter of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for New York City mayor, complained that the channel's coverage was biased in favor of Mayor David N. Dinkins.
"In light of our economic situation and the competitiveness, we're proud of what we've accomplished," Rodney B. Lowenstein, a sales director, said last week during an interview at New York 1's office in midtown Manhattan.
In the channel's first 12 months, said Larry J. Fischer, president of Time Warner City Cable Advertising, which handled sales for New York 1 News, advertising revenues exceeded $4.5 million, adding that they should reach $6 million for calendar year 1993.
"We're bullish," he said, adding, "We think we can outdo that" in 1994.
Those figures pale against the costs of starting New York 1 News, estimated at $10 million, and its annual operating costs, also estimated at $10 million. But such shortfalls are typical of ambitious media start-ups.
Still, Mr. Fischer said, "we need to generate more spot advertising," to complement the channel's results with selling sponsorships of specific programs.
"The proof of the pudding is right about now, at renewal time," he added. "We're getting tremendous response and are confident just about every sponsor will renew." They include Anheuser-Busch Inc., which signed a 65-week contract to sponsor the channel's nightly sports report, called "Budweiser Sports on 1," and New York Telephone, which signed a 52-week contract to sponsor segments like community calendar listings.
Such programming-driven advertising opportunities are emblematic of New York 1 News's marketing strategy. For example, Paul Sagan, vice president of news and programming, disclosed that the channel had agreed to televise the New York City Marathon on Nov. 14 beyond 2:30 P.M., Eastern time, when ABC Sports and WABC-TV are scheduled to end their coverage.
"That's the real New York marathon -- the other 20,000 people who finish anonymously," he asserted.
Mr. Fischer noted that his sales force is "hoping that New York Marathon sponsors will ante up additionally for our coverage." He is also planning to create short segments using archival footage of past races, call them "New York Marathon Moments" and seek sponsors for them, too.
And Mr. Lowenstein said the American Express Company, "which does not buy local cable in this marketplace," had agreed to a "six-figure deal" to sponsor entertainment segments for the next 52 weeks. The agreement came through its agency, Ogilvy & Mather New York.
When New York 1 News signed on last Sept. 8, it was available in about 850,000 homes with cable, all served by Time Warner systems. Now it is available in close to 1.2 million homes as a result of its first conquest -- an agreement to be carried by a cable system not owned by Time Warner. That came last week, when Cablevision signed to add its systems covering the Bronx and part of Brooklyn.
Landing the Bronx finally put the "New York" in New York 1 News, giving it coverage of all five boroughs, which Mr. Sagan called "important from an editorial and a marketing position."
"We're not sure what critical mass is," he added, "but a million is a nice number."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slides Against Mark And Also Drops Versus Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar slumped to a 13-week low against the German mark yesterday amid growing speculation that Germany's interest rates will remain high while poor economic growth keeps American rates depressed.
The dollar also fell against other currencies, including the Japanese yen, as trading resumed in the United States after the Labor Day holiday. 
 In New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.6047 marks, its lowest level since June 4, before recovering to close at 1.6135 marks, down from 1.6222 marks on Friday. It also dropped to 104.23 Japanese yen, from 104.55 yen on Friday.
"Marks are still in demand," said Paul Farrell, chief dealer at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "The dollar will test 1.60 marks this week, easily."
The dollar has fallen more than 8 percent against the mark since July 30, and its slide has accelerated since the Labor Department reported on Friday that the economy lost 39,000 nonfarm jobs in August. The report convinced many investors that the American economic recovery has lost momentum.
 
Forces Against Dollar
 Without stronger growth, interest rates in the United States are likely to remain low, making investments denominated in dollars less attractive.
"The U.S. economy looks weak and German central bankers are being stingy with the rate cuts," said David Gilmore, senior foreign exchange analyst at MCM Currency Watch. Those forces are conspiring to drive the dollar lower, he said.
With the slumping German economy showing signs of life, fewer analysts and traders expect Germany's central bank to lower interest rates when its leaders hold their regular policy meeting tomorrow, Mr. Gilmore said.
The Bundesbank left a key money-market rate unchanged yesterday, an indication that it will leave the discount rate steady at 6.75 percent, traders said.
A bigger-than-expected increase in western German gross domestic product reinforced the notion that the German economy is on the rebound, making the case for rate cuts less pressing, traders said. Western German gross domestic product rose five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter.
The dollar did stage a rally late in the day after the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, said short-term interest rates must rise eventually.

HEADLINE: Abbey Offers Total Care $197 Million

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Abbey Healthcare Group said yesterday that it would buy Total Pharmaceutical Care for $197 million in cash and stock.
Analysts said the deal was a logical match for two companies that have carved out complementary niches in a business that provides nursing care, equipment, drugs, therapy and intravenous nutrition to patients at home, where such services are usually less costly than in a hospital. 
 The announcement of the agreement sent Total's stock soaring to $21.25, up $8, in Nasdaq trading of about 1.6 million shares. Abbey's stock dropped 75 cents, to $22.125, on Nasdaq trading of about 203,000 shares.
 
Outstanding Stock Is Sought
 Abbey Healthcare, which earned $7 million on revenue of $147.4 million in the first half of the year, said it would buy Total's outstanding stock for $19 a share in cash and $4 a share in Abbey common stock.
Total, based in Torrance, Calif., is to become a wholly owned subsidiary of Abbey, based in Costa Mesa, Calif. Total had first-half earnings of $4.2 million on revenue of $43.6 million.
The two companies both have offices in the Northeast and the West, but their services overlap only slightly. Abbey specializes in medical equipment for rehabilitation and respiratory therapy, while Total focuses on patients who need drugs and nutrients delivered intravenously.
William Hicks, a vice president at Cowen & Company in Boston, said he considered the purchase price "high relative to the other players in the industry."
"What they appear to be banking on are the synergistic benefits from the merger: economies of scale and leveraging existing customer or referral relationships," he said.
Joel M. Ray, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody in New York, said more and more home health care companies were considering joining forces to benefit from what they predict will be sweeping changes in the nation's health care system.
Under a plan expected to be proposed in the coming months by President Clinton, buyers of health care would form alliances so they could demand lower prices. In such an environment, Mr. Ray said, larger home health care providers would flourish.
"The purchasers are going to want to deal with larger entities versus smaller entities," he said. "So you are going to see more amalgamations of provider networks."
Abbey has been in the acquisition market for some time. Last spring, it tried to buy the Lifetime Corporation, a Boston-based provider of home health care personnel, but Lifetime rejected the offer and was later purchased by Olsten, an office temporary and nursing services company.
 
Public Offering Planned
 Abbey said it would pay for Total by selling senior subordinated debt through a public offering.
The company said Timothy M. Aitken, president, chairman and chief executive officer of Abbey, would become executive chairman of Abbey's board of directors and continue as president of the Abbey Home Healthcare subsidiary.
Victor M. G. Chaltiel, chairman, chief executive officer and president of Total, is to become a director, president and chief executive officer of Abbey and continue as president of the Total subsidiary.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Head Start on Data Superhighway

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
As the boundaries blur among the telephone business, cable television and wireless communications, no company may be better prepared to navigate the new landscape than the Comcast Corporation, the nation's third-largest cable provider and fifth-largest independent cellular phone company.
For years, the smart money bet that only the conventional local telephone companies would have the money and expertise to build the information superhighway that would bring phone calls, data communications and video-on-demand to American households. But now cable television companies plan to deliver the same services at lower cost. And soon, the cable companies may outrun the phone companies by linking wireless communications services to their lower-cost cable networks. 
 "The future of cable television is brighter than ever, and so is ours," said Ralph J. Roberts, Comcast's dapper 73-year-old chairman, who runs the company with his son, Brian, 34, Comcast's president.
Alone among the major cable operators, Comcast has its hands in almost every sector of telecommunications. The exceptions are paging and long-distance, and even long-distance may eventually change if something comes out of Comcast's continuing talks with A.T.& T. and the MCI Communications Corporation over multimedia technology.
These are exciting days indeed for Comcast, the Philadelphia-based company that the Robertses have built from an $83 million concern a decade ago into one with revenue of $900.3 million last year.
Two weeks ago, the CBS television network capitulated to Comcast and other cable operators. Under a new Federal law, CBS had wanted cable companies to pay it fat cash fees for the right to carry network programs like the top-rated "60 Minutes."
But in an example of the cable industry's newfound power, CBS agreed to be compensated not in cash, but with a new CBS cable channel. Such a channel, devoted to public policy, could win new subscribers for Comcast but mire CBS in development costs.
Earlier in the summer, A.T.& T. had agreed to buy McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. for $12.6 billion, one of the largest deals ever and one that enhanced the value of most cellular operations, including those of Comcast. Comcast's stock has been trading in the low 30's recently, well above its 52-week low of $13.50. Yesterday in Nasdaq trading, the shares were down 12.5 cents, closing at $30.375.
 
Big Day Approaching

 
 Comcast, like dozens of other big communications companies, is eagerly awaiting Sept. 23. That is the day the Federal Communications Commission is to announce ground rules for personal communications services, or P.C.S., a nascent industry that aims to provide cheaper and smaller wireless devices for the mass market. These devices could include pagers with built-in answering machines, wireless fax machines and even tinier pocket telephones than the shirtpocket versions available today.
The F.C.C. permitting, cable operators like Tele-Communications Inc., Time Warner and Comcast plan to bid next year for the newly available radio frequencies that will make these devices possible.
In P.C.S., as with other emerging technologies, cable operators believe they have an edge over the local phone companies. The reason: traditional copper telephone lines do not have the capacity to carry much more than voice conversations. And even though phone companies like GTE and Pacific Telesis have laid thousands of miles of ultrahigh-capacity fiber optic lines connecting cities, they have laid next to none that lead directly to neighborhoods and individual homes.
To extend fiber optic lines to neighborhoods would require a huge rewiring effort by the phone companies involving up to 200 million miles of local lines nationwide, or the equivalent of four times the distance between Earth and Mars. And the price would be an astronomical $276 billion, according to a variety of analysts.
 
Widely Available

 
 By contrast, the cable industry already has a high-capacity network available to nearly as many homes as the phone network is. (About 64 percent of the nation's households subscribe to cable television, but the actual cables "pass" 96 percent of households -- nearly as many as have a telephone.)
Moreover, this cable network totals only a million miles, and only 15 percent of the cable system -- the long-haul part between neighborhoods and between towns -- might need to be replaced with high-capacity fiber optic lines. The cost: $26 billion, according to cable industry estimates.
Why so little rewiring? Because unlike copper phone lines, most of the television cable already has adequate carrying capacity and would not need to be replaced. The coaxial cables serving most homes have 250,000 times the information capacity of copper telephone lines. Faced with only a fraction of the rewiring costs of the phone companies, cable operators like Comcast would have the edge in pricing services cheaply. With that advantage, cable operators might offer wireless service cheaply.
Using radio transmitters inside a house or office building, where cellular calls are difficult to make today, and transmitters outside buildings attached to the telephone poles that hold up cable lines, they might be able to provide seamless service between the living room, the backyard, the street and the office. Comcast and others have experimental P.C.S. licenses from Federal regulators to test the idea.
 
'Why Reinvent the Wheel?'

 
 "The cable industry can take advantage in both the wired and wireless worlds of the billions of dollars already invested," said the younger Mr. Roberts, Comcast's president. "Why reinvent the wheel?"
The cost advantage that cable companies may have in building the information superhighway is getting increasing attention from analysts. Indeed, some view U S West's agreement in May to invest $2.5 billion in a Time Warner venture as a tacit admission of the argument for cable.
By agreeing to develop Time Warner's advanced technology for consumer video services, U S West, a phone company, was conceding that it was more economical to revamp cable television than the phone system, these analysts say.
But others contend that the cable industry does not have the borrowing capacity to finance its goals, which they concede are technically feasible. Still others simply think the industry argument is wrong.
"Coaxial cable is a 30- or 40-year-old technology and has a high mean time between failure; in other words, it breaks down a lot," said Kenneth G. McGee, an analyst at the Gartner Group in Stamford, Conn. "And who knows how to lay down fiber optic cable better than the phone companies?"
 
Possible Alliances

 
 But in Comcast's view, telephone comanies need not necessarily be its antagonists. Comcast has been talking with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and, separately, with A.T.& T.'s long-distance rival MCI about forming a venture in multimedia, the hazily defined convergence of telephones, computers and television into applications like video-conferencing.
Comcast has nothing to announce about its talks with the two companies, Mr. Roberts said in an interview, but he added that a link with a long-distance carrier could benefit all parties.
One problem with A.T.& T.'s new videophone system, for example, is that even though it costs $2,000 for a pair of phones, its quality leaves something to be desired: the picture is blurry and one-third slower than regular television because the signals must be squeezed through low-capacity telephone lines. The cable television network, by contrast, would have no problem carrying a television-quality video phone call.
"Would people pay 25 cents a minute to, once in a while, have a video-conference call with a friend in another city?" Mr. Roberts asked. "The picture would be full motion and absolutely as good as a regular TV set because it is a regular set. I think people would pay for that."
Comcast has a good track record lately in guessing what people will pay for. Analysts expect the company to exceed $1.3 billion in revenue this year, up from the $900 million of last year. Cash flow, the crucial indicator of health for cable companies, is expected to rise nearly 60 percent, to $625 million from the level a year earlier. (Much like other highly indebted cable companies, Comcast has been reporting losses since 1987.)
 
Entry to Mobile Radio

 
 Comcast has a large stake in Nextel, formerly Fleet Call, a specialized
mobile-radio company that later this year will provide cellular-like competition to cellular carriers in some major cities. In many ways, Nextel is a rehearsal for P.C.S. Using new wireless phones from Motorola, Nextel can offer static-free digital service that also provides a paging service that delivers short text messages.
In Britain, where regulation is less strict than in the United States, Comcast offers both cable television and phone service to consumers. Comcast is learning valuable marketing lessons for the day it can do the same in the United States.
And back home, Comcast has large investments in Teleport Communications Group, which provides an alternate local phone service to that of the Baby Bells, catering mainly to business customers. The other investors are also cable companies like Tele-Communications Inc. of Denver.
"Long term, the cable companies want to look like the phone companies with ubiquitous coverage," the younger Mr. Roberts said. "We've wired up nearly all the homes, but not the businesses. So that's why we're investing in Teleport."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chrysler Has a Small Car for the Young Market

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Zippy, inexpensive, environmentally friendly -- oh, and "huggable."
Such are the qualities, according to the Chrysler Corporation, of the Neon, a bubble-shaped, bug-eyed car it introduced today that will test two propositions: that a small car can make money and that Americans in the 20-something age group can be persuaded to buy a car built by the Big Three. 
 Chrysler has researched those youthful consumers, whom the Big Three fear they have lost -- as they did the baby boomers before them -- to the Japanese auto makers.
 
The 'Stereotyped' Generation
 "This generation is often stereotyped as the grunge-dressed teen-agers wearing hightops and ball caps, often backwards," said E. Thomas Pappert, Chrysler's vice president for sales. In fact, he said, the group, which he puts at ages 24-30, is diverse and accounts for about half the two- million-unit small-car market.
Hence the Neon, which will be available as a four-door in January and a two-door coupe next September. The photographs that accompanied Neon's early marketing blitz, a barometer of the forthcoming advertising campaign, display the car with young people who are being hip -- playing trumpets, scrawling graffiti, recycling.
"These are people who are faced with the knowledge that it's tough to achieve the same life style their parents did," said Robert A. Lutz, Chrysler's president, answering questions by satellite from the annual auto show in Frankfurt. "They're not willing to sacrifice anything, however."
While the base price of the Neon has been rumored to be anywhere from $9,000 to $11,500, Mr. Lutz refused to put a price on the car, saying only that it would be competitive with other American subcompacts like the Ford Escort.
The car, he said, delivers many qualities of larger, more expensive vehicles. For example, Mr. Lutz said, the Neon has 98 percent of the interior room of the Ford Mondeo, a midsize car that Ford recently put on sale in Europe and will introduce in America next year.
The Neon comes with driver- and passenger-side air bags as standard equipment. Its fuel economy -- 28 miles a gallon for city driving and 37 on highways with manual transmission -- is lower than might be expected from a subcompact because Chrysler, trying to cozy up to 20-somethings who want something fun to drive, decided to equip the car with a relatively powerful 2.0-liter engine. The car accelerates from 0 to 60 miles an hour in less than nine seconds.
Mr. Lutz said the car would be 85 to 95 percent recyclable.
 
A Washout for Detroit
 Generally, the Big Three have lost money on small cars. "The small car has been essentially a failure in the United States car market," said Arvid F. Jouppi, an auto analyst with Keane Securities. While Japanese auto makers were successful selling high-quality subcompacts here, small cars made by the Big Three have never been perceived to be of the same caliber, he said.
"It's going to be interesting to see if Chrysler can carry this one off," Mr. Jouppi added. "I think they will."
The low development costs for the Neon give it a head start on becoming profitable. Under Chrylser's new platform-team approach, the Neon was developed at the relatively small sum of $1.3 billion (compared with $6 billion for the Mondeo), and in a relatively brief period of 31 months.
While Mr. Lutz promised profits on the car, he was not extravagant in his predictions. "The car is designed to be a little better than break even," he said.
Mr. Lutz said Chrysler planned to sell the Neon worldwide. In America, the car will be carried by both Dodge and Plymouth dealers. Traditionally, auto makers market the same car, with different names and some modifications, through different dealers.
Chrysler has the capacity to build 375,000 of the cars this year, said Robert J. Eaton, the company's chairman and chief executive. Most of them will be built in Belvidere, Ill., but 75,000 four-door Neons will be built in a Chrylser plant in Toluca, Mexico.

The car will test two propositions: that a small car can make money and that Americans in their 20's can be persuaded to buy a car built by the Big Three. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Cadbury seeks a U.S. company, perhaps Dr Pepper or A & W.

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
IN recent years, Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. has often been rumored to be a takeover target. Now, the British soft drink and candy company has turned the tables.
Last month, it raised its stake in the Dr Pepper/Seven-Up Companies of Dallas to 25.9 percent from 5.7 percent and said it would not rule out an eventual bid for the entire company. That prompted Dr Pepper to raise its anti-takeover defenses. 
 In the last week, speculation has mounted that Cadbury is also stalking another of the few remaining independent soft drink companies in the United States, A & W Brands.
Analysts said that over the long term, Cadbury could benefit considerably with either Dr Pepper or A & W. But they said that financing a deal for Dr Pepper -- which would likely cost a minimum of $1 billion for the shares that Cadbury does not already own -- would be a stretch for Cadbury, given its already burdensome debt load.
A & W would be more manageable, at a rumored price of around $300 million, but the implications to Cadbury's balance sheet of financing even that deal might give investors pause.
Cadbury's American depository receipts, which had hit a 52-week high of $30.375 on Aug. 19, closed yesterday at $28.375, down 25 cents in Nasdaq trading.
The speculation about a deal in the United States has to some extent overshadowed a general improvement in Cadbury's existing businesses, largely from increasing market share and lower costs in its British soft drink business. The company will report its earnings for the first six months of the year tomorrow, and analysts are expecting a sharp gain over the period a year earlier.
John Elston of James Capel & Company in London said he was looking for pretax earnings of 165 million, or about $247 million at current exchange rates, compared with 126 million a year earlier. The earnings are expected to include one-time gains of 11 million. "It's a pretty good performance across the group," Mr. Elston said.
Cadbury is the world's third-largest soft drink company after the Coca-Cola Company and Pepsico. But its lags far behind its big rivals, and the only major market in which it is a dominant force is Britain, where its strength derives largely from its joint bottling venture with Coke.
In turning its attention to expansion in the United States, Cadbury, which currently holds 3.4 percent of the soft drink market in the United States, will not put fear in the hearts of Coke and Pepsi. But it is seeking increased clout by adding other established brands to its lineup, which includes Canada Dry, Schweppes, Sunkist and Crush.
Combining forces with Dr Pepper/Seven-Up, which has 10.6 percent of the market in the United States, or A & W, which has about 2 percent, would provide Cadbury with economies of scale and improved marketing and distribution opportunities, as well as a chance for greater profits in a market that accounts for a third of worldwide soft drink consumption.
Cadbury has not made any public comment about its rumored interest in A & W. Cadbury has said it has no immediate plans to make a bid for the rest of Dr Pepper, and has said that it would like to discuss with the Dallas company ways in which they could cooperate more closely. Dr Pepper already produces soft drink concentrates for the Cadbury brands in the United States and distributes some of them to restaurants.
Many analysts think Cadbury would be content to turn over its brands in the United States to Dr Pepper in exchange for an increased stake in the company. But what deal gets done, and how fast, depends to a large extent on how Cadbury deals with Dr Pepper's management, which seems distinctly nervous about Cadbury's intentions.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
2 Maiden Ladies and Their Century

BYLINE: By MARGO JEFFERSON

 BODY:

Having Our Say
The Delany Sisters' First 100 Years
By Sarah and A. Elizabeth Delany with Amy Hill Hearth
Illustrated. 210 pages. Kodansha. $20.
Sometimes they sound like the oldest living Confederate widows, and sometimes they sound like turn-of-the-century Negro blue bloods. They refer to the Civil War as "the Surrender" and those we would call bigots they call "those rebby boys." They are not "old maids," they are "maiden ladies," and at 103 and 101, they avoid all hospitals. "One time, some doctor asked Sadie to do a senility test. Of course, she passed. A year later, he asked her to do it again, and she said, 'Don't waste your time, doctor.' And she answered all the questions from the year before, before he could ask them. And then she said to me, 'Come on, Bess, let's get on out of here.' " 
 They are Sarah and Annie Elizabeth Delany, and their lives hold a century of social, sexual and racial codes, enforced, broken and revised. They were taught to participate in history, not just witness it, and they have had the wit to shape their histories with style. If one likes to trace American literature through the voices of American citizens, one might place the shrewdly decorous Sadie in a Charles Chesnutt story, while Bessie, with her feisty pronouncements and slangy asides, belongs in a Mark Twain monologue. And no, I am not saying that their memoirs, deftly arranged in alternating chapters by the journalist Amy Hill Hearth, are literature; I am saying that they are literature's living kin.
Anyway, the Delanys are quite involved with their own kin and their own achievements. Every group has its cherished list of firsts: the first Jewish Supreme Court Justice, the first Greek Presidential nominee, the first woman to graduate from medical school, the first open homosexual to win public office. The Delanys' father was America's first Negro Episcopal bishop. Bessie was one of the first female Negro dentists in New York, and Sadie was the first Negro to teach home economics (she calls it domestic science) in a white New York City high school. Firsts are a strange business. They advertise their importance -- the breaking down of a barrier -- even as they expose their absurdity: why should an honorable achievement be deemed unattainable or exceptional?
You have probably noticed that I do not call the Delanys blacks or African-Americans. That's because, as Bessie makes clear, she and her sister each prefer to be called "a colored woman or a Negro woman." They belong to a generation that used "black" literally and often dismissively; they also belong to a generation that considered it a proud, even daring gesture to call themselves Americans with no descriptive attached. Since I respect them, I will follow their lead. It would be rude not to, and besides, history and identity are too complicated to be summed up by any one term. Why not use them all, according to one's need and world view?
The Delanys' father, Henry, was a 9-year-old house slave in Georgia when Emancipation came. In a war-torn state short on food or supplies, where many former slaves "wandered about the country like shell-shocked soldiers," his family was lucky: "They could read and write, and they hadn't been abused, and their family was still together." Their mother's ancestry takes the sisters into the murky terrain of miscegenation. Among their great-grandparents were a Virginia slave and his white mistress, who took up with him when her husband went off to the War of 1812. Their maternal grandparents were a free black woman and a white farmer and dentist whom the law forbade to marry, but whom affection and, yes, respect kept together. The authors grew up in North Carolina on the campus of St. Augustine's, an Episcopal college for Negroes where their parents worked.
They moved to New York City in 1916 and became cosmopolites. "In North Carolina, there were white people, Negroes, and Indians," Sadie recalls. "In New York, there were Irish people, German people, Jewish people, Italian people, and so on." They became charter members of the Harlem Renaissance, too, mingling with artists, journalists, lawyers, socialites and intellectuals. Sadie became a world traveler, and Bessie became a veteran of picket lines and boycotts for civil rights.
They make each memory vivid and particular. To girls of 5 and 7, the coming of Jim Crow laws meant being told, "Sorry, I can't serve you," in the drugstore where they had always bought limeade, a store owned by a future mayor of Raleigh, N.C., who had "a colored family on the side." "His colored daughter was a friend of ours," the authors say. "She used to go over to the drugstore and he was real nice to her." By and large, they got the lives they wanted. "Fortunately," notes Sadie, "our earliest experiences with whites predated Jim Crow." When Jim Crow began to block the view, she would play the muddled minstrel-show Negro or the empty-headed, fair-skinned belle. When directed to the back of a shoe store, she cooed, "'Back where?" until the owner sighed, "Just sit anywhere, Miss Delany," and she did. Bessie, moodier and angrier, would talk and fight back in public (she once barely avoided being lynched), then "weep and weep and weep" in private.
They observed their parents' Olympian injunctions. (Father Delany to Sadie: "You are college material. You owe it to your nation, your race, and yourself to go. And if you don't, then shame on you!" Mother Delany on her daughters' achievements: "It's no more than they should have done." And they managed -- no small thing when your heart and soul are pledged to a family, a race and a nation -- to cultivate private, eccentric selves: the stuff that makes you a personality, not just a worthy symbol.
Sadie observes that as she grew old she began growing bold. Bess shakes her fist at bigotry: "all those rebby boys -- they have turned to dust". And that done, she thumbs her nose at propriety. Her sister may be a Christian woman, "but I'm afraid I am a naughty little darkey!" Bessie says. "Ha ha! I know it's not fashionable to use some of the words from my heyday, but that's who I am! And who is going to stop me? Nobody, that's who!" Who would want to, once the oldest living Negro maiden authors choose to tell all?

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sarah, left, and A. Elizabeth Delany. (Brian Douglas/Kodansha)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1040 words

HEADLINE: Suburban Renewal

BYLINE: By David Rusk; David Rusk, the former Mayor of Albuquerque, N.M., is author of "Cities Without Suburbs."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
State legislators and voters are starting to grapple with the results of four decades of misguided policies that have favored suburban development over inner cities, fragmenting urban areas by race and class. Several communities are trying innovative styles of government to bridge the economic gap between cities and suburbs and address their shared problems. These efforts are long overdue.
For example, last November in Oregon, Portland-area voters approved a home-rule charter to give new powers to the region's "metro" government, a sort of umbrella governing body. The metro government's priority, the new charter states, will be less to provide regional services than to manage the region's growth, which has been exploding. Goals include an affordable housing plan, in which each of the 24 cities and towns in the three-county jurisdiction must accept a proportionate share of low- and moderate-income housing. 
 Some 170 miles north, Seattle-area voters also endorsed a new regional strategy, giving the county enhanced control over growth. Strengthened by its new mandate, the King County Council stunned real estate developers by rejecting a new town -- 4,500 homes some 20 miles from Seattle -- to preserve surrounding forests. The council's action also strengthens the plan of Mayor Norman Rice to rebuild Seattle's declining neighborhoods, since it will keep demand for housing within the city higher.
In Minnesota, legislators representing inner-city constituents in Minneapolis-St. Paul forged a coalition this spring with lawmakers from older, blue-collar suburbs to pass the "Metropolitan Stabilization Act." Among the key provisions were low-income housing quotas for wealthy suburbs and tax changes to discourage converting farmland to subdivisions. Although Gov. Arne Carlson vetoed most of the package, a jointly appointed Advisory Council on Metropolitan Governance is now hammering out a compromise plan, and the prospects for success look good.
The Northeast is facing up to these issues as well. Parents in Hartford are suing the State of Connecticut; they assert that because the public schools depend heavily on local property taxes, the economic gap between Hartford and its suburbs is so great that inner-city children are denied their state-guaranteed right to a decent education.
To address this problem, Gov. Lowell Weicker has recommended reorganizing the state's 169 independent school districts into six regional systems, equalizing school spending and spreading low-income students more evenly throughout the schools. Now the Legislature has begun a planning process to encourage cooperation between urban and suburban school districts to improve their racial balance.
This summer Gov. Douglas Wilder of Virginia appointed a Commission on the Revitalization of Virginia's Urban Areas. The commission is studying compelling evidence that every major Virginia city has been hurt economically by a state law passed in 1979 forbidding annexation of surrounding suburbs. Without the ability to annex surrounding growth areas, most cities have lost population and jobs.
The best barometer to a city's social and economic health is whether it has been able to annex substantial new territory. Since World War II, urban population growth in the United States has occurred through low-density, sprawling suburban development. Successful cities were "elastic": they expanded their boundaries, capturing new development, holding on to middle-class families and maintaining a broad tax base.
Less fortunate were cities that were trapped within existing limits by bad laws or hostile neighboring communities. As middle-class families have left, these "inelastic" cities have become poorhouses for their suburbs. They are squeezed between rising social needs of poor residents and declining tax bases. Such cities are programmed to fail.
Forty major cities -- including New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Detroit, Baltimore and Cleveland -- were virtually frozen within their 1950 city limits. All have lost population, an average of 26 percent. Proportionally, these cities have four to five times as many poor residents as suburban communities have, and urban incomes average 71 percent of those in the suburbs. Many of these cities' budgets stand on the brink of collapse.
At the other extreme, two dozen cities expanded their limits fivefold or more. These include Austin, Charlotte and Oklahoma City and consolidated governments like Jacksonville-Duval County, Nashville-Davidson County and Indianapolis-Marion County.
This group more than tripled their populations. They have only about 20 percent more poor residents than their suburbs, rather than the four or five times for the inelastic cities. The average incomes for city residents are even slightly higher than those who live in surrounding suburbs. And the credit rating for the elastic city governments is on average two grades higher than that of cities unable to expand.
It is too late for most inelastic cities to resume annexation, and successful city-county consolidation is by no means easy: it requires both uncommon civic leadership and a farsighted electorate. That is what makes the regional initiatives in Portland, Seattle and Minneapolis-St. Paul so significant. These communities are beginning to recognize that suburbs should share responsibility for inner city social and economic problems; a dying city holds back the whole region.
This summer Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros told a delegation of mayors that there would be no major new Federal aid forthcoming. Instead, he is focusing on ending HUD practices that have made Federal public housing a primary factor in segregating poor blacks and Hispanics in inner-city ghettos. Inner-city problems, he argues, can be solved only by joint efforts between cities and suburbs.
As President Clinton embarks on an ambitious legislative program this fall, his Administration's wisest policy for America's ailing cities might be simply to adopt the Hippocratic oath: First do no harm. Salvation for America's cities is to be found not in Washington but in the cities' own suburbs. Governors and legislators must be the marriage brokers -- shotgun or otherwise.
